afflict someone with someone.example: I was foolish enough to aff lict myself with my young cousin for the weekend

afflict someone with something.definition: to cause someone to suffer from a disease or disability
afflict someone with something.example: The virus has aff licted everyone in the valley. 2.  to burden someone with trouble

afraid of one\u2019s own shadow.definition: easily frightened; always frightened, timid, or suspicious. (an exaggeration.)
afraid of one\u2019s own shadow.example: After Tom was robbed, he was even afraid of his own shadow

after a fashion.definition: in a manner that is just barely adequate; poorly
after a fashion.example: He thanked me—after a fashion—for my help

after all.definition: anyway; in spite of what had been decided. (often refers to a change in plans or a reversal of plans.)
after all.example: It looks like Tom will go to law school after all. 2. recalling or considering the fact that

after all is said and done.definition: cliché when everything is settled or concluded; finally
after all is said and done.example: After all is said and done, it will turn out just as I said

after hours.definition: after the regular closing time; after any normal or regular time, such as one’s bedtime
after hours.example: John got a job sweeping f loors in the library after hours

after the fact.definition: after something has happened; after something, such as a crime, has taken place. (originally a legal phrase.)
after the fact.example: John is always making excuses after the fact

after while crocodile.definition: good-bye till later.; see you later. (the word crocodile is used only for the sake of the rhyme. it is the response to see you later, alligator.)
after while crocodile.example: Mary: See you later, alligator. Bill: After while, crocodile

after you.definition: please go ahead of me.; please pass through ahead of me
after you.example: Bob stepped back and made a motion with his hand indicating that Mary should go first. “After you,” smiled Bob

again and again.example: He knocked on the door again and again until I finally answered

against all odds.definition: despite very low probability; in a most unlikely way
against all odds.example: Against all odds, she managed to win the trophy

against someone\u2019s will.definition: without a person’s consent or agreement
against someone\u2019s will.example: You cannot force me to come with you against my will!

against the clock.definition: in a race with time; in a great hurry to get something done before a particular time
against the clock.example: In a race against the clock, they rushed the accident victim to the hospital

against the grain.definition: across the alignment of the fibers of a piece of wood
against the grain.example: You sawed it wrong. You sawed against the grain when you should have cut with grain

age before beauty.definition: a jocular and slightly rude way of encouraging someone to go ahead of oneself; a comical, teasing, and slightly grudging way of indicating that someone else should or can go first
age before beauty.example: “No, no. Please, you take the next available seat,” smiled Tom. “Age before beauty, you know.”

the age of miracles is past.example: I’m afraid this old vacuum cleaner can’t be fixed. The age of miracles is past

age out of something.definition: [for an adult] to grow [mentally or in years] out of certain behavior or out of a group or classification that is based on age. (jargon.)
age out of something.example: Most of them tend to age out at about 35

agitate against someone or something.definition: to stir up active dissatisfaction about someone or something
agitate against someone or something.example: The students were agitating against the closing of the old cafeteria

agitate for something.definition: to stir up active support for something
agitate for something.example: The committee agitated for a change, but nothing was done

agonize oneself over someone or somethin.definition: to fret or anguish about someone or something
agonize oneself over someone or somethin.example: Now, now, don’t agonize yourself over the situation. Time cures all

agree to disagree.definition: cliché [for two or more parties] to calmly agree not to come to an agreement in a dispute
agree to disagree.example: We have accomplished nothing except that we agree to disagree

agree to something.definition: to consent to something; to allow something to be done; to approve something
agree to something.example: If you don’t agree to my leaving early, I’ll just do it anyway

agree upon someone or something.definition: to agree to the choice of someone or something
agree upon someone or something.example: Let’s try to agree upon a date

agree with someone.definition: to hold the same opinion or judgment as someone else
agree with someone.example: I simply do not agree with you! 2.  [for something] to be acceptable to someone as food. (Usually negative, referring to the disagreeable consequences of eating bad food.)

agree with something.definition: [for something] to look good or go well with something else
agree with something.example: This dress does not agree with these shoes, does it? 2.  [for something] to be in accord with something else

agree with something in something.definition: [for grammatical features] to match or go together with other grammatical features
agree with something in something.example: The subject and the verb agree in number

ahead of one\u2019s time.definition: having ideas or attitudes that are too advanced to be acceptable in the present

ahead of schedule.definition: having done something before the time given on a schedule or before the expected time
ahead of schedule.example: I want to be able to finish the job ahead of schedule

ahead of someone or something.definition: farther forward than someone or something
ahead of someone or something.example: I managed to get ahead of everyone else in line and get tickets for everyone

ahead of something.definition: ahead or on target with one’s work schedule or responsibilities
ahead of something.example: By the end of the week, I usually can get ahead of my duties, but not by much

ahead of the game.definition: being early; having an advantage in a competitive situation; having done more than necessary
ahead of the game.example: Without the full cooperation of my office staff, I find it hard to stay ahead of the game

ahead of time.example: If you show up ahead of time, you will have to wait

ahold of someone or something.definition: [get/have] a grasp of someone or something
ahold of someone or something.example: I got hold of him and dragged him back from the edge just in time

aid and abet someone.definition: cliché to help someone; to incite someone to do something, possibly something that is wrong. (originally a legal phrase.)
aid and abet someone.example: He was scolded for aiding and abetting the boys who were fighting

aid someone in doing something.example: He aided her in fixing up the back bedroom

aid someone in something.definition: to help someone in some kind of trouble
aid someone in something.example: Will you aid me in this difficulty?

aim something at someone or something.definition: to point or direct something at someone or something
aim something at someone or something.example: Wally aimed the hose at Sarah and tried to soak her

aim to do something.example: I didn’t aim to hurt your feelings, sugar, you know I didn’t

ain\u2019t fittin\u2019 to roll with a p.definition: is or are filthy or uncouth
ain\u2019t fittin\u2019 to roll with a p.example: After a day’s work in the hot sun, Clyde ain’t fittin’ to roll with a pig

ain\u2019t it the truth.definition: or jocular that is true.; isn’t that true? (used to agree with a statement someone has made.)
ain\u2019t it the truth.example: Jane: I swear, life can be a trial sometimes. Bill: Yes, Lordy. Ain’t it the truth?

ain\u2019t particular.example: Tom: Would you rather have ice cream or cheese on your apple pie? Mary: Whatever you’re having. I ain’t particular. 2.  doesn’t or don’t have a preference

the air.example: Whenever I get around Tom, I end up getting the air

air one\u2019s belly.definition: sl. to empty one’s stomach; to vomit
air one\u2019s belly.example: I had a bad case of food poisoning and was airing my belly for most of the night

air one\u2019s grievances.definition: to complain; to make a public complaint

air one\u2019s paunch.example: He got so nauseous that he spent much of the night airing his paunch

air one\u2019s pores.definition: sl. to undress oneself; to become naked

air out.definition: [for something] to remain in the fresh air and become fresher

air something out.definition: to freshen something up by placing it in the open air; to freshen a room by letting outside air move through it

alert someone to something.definition: to make someone aware of trouble or potential trouble
alert someone to something.example: The auditors alerted us to some problems with the accounts

alienate someone from someone or somethi.definition: to cause someone to feel negative about someone or something
alienate someone from someone or somethi.example: The teacher alienated the entire class from the subject of calculus

alight from something.definition: to get off something; to get down off something
alight from something.example: Almost three hundred people alighted from the plane

alight upon someone or something.definition: to land on something; [for a bird or other flying animal] to come to rest on something. (upon is more formal than on.)
alight upon someone or something.example: A small bird alighted on the branch directly over my head

align oneself with someone or something.definition: to bring oneself into agreement with someone or someone’s ideas; to associate oneself with someone or someone’s cause

align something with something.definition: to adjust, straighten, or arrange something in reference to something else
align something with something.example: Try to align this piece with the one next to it

alike as two peas in a pod.definition: very similar. (compare this with like (two) peas in a pod. *also: as ~.)

alive with people or things.definition: covered with, filled with, or active with people or creatures
alive with people or things.example: Look! Ants everywhere. The f loor is alive with ants!

all agog.example: He sat there, all agog, as the master of ceremonies read his name as the winner of first prize

all and sundry.example: Cold drinks were served to all and sundry

all around robin hood\u2019s barn.definition: going somewhere by an indirect route; going way out of the way [to get somewhere]; by a long and circuitous route

all at once.example: The entire group spoke all at once. 2.  suddenly

all at sea about something.definition: to be confused; to be lost and bewildered. (alludes to being lost at sea.)

all balled up.example: John is all balled up because his car was stolen

all better now.example: I fell off my tricycle and bumped my knee. Mommy kissed it, and it’s all better now

all by one\u2019s lonesome.example: Mary’s folks went out and left her all by her lonesome

all cats are gray in the dark.definition: when in the dark, appearances are meaningless, since everything is hard to see or unseen

all day long.definition: throughout the day; during the entire day
all day long.example: We waited for you at the station all day long

all dolled up.definition: dressed up and well-groomed. (usually used of females. *typically: be ~; get ~.)

all dressed up.definition: dressed in one’s best clothes; dressed formally

all ears.example: Well, hurry up and tell me. I’m all ears

all eyes and ears.definition: listening and watching eagerly and carefully

all for the best.definition: good in spite of the way it seems; better than you think or than it appears to be. (often said when someone dies after a painful illness.)

all gone.example: Oh, the strawberry jelly is all gone

all good things must come to an end.definition: all experiences, even pleasant ones, eventually end
all good things must come to an end.example: It’s time to leave the party, honey. All good things must end

all hell broke loose.definition: all sorts of wild or terrible things happened

all het up.definition: very angry or upset. (all “heated” up. *typically: get ~; be ~.)

all hours of the day and night.definition: very late in the night or very early in the morning

all in good time.definition: at some future time; in the near future; in good time; soon. (this phrase is used to encourage people to be patient and wait quietly.)

all in one breath.definition: spoken very rapidly, usually while one is very excited
all in one breath.example: Ann said all in one breath, “Hurry, quick! The parade is coming!”

all in one piece.example: Her son came home from school all in one piece, even though he had been in a fight

all in the family.definition: restricted to one’s own family, as with private or embarrassing information
all in the family.example: Don’t tell anyone else. Please keep it all in the family

all kinds of someone or something.definition: a great number of people or things; a great amount of something, especially money

all manner of someone or something.definition: all types of people or things

all my eye and betty martin.example: Jane is always talking about her wonderful childhood, but it’s all my eye

all night long.example: I couldn’t sleep all night long

all of a size.example: I tried to pick out the biggest tomato, but they were pretty much all of a size

all of a sudden.example: All of a sudden lightning struck the tree we were sitting under

all or nothing.example: Sally would not accept only part of the money. She wanted all or nothing

all over again.definition: starting over completely again; going through something completely yet another time

all over some place.definition: found in every place; available in all locations

all right for you.definition: that’s the end of being friendly with you!; that’s the last chance for you! (usually said by a child who is angry with a playmate.)

all roads lead to rome.definition: there are many different routes to the same goal

all show and no go.definition: sl. equipped with good looks but lacking action or energy. (used to describe someone or something that looks good but does not perform as promised.)

all spruced up.definition: freshened up; tidied up; cleaned up

all sweetness and light.definition: cliché very kind, innocent, and helpful

all systems are go.definition: cliché everything is ready. (originally said when preparing to launch a rocket.)

all talk and no action.definition: talking often about doing something, but never actually doing it
all talk and no action.example: The car needs washing, but Bill is all talk and no action on this matter

all the livelong day.example: Well, of course you get to feeling stiff, sitting in front of a computer all the livelong day

all the marbles.definition: all the winnings, spoils, or rewards
all the marbles.example: Somehow Fred always seems to end up with all the marbles. I don’t think he plays fair

all the rage.definition: in current fashion; being a current fad

all the time.definition: throughout a specific period of time

all the way.definition: from the beginning to the end; the entire distance, from start to finish

all the way live.example: Man, this place is all the way live

all there.definition: alert, aware, and mentally sound. (usually negative.)

all tore up about something.definition: very upset and sorry about something. (the correct torn can also be used. *typically: be ~; get ~.)

all tuckered out.example: Poor John worked so hard that he’s all tuckered out

all vine and no taters.definition: to be all display with no real value

all walks of life.definition: all social, economic, and ethnic groups

all well and good.example: It’s well and good that you’re here on time. I was afraid you’d be late again

all wet.example: I fell in and got all wet. 2.  mistaken; wrongheaded; on the wrong track

all wool and a yard wide.definition: trustworthy and genuinely good. (a description of good quality wool cloth.)

all wool and no shoddy.example: Everything Mary sells is the best there is, all wool and no shoddy

all work and no play makes jack a dull b.definition: it is not healthy for someone to work all the time and never play. (often used to exhort someone to stop working, or to justify why you have stopped working. you can substitute the name of the person you are addressing for jack.)
all work and no play makes jack a dull b.example: Don’t come to the office this weekend. All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy

all year round.definition: throughout all the seasons of the year; during the entire year
all year round.example: The public swimming pool is enclosed so that it can be used all year round

allot something to someone or something.definition: to give or assign something to someone or something
allot something to someone or something.example: We will allot a share of the proceeds to charity

an allout effort.definition: a very good and thorough effort
an allout effort.example: We need to make an all-out effort to get this job done on time

allout war.definition: total war, as opposed to limited military actions or threats of war
allout war.example: We are now concerned about all-out war in the Middle East

allow for someone or something.definition: to plan on having enough of something (such as food, space, etc.) for someone

allow someone up from something.definition: to permit someone to arise or get up. (fixed phrase.)

alloy something with something.definition: to combine one molten metal into another molten metal

ally oneself to someone or something.definition: to unite or affiliate oneself with someone or something

ally oneself with someone against someon.definition: to unite with someone in opposition to someone or something

the almighty dollar.definition: the u.s. dollar, or the acquisition of money, when viewed as more important than anything else

almost lost it.definition: to nearly lose one’s temper, composure, or control, as out of anger

along with someone or something.definition: in addition to someone or something; together with someone or something

alongside of someone or something.definition: as compared with a person or a thing. (the things being compared need not be beside one another. of is normally used before pronouns.)

aloof from someone or something.definition: being remote or distant from someone or something

alpha and omega.definition: both the beginning and the end; the essentials, from the beginning to the end; everything, from the beginning to the end

alphabet soup.definition: initialisms and acronyms, especially when used excessively

alsoran.definition: someone of no significance. (from horse racing, used of a horse that finishes a race but that does not finish among the money winners.)

alternate with something.definition: [for someone] to serve as a substitute for someone
alternate with something.example: I alternated with Fred as the lead in the school play

always chasing rainbows.definition: tending to look for something (more) exciting and (more) rewarding but without realistic expectations
always chasing rainbows.example: He can’t seem to settle down and enjoy life. He’s always chasing rainbows

am i glad to see you.definition: i am very glad to see you! (not a question. there is a stress on i and another on you.)
am i glad to see you.example: Bill: Well, I finally got here! John: Wow! Am I glad to see you!

am i right.definition: isn’t that so? right? (a way of demanding a response and stimulating further conversation.)
am i right.example: John: Now, this is the kind of thing we should be doing. Am I right? Sue: Well, sure. I guess

amalgamate something with something.definition: to unite something with something else; to merge two things

amalgamate with something.definition: to join with something; to merge with something
amalgamate with something.example: Our group decided to amalgamate with another group

amble along something.definition: to walk along slowly and casually somewhere

ambulance chaser.definition: a lawyer who hurries to the scene of an accident to try to get business from injured persons
ambulance chaser.example: The insurance companies are cracking down on ambulance chasers

american as apple pie.example: A small house with a white picket fence is supposed to be as American as apple pie

amount to much.definition: to be as good as something; to be any good
amount to much.example: His fine plans don’t amount to much, since he won’t work for them. (Usually negative.)

amuse someone with something.definition: to entertain or interest someone with something
amuse someone with something.example: Try to amuse the child with this little toy

ancient history.definition: someone or something from so long ago as to be completely forgotten or no longer important, as a former relationship

and change.definition: plus a few cents; plus a few hundredths. (used in citing a price or other decimal figure to indicate an additional fraction of a full unit.)

and how.example: I am really excited you are here. And how!

and that\u2019s a fact.definition: and that is true. (used to emphasize a statement.)
and that\u2019s a fact.example: John ain’t no friend of mine, and that’s a fact

and that\u2019s that.definition: that is final and nothing more needs to be said

and the like.example: Whenever we go on a picnic, we take potato chips, hot dogs, soda pop, and the like

and then some.definition: and even more; and more than has been mentioned
and then some.example: John is going to have to run like a deer and then some to win this race

and this and that.definition: and more; and other miscellaneous things

and what have you.definition: and more things; and other various things

angle for something.definition: to fish for something, as with a fishhook and line
angle for something.example: Fred was angling for a big bass

angle off toward something.definition: to turn or move toward something at an angle
angle off toward something.example: The road angles off to the right

annex something to something.definition: [for a governmental body of a town or city] to attach a parcel of land onto an existing parcel of land through legal proceedings
annex something to something.example: The village annexed some adjacent land to itself

annex to something.definition: [for the owner of a parcel of land] to have land attached to an adjacent town or city
annex to something.example: Our community doesn’t want to annex to Adamsville

announce one\u2019s support for someone.definition: to declare one’s political support for someone or something

announce something to someone.definition: to tell something publicly to someone
announce something to someone.example: The president announced his nominee for attorney general to the media

anoint someone with something.definition: to pour or rub oil on a person’s head as an honor or blessing; to put a liquid onto oneself. (mostly in biblical references.)

another country heard from.definition: yet another person adds to the conversation. used when someone joins a discussion other people are having, especially unexpectedly. (used sarcastically, implying that the new speaker is not welcome in the discussion.)

answer for someone or something.definition: to explain or justify the actions of someone or some act; to take responsibility or blame for someone or something
answer for someone or something.example: You will have to answer for your children’s bad behavior

answer the door.definition: [after hearing the doorbell or a knock] to go to the door to see who is there
answer the door.example: Would you please answer the door. I am busy

answer to someone.definition: to explain or justify one’s actions to someone. (usually with have to.)
answer to someone.example: If John can- not behave properly, he’ll have to answer to me

answer to the description of someone.definition: to match a particular set of physical or facial characteristics

any fool thing.definition: any ridiculous thing; anything that should be viewed as unimportant

anything you say.example: Mary: Will you please take these blouses over to the cleaners? Bill: Sure, anything you say

april showers bring may flowers.definition: although rain in april is annoying, it starts the flowers growing

are things getting you down.example: Jane: Gee, Mary, you look sad. Are things getting you down?

are you feeling okay.example: Tom: Are you feeling okay? Bill: Oh, fair to middling

are you going my way.definition: if you are traveling in the direction of my destination, could i please go with you or can i have a ride in your car?

around the bend.example: I think this job is sending me around the bend

as a general rule.example: He can be found in his office as a general rule

at ease.example: The performer is at ease on the stage

at liberty.example: The criminal was set at liberty by the judge

at one\u2019s wit \u2019s end.definition: at the limits of one’s mental resources

at the bottom of the hour.example: Hear the news headlines at the bottom of the hour

at the drop of a hat.definition: immediately; instantly; on the slightest signal or urging. (alludes to the dropping of a hat as a signal.)

at the eleventh hour.definition: at the last possible moment. (just before the last clock hour, 12)

at the end of nowhere.definition: at a remote place; at some distance from civilization. (an exaggeration.)

at the end of the day.definition: at the time when work or one’s waking hours end
at the end of the day.example: I will have an answer at the end of the day

at the expense of someone or something.definition: to the detriment of someone or something; to the harm of someone or something
at the expense of someone or something.example: He had a good laugh at the expense of his brother

at the height of something.definition: at the most intense or forceful aspect of something
at the height of something.example: At the height of his career, Tom was known around the world

at the helm of something.definition: in the position of being in control of something
at the helm of something.example: The president is at the helm of the company

at the last gasp.definition: at the very last; at the last chance; at the last minute. (refers to someone’s last breath before death.)
at the last gasp.example: She finally showed up at the last gasp, bringing the papers that were needed

at the last minute.definition: at the last possible chance; in the last few minutes, hours, or days. (often an exaggeration.)
at the last minute.example: Please don’t make reservations at the last minute

at the latest.example: Please pay this bill in ten days at the latest

at the most.definition: no more than the amount mentioned
at the most.example: A: How far away is the beach? B: Ten miles at most

at the outset.example: At the outset, we were told everything we had to do

at the rear of something.definition: located at the back part of something
at the rear of something.example: I keep my tools at the rear of my garage

at the same time.example: We arrived at the same time

at the top of one\u2019s game.definition: good and as good as one is likely to get. (usually of sports.)
at the top of one\u2019s game.example: I guess I was at the top of my game last year. This year, I stink

at the top of the hour.definition: at the exact beginning of an hour. (alludes to the big hand on a clock pointing to the 12. often heard on television or the radio. see also at the bottom of the hour.)
at the top of the hour.example: Every class in my school starts at the top of the hour

at the very outside.example: The car repairs will cost $300 at the very outside

at the wheel.definition: operating the wheel that turns a ship’s rudder; at the helm
at the wheel.example: The cabin boy was at the wheel with the captain close by. 2. operating the steering wheel of a car

at the worst.definition: in the most negative or pessimistic view

at the zenith of something.definition: at the highest point of something; at the pinnacle of something

at this rate.definition: at this speed; if things continue in the same way. (usually of a pessimistic view.)

at this stage of the game.definition: at the current point in some event or situation; currently

at will.example: You’re free to come and go at will

at work.example: I’m sorry to call you at work, but this is important

atone for something.definition: to make amends for an error

attach oneself to someone.definition: to become emotionally involved with someone

attach oneself to something.definition: to connect or secure oneself to something

attach to someone.definition: [for blame, importance, guilt, fault, etc.] to become “fixed” onto someone or an organization

attach to something.definition: [for something] to be meant to fit onto or into something
attach to something.example: This one attaches to this other one right at this point

an attack of an illness.definition: a bout of some sickness; an instance or acute case of some disease

attend to someone.example: Please attend to your teacher’s instructions

attend to someone or something.definition: to take care of the needs of someone or something; to respond to a request or demand from someone or something

attest to something.definition: to certify or bear witness to a fact

attire someone in something.example: The mother attired her children in new, clean clothes

attract someone or something to someone.definition: to draw or pull someone or something to someone or something else

attribute something to someone or someth.definition: to ascribe something to someone or something; to believe that someone or something is the source of something

auction something off.definition: to sell something [to the highest bidder] at an auction

avail oneself of something.definition: to help oneself by making use of something that is available

avoid someone or something like the plag.definition: to ignore or keep away from someone or something totally

aw shucks.example: Shucks, ma’am. It wasn’t anything at all

awaken from something.definition: to wake up from something, such as a dream or a deep sleep

away from it all.definition: at a place where one can avoid completely what one is leaving behind

away from one\u2019s desk.definition: not available for a telephone conversation; not available to be seen or spoken to. (sometimes said by the person who answers a telephone in an office. it means that the person whom the caller wants is not immediately available due to personal or business reasons. *typically: be ~; step ~.)
away from one\u2019s desk.example: I’m sorry, but Ann is away from her desk just now. Can you come back later?

a babe in arms.definition: a very young baby that is carried by an adult

back someone or something into someone o.definition: to guide or move someone or something backwards into someone or something

back someone or something off from somet.definition: to guide or move someone or something a short distance from something

beam up.definition: sl. to die. (alluding to the television program star trek.)

better late than never.definition: cliché doing something late is better than not doing it
better late than never.example: I’m sorry I’m late to the party. Better late than never, right?

better left unsaid.definition: [refers to a topic that] should not be discussed; [refers to a thought that] everyone is thinking, but would cause difficulty if talked about in public. (a typical beginning for this phrase might be it is, that is, the details are, or even some things are. see the examples.)
better left unsaid.example: Mary: I really don’t know how to tell you this. Bob: Then don’t. Maybe it’s better left unsaid

better luck next time.definition: an expression that comforts someone for a minor failure. (said with a pleasant tone of voice.)
better luck next time.example: Bill: That does it! I can’t run any farther. I lose! Bob: Too bad. Better luck next time

better the devil you know than the devil.definition: if you have to choose between a familiar but unpleasant situation and an unfamiliar situation, choose the familiar one because the unfamiliar situation may turn out to be worse
better the devil you know than the devil.example: Jill: I hate my job so much that I’m thinking of asking for a transfer. Jane: I’d advise against it. Better the devil you know than the devil you don’t know

between life and death.definition: in a position where living or dying is an even possibility. (especially with caught or hovering.)
between life and death.example: And there I was on the operating table, hovering between life and death

betwixt and between.example: I liked the soup and the dessert and all that came betwixt and between

a bevy of beauties.definition: cliché a group of very attractive women, as found in a beauty contest
a bevy of beauties.example: A whole bevy of beauties waltzed past the old man, but he didn’t even notice

beware of greeks bearing gifts.definition: do not trust an opponent who offers to do something nice for you. (a line from the story of the trojan horse, as told in vergil’s aeneid.)
beware of greeks bearing gifts.example: Jill: I can’t believe Melanie brought me cookies today, when we’ve been fighting for weeks. Jane: Beware of Greeks bearing gifts. She probably has ulterior motives

beware of someone or something.definition: to be cautious and watchful about someone or something
beware of someone or something.example: Beware of Ted. He’s acting irrational

beyond a reasonable doubt.definition: almost without any doubt. (a legal phrase.)
beyond a reasonable doubt.example: The jury decided beyond a reasonable doubt that she had committed the crime

beyond me.definition: completely missing or surpassing my understanding
beyond me.example: I’m confused. All this is beyond me

beyond measure.definition: in an account or to an extent more than can be quantified; in a very large amount
beyond measure.example: They brought in hams, turkeys, and roasts, and then they brought vegetables and salads beyond measure

beyond one\u2019s depth.definition: in water that is too deep
beyond one\u2019s depth.example: Sally swam out from the beach until she was beyond her depth

beyond one\u2019s ken.definition: outside the extent of one’s knowledge or understanding
beyond one\u2019s ken.example: Why she married that shiftless drunkard is beyond our ken

beyond one\u2019s means.example: I’m sorry, but this house is beyond our means. Please show us a cheaper one

beyond some emotional response.definition: in too extreme a state to feel or care
beyond some emotional response.example: Do what you want. You have hurt me so much, I am beyond caring

beyond someone or something.definition: on the other side of something
beyond someone or something.example: When we get beyond this bad road, I’ll have to check the tires

beyond the pale.definition: unacceptable; outlawed. (a pale is a barrier made of wooden stakes.)
beyond the pale.example: Your behavior is simply beyond the pale

beyond words.definition: more than one can say. (especially preceded by grateful, shocked, and thankful.)

bias someone against someone or somethin.definition: to prejudice someone against someone or something
bias someone against someone or somethin.example: Please avoid biasing everyone against me

bid adieu to someone or something.definition: cliché to say good-bye to someone or something. (the word adieu is french for good-bye and should not be confused with ado.)
bid adieu to someone or something.example: Now it’s time to bid adieu to all of you gathered here

bid something down.definition: to lower the value of something, such as stock, by offering a lower price for it each time it comes up for sale
bid something down.example: We bid the price down and then bought all of it

bid something up.definition: to raise the price of something at an auction by offering higher and higher prices; to increase the value of something, such as shares of stock, by offering a higher price for it each time it comes up for sale
bid something up.example: Who is bidding the price up on that painting?

bide one\u2019s time.example: I’ve been biding my time for years, just waiting for a chance like this

big and bold.definition: large and capable of getting attention. (usually refers to things, not people.)
big and bold.example: The big and bold lettering on the book’s cover got lots of attention, but the price was too high

the big apple.example: We spent the weekend in the Big Apple

big around as a molasses barrel.example: He ate till he was as big around as a molasses barrel

big as all outdoors.definition: cliché very big, usually referring to an indoor space of some kind. (*also: as ~.)
big as all outdoors.example: You should see Bob’s living room. It’s as big as all outdoors!

big bucks.definition: a very large amount of money
big bucks.example: He earns big bucks for doing almost nothing

the big eye.definition: a flirtatious look or gaze; a long look to get another’s attention
the big eye.example: Look at that pretty girl giving you the big eye

a big frog in a small pond.definition: an important person in the midst of less important people. (alludes to a large frog that dominates a small pond with few challengers.)
a big frog in a small pond.example: I’d rather be a big frog in a small pond than the opposite

a big hand for something.example: She got a big hand for singing so well

big man on campus.definition: sl. an important male college student. (often derisive or jocular.)
big man on campus.example: Hank acts like such a big man on campus

big of someone.example: He gave me some of his apple. That was very big of him

the big picture.definition: the whole story of something; a complete view of something
the big picture.example: The sales manager gave us all the big picture this morning, and I’m more confused than ever

a big sendoff.example: I had a wonderful send-off before I left

big with someone.definition: famous with or desired by someone or some group
big with someone.example: This kind of pizza is supposed to be big with people in Chicago

the bigger they are the harder they fall.definition: when prominent people fail, their failure is more dramatic
the bigger they are the harder they fall.example: After the newspapers reported that the mayor cheated on his wife, he lost the election and he can’t get any kind of job. The bigger they are, the harder they fall

bilk someone out of something.definition: to get something away from someone by deception
bilk someone out of something.example: The crooks bilked the old lady out of a fortune

bill someone for something.definition: to ask someone for payment for something in writing
bill someone for something.example: Just bill me for the balance

billow out.definition: [for something, such as smoke] to burst and flow outward
billow out.example: At the site of the fire, smoke billowed out

bind someone or something down.definition: to tie or secure someone or something to something
bind someone or something down.example: Bind the tarpaulin so it won’t get away

bind someone or something together.definition: to tie the parts of something together; to tie a number of things or people together
bind someone or something together.example: Can you bind together all three parts?

bind someone over to someone or somethin.definition: to deliver someone to some legal authority; to deliver someone to some legal authority. (a legal usage.)
bind someone over to someone or somethin.example: They bound the suspect over to the sheriff

binge and purge.definition: to overeat and vomit, alternatively and repeatedly. (a symptom of the condition called bulimia.)
binge and purge.example: She had binged and purged a number of times before she finally sought help from a doctor

a bird in the hand is worth two in the b.definition: having something for certain is better than the possibility of getting something better
a bird in the hand is worth two in the b.example: I might get a better offer, but a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush

a bird\u2019seye view.definition: a view seen from high above
a bird\u2019seye view.example: We got a bird’s-eye view of Cleveland as the plane began its descent

the birds and the bees.example: My father tried to teach me about the birds and the bees

birds in their little nests agree.definition: people who live together should try hard to get along peacefully. (usually used to admonish children not to fight with each other.)
birds in their little nests agree.example: Brother: She called me a name! Sister: I did not! He’s a liar! Father: Now, now, kids—birds in their little nests agree

birds of a feather flock together.definition: similar people tend to associate with each other
birds of a feather flock together.example: I always thought Amy was pretentious, and now she’s going out with that snobbish boy, Louis. Birds of a feather f lock together

a bit much.definition: beyond what is needed or tolerable
a bit much.example: The speech she gave in acceptance of the award was a bit much. She went on and on

bitch about someone or something.definition: to complain about someone or something. (use discretion with bitch, a word many consider coarse or vulgar.)
bitch about someone or something.example: You are always bitching about your girlfriend

a bitch of a someone or something.definition: a really difficult person or thing. (use discretion with bitch, a word many con- sider coarse or vulgar.)
a bitch of a someone or something.example: What a bitch of a day!

bitch someone off.definition: sl. to make someone angry. (use discretion with bitch, a word many consider coarse or vulgar.)
bitch someone off.example: You really bitch me off, do you know that?

bitch someone or something up.definition: to mess someone or something up. (use discretion with bitch, a word many consider coarse or vulgar.)

bite back at someone or something.definition: to defend an attack by biting at someone or something. (usually an animal.)
bite back at someone or something.example: I threatened the dog and the dog bit back. 2.  to fight back at someone; to return someone’s anger or attack; to speak back to someone with anger

bite into something.definition: to press one’s teeth into something
bite into something.example: As he bit into the apple, the juices ran down his chin

bite off more than one can chew.definition: to take a larger mouthful of food than one can chew easily or comfortably
bite off more than one can chew.example: I bit off more than I could chew, and nearly choked. 2.  to take (on) more than one can deal with; to be overconfident

bite on someone.definition: sl. to copy something that someone else has done; to dress the same way someone else does
bite on someone.example: Nobody will bite on Sally. She has terrible taste

bite on something.definition: to chew on something; to grasp something with the teeth
bite on something.example: The injured cowboy bit on a leather strap while they tried to fix his dislocated shoulder. 2. to respond to a lure; to fall for something. (Can refer literally to fishing, or be used figuratively.)

bite one\u2019s nails.definition: to use one’s teeth to remove parts of one’s fingernails as a means of shortening them
bite one\u2019s nails.example: Stop biting your nails! Use clippers! 2. to literally bite one’s nails from nervousness or anxiety; to be nervous or anxious

bite one\u2019s tongue.definition: to bite down on one’s tongue by accident
bite one\u2019s tongue.example: Ouch! I bit my tongue! 2.  to struggle not to say something that you really want to say

bite someone\u2019s head off.definition: to speak sharply and with great anger to someone. (fixed order.)
bite someone\u2019s head off.example: Don’t bite my head off! Be patient

bite something off.definition: to remove something in a bite
bite something off.example: Ann bit a piece off and chewed it up

bite the big one.example: I was so tired that I thought I was going to bite the big one

bite the bullet.definition: sl. to accept something difficult and try to live with it
bite the bullet.example: You are just going to have to bite the bullet and make the best of it

bite the dust.example: A shot rang out, and another cowboy bit the dust

bite the hand that feeds one.definition: to do harm to someone who does good things for you. (does not involve biting.)
bite the hand that feeds one.example: I’m your mother! How can you bite the hand that feeds you?

a bite to eat.definition: to get something to eat; to get food that can be eaten quickly
a bite to eat.example: I need a few minutes to grab a bite to eat

bite your tongue.definition: an expression said to someone who has just stated an unpleasant supposition that unfortunately may be true
bite your tongue.example: Mary: I’m afraid that we’ve missed the plane already. Jane: Bite your tongue! We still have time

bitten by the same bug.definition: having the same need, desire, or obsession
bitten by the same bug.example: Bob and I were both bitten by the same bug and ended up getting new cars at the same time

a bitter pill to swallow.definition: an unpleasant fact that has to be accepted. (does not involve pills or swallowing.)
a bitter pill to swallow.example: It was a bitter pill for her brother to swallow when she married his enemy

blab something around.definition: to gossip something to others; to spread some news or secret
blab something around.example: It’s true, but don’t blab it around

blab something out.definition: to speak out freely about something that is a secret

blackandblue.example: I’m still black-and-blue from my divorce

black as one is painted.definition: as evil as described. (usually negative. *also: as ~.)
black as one is painted.example: The landlord is not as black as he is painted. He seems quite generous to me

a black eye.definition: a bruise near the eye from being struck. (*typically have ~; get ~; give someone ~.)
a black eye.example: I got a black eye from walking into a door

a black mark beside one\u2019s name.definition: something negative associated with a person
a black mark beside one\u2019s name.example: I did it again! Now I’ve got still another black mark beside my name!

the black sheep of the family.definition: the worst member of the family
the black sheep of the family.example: Mary is the black sheep of the family. She’s always in trouble with the police

black something out.definition: to cut or turn out the lights or electric power
black something out.example: The lightning strike blacked the entire town out

blackmail someone into doing something.definition: to force a person to do something by threatening to reveal some secret about the person
blackmail someone into doing something.example: Are you trying to blackmail me into doing what you want?

the blame for something.definition: the responsibility of having done something wrong or caused something bad to happen
the blame for something.example: I absolutely refuse to shoulder the blame for the entire fiasco!

blame someone for something.definition: to hold someone responsible for something; to name someone as the cause of something
blame someone for something.example: Please don’t blame Jill for it

blame something on someone.definition: to say that something is someone’s fault; to place the guilt for something on someone

blanch at something.definition: to cringe at something; to become pale at the thought of something
blanch at something.example: Jill blanched at the thought of swimming in that cold water

blanch with something.definition: to become pale with some emotion, such as anger or fear
blanch with something.example: He saw the injury and blanched with fear

a blank check.definition: freedom or permission to act as one wishes or thinks necessary
a blank check.example: He’s been given a blank check with regard to reorganizing the work force

blank something out.definition: to erase something, as on a computer screen
blank something out.example: Who blanked out the information that was on my screen?

blanket someone or something with someth.definition: to cover someone or something with something
blanket someone or something with someth.example: They blanketed the flames with a layer of foam

blast off for some place.definition: [for a space vehicle] to take off and head toward a destination
blast off for some place.example: The rocket blasted off for the moon

blast something off something else.definition: to remove something from something else with a powerful charge, pressure, or force
blast something off something else.example: They blasted the writing off the wall with a stream of sand

blaze a trail.definition: to make and mark a trail
blaze a trail.example: The scout blazed a trail through the forest. 2.  to do early or pioneering work that others will follow up on

blaze away at someone or something.definition: [for gunfire] to fire continually at someone or something
blaze away at someone or something.example: The guns blazed away at the oncoming ducks

blaze down on someone or something.definition: [for the sun or other hot light] to burn from above onto someone or something
blaze down on someone or something.example: The sun blazed down on the people on the beach

blaze up.example: The fire blazed up and warmed all of us

blaze with something.definition: to burn with some quality, such as great heat or sound
blaze with something.example: The sun blazed with unbelievable heat

bleach something out.definition: to remove the color or stain from something
bleach something out.example: Wally bleached his jeans out so they looked more stylish

bleed for someone.definition: to feel the emotional pain that someone else is feeling; to sympathize or empathize with someone
bleed for someone.example: I just bled for him when I heard his sad story

bleed from something.definition: for blood to emerge from a wound or other source
bleed from something.example: He was bleeding from a number of wounds

bleed to death.definition: to die from the loss of blood
bleed to death.example: If something isn’t done, he will bleed to death

bleeding heart.definition: someone, usually considered politically liberal or leftist, who is very emotional about certain political issues, such as endangered species, downtrodden people, the suffering poor, etc
bleeding heart.example: Bob is such a bleeding heart. No cause is too far out for him

bleep something out.definition: to replace a word or phrase in a radio or television broadcast with some sort of covering tone. (this is sometimes done to prevent a taboo word or other information from being broadcast.)
bleep something out.example: He tried to say the word on television, but they bleeped it out

blend in with someone or something.definition: to mix well with someone or something; to combine with someone or something
blend in with someone or something.example: Everyone there blended in with our group

blend into something.definition: to combine nicely with something; to mix well with something
blend into something.example: The oil won’t blend into the water very well

blend something together with something.definition: to mix something evenly with something else
blend something together with something.example: Blend the egg together with the cream

bless someone or something with somethin.definition: [for god or fate] to give someone or something a valuable gift
bless someone or something with somethin.example: God has blessed us with a bountiful harvest

blessed event.example: My sister is expecting a blessed event sometime in May

blessed is he who expects nothing for he.definition: if you do not expect good things to happen, you will not be disappointed when they fail to happen
blessed is he who expects nothing for he.example: Ellen: This is going to be the best vacation we’ve ever had; we’re going to have fun every minute of every day. Fred: Blessed is he who expects nothing, for he shall never be disappointed

a blessing in disguise.definition: something that at first seems bad, but later turns out to be beneficial
a blessing in disguise.example: Tony’s motorcycle accident was a blessing in disguise, because he got enough insurance money from the other driver to make a down payment on a house

a blight on the land.definition: something that harms the land or the enviornment
a blight on the land.example: Your garage is ugly! No, it’s a blight on the land!

blimp out.definition: to overeat; to eat too much and gain weight
blimp out.example: I blimp out almost every weekend

blind as a bat.definition: completely blind. (bats are not really blind. *also: as ~.)
blind as a bat.example: He lost his sight in an accident and is as blind as a bat. 2. not able to see well

the blind leading the blind.definition: someone who is not capable of dealing with a situation is guiding someone else who is not capable of dealing with it
the blind leading the blind.example: Jill: Mike is helping me fill out my tax forms this year. Jane: Is he a tax expert? Jill: He read a book about income tax once. Jane: Sounds to me like the blind leading the blind

blind someone to something.definition: to prevent someone from seeing or understanding something
blind someone to something.example: The king blinded his subjects to what was going on by controlling what appeared in the newspapers

blink at something.definition: to open and close the eyelids quickly, one or more times
blink at something.example: I blinked at the bright light and finally had to close my eyes

blink one\u2019s tears back.definition: to try to keep from crying
blink one\u2019s tears back.example: She blinked back her tears and went on

bliss out.definition: sl. to be overcome with happiness
bliss out.example: She blissed out at the concert, because she loves that kind of music

bliss someone out.definition: sl. to cause someone to be overcome with happiness
bliss someone out.example: This kind of sunny weather just blisses me out

blitz someone out.definition: sl. to shock or disorient someone
blitz someone out.example: The accident blitzed her out for a moment

blitzed out.example: Ann was totally blitzed out by the events of the day

block someone up.example: That food always blocks me up

block something off.definition: to prevent movement through something by putting up a barrier; to close a passageway
block something off.example: Sam blocked the corridor off with a row of chairs

block something out.definition: to obscure a clear view of something
block something out.example: The trees blocked the sun out

block something up.definition: to obstruct something; to stop the flow within a channel
block something up.example: The heaps of debris blocked the channel up

blood and guts.example: There is a lot of blood and guts around here, but we get our work done anyway

blood sweat and tears.definition: the signs of great personal effort
blood sweat and tears.example: There will be much blood, sweat, and tears before we have completed this project

blood will have blood.definition: people will use violence to get revenge for violent acts; murderers will themselves be murdered
blood will have blood.example: Although no one suspected him of the murder he had committed, Parker lived in fear. He had heard that blood will have blood

blood will tell.definition: a person whose ancestors had certain characteristics, often bad ones, will eventually turn out to be similar
blood will tell.example: Lisa’s father was a gambler, and now Lisa has started to gamble, too. Blood will tell

bloody but unbowed.definition: showing signs of a struggle, but not defeated. (originally referring to the head. from the poem invictus by william earnest henley.)
bloody but unbowed.example: Liz emerged from the struggle, her head bloody but unbowed

blossom forth.definition: [for a plant] to burst into flower
blossom forth.example: All the trees blossomed forth at the same time

blossom into something.definition: [for a plant] to develop into full bloom
blossom into something.example: The bush blossomed into beautiful red roses

blossom out.definition: [for a plant or tree] to become covered with flowers
blossom out.example: The apple tree blossomed out for the last time. 2.  [for someone or a concept] to develop fully, physically and intellectually

a blot on the landscape.definition: a sight that spoils the look of a place
a blot on the landscape.example: That monstrosity you call a house is a blot on the landscape. You should have hired a real architect!

blot someone or something out.definition: to forget someone or something by covering up memories or by trying to forget
blot someone or something out.example: I try to blot those bad thoughts out

blot someone out.definition: sl. to kill someone. (originally underworld slang.)
blot someone out.example: Sorry, chum, we got orders to blot you out

blot something out.definition: to make something invisible by covering it
blot something out.example: Don’t blot the name out on the application form

blow away.definition: [for something light] to be carried away by the wind
blow away.example: The leaves blew away on the autumn winds

blow hot and cold.definition: to be changeable or uncertain (about something)
blow hot and cold.example: He keeps blowing hot and cold on the question of moving to the country

blow in.definition: [for something] to cave in to the pressure of moving air
blow in.example: The door blew in during the storm

blow in from some place.definition: [for a wind] to move air in from some place
blow in from some place.example: A huge mass of frigid air blew in from Canada

blow into some place from some place.definition: sl. [for someone] to arrive at a place suddenly, or surprisingly, or with a casual air
blow into some place from some place.example: We blew into town about midnight from Detroit

blow it out your ear.definition: sl. go away!; leave me alone!
blow it out your ear.example: Oh, blow it out your ear, you cornball!

blow itself out.definition: [for a storm or a tantrum] to lose strength and stop; to subside. (fixed order.)

blow on it.definition: sl. cool it!; take it easy!
blow on it.example: It’s all right, Tom. Blow on it!

blow on something.definition: to force air across something especially with a puff of breath
blow on something.example: Jill blew on the hot soup

blow one\u2019s nose.definition: to expel mucus and other material from the nose using air pressure from the lungs
blow one\u2019s nose.example: Excuse me, I have to blow my nose

blow over.definition: [for something] to diminish; to subside. (as with a storm or a temper tantrum.)
blow over.example: Her display of temper finally blew over

blow someone a kiss.definition: to pantomine the sending of a kiss to a person visible nearby by kissing one’s hand and “blowing” the kiss off the hand toward the person
blow someone a kiss.example: As she boarded the train she blew him a kiss, and he waved back

blow someone away.definition: sl. [for something shocking or exciting] to overwhelm a person; to excite a person very much
blow someone away.example: The amount of the check blew me away

blow someone or something away.definition: [for the wind] to carry someone or something away
blow someone or something away.example: The wind almost blew her away

blow someone or something down.definition: [for a rush of air] to knock someone or something over

blow someone or something out of the wat.definition: to destroy utterly someone or something, such as a plan. (alludes to a torpedo or other weapon striking a ship and causing a great explosion that makes pieces of the ship fly out of the water.)
blow someone or something out of the wat.example: I will blow him out of the water if he shows up around here

blow someone or something over.definition: [for the wind] to move strongly and upset someone or something
blow someone or something over.example: The wind almost blew us over

blow someone or something to kingdom com.definition: to destroy someone or something by means of an explosion
blow someone or something to kingdom com.example: You’d better get that gas leak fixed or it will blow you and your car to kingdom come

blow someone or something up.definition: to destroy someone or something by explosion
blow someone or something up.example: The terrorists blew the building up at midday

blow someone out.definition: sl. to kill someone, especially with gunshots. (fixed order.)
blow someone out.example: Lefty set out to blow Max out once and for all

blow someone over.definition: [for the wind or an explosion] to knock someone over
blow someone over.example: The force of the wind nearly blew me over

blow someone\u2019s brains out.definition: sl. to kill someone with a gun
blow someone\u2019s brains out.example: Careful with that gun, or you’ll blow your brains out

blow someone\u2019s cover.definition: sl. to reveal someone’s true identity; to ruin someone’s scheme for concealment
blow someone\u2019s cover.example: The dog recognized me and blew my cover

blow someone\u2019s doors off.definition: sl. [for a driver] to speed past another vehicle
blow someone\u2019s doors off.example: Wow, he almost blew my doors off!

blow someone\u2019s mind.definition: sl. to disturb or distract; to destroy the function of one’s brain
blow someone\u2019s mind.example: It was a terrible experience. It nearly blew my mind

blow someone to something.definition: sl. to pay for something or someone, such as a meal, a movie, a drink, etc
blow someone to something.example: Let me blow you to a meal

blow something out.definition: to extinguish a flame with a puff of breath

blow something up.example: He didn’t have enough breath to blow the balloon up

blow the joint.definition: sl. to get out of a place, usually in a hurry or without delay
blow the joint.example: Come on, let’s blow the joint before there’s trouble

blow the lid off something.definition: sl. to expose something to public view
blow the lid off something.example: The police inspector blew the lid off the work of the gang of thugs

blow the whistle on someone.definition: to report someone’s wrongdoing to someone (such as the police) who can stop the wrongdoing. (alludes to blowing a whistle to attract the police.)
blow the whistle on someone.example: The citizens’ group blew the whistle on the street gangs by calling the police

blow up.example: The bomb might have blown up if the children had tried to move it

blow up in someone\u2019s face.definition: to blow up or explode suddenly
blow up in someone\u2019s face.example: The bomb blew up in the terrorist’s face

blue blood.definition: the blood [heredity] of a noble family; aristocratic ancestry
blue blood.example: The earl refuses to allow anyone who is not of blue blood to marry his son

blue collar.definition: of the lower class or working class; of a job or a worker, having to do with manual labor. (also, when used as an attributive adjective, often blue-collar. com- pare this with white collar. alludes to the typical color of work shirts worn by mechanics, laborers, etc.)
blue collar.example: His parents were both blue-collar workers. He was the first person in his family to go to college

the blues.example: You’ll have to excuse Bill. He’s getting the blues thinking about Jane

bluff one\u2019s way out of something.definition: to get out of a difficult situation by deception or cunning
bluff one\u2019s way out of something.example: I will try to bluff my way out of this mess

bluff someone into something.definition: to mislead or deceive someone into doing something
bluff someone into something.example: Are you trying to bluff me into giving up without a fight?

bluff someone out of something.definition: to get something away from someone through deception
bluff someone out of something.example: We bluffed her out of her share of the pie

blurt something out at someone.definition: to say something to someone without thinking. (usually to say something that should not be said.)
blurt something out at someone.example: It was a secret. Why did you blurt it out?

blush with something.definition: [for someone’s cheeks] to redden from a particular emotion or reaction

board someone or an animal out.definition: to send someone or an animal away to live, temporarily. (usually said of a schoolage child or a pet.)

born out of wedlock.example: The child was born out of wedlock

the bottle.example: His friends thought he was a bit too fond of the bottle
