a bum steer.definition: misleading instructions or guidance; a misleading suggestion. (bum= false; phony. steer = guidance, as in the steering of a car. *typically: get ~; have ~; give someone ~.)
a bum steer.example: Wilbur gave Ted a bum steer and Ted ended up in the wrong town

bumble through something.example: I guess I will have to bumble through this speech again

bummed out.example: I feel so bummed. I think I need a nice hot bath

bump someone or something up.definition: to damage or batter someone or something
bump someone or something up.example: The crash into the wall bumped the race driver up a little

bump up against someone or something.definition: to strike someone or something accidentally, usually relatively gently
bump up against someone or something.example: The car bumped up against the curb

bumper to bumper.definition: [of traffic] close together and moving slowly
bumper to bumper.example: The traffic is bumper to bumper from the accident up ahead

a bunch of fives.definition: sl. a punch from a closed fist
a bunch of fives.example: How would you like a bunch of fives right in the kisser?

bunch someone or something up.definition: to pack or cluster things or people together
bunch someone or something up.example: Bunch them up so you can squeeze them into the sack

a bundle of nerves.example: I was a bundle of nerves before my dental appointment

bundle off.definition: to leave in a hurry; to take all one’s parcels or baggage and leave in a hurry
bundle off.example: She got ready and bundled off after her bus

bundle oneself up against something.definition: to wrap oneself up in protective clothing or bedding as protection against the cold
bundle oneself up against something.example: Please bundle yourself up against the frigid wind

bundle someone off to some place.definition: to send someone, usually a child, somewhere
bundle someone off to some place.example: Robert bundled the children off to school

bundle someone up against something.definition: to wrap someone up in protective clothing or bedding against the cold
bundle someone up against something.example: Wally bundled Billy up against the winter storm

bundle someone up in something.definition: to wrap someone up in protective clothing or bedding
bundle someone up in something.example: Bill bundled Billy up in his parka

bundle something off to someone or some.definition: to send something off in a bundle to someone
bundle something off to someone or some.example: He bundled his laundry off to his mother, who would wash it for him

bung something in.definition: to cram or bang something into something
bung something in.example: He bunged the cork into the barrel

bung something up.definition: to damage someone or something by blows
bung something up.example: Don’t let the watermelon roll around in the trunk of your car. You don’t want to bung it up

bunged up.example: It used to be a nice table, but it got all bunged up

bungle something up.definition: to botch something; to mess something up
bungle something up.example: Please don’t bungle this job up

bunk down for the night.definition: to bed down for the night; to go to bed
bunk down for the night.example: Where are you going to bunk down for the night?

bunk up together.definition: [for two or more people] to share a bed, a bedroom, or a tent

bunk up with someone.definition: to share a bed, a bedroom, or a tent with someone
bunk up with someone.example: Are you going to bunk up with Fred?

buoy someone or something up.definition: to keep someone or something afloat
buoy someone or something up.example: Use this cushion to buoy yourself up

buoy someone up.definition: to support, encourage, or sustain someone
buoy someone up.example: The good news buoyed her up considerably

burden someone or something with someone.definition: to bother or weigh down someone or something with someone or something
burden someone or something with someone.example: Please don’t burden us with the bad news at this time

burden someone with something.definition: to give unpleasant information to someone; to give someone some bad news
burden someone with something.example: I hate to burden you with this, but your cat ran away

burgeon out.definition: to develop and grow rapidly; to burst forth
burgeon out.example: The flowers burgeoned out and made the garden beautiful again

burn something to a crisp.definition: to burn something totally or very badly
burn something to a crisp.example: The cook burned the meat to a crisp

burn away.definition: [for something] to burn until there is no more of it

burn down.definition: [for a building] to be destroyed by fire

burn for someone or something.definition: to desire someone or something very much
burn for someone or something.example: Jim said he was burning for Sally

burn itself out.definition: [for a flame or fire] to run out of fuel and go out
burn itself out.example: Finally, the fires burned themselves out

burn not your house to fright the mouse.definition: do not do something drastic when it is not necessary
burn not your house to fright the mouse.example: Ellen: I don’t like the shape of my nose; I think I’ll have surgery to make it look better. Jane: But you can make your nose look better just by using different makeup. Don’t burn your house to fright the mouse away

burn off.definition: [for some excess volatile or flammable substance] to burn away or burn up
burn off.example: A film of oil on the surface of the water was burning off, making dense black smoke

burn one\u2019s bridges behind one.definition: to cut off the way back to where you came from, making it impossible to retreat
burn one\u2019s bridges behind one.example: The army, which had burned its bridges behind it, couldn’t go back

burn one\u2019s bridges in front of one.definition: to create future problems for oneself. (a play on burn one’s bridges (behind one).)
burn one\u2019s bridges in front of one.example: I made a mistake again. I always seem to burn my bridges in front of me

burn oneself out.definition: to do something so long and so intensely that one gets sick and tired of doing it
burn oneself out.example: I burned myself out as a competitive swimmer. I just cannot stand to practice anymore

burn someone at the stake.definition: to set fire to a person tied to a post (as a form of execution)
burn someone at the stake.example: They used to burn witches at the stake. 2.  to chastise or denounce some- one severely or excessively

burn someone down.example: Man, don’t you ever burn me down like that again!

burn someone in effigy.definition: to burn a dummy or other figure that represents a hated person
burn someone in effigy.example: For the third day in a row, they burned the king in effigy

burn someone up.example: The house fire burned the victims up

burn something away.definition: to remove or destroy something by burning
burn something away.example: The doctor burned the wart away

burn something down.definition: [for a fire] to destroy a building completely
burn something down.example: The fire burned the barn down

burn something out.definition: to burn away the inside of something, getting rid of excess deposits
burn something out.example: The mechanic burned the carbon out of the manifold

burn something up.definition: to destroy something by fire; [for fire] to consume something
burn something up.example: Take this cardboard and burn it up

burn the candle at both ends.definition: to work very hard and stay up very late at night. (one end of the candle is work done in the daylight, and the other end is work done at night.)
burn the candle at both ends.example: No wonder Mary is ill. She has been burning the candle at both ends for a long time

burn the midnight oil.definition: to stay up working, especially studying, late at night. (alludes to working by the light of an oil lamp late in the night.)
burn the midnight oil.example: I have a big exam tomorrow so I’ll be burning the midnight oil tonight

burn up.definition: to become destroyed or consumed by fire
burn up.example: The wood burned up and left only ashes

burn with a low blue flame.definition: [of a properly adjusted gas burner] to burn and put off heat
burn with a low blue flame.example: Each burner on the stove burns with a low blue flame giving the maximum amount of heat per BTU. 2.  to be quietly and intensely angry

burn with something.definition: [for a fire] to burn with a particular quality
burn with something.example: The building burned with great ferocity

burned to a cinder.definition: burned very badly. [very often used figuratively.]
burned to a cinder.example: I stayed out in the sun too long, and I am burned to a cinder

burned up.definition: very angry. (from the heat of anger. see also burn someone up.)
burned up.example: My new assistant’s mistakes are so maddening! I’ve never been so burned up in my life

a burnt child dreads the fire.definition: if something has hurt you once, you avoid it after that
a burnt child dreads the fire.example: Jill: Let’s go ride the roller coaster! Jane: No, thanks. I got sick on one of those once, and a burnt child dreads the fire

burst at the seams.definition: to be very full and burst, perhaps at the seams. (alludes to something that would burst at the seams if overfilled.)
burst at the seams.example: I am so full from dinner! I’m ready to burst at the seams

burst forth.example: The words burst forth and frightened everyone

burst in on someone or something.definition: to enter a room, interrupting someone or some activity. (often without knocking or seeking permission to enter.)
burst in on someone or something.example: Tom burst in on his sister and her boyfriend while they were kissing

burst in upon someone or something.definition: to intrude or come in thoughtlessly and suddenly and interrupt someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
burst in upon someone or something.example: I didn’t mean to burst in on you

burst in with something.example: Ted burst in with the good news

burst into flames.definition: [for something] to catch fire and become a large fire quickly
burst into flames.example: As soon as the flame reached the curtains, the entire wall seemed to burst into f lames

burst into sight.definition: to come into view suddenly. (as if the sight appeared as suddenly as an explosion.)
burst into sight.example: The sun finally burst into sight at the horizon

burst into some place.definition: to intrude or come in thoughtlessly and suddenly
burst into some place.example: Ted burst into the room and sat down right in the middle of the meeting

burst onto the scene.definition: to appear suddenly in a location
burst onto the scene.example: When Charles burst onto the scene, no one was prepared for the news he brought

burst out.definition: to explode outward; to break open under force
burst out.example: The door burst out and released the trapped people

burst out doing something.definition: to begin to do something suddenly, such as cry, laugh, shout, etc

burst out laughing.example: The entire audience burst out laughing when the clown took a fall

burst out of some place.definition: to come out of a place very rapidly, like an explosion
burst out of some place.example: Everyone burst out of the burning building

burst out of something.definition: to seem to explode out of something; to become [suddenly] too big for something, such as clothes, a house, etc
burst out of something.example: She is practically bursting out of her dress

burst out with something.definition: to utter something loudly and suddenly. (compare this with burst in (with something).)
burst out with something.example: The child burst out with a scream

burst someone\u2019s bubble.definition: to destroy someone’s illusion or delusion; to destroy someone’s fantasy
burst someone\u2019s bubble.example: I hate to burst your bubble, but Columbus did not discover Canada

burst through something.definition: to break through or penetrate something with force
burst through something.example: The tank burst through the barrier easily

burst upon someone.definition: [for an idea] to strike someone suddenly. (as if an idea had burst forth. upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
burst upon someone.example: After thinking all morning long, this really tremendous idea burst upon me

burst upon the scene.definition: to appear suddenly somewhere; to enter or arrive suddenly some place. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
burst upon the scene.example: The police suddenly burst upon the scene

burst with excitement.definition: to have a strong feeling of excitement
burst with excitement.example: Joe was just bursting with excitement because of his triumph

burst with joy.definition: [for someone] to be full to the bursting point with happiness. (to be so filled with joy as if to burst.)
burst with joy.example: When I got my grades, I could have burst with joy

burst with pride.definition: to be full as if to the bursting point with pride
burst with pride.example: My parents were bursting with pride when I graduated from college

bury oneself in something.definition: to become very busy with something
bury oneself in something.example: She stopped taking phone calls and buried herself in her work

bury someone or something away some plac.definition: to bury or hide someone or something some place
bury someone or something away some plac.example: The dog buried the bone away under a bush

bury someone or something in something.definition: to inter someone or something in a grave, the ground, a vault, a tomb, etc
bury someone or something in something.example: They buried the old man in the family vault

bury someone or something under somethin.definition: to bury someone or something beneath something, sometimes to hide or conceal it
bury someone or something under somethin.example: Joe buried the money under a stone in the forest

bury the hatchet.example: Let’s stop arguing and bury the hatchet

bush out.definition: [for a plant, bush, beard, head of hair] to develop many small branches or hairs
bush out.example: His beard bushed out and really needed trimming

a bushel and a peck and some in a gourd.definition: a great deal or amount. (usually used to answer the question, “how much do you love me?”)
a bushel and a peck and some in a gourd.example: Mary: How much do you love me? Tom: A bushel and a peck and some in a gourd

business as usual.definition: having things go along as usual
business as usual.example: Even right after the f lood, it was business as usual in all the stores

business before pleasure.definition: you should finish your work before starting to relax and enjoy yourself
business before pleasure.example: Alan: Hi, Ted. Shall we get something to drink? Ted: Business before pleasure, Alan. Do you have the reports I asked you to bring?

the business end of something.definition: the part or end of something that actually does the work or carries out the procedure
the business end of something.example: Keep away from the business end of the electric drill so you won’t get hurt

a busman\u2019s holiday.definition: leisure time spent doing something similar to what one does at work. (alludes to a bus driver going on a bus tour for his vacation or on a day off.)
a busman\u2019s holiday.example: Tutoring students in the evening is a busman’s holiday for our English teacher

bust a bronco.definition: to ride and thus tame a wild horse so that it can be ridden. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst.)
bust a bronco.example: In them days, I made my living busting broncos

bust a gut to do something.definition: to work very hard; to strain oneself to accomplish something. (the word gut is considered impolite in some circumstances. bust is a nonstandard form of burst.)
bust a gut to do something.example: I don’t intend to bust a gut to get there on time

bust a move.example: Let’s go. Time to bust a move

bust ass out of some place.definition: sl. to get out of some place in a hurry. (potentially offensive. use only with discretion.)
bust ass out of some place.example: I had to bust ass out of the house and run all the way to school

bust out laughing.example: I busted out laughing when I saw him in that getup

bust out of some place.definition: sl. to break out of some place, especially a prison. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst meaning ‘break’ here.)
bust out of some place.example: Somehow the gangsters busted out of prison and left the country

bust some suds.definition: sl. to drink some beer. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst. see also crack some suds.)
bust some suds.example: Let’s go out and bust some suds

bust someone one.definition: sl. to punch someone; to give someone a punch, probably in the face. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst meaning ‘hit’ here.)
bust someone one.example: You better shut up, or I’ll bust you one!

bust someone up.definition: sl. to cause lovers to separate; to break up a pair of lovers, including married persons. ’ here.)
bust someone up.example: Mary busted Terri and John up

bust someone wide open.definition: sl. to beat someone severely. (an exaggeration. bust is a nonstandard form of burst.)
bust someone wide open.example: If you ever take a step onto my property, I’ll bust you wide open

bust something up.definition: to break or ruin something; to break something into smaller pieces. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst meaning ‘break’ here.)

bust up.definition: sl. [for lovers] to separate or break up. (bust is a nonstandard form of burst meaning ‘break’ here.)
bust up.example: Tom and Alice busted up for good

bustle about doing something.definition: to go about doing something busily and energetically
bustle about doing something.example: Greg bustled about all day, doing the chores

bustle about some place.definition: to move about some place very busily, or as if busy
bustle about some place.example: They were all bustling about the kitchen, getting the feast ready

bustle around.example: The people were bustling around, trying to get things ready for the picnic

bustle off.example: Well, I have to bustle off or I’ll miss my f light

bustle someone off.definition: to help someone leave; to send someone out or away
bustle someone off.example: The cops bustled the crook off

busy as a hibernating bear.example: Tom: I can’t go with you. I’m busy. Jane: Yeah. You’re as busy as a hibernating bear

busy oneself with someone or something.definition: to occupy one’s time by dealing with someone or something
busy oneself with someone or something.example: Tony busied himself with helping Sam

busy someone with someone or something.definition: to keep someone busy dealing with someone or something
busy someone with someone or something.example: You should busy the children with some activity

but for someone or something.definition: if it were not for someone or something
but for someone or something.example: But for the railing, I’d have fallen down the stairs

but good.example: She told him off but good

butt in on someone or something.example: Pardon me for butting in on your conversation, but this is important

butt into something.definition: to intrude upon something; to break into a conversation
butt into something.example: Please don’t butt into my conversation; I’m on the phone

the butt of a joke.definition: the reason for or aim of a joke, especially when it is a person
the butt of a joke.example: Poor Fred was the butt of every joke told that evening

butt out.definition: to exit [as abruptly as one has intruded]. (compare this with butt in (on someone or something). usually a command.)

butt up against someone or something.definition: to press against someone or something firmly
butt up against someone or something.example: This board is supposed to butt up against the one over there

butter wouldn\u2019t melt in someone\u20.definition: someone is acting as if innocent
butter wouldn\u2019t melt in someone\u20.example: By the time her parents came home, Emily had cleaned up all evidence of having broken the valuable figurine, and she looked as though butter wouldn’t melt in her mouth

butterflies in one\u2019s stomach.definition: a nervous feeling in one’s stomach
butterflies in one\u2019s stomach.example: Whenever I have to speak in public, I get butterf lies in my stomach

button something down.definition: to fasten something down with buttons
button something down.example: Button your collar down. You look too casually dressed

button up.example: Your jacket’s open. You’d better button up. It’s cold

buttress something up.definition: to brace something; to provide architectural support for something
buttress something up.example: We have to buttress up this part of the wall while we work on it

buy a pig in a poke.definition: to buy something without looking inside first
buy a pig in a poke.example: If you don’t get a good look at the engine of a used car before you buy it, you’ll wind up buying a pig in a poke

buy into something.definition: to purchase shares of something; to buy a part of something the ownership of which is shared with other owners
buy into something.example: I bought into a company that makes dog food

buy one\u2019s way into something.definition: to achieve entry or membership in something often by paying money
buy one\u2019s way into something.example: Do you think you can buy your way into this fraternity?

buy one\u2019s way out of something.definition: to get out of trouble by bribing or influencing someone to ignore what one has done wrong
buy one\u2019s way out of something.example: You can’t buy your way out of this mess, buster!

buy someone off.definition: to bribe someone to ignore what one is doing wrong
buy someone off.example: Do you think you can buy her off ?

buy someone or something out.definition: to purchase full ownership of something from someone or a group
buy someone or something out.example: We liked the company, so we borrowed a lot of money and bought it out

buy someone\u2019s wolf ticket.definition: sl. to challenge someone’s boast or taunt
buy someone\u2019s wolf ticket.example: He wants me to buy his wolf ticket bad

buy something at something.definition: to purchase something at a particular place or at a particular type of sale, such as a store, an auction, a clearance sale, etc
buy something at something.example: I bought this table at an auction

buy something back from someone.definition: to repurchase something that one has previously sold from the person who bought it
buy something back from someone.example: Can I buy it back from you? I have decided I need it

buy something on credit.definition: to purchase something now and pay for it later (normally plus interest)
buy something on credit.example: Almost everyone who buys a house buys it on credit

buy something on time.example: Tom: That’s an awful fancy TV. Are you sure you can afford it? Jane: I’m buying it on time

buy something out.definition: to buy all that is available of a particular item
buy something out.example: The kids came in and bought all our bubble gum out

buy something sight unseen.definition: to buy something without seeing it first
buy something sight unseen.example: I bought this land sight unseen. I didn’t know it was so rocky

buy something up.definition: to buy all of something; to buy the entire supply of something
buy something up.example: He bought the oranges up from all the groves

buy the big one.example: I don’t plan to buy the big one for at least another thirty years

buy time.definition: to postpone an event hoping that the situation will improve
buy time.example: You are just stalling to buy time

buy trouble.definition: to encourage trouble; to bring on trouble. (as if certain acts would pay for or cause difficulties that would have to be suffered through.)
buy trouble.example: I don’t want to buy trouble. I have enough already

buzz along.definition: to move or drive along fast
buzz along.example: The cars were buzzing along at a great rate

buzz for someone.definition: to sound a signal for someone
buzz for someone.example: Please buzz for the bell captain

buzz into some place.definition: to come into a place rapidly or unexpectedly
buzz into some place.example: The child buzzed into the shop and bought a nickel’s worth of candy

buzz off.example: I’ve got to buzz off. Bye

buzz with something.definition: [for a place] to be busy or filled with something

by a mile.definition: by a great distance. (usually an exaggeration.)
by a mile.example: You missed the target by a mile

by a show of hands.definition: [of a vote taken] expressed by people raising their hands
by a show of hands.example: We were asked to vote for the candidates for captain by a show of hands

by all appearances.definition: apparently; according to what one sees or how things seem
by all appearances.example: She is, by all appearances, ready to resume work

by all means.example: I will attempt to get there by all means

by all means of something.definition: trying to do something by the use of every possible manner of something
by all means of something.example: People will be arriving by all means of transportation

by and by.definition: at some time in the future; as time passes
by and by.example: The weather’s sure to clear up by and by

by and large.example: I find that, by and large, people tend to do what they are told to do

by ankle express.example: After my horse was stolen, I had to go by ankle express

by any means.example: I need to get there soon by any means

by any stretch of the imagination.definition: as much as anyone could imagine; as much as is imaginable. (often negative.)
by any stretch of the imagination.example: I don’t see how anyone by any stretch of the imagination could fail to understand what my last sentence meant

by brute strength.example: The men moved the heavy door by brute strength

by chance.example: I found this book by chance at a book sale

by check.definition: by using a check for payment
by check.example: He paid for the book by check

by choice.definition: due to conscious choice; on purpose
by choice.example: I do this kind of thing by choice. No one makes me do it

by coincidence.definition: by an accidental and strange similarity; by an unplanned pairing of events or occurrences
by coincidence.example: We just happened to be in the same place at the same time by coincidence

by cracky.definition: by god! (a mild oath, often used to express surprise or approval.)
by cracky.example: Jim said he’d get the whole house painted this weekend, and by cracky, that’s just what he did

by dint of something.definition: because of something; due to the efforts of something. (dint is an old word meaning ‘force,’ and it is never used except in this phrase.)
by dint of something.example: They got the building finished on time by dint of hard work and good organization

by force of habit.definition: owing to a tendency to do something that has become a habit
by force of habit.example: After I retired, I kept getting up and getting dressed each morning by force of habit

by godfrey.example: By godfrey, Jim’s brother is a big man!

by hand.definition: made by human hands and handheld tools as opposed to a machine
by hand.example: This fine wooden cabinet was made by hand

by hook or by crook.definition: by any means, legal or illegal
by hook or by crook.example: I’ll get the job done by hook or by crook

by itself.definition: with the help of nothing else; without the addition of anything else
by itself.example: Will this food be enough by itself for all of us?

by leaps and bounds.example: The brush we cut back last fall is growing by leaps and bounds

by main strength and awkwardness.example: Tom: How did you get that piano up the stairs? Mary: By main strength and awkwardness

by means of something.definition: using something; with the use of something
by means of something.example: I opened the bottle by means of a bottle opener

by mistake.example: I’m sorry. I came into the wrong room by mistake

by myself.definition: with no one else present; alone
by myself.example: I sat at the table by myself

by no means.example: I’m by no means angry with you

by oneself.definition: with no one else present; alone (of two or more people)
by oneself.example: Must one sit by oneself or may one join another group?

by ourselves.definition: with no one else present; alone
by ourselves.example: Do we have to sit here by ourselves? Can’t we sit with Mary and Max?

by rote.definition: [of learning or memorizing] done as habit and without thinking
by rote.example: I simply memorized the speech by rote. I don’t know what it means

by shank\u2019s mare.definition: by foot; by walking. (shank refers to the shank of the leg.)
by shank\u2019s mare.example: My car isn’t working, so I’ll have to travel by shank’s mare

by the day.example: I don’t know when I’ll have to leave town, so I rent this room by the day

by the dozen.definition: in groups of 12. (compare this with by the dozens.)
by the dozen.example: Eggs are normally sold by the dozen

by the dozens.definition: many; by some fairly large, indefinite number. (similar to but implying less than hundreds. compare this with by the dozen.)
by the dozens.example: Just then people began showing up by the dozens

by the end of the day.definition: by the time when the workday is over; by the time that the sun goes down
by the end of the day.example: Will this task be completed by the end of the day?

by the handful.definition: in amounts equal to a handful; in quantity
by the handful.example: Billy is eating candy by the handful

by the hour.definition: at each hour; once each hour
by the hour.example: It kept growing darker by the hour

by the month.example: Not many apartments are rented by the month

by the nape of the neck.definition: by the back of the neck. (mostly said in threats.)
by the nape of the neck.example: He grabbed me by the nape of the neck and told me not to turn around if I valued my life. I stood very still

by the same token.definition: cliché a phrase indicating that the speaker is introducing parallel or closely contrasting information
by the same token.example: Tom: I really got cheated! Bob: You think they’ve cheated you, but, by the same token, they believe that you’ve cheated them

by the seat of one\u2019s pants.definition: by sheer luck and use of intuition
by the seat of one\u2019s pants.example: I got through school by the seat of my pants

by the skin of one\u2019s teeth.definition: just barely. (by an amount equal to the thickness of the (imaginary) skin on one’s teeth.)
by the skin of one\u2019s teeth.example: I got through calculus class by the skin of my teeth

by the sweat of one\u2019s brow.definition: by one’s efforts; by one’s hard work
by the sweat of one\u2019s brow.example: Tom raised these vegetables by the sweat of his brow

by the week.example: I plan my schedules by the week

by the year.example: Most apartments are available by the year

by themselves.definition: with help from no one else
by themselves.example: Do you think they can do it by themselves?

by virtue of something.definition: because of something; due to something
by virtue of something.example: She’s permitted to vote by virtue of her age

by way of something.definition: passing through something (as a place); via something
by way of something.example: He came home by way of Toledo

by word of mouth.example: I learned about it by word of mouth

by yourself.definition: with no one else present; alone
by yourself.example: Do you want to sit here by yourself, or can I sit here too?

by yourselves.definition: with no one else present; alone (of two or more people)
by yourselves.example: Are you two going to stand here by yourselves all evening?

caesar \u2019s wife must be above suspic.definition: the associates of public figures must not even be suspected of wrongdoing. (the ancient roman julius caesar is supposed to have said this when asked why he divorced his wife, pompeia. because she was suspected of some wrongdoing, he could not associate with her anymore.)
caesar \u2019s wife must be above suspic.example: Jill: I don’t think the mayor is trustworthy; his brother was charged with embezzlement. Jane: But the charges were never proved. Jill: That doesn’t matter. Caesar’s wife must be above suspicion

cage someone or something in.definition: to enclose someone or something in a cage
cage someone or something in.example: We caged the monkey in, but it threw a fit

the customer is always right.definition: in order to keep customers happy, the people who serve them should always obey their wishes. (often cited as a principle of good business dealings; customers sometimes say it to the people serving them in order to try to get good service.)

cut a deal.definition: to arrange a deal; to negotiate an agreement
cut a deal.example: Maybe we can cut a deal. Let’s talk

cut a fine figure.definition: to look good; to look elegant. (usually said of a male.)

a cut above average.example: John isn’t the best mechanic in town, but he’s a cut above average

a cut above something.definition: a measure or degree better than something else

cut along something.definition: to make a cut following a line or guide

cut and dried.definition: fixed; determined beforehand; usual and uninteresting. (can be hyphenated before nominals.)

cut and paste.definition: to cut something out of paper with scissors and paste it onto something else

cut and run.definition: sl. to run away quickly. (alludes to cutting loose a ship’s or boat’s anchor and sailing away in a hurry.)

cut around something.definition: to move rapidly around something, such as a corner, pole, beam, etc

cut back.definition: to turn back; to reverse direction

cut back on something.definition: to reduce the use, amount, or cost of something

cut back to someone or something.definition: [for a film or television camera] to return to a picture of someone or something

cut both ways.definition: to affect both sides of an issue equally

cut corners.definition: to take shortcuts; to save money or effort by finding cheaper or easier ways to do something

cut down on something.definition: to reduce the amount of something or of doing something; to use or buy less of something

cut in ahead of someone or something.definition: to move quickly and carelessly into line ahead of someone, as in a line of people or in traffic

cut in on someone.definition: [for someone] to ask to replace one member of a dancing couple

cut in on something.definition: to interrupt something, especially some sort of electronic transmission

cut in with something.definition: to interrupt [someone] with a comment; to speak abruptly, interrupting what someone else is saying

cut into something.definition: to slice something; to gouge something

cut it out.definition: stop doing that!; stop saying that! (fixed order.)

cut no ice with someone.definition: sl. to have no influence on someone; to fail to convince someone

cut off.definition: to stop by itself or oneself

cut one\u2019s eyes at someone or someth.definition: to glance at someone or something

cut one\u2019s eyeteeth on something.definition: to grow up experiencing something; to have had the experience of dealing with something [successfully] at a very early age

cut one\u2019s own throat.definition: [for someone] to bring about one’s (own) failure

cut one\u2019s wolf loose.definition: sl. to go on a drinking bout; to get drunk

cut oneself loose from someone or someth.definition: to get out from under the domination of someone or something

cut oneself on something.definition: to slice one’s flesh with something accidentally

cut out.definition: to depart; to leave in a hurry

cut out for someone or something.definition: to run hurriedly toward someone or something

cut out for something.example: She was bright and she loved to read. Her folks thought she was cut out for being a schoolteacher

cut out to be something.definition: destined to be something or a particular type of person
cut out to be something.example: I don’t think I was cut out to do this

cut someone a check.definition: to write a check; to have a computer print a check. (used in business especially of machine-made checks.)

cut someone dead.example: Joan was just about to speak to James when he walked away and cut her dead

cut someone down.definition: to kill someone with a weapon, such as a sword, or with gunfire, etc

cut someone in on something.definition: sl. to permit someone to share something, such as profits or loot

cut someone off at the pass.definition: to block someone’s effort to get away; to thwart someone’s efforts

cut someone off without a penny.definition: to end someone’s allowance; to fail to leave someone money in one’s will

cut someone or something loose from some.definition: to sever the connection between people or things, in any combination

cut someone or something off from someth.definition: to block or isolate someone or something from some place or something

cut someone or something off short.definition: to interrupt someone or something; to prevent someone from continuing to speak

cut someone or something out.example: They cut out the free coffee with lunch at the cafeteria

cut someone or something to something.definition: to chop or slice up someone or something, especially to bits or pieces

cut someone or something up.definition: to criticize someone or something severely

cut someone\u2019s water off.definition: to squelch someone; to thwart someone. (fixed order.)

cut someone to ribbons.definition: to cut or slice someone severely

cut someone up.example: That comedian’s routine really cut me up

cut something away from something.definition: to separate something from something by cutting

cut something back.definition: to prune plants; to reduce the size of plants, bushes, etc
cut something back.example: Let’s cut these bushes back. They’re getting in the way

cut something down.definition: to chop something down; to saw or cut at something until it is felled

cut something down to something.definition: to reduce something to a manageable size
cut something down to something.example: We cut the program down to size and it was very enjoyable

cut something from something.definition: to remove something from something by cutting
cut something from something.example: She carefully cut the blossoms from the bush

cut something off.example: Cut this board off a bit, would you?

cut something on something.definition: to slice something on or against something, accidentally
cut something on something.example: I cut my finger on the knife

cut something to the bone.definition: to slice deep to a bone
cut something to the bone.example: The knife cut John to the bone. He had to be sewed up

cut something with something.definition: to dilute something with something else

cut teeth.definition: [for a baby or young person] to have new teeth emerging through the gums

cut the dust.definition: to take a drink of liquor

cut through something.definition: to penetrate something by cutting; to slice through something

cut up.definition: to act wildly; to show off and be troublesome; to act like a clown

cut up about someone or something.definition: sl. emotionally upset about someone or something

cut your peaches.definition: go on with what you were doing

cute as a bug\u2019s ear.example: That little baby is cute as a bug’s ear

the cutting edge.definition: the most forward part of a trend; the leading part of a trend. (alludes to the edge of a sword. see also on the cutting edge. see also on the bleeding edge.)

dab at something.example: The painter dabbed at the canvas, making little changes here and there

dabble at something.definition: to play at doing something; to do something halfheartedly

dad fetch my buttons.example: Dad fetch my buttons! It’s a letter from Aunt Rita!

daily dozen.example: My brother always feels better after his daily dozen

the daily grind.example: I’m getting very tired of the daily grind

dally over something.definition: to waste time or take too long doing something

damn it to blue blazes.example: Damn it to blue blazes, I told you I can’t lend you any more money!

a damn sight better.example: Mary can sing a damn sight better than Tom can

damn someone or something with faint pra.definition: to criticize someone or something indirectly by not praising enthusiastically

dance with someone.definition: to perform social dancing with another person
dance with someone.example: Do you think you would like to dance with Wally?

dangle from something.example: A number of colorful glass balls dangled from the branches of the tree

dangle something from something.definition: to hang something loosely from something else

dawdle about.definition: to waste time in a place; to waste time talking idly

dead ahead.example: Look out! There is a cow in the road dead ahead

dead and buried.definition: dead and interred, and soon to be forgotten
dead and buried.example: Now that Uncle Bill is dead and buried, we can read his will. 2.  gone forever

dead and gone.example: Old Gert’s been dead and gone for quite a spell

dead broke.example: I’m dead broke—not a nickel to my name

a dead cat on the line.example: I’m afraid there’s a dead cat on the line over at Martha’s place. I haven’t heard from them for days

dead center.definition: at the exact center of something

dead drunk.example: They were both dead drunk. They could only lie there and snore

dead easy.example: This whole job is dead easy

dead from the neck up.example: She acts like she is dead from the neck up. 2.  no longer open to new ideas

a dead giveaway.definition: something that reveals a fact or an intention completely

dead in someone\u2019s or an animal\u201.definition: exactly where someone or something is at the moment; at this instant. (this does not usually have anything to do with death. the phrase is often used with stop.)
dead in someone\u2019s or an animal\u201.example: Her unkind words stopped me dead in my tracks

dead meat.definition: dead; as good as dead. (usually an exaggeration.)

dead on.example: That’s a good observation, Tiffany. You are dead on

dead serious.example: Tom: You’re funning me. Bill: No, I’m dead serious

dead to the world.example: After all that exercise, he’s dead to the world

deadly dull.example: The lecture was deadly dull, and I went to sleep

deaf and dumb.example: Fred objected to being called deaf and dumb

deaf as a post.example: When my cousin was a teenager, she played her drum set without ear protection, and she was as deaf as a post by the age of twentyfive

deal in something.example: My uncle is a stockbroker. He deals in stocks and bonds

dear departed.definition: euph. a dead person, as referred to at a funeral
dear departed.example: Let’s take a moment to meditate on the life of the dear departed. dedicate a Dear John letter a letter a woman writes to her boyfriend telling him that she does not love him anymore

decide upon someone or something.example: Will you please hurry up and decide upon someone to vote for?

declare oneself for someone or something.definition: to state one’s support of someone or something
declare oneself for someone or something.example: Susan declared herself for Mary’s candidacy

decorate someone for something.example: The town decorated her for her heroic act

decorate something with something.definition: to adorn or ornament something with something
decorate something with something.example: I will decorate the cake with roses made of sugar

distance lends enchantment to the view.definition: things that are far away from you appear better than they really are

don\u2019t bother.example: Mary: Should I make some dinner for you? Bill: No, don’t bother; it’s late

don\u2019t bother me.example: Tom: Hey, Bill! Bill: Don’t bother me! I’m busy. Can’t you see?

don\u2019t breathe a word of this to any.definition: this is a secret or secret gossip. do not tell it to anyone. (breathing a word is fig. for whispering.)
don\u2019t breathe a word of this to any.example: Bill: Have you heard about Mary and her friends? Sally: No. Tell me! Tell me! Bill: Well, they all went secretly to Mexico for the weekend. Now, don’t breathe a word of this to anyone

don\u2019t call us we\u2019ll call you.definition: cliché a formulaic expression said to applicants who have just interviewed or auditioned for a job or part
don\u2019t call us we\u2019ll call you.example: Thank you, Eddie Evans. Don’t call us, we’ll call you

don\u2019t count your chickens before th.definition: cliché do not act as though something has turned out favorably for you until it has really turned out that way
don\u2019t count your chickens before th.example: Jill: When I get my raise, I’ll use the extra money to go on vacation. Jane: But you don’t know for sure that you’re going to get a raise. Don’t count your chickens before they are hatched

don\u2019t cry before you are hurt.definition: do not be upset about a bad thing that might happen; only be upset when something bad really does happen
don\u2019t cry before you are hurt.example: Fred: What am I going to do? There’s a possibility that my job will be eliminated! Jane: Don’t cry before you are hurt. They haven’t eliminated you yet

don\u2019t do anything i wouldn\u2019t d.definition: an expression said when two friends are parting
don\u2019t do anything i wouldn\u2019t d.example: Bill: See you next month, Tom. Tom: Yeah, man. Don’t do anything I wouldn’t do

don\u2019t even look like something.definition: do not even appear to be doing something! (the something can be thinking about something or actually doing something.)
don\u2019t even look like something.example: Mary: Are you thinking about taking that last piece of cake? Bob: Of course not. Mary: Well, don’t even look like you’re doing it!

don\u2019t even think about doing it.definition: do not do it, and do not even think about doing it
don\u2019t even think about doing it.example: John reached into his jacket for his wallet. The cop, thinking John was about to draw a gun, said, “Don’t even think about it.”

don\u2019t even think about it happening.definition: do not think about something like that happening, as the mere thought of it is so bad. (compare this with don’t even think about (doing) it.)
don\u2019t even think about it happening.example: Mary: Oh, those cars almost crashed! How horrible! Fred: Don’t even think about it

don\u2019t get your bowels in an uproar.example: Bill: What have you done to my car? Where’s the bumper? The side window is cracked! Bob: Calm down! Don’t get your bowels in an uproar!

don\u2019t give a continental.definition: does not care at all. (also with doesn’t. don’t used with all persons is folksy.)
don\u2019t give a continental.example: I don’t give a continental if I never see him again

don\u2019t give a hoot in hell\u2019s ho.definition: to not care one bit. (also with doesn’t. don’t used with all persons is folksy.)
don\u2019t give a hoot in hell\u2019s ho.example: Mary: Joe left town. Are you sorry to see him go? Tom: No! I don’t give a hoot in hell’s hollow

don\u2019t give me any of your lip.example: Do as I tell you and don’t give me any of your lip!

don\u2019t give up.definition: do not stop trying!; keep trying!
don\u2019t give up.example: John: Get in there and give it another try. Don’t give up! Bill: Okay. Okay. But it’s hopeless

don\u2019t give up the ship.definition: do not give up yet!; do not yield the entire enterprise! (fixed order. alludes to the words on a flag made by captain oliver hazard perry in the battle of lake erie during the war of 1812.)
don\u2019t give up the ship.example: Bill: I’m having a devil of a time with calculus. I think I want to drop the course. Sally: Keep trying. Don’t give up the ship!

don\u2019t give up without a fight.definition: do not yield easily.; keep struggling and you may win.; do not give up too soon. (also with don’t. don’t used with all persons is folksy.)
don\u2019t give up without a fight.example: Sue: She says no every time I ask her for a raise. Mary: Well, don’t give up without a fight. Keep after her

don\u2019t have a cow.definition: calm down!; don’t get so excited! (made famous in the television show, the simpsons.)
don\u2019t have a cow.example: Chill out, man! Don’t have a cow!

don\u2019t have a pot to piss in or a wi.definition: doesn’t have anything of value; very poor. (use with caution.)
don\u2019t have a pot to piss in or a wi.example: When Ed was a young man, he didn’t have a pot to piss in

don\u2019t hold your breath.definition: do not stop breathing waiting for something to happen that won’t happen. (meaning that it will take longer for it to happen than you can possibly hold your breath.)
don\u2019t hold your breath.example: Tom: The front yard is such a mess. Bob: Bill’s supposed to rake the leaves. Tom: Don’t hold your breath. He never does his share of the work

don\u2019t i know it.example: Mary: Goodness gracious! It’s hot today. Bob: Don’t I know it!

don\u2019t i know you from somewhere.definition: a way of striking up a conversation with a stranger, as at a party or other gathering
don\u2019t i know you from somewhere.example: Bill: Don’t I know you from somewhere? Mary: I don’t think so. Where did you go to school?

don\u2019t knock it.example: You don’t want any okra? Don’t knock it

don\u2019t know whether to eat it or rub.definition: do not know what to do with something. (used to describe a kind of food one does not recognize or that looks unusual.) (also with doesn’t. don’t used with all persons is folksy.)
don\u2019t know whether to eat it or rub.example: That sure was a fancy dessert Mary served. I didn’t know whether to eat it or rub it on

don\u2019t let someone or something get.definition: do not allow yourself to be overcome or disappointed by someone or something
don\u2019t let someone or something get.example: Don’t let their constant teasing get you down

don\u2019t let the bastards wear you dow.definition: don’t let those people get the best of you. (exercise caution with bastard.)
don\u2019t let the bastards wear you dow.example: Bill: The place I work at is really rough. Everybody is rude and jealous of each other. Tom: Don’t let the bastards wear you down

don\u2019t look a gift horse in the mout.definition: do not look for defects in a gift
don\u2019t look a gift horse in the mout.example: Jill: I wonder why Grandma gave me this table. Maybe it has one leg shorter than the others. Jane: Don’t look a gift horse in the mouth

don\u2019t make me laugh.example: You a judge? Don’t make me laugh!

don\u2019t make two bites of a cherry.definition: do not leave a simple job half-done
don\u2019t make two bites of a cherry.example: Tom: I washed the dishes and left them in the rack. I’ll put them away tomorrow. Mary: Oh, come on. Don’t make two bites of a cherry

don\u2019t mention it.definition: you are welcome and your thanks are not necessary
don\u2019t mention it.example: A: Thank you so much! B: Don’t mention it

don\u2019t mind me.definition: don’t pay any attention to me.; just ignore me. (sometimes sarcastic.)
don\u2019t mind me.example: Bill and Jane were watching television when Jane’s mother walked through the room, grabbing the newspaper on the way. “Don’t mind me,” she said

don\u2019t push me.definition: i can move on my own, so don’t shove me!
don\u2019t push me.example: I can’t move any faster than this. Don’t push me! 2.  Don’t put pressure on me to do something!

don\u2019t put all your eggs in one bask.definition: do not risk everything on one undertaking
don\u2019t put all your eggs in one bask.example: Keep your day job while you pursue your acting career at night, just in case the acting doesn’t go so well. You know—don’t put all your eggs in one basket

don\u2019t put off for tomorrow what you.example: Father: Take out the garbage. Child: I’ll do it in the morning. Father: It only takes a minute. Don’t put off for tomorrow what you can do today

don\u2019t put the cart before the horse.definition: do not do things in the wrong order. (this can imply that the person you are addressing is impatient.)
don\u2019t put the cart before the horse.example: Tune the guitar first, then play it. Don’t put the cart before the horse

don\u2019t rush me.example: Bill: Hurry up! Make up your mind! Bob: Don’t rush me! Bill: I want to get out of here before midnight

don\u2019t say it.definition: i don’t want to hear it!; i know, so you don’t have to say it
don\u2019t say it.example: John (joking): What is that huge pile of stuff on your head? Bill: Don’t say it! I know I need a haircut

don\u2019t speak too soon.definition: i think you may be wrong. don’t speak before you know the facts. (compare this with don’t be too sure.)
don\u2019t speak too soon.example: Bill: It looks like it’ll be a nice day. Mary: Don’t speak too soon. I just felt a raindrop

don\u2019t spend it all in one place.definition: a phrase said after giving someone some money, especially a small amount of money
don\u2019t spend it all in one place.example: Fred: Dad, can I have a dollar? Father: Sure. Here. Don’t spend it all in one place

don\u2019t stand on ceremony.definition: do not wait for a formal invitation.; please be at ease and make yourself at home. (some people read this as “don’t remain standing because of ceremony,” and others read it “don’t be totally obedient to the requirements of ceremony.”)
don\u2019t stand on ceremony.example: Come in, Tom. Don’t stand on ceremony. Get yourself a drink and something to eat and introduce yourself to everyone.”

don\u2019t start on me.example: Yes, I know it’s a mess. Don’t start!

don\u2019t stay away so long.definition: please visit more often. (said upon the arrival or departure of a guest.)
don\u2019t stay away so long.example: John: Hi, Bill! Long time no see. Don’t stay away so long! Bill: Thanks, John. Good to see you

don\u2019t take any wooden nickels.definition: be careful and do not let anyone cheat you. (often used as a jocular way of saying good-bye.)
don\u2019t take any wooden nickels.example: Tom: So long. Bill: Don’t take any wooden nickels

don\u2019t teach your grandmother to suc.definition: do not try to instruct someone who is more experienced than you. (extremely casual; potentially rude.)
don\u2019t teach your grandmother to suc.example: Bob told the seasoned guitar player that she was holding the guitar incorrectly. “Don’t teach your grandmother to suck eggs,” she replied

don\u2019t tell a soul.definition: please do not tell anyone this gossip
don\u2019t tell a soul.example: Bill: Is your brother getting married? Sally: Yes, but don’t tell a soul. It’s a secret

don\u2019t tell me what to do.example: Sue: Next, you should get a haircut, then get some new clothes. You really need to fix yourself up. Sally: Don’t tell me what to do! Maybe I like me the way I am!

don\u2019t throw the baby out with the b.definition: do not discard something valuable in your eagerness to get rid of some useless thing associated with it
don\u2019t throw the baby out with the b.example: Jill: As long as I’m selling all the books Grandpa had, I might as well sell the bookcases, too. Jane: Don’t throw the baby out with the bathwater. You can use the bookcases for something else

don\u2019t touch that dial.definition: do not change your radio or television dial, but continue to listen to this station. (from broadcasts in the days when tuning was done with a dial.)
don\u2019t touch that dial.example: Don’t touch that dial. Stay tuned for The Adventures of Blondie. 2.  Do not change anything or divert your attention

don\u2019t waste my time.definition: do not take up my valuable time with a poor presentation.; do not waste my time trying to get me to do something
don\u2019t waste my time.example: Bob: I’d like to show you our new line of industrial-strength vacuum cleaners. Bill: Beat it! Don’t waste my time

don\u2019t waste your breath.definition: you will not get a positive response to what you have to say, so don’t even say it.; talking will get you nowhere
don\u2019t waste your breath.example: Alice: I’ll go in there and try to convince her otherwise. Fred: Don’t waste your breath. I already tried it

don\u2019t waste your time.definition: you will not get anywhere with it, so don’t waste time trying
don\u2019t waste your time.example: Mary: Should I ask Tom if he wants to go to the convention, or is he still in a bad mood? Sally: Don’t waste your time. Mary: Bad mood, huh?

don\u2019t work too hard.definition: an expression said at the end of a conversation after or in place of good-bye
don\u2019t work too hard.example: Mary: Bye, Tom. Tom: Bye, Mary. Don’t work too hard

don\u2019t worry about a thing.definition: do not become anxious about something.; everything will be all right
don\u2019t worry about a thing.example: “Don’t worry, Fred,” comforted Bill, “everything will be all right.”

don\u2019t worry your pretty little head.definition: do not worry about it. (said condescendingly, and can cause offense.)
don\u2019t worry your pretty little head.example: Mary: How are you going to get another job if you don’t start looking for one? Tom: Now don’t worry your pretty little head about it. Just leave it to me

don\u2019t you know it.definition: you can be absolutely sure about that!; you’re exactly right, and i agree with you. (this is not a question.)
don\u2019t you know it.example: Alice: Man, is it hot! Fred: Don’t you know it!

don\u2019t you wish.definition: don’t you wish that what you have just said were really true?
don\u2019t you wish.example: Mary: I’m going to get a job that lets me travel a lot. Sally: Don’t you wish!

doom someone or something to something.definition: to destine someone or something to something unpleasant
doom someone or something to something.example: The judgment doomed her to a life in prison

doomed to something.definition: condemned to something; facing something as a future or as a consequence [of something]
doomed to something.example: The project was doomed to failure from the start

a door must be either shut or open.definition: if you have only two alternatives, you must choose one or the other; you cannot have both
a door must be either shut or open.example: Either you’re going to marry that girl, or you’re not. A door must be either shut or open

doors open up to someone.example: After Ann made a few inquiries, doors began to open up to me

doortodoor.definition: having to do with movement from one door to another or from one house to another

dope someone or an animal up.definition: to give drugs to someone or an animal
dope someone or an animal up.example: Her parents doped her up with medicine so she would sleep through the night

dope something out.example: He spent a lot of time trying to dope the assignment out so he could understand it

dork off.definition: sl. to waste time; to goof off
dork off.example: Stop dorking off and get busy

dose someone or an animal with something.definition: to give medicine to someone or an animal
dose someone or an animal with something.example: You should dose the child with a little nonaspirin painkiller

doss down for some time.definition: sl. to lie down to sleep for a period of time
doss down for some time.example: Chuck dossed down for a few hours before the evening performance

dot something with something.definition: to put little bits or dots of something on something
dot something with something.example: She dotted her face with red marks to make it look as if she had measles

dote upon someone or something.definition: to adore or spoil someone or something; to like very much. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
dote upon someone or something.example: His aunt simply dotes upon him

double as someone or something.definition: [for someone] to serve in two capacities
double as someone or something.example: The chairman will have to double as CEO until we find a new one

double back on someone or something.definition: [for a person or animal] to reverse motion, moving toward (rather than away from) someone or something. (refers primarily to a person or animal that is being pursued by someone or a group.)
double back on someone or something.example: The deer doubled back on the hunter

double dutch.definition: language or speech that is difficult or impossible to understand
double dutch.example: This book on English grammar is written in double Dutch. I can’t understand a word

double in brass as something.definition: to serve in two capacities. (alludes to a musician who could play the brass instruments as well as other instruments.)
double in brass as something.example: Wally was our bookkeeper and doubled in brass as a clerk

double over.definition: [for a person] to bend at the waist
double over.example: Suddenly, he doubled over and collapsed

double someone over.definition: to cause someone to bend at the waist
double someone over.example: The blow to the back of the head doubled Steve over

double something over.example: Double the paper over twice, then press it f lat

double up on someone or something.definition: [for people] to deal with someone or something in pairs
double up on someone or something.example: We are going to have to double up in this job

double up with laughter.definition: to laugh so hard that one bends over
double up with laughter.example: We all just doubled up with laughter

double up with pain.definition: to bend at the waist with severe pain
double up with pain.example: The man doubled up with pain when he was stabbed

double up with someone.example: We don’t have enough books. Tom, will you double up with Jane?

a double whammy.definition: a double dose of something; a strong or powerful helping of something
a double whammy.example: When the Federal Reserve Board raised the interest rates, I got a double whammy. My stocks went down and my bonds did too

doublecross someone.definition: to betray someone. (originally a more complicated switching of sides in a conspiracy wherein the double-crosser sides with the victim of the conspiracy—against the original conspirator.)
doublecross someone.example: Don’t even think about double-crossing me!

doubting thomas.definition: someone who will not easily believe something without strong proof or evidence. (can be said of a man or a woman. from the biblical account of the apostle thomas, who would not believe that jesus had risen from the dead until he actually touched the risen christ.)
doubting thomas.example: Mary won’t believe that I have a dog until she sees it. She’s such a doubting Thomas

douse someone or something with somethin.definition: to splash or drench someone with something
douse someone or something with somethin.example: She doused her brother with a bucket of cold water

dovetail something into something.definition: to fit something neatly into something; to make something interlock nicely with something else
dovetail something into something.example: She dovetailed her story into mine perfectly and the police let us go

dovetail with something.definition: to interlock tightly with something using a dovetail joint
dovetail with something.example: The side of the drawer dovetails with the front of the drawer. 2.  to fit neatly into something

down and dirty.example: (Used as an attributive.) The last time he painted the kitchen, it was a down and dirty job because he thought we were moving.  coarse; mean-spirited

down by some amount.definition: having a score that is lower, by the specified amount, than someone else’s score or the other team’s score
down by some amount.example: At halftime, the home team was down by 14 points

down for something.definition: having one’s name written down for something
down for something.example: Am I down for an evening appointment?

down in the dumps.example: I’ve been down in the dumps for the past few days

down in the mouth.example: Since her dog died, Barbara has been down in the mouth

down on one\u2019s luck.example: Can you lend me twenty dollars? I’ve been down on my luck lately

down pat.example: I have practiced my speech until I have it down pat

down south.definition: to or at the southeastern united states
down south.example: I used to live down South

down the chute.example: A lot of money went down the chute on that deal, and all for nothing

down the drain.example: Well, there’s 400 bucks down the drain

down the hatch.definition: i am about to drink this.; let’s all drink up. (said as one is about to take a drink, especially of something bad-tasting or potent. also used as a jocular toast.)
down the hatch.example: Bob said, “Down the hatch,” and drank the whiskey in one gulp

down the little red lane.definition: down someone’s throat; down a child’s throat
down the little red lane.example: This really tasty medicine has to go down the little red lane

down the road.definition: farther along on this same road
down the road.example: Just continue down the road until you come to a little church. Turn left there. 2.  in the future

down the street.definition: a short distance away on this same street
down the street.example: Sally lives just down the street

down the tubes.example: His political career went down the tubes after the scandal. He’s lost his job

down to a gnat\u2019s eyebrow.example: He described what the thief was wearing down to a gnat’s eyebrow

down to chili and beans.definition: very poor; down to one’s last penny
down to chili and beans.example: Mary and Tom aren’t doing too well. They’re down to chili and beans

down to the last bit of money.definition: having only a small amount of money left
down to the last bit of money.example: I’m down to my last nickel

down to the last detail.example: Jean planned the party very carefully, down to the last minute

down under.example: I’ve always wanted to visit down under

down with a disease.definition: ill; sick at home. (can be said about many diseases. *typically: be ~; come ~; get ~.)
down with a disease.example: Tom isn’t here. He’s down with a cold

down with someone or something.definition: do away with someone or something!; i am opposed to someone or something!
down with someone or something.example: Down with higher taxes! Down with corporate tax breaks!

downandout.definition: having no money or means of support
downandout.example: There are many young people down-and-out in the city

downattheheels.definition: [of shoes] worn on the bottom of the heels
downattheheels.example: This pair is a little down-at-the-heels, but I only use them for gardening. 2.  worn down; showing signs of use or age

downgrade someone or something to someth.definition: to decrease the status of someone or something to something
downgrade someone or something to someth.example: In effect, this downgrades your project to unimportant

downhill all the way.example: Don’t worry about your algebra course. It’s downhill all the way after this chapter

downhill from here on.example: The worst part is over. It’s downhill from here on

downhome.definition: as one would find in rural, especially southern, america
downhome.example: She speaks with a kind of down-home accent that sounds more friendly than the typical, urban northener

downtime.definition: the time when a computer or some other system is not operating. (computer jargon.)
downtime.example: I can’t afford a lot of downtime in the system I buy

downtoearth.example: You can depend on Ann. She’s very down-to-earth

downtothewire.definition: waiting until the very last moment; right up to the deadline
downtothewire.example: It came down-to-the-wire before I turned the proposal in

doze off to sleep.example: I dozed off to sleep during the second act of the opera

draft someone for something.definition: to select someone for something or to do something
draft someone for something.example: We drafted a bunch of the boys for moving tables

draft someone into something.definition: to conscript someone into the armed services
draft someone into something.example: The draft board drafted Scott into the army

drag behind.definition: to follow along close behind someone
drag behind.example: His little brother came along, dragging behind

a drag on someone.example: I wish you wouldn’t be such a drag on your friends

a drag on something.definition: sl. a puff or any kind of cigarette
a drag on something.example: She had a drag on her cigarette and crushed it out on the sidewalk

drag someone in on something.definition: to force someone to join something or participate in something
drag someone in on something.example: Don’t drag me in on this

drag someone or something down.definition: to pull someone or something to the ground or to a lower level
drag someone or something down.example: The lions dragged the antelope down and made dinner out of it

drag someone or something off to someone.definition: to haul someone or something away to someone, something, or some place
drag someone or something off to someone.example: The cops dragged her off to jail

drag someone through the mud.definition: to insult, defame, and debase someone
drag someone through the mud.example: The newspapers dragged the actress through the mud week after week

drag someone up.definition: to force someone to come up or to come and stand nearby
drag someone up.example: He wouldn’t come on his own, so I dragged him up

drag something behind one.definition: to pull something that is behind one
drag something behind one.example: The child dragged the wooden toy behind him

drag something up.definition: to pull something close, such as a chair, stool, etc., to sit in
drag something up.example: Please drag a chair up and sit down

dragged out.example: I feel so dragged out. I think I need some sleep

dragoon someone into something.definition: to force someone into doing something
dragoon someone into something.example: We dragooned the boys into helping us

drain away.example: All the water drained away and exposed the mud and rocks on the bottom of the pond

drain from something.example: All the dirty oil drained from the engine

drain out.example: All the milk drained out of the container onto the bottom of the refrigerator

drain someone or something of something.definition: to exhaust someone or something of something, such as energy, motivation, etc
drain someone or something of something.example: This day has drained me of all my motivation

drain something away from something.definition: to channel some liquid away from something
drain something away from something.example: Drain all of the standing water away from the foundation of the house

drain something from someone or somethin.definition: to cause something to flow out of someone or something
drain something from someone or somethin.example: The farmers drained the water from the f looded fields

drain something of something.definition: to empty something out of something
drain something of something.example: He drained the glass of the remaining beer

drape oneself over something.definition: to sprawl on a piece of furniture
drape oneself over something.example: He draped himself over the armchair and dropped off to sleep

drape over something.definition: [for cloth] to cover something and hang down
drape over something.example: The robe draped over her knees, but she was still cold

drape someone or something in something.definition: to wrap or cover someone or something in something
drape someone or something in something.example: They draped her in golden silks, but she still looked like a country girl

drape someone or something with somethin.definition: to hang something on or over someone or something
drape someone or something with somethin.example: They draped each guest with a makeshift toga

drape something around someone or someth.definition: to wrap or hang something around someone or something
drape something around someone or someth.example: She draped the shawl around her shoulders and felt a little warmer

draw a blank.definition: to get no response; to find nothing
draw a blank.example: I asked him about Tom’s financial problems, and I just drew a blank

draw a line in the sand.definition: to create or declare an artificial boundary and imply that crossing it will cause trouble
draw a line in the sand.example: Todd drew a line in the sand by giving his roommate an ultimatum about his sloppiness—he had to start cleaning up after himself or move out

draw against an amount of money.definition: to withdraw money from something in advance
draw against an amount of money.example: I can draw against my allowance—at least a small amount

draw ahead of someone or something.definition: to pull or move ahead of someone or something in motion
draw ahead of someone or something.example: I drew ahead of the car in front of me

draw blood.definition: to hit or bite (a person or an animal) and make a wound that bleeds
draw blood.example: The dog chased me and bit me hard, but it didn’t draw blood

draw interest.definition: to appear interesting and get (someone’s) attention. (note the variation in the examples.)
draw interest.example: This kind of event isn’t likely to draw a lot of interest

draw oneself aside.example: I drew myself aside so the children could pass

draw oneself up to something.definition: to stand up straight to one’s full height. (fixed order.)
draw oneself up to something.example: Walter drew himself up to his six-foot height and walked away

draw people or things together.definition: to pull people together; to pull things together
draw people or things together.example: She drew her toys together in preparation for leaving

draw some kind of attention away from so.definition: to capture attention or praise due to someone or something
draw some kind of attention away from so.example: Her sterling performance drew attention away from the big star in one of the other roles

draw someone aside.definition: to pull or steer someone aside
draw someone aside.example: The teacher drew Bob aside to have a word with him

draw someone or something from something.definition: to sketch (someone or something) from a particular source, such as memory, real life, a photograph, etc
draw someone or something from something.example: He is a very good artist. He can draw from a photograph or a painting

draw someone or something toward someone.definition: to pull someone or something to someone or something
draw someone or something toward someone.example: She drew him toward her and kissed him

draw someone\u2019s attention to someone.definition: to attract someone to notice or focus on someone or something
draw someone\u2019s attention to someone.example: Now, I would like to draw your attention to Fred, the gentleman we have all heard so much about

draw someone together.definition: to make people seek one another for emotional support
draw someone together.example: The tragic accident drew the family all together

draw something apart.definition: to pull something, such as curtains or drapes, open or apart
draw something apart.example: She drew the curtains apart and looked out the window
