for that matter.example: If you’re hungry, take one of my doughnuts. For that matter, take two

for the asking.definition: if one just asks (for something); simply by asking; on request
for the asking.example: Do you want to use my car? It’s yours for the asking

for the better.example: A change of government would be for the better

for the birds.example: This television program is for the birds

for the duration.definition: for the whole time that something continues; for the entire period of time required for something to be completed; for as long as something takes
for the duration.example: We are in this war for the duration

for the fun of it.definition: just for the entertainment value of doing it
for the fun of it.example: We went on a picnic just for the fun of it

for the good of someone or something.definition: for the benefit, profit, or advantage of someone or something
for the good of someone or something.example: The president said the strict drug laws were for the good of the country

for the life of me.definition: at all; even one little bit. (used with a negative.)
for the life of me.example: For the life of me, I can’t figure this out

for the most part.example: For the most part, the class is enjoying geometry

for the record.definition: so that (one’s own version of ) the facts will be known; for open, public knowledge. (this often is said when there are reporters present.)
for the record.example: I’d like to say—for the record—that at no time have I ever accepted a bribe from anyone

for your information.definition: a phrase that introduces or follows a piece of information. (can be spoken with considerable impatience.)
for your information.example: Mary: What is this one? Sue: For your information, it is exactly the same as the one you just asked about

forage around for something.definition: to search for something, especially something to eat
forage around for something.example: I will go to the kitchen and forage around for some cereal or something

forbidden fruit.definition: someone or something that one finds attractive or desirable partly because having the person or thing is immoral or illegal. (biblical; from the apple in the garden of eden that was forbidden to adam by god.)
forbidden fruit.example: Jim flirts with his sister-in-law only because she’s forbidden fruit

force someone or an animal from somethin.definition: to drive someone or an animal away from something
force someone or an animal from somethin.example: We forced the horses from the corral, putting them back into the pasture

force someone or something down.definition: to press or push someone or something downward
force someone or something down.example: I forced him down and slipped the handcuffs on him

force someone or something off on someo.definition: to make someone take someone or something
force someone or something off on someo.example: I didn’t want it, but she forced it off on me

force someone or something through somet.definition: to push someone or something through an opening
force someone or something through somet.example: First, you must force the others through the opening and then go through yourself

force someone\u2019s hand.definition: to force a person to reveal plans, strategies, or secrets. (alludes to a handful of cards in card playing.)
force someone\u2019s hand.example: We didn’t know what she was doing until Tom forced her hand

force something down.definition: to force oneself to swallow something
force something down.example: I can’t stand sweet potatoes, but I manage to force them down just to keep from making a scene

force something through something.definition: to press or drive something through something that resists
force something through something.example: They forced the bill through the legislature

a force to be reckoned with.definition: someone or something that is important and powerful and must not be ignored
a force to be reckoned with.example: Walter is a force to be reckoned with. Be prepared to deal with him

fore and aft.definition: at the front and the back, usually of a boat or ship
fore and aft.example: They had to attach new lights fore and aft because the old ones were not bright enough to meet the new regulations

foreclose on something.definition: to take the property on which a mortgage is held; to satisfy an unpaid loan by taking ownership of the property put up for security on the loan
foreclose on something.example: If you don’t pay, we will be forced to foreclose on your house

a foregone conclusion.definition: cliché a conclusion already reached; an inevitable result
a foregone conclusion.example: That the company was moving to California was a foregone conclusion

forewarned is forearmed.definition: if you know about something beforehand, you can prepare for it
forewarned is forearmed.example: Before you meet Lily, I should tell you that she’s a little eccentric. Forewarned is forearmed, right?

forget about it.definition: drop the subject!; never mind!; don’t bother me with it
forget about it.example: Jane: Then, there’s this matter of the unpaid bills. Bill: Forget it! You’ll have to pay them all!

forget about someone or something.definition: to put someone or something out of one’s mind

forget one\u2019s manners.example: Jimmy! Have we forgotten our manners?

forget oneself.definition: to forget one’s manners or training. (said in formal situations in reference to belching, bad table manners, and, in the case of very young children, pantswetting.)

forgive and forget.definition: you should not only forgive people for hurting you, you should also forget that they ever hurt you
forgive and forget.example: When my sister lost my favorite book, I was angry at her for weeks, but my mother finally convinced me to forgive and forget

forgive someone for something.example: Please forgive me for being late

fork some money out for something.definition: to pay (perhaps unwillingly) for something. (often mention is made of the amount of money. see the examples.)
fork some money out for something.example: Do you think I’m going to fork twenty dollars out for that book?

fork something out to someone.definition: to serve food to someone, using a fork
fork something out to someone.example: He forked out the chicken to everyone

fork something over to someone.definition: to give something to someone. (usually refers to money.)
fork something over to someone.example: Come on! Fork the money over to me!

form an opinion.definition: to think up or decide on an opinion. (note the variations in the examples.)
form an opinion.example: I don’t know enough about the issue to form an opinion

form and substance.example: The first act of the play was one screaming match after another. It lacked form and substance throughout

form from something.definition: [for something] to develop from something; [for something] to assume a shape, using something else as raw material
form from something.example: Suddenly, an idea began to form from the things that you had said

form someone or something into something.definition: to shape someone or something into something
form someone or something into something.example: We formed the people into a line

form something out of something.example: He formed a tiny elephant out of the clay

form up into something.definition: [for a group of people] to assume the shape of something
form up into something.example: The boys formed up into a jagged line

fortify someone or an animal against som.definition: to strengthen someone or an animal against something with something
fortify someone or an animal against som.example: I’ll need a cup of hot chocolate to fortify me against the storm

forty winks.example: I could use forty winks before I have to get to work

forward something from some place to som.definition: to send something onward to someone from the place it was originally received
forward something from some place to som.example: We forwarded the letter from Chicago to Springfield

foul one\u2019s own nest.definition: to harm one’s own interests; to bring disadvantage upon oneself. (alludes to a bird excreting into its own nest. see also it’s an ill bird that fouls its own nest.)
foul one\u2019s own nest.example: He tried to discredit a fellow senator with the president, but just succeeded in fouling his own nest

foul out of something.definition: [for a basketball player] to be forced out of a game because of having too many fouls
foul out of something.example: The center fouled out in the first fifteen minutes

foul play.example: The police investigating the death suspect foul play

foul someone or something up.definition: to cause disorder and confusion for someone or something; to tangle up someone or something; to mess someone or something up
foul someone or something up.example: Go away! Don’t foul me up any more

foul up.example: Please don’t foul up this time

fouled up.definition: messed up; ruined; tangled up. (usually as fouled-up when attributive.)
fouled up.example: This is sure a fouled-up mess

found money.definition: money that has come to someone with such ease or surprise that one might have just as well found it by accident
found money.example: The money he got from his uncle’s estate is all found money except for the taxes. He did nothing to earn it

found something upon something.definition: to establish something on some kind of basis or justification. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
found something upon something.example: The owners founded this company upon prompt service

fraidy cat.definition: a coward; a person who is frightened of everything. (used in children’s taunts.)
fraidy cat.example: Don’t be a fraidy cat. Go ahead, jump!

frame something in something.definition: to place a frame of something around something
frame something in something.example: Let us frame the photograph in a wood frame rather than a metal one

frame something out.definition: to build the basic wood structure of a building, such as a house
frame something out.example: The carpenters, working fast, framed the whole house out in a day

fraternize with someone or something.definition: to associate with someone or a group; to consort with someone or a group
fraternize with someone or something.example: They were instructed not to fraternize with the opposing team before the game

fraught with danger.definition: cliché [of something] full of something dangerous or unpleasant
fraught with danger.example: The spy’s trip to Russia was fraught with danger

freak out on something.definition: to lose control of one’s mind because of something, usually a drug
freak out on something.example: She freaked out on the stuff she was smoking

freak someone out.example: The whole business freaked me out

freaked out.definition: shocked; disoriented. (sometimes used of the effects of drugs or alcohol.)
freaked out.example: I was too freaked out to reply

free and clear.definition: without encumbrance, particularly in regard to the ownership of something
free and clear.example: After the last payment, Jane owned the car free and clear

free and easy.example: John is so free and easy. How can anyone be so relaxed?

free gift.definition: something extra given to you when you buy something else
free gift.example: When you order your magazine subscription, this book is yours to keep as our free gift

a free hand with someone or something.definition: freedom to exercise complete control over something
a free hand with someone or something.example: I didn’t get a free hand with the last project

free lunch.definition: something of value that is free. (often negative. see also there’s no such thing as a free lunch.)
free lunch.example: There’s always somebody who’ll do anything to get a free lunch

a free ride.definition: a ride to somewhere for which no payment is demanded
a free ride.example: I got a free ride from a truck driver who was headed for town

free someone or something from someone o.definition: to release or unburden someone or something from someone or something
free someone or something from someone o.example: We freed the raccoon from the trap

a freeze on doing something.definition: a policy that put a temporary end to something
a freeze on doing something.example: The company put a freeze on hiring as soon as they took us over

freeze one\u2019s tail off.definition: to freeze; to get very cold
freeze one\u2019s tail off.example: Don’t stand out there in the cold wind! You’ll freeze your tail off!

freeze onto something.definition: [for something] to touch something very cold and freeze hard and fast to it
freeze onto something.example: My hand froze to the railing

freeze over.definition: [for a body of water] to get cold and form a layer of ice on top
freeze over.example: The pond froze over, so we went skating

freeze someone or something in one\u2019.definition: to preserve the image of someone or something in one’s memory
freeze someone or something in one\u2019.example: I tried to freeze her in my memory so I would have her with me always

freeze someone or something to death.definition: [for cold weather] to kill someone or something
freeze someone or something to death.example: I was afraid that the cold snap would freeze the dog to death. 2.  to make someone or something very cold

freeze someone out.definition: to make it too cold for someone, usually by opening windows or through the use of air-conditioning
freeze someone out.example: Turn up the heat unless you’re trying to freeze us out

freeze someone\u2019s wages.definition: to hold someone’s pay at its current level
freeze someone\u2019s wages.example: The company froze everyone’s wages as soon as the economy went sour

freeze something into something.definition: to use cold to solidify something into a different state, usually water into ice
freeze something into something.example: The extreme cold froze the water of the river into solid ice

freeze up.definition: [for something] to freeze and stop functioning
freeze up.example: The joint froze up and wouldn’t move anymore. 2.  [for someone] to become frightened and anxious, and be unable to move, speak, or continue with something

fresh and sweet.example: Now the baby is changed and she is all fresh and sweet. 2.  just out of jail

fresh as a daisy.definition: cliché very fresh; [of a person] always alert and ready to go. (*also: as ~.)
fresh as a daisy.example: How can you be fresh as a daisy so early in the morning?

a fresh start.definition: a new start; an act of starting over
a fresh start.example: After our apologies and a little discussion, we decided to make a fresh start

fresh with someone.definition: overly bold or impertinent with someone
fresh with someone.example: When I tried to kiss Mary, she slapped me and shouted, “Don’t get fresh with me!”

freshen someone or something up.definition: to revive or restore the appearance or vitality of someone or something
freshen someone or something up.example: What can we do to freshen this room up?

freshen up.definition: to get cleaned up, rested up, or restored
freshen up.example: I need a few minutes to freshen up before dinner

fret not.definition: don’t worry!; do not fret about it!
fret not.example: Mary: Oh, look at the clock! I’m going to be late for my appointment! Bob: Fret not! I’ll drive you

a friend in need is a friend indeed.definition: a true friend is a person who will help you when you really need help
a friend in need is a friend indeed.example: When Bill helped me with geometry, I really learned the meaning of “A friend in need is a friend indeed.”

friend or foe.example: I can’t tell whether Jim is friend or foe

frighten someone or an animal into doing.definition: to threaten someone or an animal into doing something
frighten someone or an animal into doing.example: You can’t frighten me into leaving!

fritter something away on someone or som.definition: to waste something, such as money, on someone or something, foolishly
fritter something away on someone or som.example: Did you fritter good money away on that old car?

a frog in one\u2019s throat.definition: a feeling of hoarseness or a lump in one’s throat. (often regarded as a sign of fear. *typically: get ~; have ~.)

from a to z.definition: of a complete and wide variety
from a to z.example: We have just about everything from A to Z

from dawn to dusk.definition: during the period of the day when there is light; from the rising of the sun to the setting of the sun
from dawn to dusk.example: I have to work from dawn to dusk on the farm

from day to day.definition: on a daily basis; one day at a time; occasionally
from day to day.example: We face this kind of problem from day to day

from door to door.definition: moving from one door to another— typically, from one house to another
from door to door.example: The candidate went from door to door, campaigning for town council

from giddyup to whoa.definition: all the way from the beginning to the end
from giddyup to whoa.example: The road is paved from giddy-up to whoa

from hand to hand.definition: from one person to a series of other persons
from hand to hand.example: The book traveled from hand to hand until it got back to its owner

from head to toe.definition: from the top of one’s head to one’s feet
from head to toe.example: She was decked out in f lowers from head to toe

from hell to breakfast.definition: from one end of the earth to the other; all over; everywhere. (use with caution.)

from here till next tuesday.definition: for a great distance; for a long time
from here till next tuesday.example: If you try that again, I’ll knock you from here till next Tuesday

from missouri.definition: requiring proof; needing to be shown something in order to believe it. (from the nickname for the state of missouri, the show me state.)

from overseas.definition: from a location on the other side of the atlantic or pacific ocean, according to the point of view of someone located in the u.s

from pillar to post.definition: from one place to a series of other places; (figuratively) from person to person, as with gossip
from pillar to post.example: My father was in the army, and we moved from pillar to post year after year

from rags to riches.definition: from poverty to wealth; from modesty to elegance
from rags to riches.example: The princess used to be quite poor. She certainly moved from rags to riches

from scratch.definition: [making something] by starting from the beginning with the basic ingredients.  ~.)
from scratch.example: We made the cake from scratch, using no prepared ingredients

from sea to shining sea.definition: from coast to coast. (taken from the lyrics of the song “america the beautiful”.)
from sea to shining sea.example: The new insect pest spread from sea to shining sea in a matter of months

from side to side.definition: moving first to one side and then to the other, repeatedly
from side to side.example: The pendulum of the clock swings from side to side

from start to finish.example: I disliked the whole business from start to finish

from stem to stern.definition: from the front of a boat or ship to the back
from stem to stern.example: He inspected the boat from stem to stern and decided he wanted to buy it. 2.  from one end to another

from the bottom of one\u2019s heart.example: When I returned the lost kitten to Mrs. Brown, she thanked me from the bottom of her heart

from the cradle to the grave.example: The government promised to take care of us from the cradle to the grave

from the gitgo.example: This kind of thing has been a problem from the git-go

from the ground up.example: We must plan our sales campaign carefully from the ground up

from the heart.definition: from a deep and sincere emotional source
from the heart.example: I know that your kind words come from the heart

from the outset.example: I felt from the outset that Lisa was the wrong one for the job

from the sublime to the ridiculous.definition: from something fine and uplifting to something ridiculous or mundane
from the sublime to the ridiculous.example: After Mr. Jones had introduced my wife to his wife, he jokingly turned to introduce me and said, “From the sublime to the ridiculous.”

from the top.definition: from the beginning of something, such as a song or a script
from the top.example: Okay, let’s try it again from the top

from the word go.example: I knew about the problem from the word go

from time to time.definition: irregularly; now and then; occasionally; sometimes; not predictably

from tip to toe.definition: from the top to the bottom
from tip to toe.example: She is wearing all new clothes from tip to toe

from top to bottom.definition: from the highest point to the lowest point; throughout
from top to bottom.example: I have to clean the house from top to bottom today

from way back.definition: from far in the past; from a much earlier time

front for someone or something.definition: to serve as the public contact or public “face” for someone or something
front for someone or something.example: Her publicity agent fronted for her most of the time

front off about something.definition: sl. to be brash and resentful about something
front off about something.example: Todd was fronting off about his assignment and got a detention for it

front on something.definition: [for a building or a piece of land] to face out on something

the frontrunner.definition: the person or thing thought most likely to win or succeed
the frontrunner.example: The press found out some juicy secrets about the front-runner and made them all public

frost over.example: The windows had all frosted over in the night

frosted over.example: The clerk was really frosted over when I asked for a better one

froth something up.definition: to whip or aerate something until it is frothy
froth something up.example: Froth the milk up before you add it to the sauce

froth up.definition: [for something] to build up a froth when whipped, aerated, or boiled
froth up.example: The mixture began to froth up as Dan beat it

frown at someone or something.definition: to scowl at someone or something
frown at someone or something.example: Please don’t frown at me. I didn’t do anything

frown on someone or something.definition: to disapprove of someone or something; to show displeasure or disapproval of someone or something
frown on someone or something.example: The Internal Revenue Service frowns on tax cheaters

the fruits of one\u2019s labors.example: We displayed the fruits of our labor at the county fair

fry something up.example: Let’s fry some chicken up for dinner

fuck you.example: Fuck you! Why did you have to do that?

fudge factor.example: I never use a fudge factor. I measure correctly, and I cut the material exactly the way I measured it

fuel something up.example: I have to fuel this car up before I go any farther

fuel up.definition: to fill one’s tank with fuel
fuel up.example: Let’s stop here and fuel up

full as a tick.definition: very full of food or drink. (alludes to a tick that has filled itself full of blood. see also tight as a tick. *also: as ~.)
full as a tick.example: Little Billy ate and ate until he was as full as a tick

full of holes.definition: [of an argument or plan] that cannot stand up to challenge or scrutiny
full of holes.example: Your argument is full of holes

full of oneself.example: Mary is very unpopular because she’s so full of herself

a full plate.definition: a full schedule; a lot to do
a full plate.example: I’m very busy at work, and I’ve got a full plate at home too

full steam ahead.example: We started moving full steam ahead on the project

full up.example: I ate till I was full up

fulminate against someone or something.example: The workers were fulminating against their employer

fumble for something.definition: to try to grasp awkwardly for something
fumble for something.example: He fumbled for his wallet, hoping Wally would pay the bill

fume at someone.example: She was really fuming at Sam, who had broken her table leg

fun and games.example: All right, Bill, the fun and games are over. It’s time to get down to work

funked out.example: Do you think you can go through life funked out all the time?

funny as a barrel of monkeys.example: Ron was as funny as a barrel of monkeys

funny as a crutch.example: Your trick is about as funny as a crutch. Nobody thought it was funny

funny haha.definition: amusing; comical. (as opposed to funny peculiar.)
funny haha.example: I didn’t mean that Mrs. Peters is funny ha-ha. She’s weird—funny peculiar in fact

funny money.example: The bank teller spotted the funny money in the man’s deposit almost immediately. 2.  temporary or substitute money, good only in certain places

funny peculiar.definition: odd; eccentric. (as opposed to funny haha.)
funny peculiar.example: I didn’t mean that Mrs. Peters is funny ha-ha. She’s weird—funny peculiar in fact

a fur piece.example: It’s a fur piece to the library. You’d best take the bus instead of walking

furnish something for something.definition: to provide something to be used as something
furnish something for something.example: Could you furnish the salad for our picnic?

a furtive glance.definition: a secret or quick glance, quickly averted
a furtive glance.example: He made a furtive glance in the direction of the closet when the robbers asked where the jewelery was hidden

fuse something with something.definition: to bond something together with something
fuse something with something.example: You have to fuse the upper layer to the lower layer with heat

fuse with something.example: The metal has fused with the glass coating on the tank

fuss about someone or something.definition: to complain about someone or something
fuss about someone or something.example: What are you fussing about now?

fuss and feathers.definition: fancy addictions that are overdone or troublesome
fuss and feathers.example: A truly elegant dress doesn’t have a lot of fuss and feathers

fuss around with someone or something.definition: to keep bothering with someone or something; to fiddle with someone or something
fuss around with someone or something.example: Don’t fuss around with it. We’ll have to get a new one

fuss over someone or something.definition: to go to a lot of bother about someone or something
fuss over someone or something.example: My aunt always fusses over me and my sister

futz around.example: Stop futzing around and get the job done

gag on something.definition: to choke on something; to retch on something
gag on something.example: The dog is gagging on whatever you gave her

gain dominion over someone or something.definition: to achieve total authority over someone or something
gain dominion over someone or something.example: The dictator sought to gain dominion over the entire country

gain from something.example: I hope you gain from this experience

gain ground.definition: to make progress; to advance; to become more important or popular

gain in something.definition: to advance in a particular quality
gain in something.example: Todd grew in stature and gained in wisdom

gain on someone or something.definition: to begin to catch up or move ahead of someone or something
gain on someone or something.example: We were gaining on them when they suddenly sped up

gain something from something.definition: to earn or achieve something from something

gallop through something.definition: [for a horse] to pass through something at a gallop

gamble on someone or something.definition: to make a wager on something concerning someone or something
gamble on someone or something.example: I wouldn’t gamble on it happening

gamble something away.definition: to lose all of something by gambling
gamble something away.example: He gambled all his money away

a game that two can play.definition: a manner of competing that two competitors can use; a strategy that competing sides can both use. (said when about to use the same ploy that an opponent has used.)
a game that two can play.example: The mayor shouted at the city council, “Politics is a game that two can play.”

gang up on someone.example: We can’t win against the robber unless we gang up on him

gape at someone or something.definition: to stare at someone or something in wonder

garbage in garbage out.definition: if you give nonsensical instructions to people or computers, those instructions will produce nonsensical results
garbage in garbage out.example: Jill: Why is my computer generating all this gibberish? Jane: You must have made a mistake in the program. Garbage in, garbage out

garnish something with something.definition: to embellish or decorate something, such as food, with something
garnish something with something.example: For the final presentation, I will garnish the dish with a sprig of parsley

gas something up.definition: to put gasoline into a vehicle
gas something up.example: I have to gas this car up soon

gas up.definition: to fill up one’s gasoline tank with gasoline
gas up.example: I have to stop at the next service station and gas up

gasp at someone or something.definition: to inhale sharply in surprise or shock at someone or something
gasp at someone or something.example: I gasped at the sight that lay before me

gasp for air.definition: to fight for a breath of air. (after one has been deprived of air.)

gasp for breath.definition: to labor for one’s breath. (usually because of physical exertion.)
gasp for breath.example: She ran and ran until she was gasping for breath

gasp something out.example: She gasped the words out haltingly

gassed up.example: Fred is gassed up and very wobbly

gather around someone or something.definition: to collect around someone or something

gather dust.definition: [for something] to sit unused for a long time

gather someone or something around onese.definition: to collect people or things around oneself; to draw someone or something to oneself

gather someone or something to oneself.definition: to draw someone or something to oneself
gather someone or something to oneself.example: The hen gathered her chicks to herself

gather someone or something together.definition: to assemble people or things together in one place

gather something from someone.example: I will gather the papers from Wally, and you go get those that Ted is working on

get the shaft.definition: sl. to be cheated; to be taken advantage of; to be mistreated
get the shaft.example: Why do I get the shaft when I did nothing wrong?

get the word.definition: to receive an explanation; to receive the final and authoritative explanation
get the word.example: I’m sorry, I didn’t get the word. I didn’t know the matter had been settled

get the wrinkles out of something.definition: to remove the wrinkles from fabric by ironing or flattening in some way
get the wrinkles out of something.example: This has been packed in my suitcase for a week, and I know I’ll never be able to get the wrinkles out of it. 2.  to eliminate some initial, minor problems with an invention, a procedure, a computer program, or a mechanical device

get through something.example: We couldn’t get through the hard concrete with a drill, so we will have to blast

get through to someone.definition: to reach someone; to manage to communicate to someone
get through to someone.example: I called her on the telephone time after time, but I couldn’t get through to her

get through to something.definition: to make contact by radio or telephone with a company, organization, or group
get through to something.example: I could not get through to the police because the telephone line was down

get through with someone or something.definition: to manage to transport someone or something through difficulties or barriers
get through with someone or something.example: Customs was a mess, but we got through with all our baggage in only twenty minutes

get to one\u2019s feet.example: On a signal from the teacher, the students got to their feet

get to the bottom of something.definition: to get an understanding of the causes of something
get to the bottom of something.example: We must get to the bottom of this problem immediately

get to the point of something.definition: to arrive at a discussion or explanation of the purpose of something
get to the point of something.example: Please get to the point of all this

get to the top of something.definition: to get to the highest point of something
get to the top of something.example: We finally got to the top of the mountain and planted the f lag

get tough with someone.definition: to become firm with someone; to use physical force against someone
get tough with someone.example: The teacher had to get tough with the class because the students were acting badly

get under someone\u2019s skin.example: John is so annoying. He really gets under my skin

get under something.example: The cat came in and got under the sofa where she couldn’t be seen

get up.definition: to wake up and get out of bed
get up.example: What time do you usually get up?

get up a full head of steam.definition: [for a steam engine] to build steam pressure in order to start operating
get up a full head of steam.example: It took nearly thirty minutes to get up a full head of steam so that the locomotive could start moving. 2.  to develop sufficient energy, enthusiasm, commitment, or determination to undertake something

get up against someone or something.definition: to press close against someone or something
get up against someone or something.example: I got up against the wall, out of the way

get up an appetite.definition: to do something to make one very hungry. (usually in this order.)
get up an appetite.example: He can’t seem to get up an appetite these days

get up from something.definition: to go to a standing position from a lower position
get up from something.example: She got up from the chair and walked to the door

get up off of something.definition: to rise up and get off something. (of is usually retained before pronouns.)
get up off of something.example: Please get up off the sofa. I have to turn the cushions over

get up on one\u2019s hind legs.definition: to get angry and assertive. (alludes to the action of a horse when it is excited or frightened.)
get up on one\u2019s hind legs.example: She got up on her hind legs and told them all to go to blazes

get up something.example: I was so tired I couldn’t get up the stairs

get up to something.definition: to climb up to something, at a certain height or level
get up to something.example: We finally got up to the top

get well.example: Ann had a cold for a week, and then she got well

get wet.definition: to become moist or soaked with water
get wet.example: Get out of the rain or you’ll get wet

get with it.definition: to modernize one’s attitudes and behavior
get with it.example: Get with it, Martin. Go out and buy some new clothes!

get with the program.definition: follow the rules; do what you are supposed to do. (implies that there is a clearly known method or “program” that is usually followed.)
get with the program.example: Come on, Mark. Get with the program. Do what you are told

get your head out of the clouds.example: Get your head out of the clouds and watch where you are driving! You’re going to kill us all

a ghost of a chance.example: She can’t do it. She doesn’t have a ghost of a chance

giggle at someone or something.definition: to snicker or chuckle at someone or something

gild the lily.definition: to add ornament or decoration to something that is pleasing in its original state; to attempt to improve something that is already fine the way it is. (often refers to flattery or exaggeration.)
gild the lily.example: Your house has lovely brickwork. Don’t paint it. That would be gilding the lily

gird up one\u2019s loins.definition: to get ready, especially for hard work; to prepare oneself (for something)
gird up one\u2019s loins.example: Well, I guess I had better gird up my loins and go to work

give a good account of oneself.example: John gave a good account of himself when he gave his speech last night

give a little.definition: to give a small amount of something, probably money
give a little.example: If everyone will just give a little, we can have enough money to provide a nice Thanksgiving dinner for the needy. 2.  to move a slight amount

give as good as one gets.definition: to give as much as one receives; to pay someone back in kind. (usually in the present tense.)
give as good as one gets.example: John can take care of himself in a fight. He can give as good as he gets

give birth to someone or something.definition: to have a child; [for an animal] to bring forth young
give birth to someone or something.example: She gave birth to a baby girl

give cause for something.definition: to serve as a just cause for something; to warrant something
give cause for something.example: Your comments give cause for further investigation

give chase to someone or something.example: The dogs gave chase to the fox

give credence to someone or something.definition: to consider someone or something as believable or trustworthy
give credence to someone or something.example: How can you give credence to a person like Henry?

give credit where credit is due.example: Jill: Jane, that was a wonderful meal. Jane: I must give credit where credit is due; Alan helped with all of the cooking

give currency to something.definition: to spread a story around. (with a negative if there is doubt about what is said.)
give currency to something.example: I can’t give any currency to anything Ralph Jones says

give evidence of something.definition: to show signs of something; to give proof of something
give evidence of something.example: You are going to have to give evidence of your good faith in this matter. A nominal deposit would be fine

give ground.definition: to retreat, yielding land or territory
give ground.example: I approached the barking dog, but it wouldn’t give ground. 2.  to “retreat” from an idea or assertion that one has made

give in.example: The rotting door gave in when we pushed, and we went inside

give in to someone or something.definition: to yield to someone or something; to give up to someone or something
give in to someone or something.example: He argued and argued and finally gave in to my demands

give it a rest.definition: stop talking so much. give your mouth a rest. (familiar or rude. compare this with give me a rest!)
give it a rest.example: Mary: So, I really think we need to discuss things more and go over all our differences in detail. Bill: Stop! I’ve heard enough. Give it a rest! Mary: Oh, am I disturbing you?

give it all you\u2019ve got.example: Go out there and try. Give it all you’ve got!

give it time.definition: be patient.; in time, things will change. (usually said to encourage someone to wait or be patient.)
give it time.example: Things will get better. Don’t worry. Give it time

give it to someone straight.definition: to tell something to someone clearly and directly
give it to someone straight.example: Come on, give it to me straight. I want to know exactly what happened

give it up.definition: stop trying!; you are wasting your time! (fixed order.)
give it up.example: Bob: I just can’t understand calculus! Bill: Give it up! Get out of that course and get into something less cruel

give me a chance.definition: please give me an opportunity to do something!
give me a chance.example: Mary: I just know I can do it. Oh, please give me a chance! Sue: All right. Just one more chance

give me a rest.definition: stop being such a pest!; stop bothering me with this problem! (compare this with give it a rest!)
give me a rest.example: “Go away and stop bothering me!” moaned Bob. “Give me a rest!”

give of oneself.definition: to be generous with one’s time and concern
give of oneself.example: Tom is very good with children because he gives of himself

give one one\u2019s freedom.definition: to set someone free; to divorce someone
give one one\u2019s freedom.example: Mrs. Brown wanted to give her husband his freedom

give one\u2019s notice.definition: to formally tell one’s employer that one is quitting one’s job
give one\u2019s notice.example: Did you hear that James is leaving? He gave his notice yesterday

give oneself over to someone or somethin.definition: to surrender to someone or something
give oneself over to someone or somethin.example: He went to the station and gave himself over to the police

give oneself up to someone or something.definition: to surrender to someone or something
give oneself up to someone or something.example: Fran gave herself up to the disease

give out.definition: to wear out and stop; to quit operating
give out.example: My old bicycle finally gave out

give rise to something.definition: to cause something; to instigate something
give rise to something.example: The attack gave rise to endless arguments

give some thought to something.definition: to think about something; to devote some time to thinking about something
give some thought to something.example: After I have had time to give some thought to the matter, I will call you

give someone a dig.definition: sl. to insult someone; to say something which will irritate a person
give someone a dig.example: Jane gave Bob a dig about his carelessness with money

give someone a good bawling out.definition: to bawl someone out; to chastise someone
give someone a good bawling out.example: When the teacher caught Billie, he gave him a good bawling out

give someone a pain.example: Please don’t give me a pain. I’ve had a hard day

give someone a piece of one\u2019s mind.definition: to bawl someone out; to tell someone off
give someone a piece of one\u2019s mind.example: I’ve had enough from John. I’m going to give him a piece of my mind

give someone a red face.example: We really gave him a red face when we caught him eavesdropping

give someone away to someone.definition: [for the bride’s father] to give the bride away to the groom. (customarily done just prior to the actual marriage ceremony.)
give someone away to someone.example: Mr. Franklin gave Amy away to Terry just as he had done in the rehearsal

give someone enough rope and he\u2019ll.definition: if you give someone that you suspect of bad behavior the freedom to behave badly, eventually he or she will be caught and punished
give someone enough rope and he\u2019ll.example: Jill: I think Matilda’s been stealing things out of my desk. Should I tell the boss? Jane: No; give her enough rope and she’ll hang herself. One of these days she’ll steal something important, the boss will find out for himself, and he’ll fire her

give someone hail columbia.example: The teacher gave her students Hail Columbia over their poor test scores

give someone odds that.definition: to propose a sham bet to someone, the implication being that even at favorable odds the outcome will defy the odds. (often with a negative.)
give someone odds that.example: I’ll give you odds that you won’t be able to order a decent steak at this restaurant

give someone or something a wide berth.definition: to keep a reasonable distance from someone or something; to steer clear (of someone or something). (originally referred to sailing ships.)
give someone or something a wide berth.example: The dog we are approaching is very mean. Better give it a wide berth

give someone or something away.definition: to reveal a secret about someone or something
give someone or something away.example: I thought no one knew where I was, but my loud breathing gave me away

give someone or something back to someon.definition: to return someone or something to someone or something
give someone or something back to someon.example: Please give it back to me

give someone or something up for lost.definition: to abandon someone or something as being lost; to quit looking for someone or something that is lost
give someone or something up for lost.example: After a week we had given the cat up for lost when suddenly she appeared

give someone or something up to someone.definition: to hand someone or something over to someone; to relinquish claims on someone or something in favor of someone else
give someone or something up to someone.example: We had to give the money we found up to the police

give someone pause for thought.definition: to cause someone to stop and think
give someone pause for thought.example: When I see a golden sunrise, it gives me pause for thought

give someone some lip.definition: to speak rudely or disrespectfully to someone; to sass someone
give someone some lip.example: Billy gave me some lip, so I whupped him

give someone some skin.definition: sl. [for two people] to touch two hands together in a special greeting, like a handshake. (one hand may be slapped down on top of the other, or they may be slapped together palm to palm with the arms held vertically. usually said as a command.)
give someone some skin.example: Hey, Bob, give me some skin!

give someone some sugar.example: Come here, honey, and give me some sugar

give someone static.definition: to argue with someone; to give someone back talk
give someone static.example: I want you to do it and do it now! Don’t give me any static!

give someone the eye.definition: to look at someone in a way that communicates romantic interest
give someone the eye.example: Ann gave John the eye. It really surprised him

give someone the finger.definition: to display the middle finger upright as a sign of derision. (the gesture is derisive and offensive. see also flip someone off, flip someone the bird.)
give someone the finger.example: Did one of you guys give Ted the finger?

give someone the gate.definition: sl. to get rid of someone
give someone the gate.example: The chick was a pest, so I gave her the gate

give someone the goby.definition: to bypass someone; to ignore someone
give someone the goby.example: Gert gave us all the go-by when she took up with that rich boyfriend

give someone the raspberry.definition: to make a rude noise with the lips at someone
give someone the raspberry.example: The audience gave him the raspberry, which gave him some second thoughts about his choice of career

give someone the shaft.definition: sl. to cheat or deceive someone; to mistreat someone
give someone the shaft.example: The boss really gave Wally the shaft

give someone the shirt off one\u2019s ba.definition: to give anything that is asked for, no matter the sacrifice required
give someone the shirt off one\u2019s ba.example: Tom would give any of his old army buddies the shirt off his back

give someone the slip.definition: sl. to escape from a pursuer
give someone the slip.example: We were on his tail until he gave us the slip

give someone tit for tat.definition: to give someone something equal to what was given you; to exchange a series of very similar things, one by one, with someone
give someone tit for tat.example: They gave me the same kind of difficulty that I gave them. They gave me tit for tat

give someone to understand something.definition: to explain something to someone; to imply something to someone. (possibly misleading someone, accidentally or intentionally. see also given to understand.)
give someone to understand something.example: Mr. Smith gave Sally to understand that she should be home by midnight

give someone up for dead.definition: to give up hope for someone who is dying; to abandon a dying person as already dead
give someone up for dead.example: The cowboys gave up their comrade for dead and rode off

give something away to someone.definition: to donate to, or bestow something upon, someone
give something away to someone.example: I gave the old clothing away to Tom

give something back to someone with inte.definition: to return money to someone with an additional amount for interest
give something back to someone with inte.example: You are going to have to give that money back to me with interest

give something for something.example: I will give two brownies for that piece of cake in your lunch box

give something off.definition: to release something, such as smoke, a noise, an odor, fragrance, etc
give something off.example: The little animal gave a foul smell off

give something out.definition: to distribute something; to pass something out
give something out.example: The teacher gave the test papers out

give something over to someone or someth.definition: to hand something over to someone or something
give something over to someone or someth.example: Please give the money over to Sherri, who handles the accounts

give something to someone.definition: to bestow something, such as a gift, on someone
give something to someone.example: Please give this to Sally Wilson

give something under the threat of somet.definition: to give something only because one is threatened
give something under the threat of somet.example: He gave the money under threat of exposure. I think that is blackmail

give something up.definition: to forsake something; to stop using or eating something
give something up.example: I gave coffee up because of the caffeine

give the game away.definition: to reveal a plan or strategy
give the game away.example: Now, all of you have to keep quiet. Please don’t give the game away

give the lie to something.definition: to show that something is a lie
give the lie to something.example: The evidence gives the lie to your testimony

give up.example: I give up! I won’t press this further

give up all hope.definition: to stop hoping for something. (fixed order.)
give up all hope.example: Don’t give up hope. There’s always a chance

give up on someone or something.definition: to give up trying to do something with someone or something, such as being friendly, giving advice, managing, etc
give up on someone or something.example: I gave up on jogging. My knees went bad

give up the ghost.definition: euph. to die. (fixed order. often used to describe machines breaking down.)
give up the ghost.example: The old man gave up the ghost

give us the tools and we will finish the.definition: a reply to someone who wants you to do a task for which you lack the equipment
give us the tools and we will finish the.example: How am I supposed to wash the upstairs windows without a ladder? Give us the tools, and we will finish the job!

give vent to something.definition: to express anger. (the something is usually anger, ire, irritation, etc.)
give vent to something.example: John gave vent to his anger by yelling at Sally

give voice to something.definition: to express a feeling or an opinion in words; to speak out about something
give voice to something.example: The bird gave voice to its joy in the golden sunshine

give way to someone or something.definition: to yield to someone or something; to give preference to someone or something
give way to someone or something.example: The cars gave way to the pedestrians

give weight to something.example: I give a lot of weight to your opinion

give with something.definition: to give something to someone; to tell something to someone
give with something.example: Come on! Give with the money!

given to doing something.definition: likely to do something; inclined to do something habitually
given to doing something.example: Mary is given to singing in the shower

given to understand.example: They were given to understand that there would be no tax increase, but after the election taxes went up

the glad hand.definition: an overly friendly welcome; a symbol of insincere attention
the glad hand.example: Whenever I go into that store, I get the glad hand

glance around some place.definition: to look quickly around some place
glance around some place.example: He glanced around the room, looking for his favorite cap

glance at someone or something.definition: to look quickly at someone or something
glance at someone or something.example: Sharon glanced at Todd to see if he looked as if he was ready to go

glance back at someone.definition: to look quickly at someone who is looking at you
glance back at someone.example: He glanced back at Mary, so he could remember her smile

glance down at something.definition: to look quickly downward at something
glance down at something.example: Sherri glanced down at her watch and then pressed on the accelerator

glance off someone or something.definition: to bounce off someone or something
glance off someone or something.example: The bullet glanced off the huge boulder

glance over someone or something.definition: to examine someone or something very quickly
glance over someone or something.example: I only glanced over the papers. They look okay to me

glance through something.definition: to look quickly at the contents of something
glance through something.example: I glanced through the manuscript, and I don’t think it is ready yet

glare at someone or something.definition: to scowl at someone or something

glare down on someone or something.definition: [for someone] to scowl down at someone or something
glare down on someone or something.example: The judge glared down on the accused

glass something in.definition: to enclose something, such as a porch, in glass
glass something in.example: I want to glass this porch in, so we can use it in the winter

glaze over.definition: [for something] to be covered over with a coat of something cloudy or ice
glaze over.example: The roads glazed over and became very dangerous

gleam with something.definition: to sparkle or shine with something
gleam with something.example: The crystal goblets gleamed with the sparkling candlelight

glide across something.definition: to float or slide across something
glide across something.example: The skaters glided across the frozen expanse of the river

glide away from someone or something.definition: to slide or float away from someone or something
glide away from someone or something.example: The skaters glided away from the center of the rink

glint with something.definition: to sparkle or shine with something
glint with something.example: Her bright eyes glinted with the sunlight

glisten with something.definition: to sparkle or shimmer with something
glisten with something.example: The trees glistened with a thin coating of ice from the freezing rain

glitter with something.example: Her earrings glittered with many tiny diamonds

gloat over something.definition: to rejoice smugly over something; to be glad that something unfortunate has happened to someone else
gloat over something.example: He gloated over his good luck in a way that made all of us angry

glory be.definition: an exclamation expressing surprise or shock. (a bit old-fashioned.)
glory be.example: Mary: Glory be! Is that what I think it is? Sue: Well, it’s a kitten, if that’s what you thought

glory in something.definition: to take great pleasure in something; to revel in something
glory in something.example: He just glories in all the attention he is getting

gloss over something.definition: to cover up, minimize, or play down something bad
gloss over something.example: Don’t gloss over your own role in this fiasco!

the gloves are off.definition: there is going to be a serious dispute. (as if boxers had removed their gloves in order to inflict more damage. see also take the gloves off.)
the gloves are off.example: Bob got mad and yelled, “Ok, the gloves are off!” and started cussing and pounding the table

glow with something.definition: [for something] to put out light, usually because of high heat
glow with something.example: The embers glowed with the remains of the fire

glower at someone or something.definition: to scowl intently at someone or something
glower at someone or something.example: The judge glowered at the irate wit- ness until order was restored

glue something down.definition: to fix something down onto something with cement
glue something down.example: Glue the edge of the rug down before someone trips over it

glue something together.definition: to attach the pieces of something together with glue
glue something together.example: She glued the pieces of the model plane together

glued to someone or something.definition: following someone everywhere; very close to or touching something
glued to someone or something.example: His little sister was glued to him all afternoon. Finally he sent her home

glut someone or something with something.definition: to overfill someone or something with something
glut someone or something with something.example: The hungry lions glutted themselves with the meat of their recent kill

a glutton for punishment.definition: someone who is eager for a burden or some sort of difficulty; someone willing to accept a difficult task
a glutton for punishment.example: Tom works too hard. He is a glutton for punishment

gnash one\u2019s teeth.definition: to grind or bite noisily with one’s teeth
gnash one\u2019s teeth.example: Bill clenched his fists and gnashed his teeth in anger

a gnashing of teeth.definition: a show of anger or dismay. (biblical: “weeping, wailing, and gnashing of teeth.”)
a gnashing of teeth.example: After a little gnashing of teeth and a few threats, the boss calmed down and become almost reasonable

gnaw away at someone.definition: to worry someone; to create constant anxiety in someone
gnaw away at someone.example: The thought of catching some horrible disease gnawed away at her

gnaw away at someone or something.definition: to chew at someone or something
gnaw away at someone or something.example: I hear a mouse gnawing away at the wall

gnaw on something.definition: to chew on something. (usually said of an animal.)
gnaw on something.example: The puppy has been gnawing on my slippers!

go about something.definition: to approach the doing of something in a particular way
go about something.example: How should I go about researching this topic?

go above someone or something.definition: to travel over someone or something
go above someone or something.example: The model airplane swooped low right at us but went above us at the last minute

go across something.definition: to cross something, such as water, a bridge, land, the ocean, etc
go across something.example: We went across the ocean in just three hours

go across something to someone or someth.definition: to cross something to someone, something, or some place on the other side
go across something to someone or someth.example: We went across the bridge to the island

go after someone.definition: to investigate someone or something for possible criminal prosecution
go after someone.example: The prosecutor went after Max first, knowing that Max was the gang leader

go after someone something or an animal.definition: to pursue someone, something, or an animal
go after someone something or an animal.example: The dogs went after the burglar

go ahead.definition: please do it.; you have my permission and encouragement to do it
go ahead.example: Alice: I’m leaving. John: Go ahead. See if I care

go ahead make my day.definition: just try to do me harm or disobey me. i will enjoy punishing you. (from a phrase said in a movie where the person saying the phrase is holding a gun on a villain and would really like the villain to do something that would justify firing the gun. compare this with keep it up!)
go ahead make my day.example: The crook reached into his jacket for his wallet. The cop, thinking the crook was about to draw a gun, said, “Go ahead, make my day!”

go ahead of someone or something.definition: to get in front of and proceed someone or something
go ahead of someone or something.example: Please let me go ahead of you

go ahead with something.definition: to continue with something; to continue with plans to do something
go ahead with something.example: Can we go ahead with our party plans?

go all out for someone or something.definition: to do everything possible for someone or something
go all out for someone or something.example: We went all out for George and threw a big party on his return

go along.example: Things are going along quite nicely in my new job

go along with someone for the ride.definition: to accompany someone just to be taking a ride
go along with someone for the ride.example: Why don’t you go along with us for the ride?

go along with someone or something.definition: to travel along with someone or something
go along with someone or something.example: Dorothy went along with the scarecrow for a while until they met a lion. 2.  to agree with someone or agree to something

go ape over someone or something.definition: sl. to become very excited over something
go ape over someone or something.example: I just go ape over chocolate

go around doing something.example: She keeps going around telling lies about me

go around in circles.definition: to move over and over on a circular path
go around in circles.example: The model plane went around in circles until it ran out of fuel

go around someone.definition: to walk or travel in such a way as to avoid hitting or touching someone
go around someone.example: I can’t move from this place right now. You’ll have to go around me. 2. Idiomatic to avoid dealing with someone

go astray.definition: to wander off the road or path
go astray.example: Stick to the path and try not to go astray

go at one another tooth and nail.definition: to fight one another like animals. (one another can also be each other.)
go at one another tooth and nail.example: The man and his wife went at one another tooth and nail

go at someone or something.definition: to attack someone or something; to move or lunge toward someone or something
go at someone or something.example: The dog went at the visitor and almost bit him

go at something like a boy killing snake.definition: to do something with a great deal of energy
go at something like a boy killing snake.example: Once Mary decided to take that test, she went at her books like a boy killing snakes

go away.definition: leave me!; get away from me!
go away.example: Mary: You’re such a pest, Sue. Go away! Sue: I was just trying to help

go away emptyhanded.example: I hate for you to go away empty-handed, but I cannot afford to contribute any money

go away for something.definition: to leave for a period of time
go away for something.example: I have to go away for a week or two

go away with someone or something.definition: to leave in the company of someone or something
go away with someone or something.example: I saw him go away with Margie

go awol.definition: to become absent without leave. (originally military.)
go awol.example: Private Smith went AWOL last Wednesday. Now he’s in a military prison

go back.definition: to return to the place of origin
go back.example: That’s where I came from, and I’ll never go back

go back to someone or something.definition: to return to someone, something, or some place
go back to someone or something.example: She went back to her husband after a few months

go back to square one.definition: to return to the starting point. (alludes to the squares of a board game.)
go back to square one.example: It’s back to square one. We have to start over

go back to the drawing board.definition: to return to the planning stage, so that a failed project can be planned again
go back to the drawing board.example: These plans have to go back to the drawing board

go back to the salt mines.definition: to return to one’s work. (jocular; fig. on the image of menial labor working in salt mines.)
go back to the salt mines.example: It’s late. I have to go back to the salt mines

go bad.definition: to become rotten, undesirable, evil, etc
go bad.example: I’m afraid that this milk has gone bad

go badly with someone or something.definition: [for something] to proceed badly for someone or something
go badly with someone or something.example: I hope that things are not still going badly with you

go bananas.example: Sorry, I just went bananas for a minute

go before someone or something.example: Do you wish to go before me?

go begging.definition: to be left over, unwanted, or unused. (as if a thing were begging for an owner or a user.)
go begging.example: There is still food left. A whole lobster is going begging. Please eat some more

go behind someone\u2019s back.definition: to move behind someone; to locate oneself at someone’s back

go below.definition: to go beneath the main deck of a ship. (nautical.)

go berserk.example: She went berserk and strangled her cat

go between someone or something and some.definition: to get in between people or things, in any combination
go between someone or something and some.example: The dog went between Mr. Franklin and the wall

go beyond someone or something.definition: to pass ahead of someone or something
go beyond someone or something.example: I went beyond the place where I should have turned off

go beyond something.definition: to do more of something than the expected amount; to go further with something than was required
go beyond something.example: You clearly went beyond what was required of you

go broke.definition: to completely run out of money and other assets

go by someone or something.definition: to pass by someone or something

go down in flames.example: The enemy fighter planes went down in f lames, ending the battle

go down in history as someone or somethi.definition: to be recorded for history as a significant person or event

go down something.definition: to descend something; to fall down something

go down to something.definition: [for something] to decline or diminish to some level

go down with something.definition: to be stricken with a disease

go downhill.definition: [for something] to decline and grow worse and worse

go easy on someone or something.definition: to be gentle on someone or something; not to be too critical of someone or something; to take it easy on someone or something

go for it.definition: go ahead! give it a good try!

go for nothing.definition: [for something] to be done for no purpose

go forward with something.definition: to continue with something; to do something that is planned

go from bad to worse.definition: to progress from a bad situation to one that is worse

go from one extreme to the other.definition: to change from one thing to its opposite

go home to mama.definition: to give up something—such as a marriage— and return to one’s mother’s home

go hungry.definition: to miss a meal and end up hungry

go in and out of something.definition: to pass in and out of something or some place

go in one ear and out the other.definition: cliché  [for something] to be heard and then soon ignored or forgotten

go in with someone on something.definition: to join together with someone to work on a project; to pool financial resources with someone to buy something

go into orbit.definition: [for a rocket, satellite, etc.] to rotate around a heavenly body in a fixed path

go into service.example: When will the new elevator go into service?

go into the service.definition: to enter one of the military services

go it alone.example: Do you need help, or will you go it alone?

go like clockwork.definition: to progress with regularity and dependability

go near to someone or something.example: Don’t go near Sue. She’s got chicken pox

go off by oneself.definition: to go into seclusion; to isolate oneself
go off by oneself.example: She went off by herself where no one could find her

go off halfcocked.definition: to go into action too early or without thinking. (originally refers to a flintlock or matchlock gun firing prematurely, before the trigger was pulled.)

go off into something.definition: to go away to something; to depart and go into something

go on a binge.definition: to do too much of something, especially to drink too much

go on and on.definition: to (seem to) last or go forever

go on the block.definition: [for something] to go up for auction; [for something] to be placed on the auction block

go on tour.definition: [for a performing group] to go from place to place, performing

go out of service.definition: [for something] to stop working; [for something] to have been turned off so it cannot be used

go over.definition: euph. to leave one’s country and go to ideologically opposed or enemy country; to defect

go over someone or something.example: The doctor will go over you very carefully, I’m sure

go over to some place.definition: to travel some distance or cross water to get to some place

go over with a bang.definition: [for something] to be funny or entertaining
go over with a bang.example: Our presentation was a success. It really went over with a bang

go overboard.definition: to fall out of a boat or off of a ship; to fall overboard

go past someone or something.definition: to pass by someone or something
go past someone or something.example: You went right past Tom. Did you mean to?

go skyhigh.example: Prices go sky-high whenever there is inf lation

go so far as to say something.definition: to put something into words; to risk saying something

go through someone or something.definition: [for something sharp] to penetrate someone or something

go to bat against someone.definition: to aid someone against someone else

go to press.definition: [for a publication] to be sent to the printing presses

go to the limit.definition: to do as much as is possible to do

go to town.definition: to travel into town or a city

go to trial.definition: [for a case] to go into court to be tried

go to war over someone or something.definition: to wage a war over someone or something. (often an exaggeration.)

go to waste.definition: [for something] to be wasted; to be unused (and therefore thrown away)

go to work on someone or something.definition: to begin working on someone or something

go toward someone or something.definition: to move toward someone or something

go under the name of something.definition: [for someone or something] to be known under a particular name

go under the wrecking ball.definition: to be wrecked or torn down

go up.example: Gasoline prices are still going up

go up against someone.definition: to compete with someone; to face someone in competition
go up against someone.example: She is going up against Rodney in the spelling bee

go up something.example: The monkey went up the tree in no time

go up the wall.definition: to climb or run up the wall

go windowshopping.example: The office workers go window-shopping on their lunch hour, looking for things to buy when they get paid

go without someone or something.definition: to manage without a particular type of person or thing

goad someone into something.definition: to urge or coerce someone into doing something

god only knows.definition: only god knows.; no one knows but god

god rest someone\u2019s soul.definition: may god bless a previously mentioned person who has died

god\u2019s gift to women.definition: a desirable or perfect man. (usually sarcastic.)

god takes soonest those he loveth best.example: The minister told the boy’s grieving parents that God takes soonest those he loveth best

god willing.example: John: Please try to be on time. Alice: I’ll be there on time, God willing

god\u2019s in his heaven all\u2019s righ.example: Now that my wife has returned from her long trip, God’s in his heaven; all’s right with the world

the gods send nuts to those who have no.definition: people often get good fortune that is no use to them
the gods send nuts to those who have no.example: Soon after Melissa lost her hearing, she won season tickets to the symphony. The gods send nuts to those who have no teeth

goggle at someone or something.definition: to stare at someone or something with bulging eyes
goggle at someone or something.example: Don’t stand there goggling at me!

going going gone.definition: [in an auction] close to being sold, almost sold, sold
going going gone.example: Going, going, gone. The new owner is the handsome gentleman in the back row. 2.  disappearing and finally gone

going great guns.example: I’m over my cold and going great guns

the going rate.definition: the current rate or the current charges for something
the going rate.example: The going interest rate for your account is 10 percent

going strong.example: We are still well and going strong

a gold mine of information.definition: someone or something that is full of information

a golden key can open any door.example: Jill: I’m amazed that Sally got into a good university; her grades were so poor. Jane: Well, she comes from a wealthy family, and a golden key can open any door

a golden opportunity.definition: an excellent opportunity that is not likely to be repeated

gone but not forgotten.definition: cliché gone or dead and still remembered

gone goose.definition: someone or something that has departed or run away

gone to meet one\u2019s maker.example: Poor old Bob has gone to meet his maker

gone with the wind.definition: gone as if taken away by the wind. (a phrase made famous by the margaret mitchell novel and subsequent film gone with the wind. the phrase is used to make gone have a stronger force.)
gone with the wind.example: Everything we worked for was gone with the wind

good afternoon.definition: the appropriate greeting for use between noon and supper time

good and something.definition: very or completely something. (something is a state of being.)

good as new.example: A little rest and I’ll be as good as new

a good bet.example: It’s a good bet that he will be late because of the rain

the good book.example: I read some in the Good Book every day

the good die young.definition: good people tend to die at an early age

a good egg.example: He seems like a good egg. I’ll take a chance on him

good enough.example: Bill: Well, now. How’s that? Bob: Good enough

half under.example: I was half under and could hear what the doctor was saying

hit the broad side of a barn.definition: to hit an easy target. (usually negative.)

hit the bull\u2019seye.definition: to hit the very center of a circular target
hit the bull\u2019seye.example: The archer hit the bull’s-eye three times in a row

hit the deck.definition: to fall down; to drop down to the floor or ground
hit the deck.example: Hit the deck. Don’t let them see you

hit the fan.definition: to become publicly known; to become a scandal. (from the phrase when the shit hit the fan.)
hit the fan.example: I wasn’t even in the country when it hit the fan

hit the ground running.definition: to start the day very energetically
hit the ground running.example: A decade ago I had a lot more energy. I would wake up, hit the ground running, and never stop until I went to bed again

hit the high spots.definition: to do only the important, obvious, or good things
hit the high spots.example: I won’t discuss the entire report. I’ll just hit the high spots

hit the jackpot.definition: to win a large amount of money gambling or in a lottery
hit the jackpot.example: I hit the jackpot in the big contest

hit the nail right on the head.definition: to strike a nail precisely on the head with a hammer
hit the nail right on the head.example: If you expect to drive a nail straight, you have to hit the nail on the head. 2.  to do exactly the right thing; to do something in the most effective and efficient way

hit the road.definition: to depart; to begin one’s journey, especially on a road trip; to leave for home
hit the road.example: It’s time to hit the road. I’ll see you

hit the skids.definition: to decline; to decrease in value or status
hit the skids.example: Jed hit the skids when he started drinking

hit the spot.definition: to be exactly right; to be refreshing
hit the spot.example: This cool drink really hits the spot

hit the trail.definition: to leave. (as if one were hiking or riding a horse.)
hit the trail.example: I have to hit the trail before sunset

hit town.example: The minute he hit town, he checked into a hotel and took a long nap

hit upon someone or something.definition: to strike or pound on someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
hit upon someone or something.example: Jeff hit upon the mugger over and over

hitch someone or something up to somethi.definition: to attach someone or something to something
hitch someone or something up to somethi.example: Please hitch the horse up to the wagon, and let’s get going

hitch your wagon to a star.definition: always aspire to do great things.; do not set pessimistic goals. (from ralph waldo emerson’s essay, “civilization.”)
hitch your wagon to a star.example: The speaker who delivered the high school commencement address challenged the graduating students to hitch their wagons to a star

a hive of activity.definition: a location where things are very busy
a hive of activity.example: The hotel lobby was a hive of activity each morning

hoard something up.definition: to accumulate a large store of something against bad times
hoard something up.example: Scott was hoarding canned goods up for the hard times ahead

hoarse as a crow.example: After shouting at the team all afternoon, the coach was as hoarse as a crow

hobnob with someone or something.definition: to associate with someone or a group, especially with those more wealthy, famous, etc
hobnob with someone or something.example: I’m not used to hobnobbing with such luminaries

hobson\u2019s choice.definition: the choice between taking what is offered and getting nothing at all. (from the name of a stable owner in the seventeenth century who always hired out the horse nearest the door.)
hobson\u2019s choice.example: We didn’t really want that particular hotel, but it was a case of Hobson’s choice. We booked very late and there was nothing else left

hoe one\u2019s own row.example: Tom: You’re cutting up those carrots awful small. Jane: Hoe your own row!

hog wild.example: I went hog wild at the sale and bought six new pairs of shoes

hoist with one\u2019s own petard.definition: to be harmed or disadvantaged by an action of one’s own which was meant to harm someone else. (from a line in shakespeare’s hamlet.)
hoist with one\u2019s own petard.example: She intended to murder her brother but was hoist with her own petard when she ate the poisoned food intended for him

hoist your sail when the wind is fair.definition: begin a project when circumstances are the most favorable
hoist your sail when the wind is fair.example: Don’t ask your mother for permission now; she’s in a bad mood. Hoist your sail when the wind is fair

hold a meeting.definition: to meet; to have a meeting (of an organization)
hold a meeting.example: We’ll have to hold a meeting to make a decision

hold back on something.definition: to withhold something; to give or take only a limited amount
hold back on something.example: Hold back on the gravy. I’m on a diet

hold by something.example: I hope that you will hold by our agreement

hold everything.example: “Hold everything!” cried Mary. “There’s a squirrel loose in the kitchen!”

hold forth on someone or something.definition: to speak at great length about someone or something
hold forth on someone or something.example: Sadie held forth on the virtues of home cooking

hold good for someone or something.definition: [for an offer] to remain open to someone or a group
hold good for someone or something.example: Does your offer of help still hold good for us?

hold it.example: Tom: Hold it! Mary: What’s wrong? Tom: You almost stepped on my contact lens

hold no brief for someone or something.definition: not to tolerate someone or something; to be opposed to someone or something
hold no brief for someone or something.example: I hold no brief for Wally and his friends

hold off from doing something.definition: to avoid doing something; to postpone doing something
hold off from doing something.example: Can you hold off from buying a new car for another few months?
