hold off on someone or something.definition: to delay doing something concerning someone or something
hold off on someone or something.example: Please hold off on Tom until we interview the other candidates

hold on.example: Just hold on. Everything will work out in good time

a hold on someone.definition: a strong and secure influence on someone
a hold on someone.example: The strange religion seemed to have a strong hold on its followers

hold on tight.example: Here we go on the merry-go-round! Hold on tight!

hold one\u2019s breath.definition: to stop breathing for a short period, on purpose
hold one\u2019s breath.example: Do you hold your breath when you dive into the water?

hold one\u2019s end up.definition: to carry one’s share of the burden; to do one’s share of the work
hold one\u2019s end up.example: You’re not holding your end up. We’re having to do your share of the work

hold one\u2019s fire.definition: to refrain from shooting (a gun, etc.)
hold one\u2019s fire.example: The sergeant told the soldiers to hold their fire

hold one\u2019s head up.definition: to be confident of the respect of other people; to hold up one’s head with pride rather than bowing one’s head. (a bowed head would indicate a lack of confidence.)
hold one\u2019s head up.example: I am so embarrassed. I will never be able to hold my head up again

hold one\u2019s liquor.definition: to be able to drink alcohol in quantity without ill effects
hold one\u2019s liquor.example: Old Jed can sure hold his liquor— and a lot of it, too

hold one\u2019s mouth the right way.definition: do something very carefully under optimal conditions
hold one\u2019s mouth the right way.example: It was a tedious task. If I didn’t hold my mouth just the right way, I wouldn’t be able to do it

hold one\u2019s nose.definition: to use one’s fingers to keep one’s nose closed to avoid a bad smell or to keep water out
hold one\u2019s nose.example: The kid held his nose and jumped off the dock into the lake. 2.  to attempt to ignore something unpleasant, illegal, or “rotten.”

hold one\u2019s own.definition: to do as well as anyone else
hold one\u2019s own.example: I can hold my own in a footrace any day

hold one\u2019s peace.example: Bill was unable to hold his peace any longer. “Don’t do it!” he cried

hold one\u2019s tongue.definition: to refrain from speaking; to refrain from saying something unpleasant
hold one\u2019s tongue.example: I felt like scolding her, but I held my tongue

hold oneself together.definition: to maintain one’s calmness or sanity
hold oneself together.example: I don’t know if I can hold myself together through another horrible day like this one

hold out against someone or something.definition: to continue one’s defense against someone or something
hold out against someone or something.example: We can hold out against them only a little while longer

hold out for someone or something.definition: to strive to wait for someone or something
hold out for someone or something.example: I will hold out for someone who can do the job better than the last person we interviewed

hold out the olive branch.definition: to offer to end a dispute and be friendly; to offer reconciliation. (the olive branch is a symbol of peace and reconciliation. a biblical reference.)
hold out the olive branch.example: Jill was the first to hold out the olive branch after our argument

hold someone for ransom.definition: to demand money for the return of a person who has been kidnapped
hold someone for ransom.example: The kidnappers held me for ransom, but no one would pay

hold someone hostage.definition: to keep someone as a hostage
hold someone hostage.example: The terrorists planned to hold everyone hostage in the airplane

hold someone or an animal down.definition: to keep someone, something, or an animal down
hold someone or an animal down.example: The heavy beam held him down, and he could not rise

hold someone or something at bay.definition: to make someone, a group, or an animal stay at a safe distance. (originally referred only to animals.)
hold someone or something at bay.example: I held the attacker at bay while Mary got away and called the police

hold someone or something at something.definition: to keep someone or something at some distance, such as an arm’s length, respectful distance, comfortable distance, etc
hold someone or something at something.example: I held the child at an arm’s length until he could be calmed

hold someone or something by something.definition: to grasp someone or something by a particular part
hold someone or something by something.example: I held him by the shoulder while I talked to him

hold someone or something in high regard.definition: to think well of someone or something
hold someone or something in high regard.example: All of us hold the vice president in high regard

hold someone or something in low regard.definition: to think poorly of someone or something
hold someone or something in low regard.example: I’m afraid that Hazel holds you in low regard

hold someone or something over.definition: to retain someone or something (for a period of time)
hold someone or something over.example: The storm held John over for another day

hold someone or something together.definition: to keep a group of people or things together
hold someone or something together.example: She worked at two jobs in order to hold her family together

hold someone or something up.definition: to keep someone or something upright
hold someone or something up.example: Johnny is falling asleep. Please hold him up until I prepare the bed for him

hold someone or something up as an examp.definition: to single out someone or something as a person or thing worthy of imitation
hold someone or something up as an examp.example: No one has ever held me up as an example

hold someone or something up to ridicule.example: They must stop holding Matt up to ridicule! Who do they think they are?

hold someone or something up to scorn.definition: to single out someone or something for repudiation
hold someone or something up to scorn.example: The entire crowd held Randy up to scorn for his part in the riot

hold someone\u2019s attention.definition: to keep someone’s attention; to keep someone interested
hold someone\u2019s attention.example: The boring teacher could not hold the students’ attention

hold someone\u2019s hand.definition: to hold the hand of someone who is frightened, especially a child
hold someone\u2019s hand.example: Please hold Jimmy’s hand when you cross the street. 2.  to comfort someone who is anxious or frightened

hold someone something or an animal back.definition: to restrain someone, something, or an animal from getting at or getting to someone or something
hold someone something or an animal back.example: The parents held the children back from the cake and ice cream until the hostess said she was ready

hold someone to something.definition: to make someone adhere to an agreement
hold someone to something.example: You promised me that you would buy six of them, and I’m going to hold you to your promise

hold someone up to something.definition: to lift someone up to the level of something
hold someone up to something.example: I held up little Mary to the window so she could see out

hold something against someone.definition: to blame something on someone; to bear a grudge against someone; to resent someone
hold something against someone.example: Your brother is mean to me, but I can’t hold it against you

hold something against someone or someth.definition: to press something against someone, a group, or something
hold something against someone or someth.example: Max held the gun against the bank guard’s head and threatened to pull the trigger

hold something for someone.definition: to keep something safe for someone
hold something for someone.example: I will hold your money for you

hold something in abeyance.example: This is a good plan but not at this time. Let’s just hold it in abeyance until things get better

hold something out to someone.example: I held a bouquet of roses out to her

hold something over someone\u2018s head.definition: to have knowledge of something about a person and to use that knowledge to control the person
hold something over someone\u2018s head.example: So I made a mistake when I was young. Are you going to hold that over my head all my life?

hold something together.definition: to keep the parts of an object together
hold something together.example: Hold this broken vase together until I get back with the glue

hold terror for someone.definition: [for something] to be frightening to a person
hold terror for someone.example: The thought of f lying to Rio by myself held great terror for me

hold the fort.definition: to take care of a place while someone who is usually there is gone, such as a store or one’s home. (from western movies.)
hold the fort.example: I’m going next door to visit Mrs. Jones. You stay here and hold the fort

hold the line at someone or something.definition: not to exceed a certain limit regarding someone or something
hold the line at someone or something.example: Having your wife on the payroll is one thing, but no one else from the family—I will hold the line at her

hold together.definition: [for something] to keep from falling apart
hold together.example: Don’t run the engine too fast because it won’t hold together

hold true.definition: [for something] to be true; [for something] to remain true
hold true.example: Does this rule hold true all the time?

hold up on someone or something.definition: to delay or postpone further action on someone or something
hold up on someone or something.example: I know you are getting ready to choose someone, but hold up on Tom. There may be someone better

hold your tongue.definition: you have said enough!; you have said enough rude things
hold your tongue.example: Bill: You’re seeing Tom a lot, aren’t you? You must be in love. Jane: Hold your tongue, Bill Franklin!

hole in one.definition: an instance of hitting a golf ball from the tee to the hole in only one try. (from the game of golf.)
hole in one.example: John made a hole in one yesterday

a hole in the wall.definition: a tiny shop, room, etc., not much wider than its doorway
a hole in the wall.example: I went into this little hole in the wall where they had the nicest little gifts

hole up somewhere.example: During the blizzard, we holed up in a lean-to made of branches

holler something out.example: The guard hollered a warning out

hollow something out.definition: to make the inside of something hollow
hollow something out.example: Martha hollowed the book out and put her money inside

holy cow.example: Holy cow! I never expected such a nice gift!

holy joe.definition: a chaplain; a cleric; a clergyman
holy joe.example: I went to see the holy Joe, and he was a lot of help

holy mackerel.example: Holy mackerel! What a beautiful day!

home folks.example: It sure is good to see the home folks again

home free.definition: safe and without problems. (not necessarily about home or about money. *typically: be ~; get ~.)
home free.example: Everyone else had a lot of trouble with the bureaucrats, but we got home free

home in on someone or something.definition: to aim directly at someone or something
home in on someone or something.example: She came into the room and homed in on the chocolate cake

home is where the heart is.definition: people long to be at home.; your home is whatever place you long to be
home is where the heart is.example: I’ve had a lovely time visiting you, but home is where the heart is, and I think it’s time I went back

home onto something.definition: to aim directly at something; to fix some type of receiver on a signal source
home onto something.example: The navigator homed onto the radio beam from the airport

homely enough to stop a clock.example: She’s a sweet girl, but homely enough to stop a clock

hone for someone or something.definition: to long for someone or something
hone for someone or something.example: Tom: What’s wrong with Jane? Mary: She’s honing for her sweetheart

honesty is the best policy.definition: you should always tell the truth, even when it seems as if it would be useful to tell a lie
honesty is the best policy.example: Jill: I borrowed Jane’s white blouse without asking her, and then I spilled tomato sauce on it. Should I tell her what happened, or should I just put the blouse back in her closet and hope she won’t notice? Jane: Honesty is the best policy

the honeymoon is over.definition: the early pleasant beginning (as at the start of a marriage) has ended
the honeymoon is over.example: Okay, the honeymoon is over. It’s time to settle down and do some hard work

honk at someone or something.definition: to sound a horn at someone or something

honor someone as something.definition: to praise someone as something; to praise someone for being something
honor someone as something.example: Aren’t you going to honor Kevin as a hero?

honor someone for something.definition: to praise someone for doing something
honor someone for something.example: The committee agreed to honor Laurel for her role in the benefit dance

honor someone\u2019s check.definition: to accept someone’s personal check in payment of an obligation
honor someone\u2019s check.example: The clerk at the store wouldn’t honor my check. I had to pay cash

honor someone with something.definition: to show one’s respect for someone with something, such as a gift, party, ceremony, a response, etc
honor someone with something.example: We would like to honor you with a little reception

hooched up.example: Sally is too hooched to drive

hoodwink someone into something.definition: to deceive someone into doing something
hoodwink someone into something.example: She will try to hoodwink you into driving her to the airport. Watch out

hoodwink someone out of something.definition: to get something away from someone by deception
hoodwink someone out of something.example: Are you trying to hoodwink me out of my money?

hoof it.example: If nobody gives us a ride, we’ll have to hoof it

hook into something.example: We will hook into the water main tomorrow morning

hook line and sinker.example: She fell for our story hook, line, and sinker

hook oneself on someone or something.definition: to become enamored of someone or something
hook oneself on someone or something.example: I’m afraid I’ve hooked myself on Alice

hook someone on something.definition: to addict someone to a drug or alcohol
hook someone on something.example: Careful, or you’ll hook yourself on those tranquilizers

hook someone up with someone.definition: to arrange for someone to go out with someone
hook someone up with someone.example: I hooked Alice up with Tom last year, and now they’re getting married

hook something down.definition: to attach something and hold it down with a hook
hook something down.example: Please hook the lid down so it doesn’t fall off

hook something into something.example: I want to hook another communication line into the system

hook something up.definition: to set something up and get it working. (the object is to be connected to a power supply, electronic network, telephone lines, etc.)
hook something up.example: Will it take long to hook the telephone up?

hook up with someone.example: Fancy hooking up with you here, Bill. How have you been?

hooked on something.definition: addicted to a drug or something similar

hoot and holler.definition: to shout in disapproval; to call and shout one’s displeasure
hoot and holler.example: After the umpire rendered his decision, the spectators hooted and hollered their thoughts on the matter

hop into something.definition: to jump into something; to get into something
hop into something.example: Hop into your car and drive over to my house

hop off of something.definition: to jump off something. (of is usually retained before pronouns.)
hop off of something.example: She hopped off her bike and came into the house

hop onto something.definition: to jump or get onto something that is moving
hop onto something.example: Sometimes you have to hop onto the cable car after it has started to move

a hop skip and a jump.example: Bill lives just a hop, skip, and a jump from here. We can be there in two minutes

hop something up.definition: sl. to make a machine, especially a car, run extra fast or give it extra power
hop something up.example: He will take that junk heap home and hop it up

hop to it.example: Bill: I have to get these things stacked up before I go home. Bob: Then hop to it! You won’t get it done standing around here talking

hop up to someone or something.definition: [for an animal] to come close to someone or something by hopping
hop up to someone or something.example: The bunny hopped up to me and just sat there

hope against all hope.definition: to have hope even when the situation appears to be hopeless
hope against all hope.example: We hope against all hope that she’ll see the right thing to do and do it

hope for something.definition: to be optimistic that one’s wish for something will come true
hope for something.example: I still hope for her return

hope for the best.definition: to desire the best to happen
hope for the best.example: Good luck. You know we all hope for the best

hope is a good breakfast but a bad suppe.definition: it is good to start the day feeling hopeful, but if none of the things you hope for come to pass by the end of the day, you will feel disappointed. (can be used to warn someone against hoping for something that is unlikely to happen.)
hope is a good breakfast but a bad suppe.example: Lisa began the day hoping that she would find work, and by the end of the day she had learned that hope is a good breakfast but a bad supper

hope springs eternal in the human breast.definition: people will continue to hope even though they have evidence that things cannot possibly turn out the way they want. (from alexander pope’s poem, “essay on man.” sometimes used to remark that you believe someone’s situation is hopeless, as in the first example.)
hope springs eternal in the human breast.example: Jill: The boss may have turned me down the first twelve times I asked for a raise, but this time I really think she’ll give it to me. Jane: Hope springs eternal in the human breast

hopped up.definition: sl. intoxicated with drugs or alcohol; stimulated by drugs or alcohol
hopped up.example: The old man was hopped up again. He was addicted to opium

hopping mad.example: Joe got hopping mad when the salesclerk was rude to him

horn in on someone.definition: to attempt to displace someone; to interfere with someone, especially with someone’s romantic interests
horn in on someone.example: I’m going to ask Sally to the party. Don’t you dare try to horn in on me!

horn in on something.definition: to attempt to participate in something without invitation or consent
horn in on something.example: Are you trying to horn in on my conversation with Sally?

horse around with someone or something.definition: to play around roughly with someone or something, possibly abusing someone or something
horse around with someone or something.example: Stop horsing around with your little brother. Leave him alone

horse sense.example: Bob is no scholar but he has a lot of horse sense

hose someone down.definition: sl. to kill someone. (underworld. from the image of spraying someone with bullets.)
hose someone down.example: Mr. Big told Sam to hose Wilbur down

hose someone or something down.definition: to wash something down with water from a hose
hose someone or something down.example: Hose her down to cool her off and maybe she will do the same for you

hot and bothered.example: Now don’t get hot and bothered. Take it easy

hot and heavy.definition: referring to serious passion or emotions
hot and heavy.example: Things were getting a little hot and heavy so Ellen asked to be taken home

hot damn.definition: wow!; hooray! (an exclamation of surprise and delight.)
hot damn.example: Hot damn! I just won a vacation trip to Florida!

hot enough to burn a polar bear \u2019s.example: Every day in August was hot enough to burn a polar bear’s butt

hot off the press.definition: freshly printed; just released by a publisher
hot off the press.example: Here is a copy of the new Perry Hodder novel. It’s hot off the press

hot on something.definition: enthusiastic about something; very much interested in something; knowledgeable about something

hot on the trail of someone some creatur.definition: very close to finding or catching up with someone, some creature, or something
hot on the trail of someone some creatur.example: I am hot on the trail of the book that I have been seeking for months

a hot ticket.definition: something that is really popular and attractive at the moment
a hot ticket.example: Singers who can dance are a hot ticket right now. Who knows what folks will like next month?

hot under the collar.example: The boss was really hot under the collar when you told him you lost the contract

a hotbed of something.definition: a nest of something; a gathering place of something
a hotbed of something.example: This office is a hotbed of lazy people

hotfoot it off to somewhere.definition: to go somewhere as fast as possible
hotfoot it off to somewhere.example: I’ve got to hotfoot it off to school

hotfoot it out of somewhere.definition: to run away from a place
hotfoot it out of somewhere.example: Did you see Tom hotfoot it out of the office when the boss came in?

hound someone or an animal down.definition: to pursue and capture someone or an animal
hound someone or an animal down.example: I will hound the killer down if it takes me the rest of my life

hound something out of someone.definition: to force someone to give information
hound something out of someone.example: We are going to have to hound the information out of her

a house divided against itself cannot st.definition: if the members of a group fight each other, the group will disintegrate. (often the group under discussion is a family.)
a house divided against itself cannot st.example: The leader of the newly formed union tried hard to reconcile the different factions within his organization, because he knew that a house divided against itself cannot stand

house of correction.example: He was sentenced to five years in the county’s house of correction

hover around someone or something.definition: to hang or wait around someone or something
hover around someone or something.example: The mugger hovered around the side door to the theater, waiting for a victim

hover between something and something el.definition: to float or hang between things
hover between something and something el.example: The helicopter hovered between the buildings and lowered a rescue chair

hover over someone or something.definition: to remain suspended over someone or something
hover over someone or something.example: The rescue helicopter hovered over the f loating sailor

how about that.example: A: My husband and I just celebrated our sixtieth anniversary. B: How about that!

how about you.definition: what do you think?; what is your choice?; what about you?
how about you.example: Bob: How are you, Bill? Bill: I’m okay. How about you? Bob: Fine, fine. Let’s do lunch sometime

how are you doing.definition: a standard greeting inquiry. (the entry without are is informal and usually pronounced “how ya doin’?”)
how are you doing.example: Jane: How are you doing? Mary: I’m okay. What about you? Jane: Likewise

how are you feeling.definition: an inquiry into the state of someone’s health
how are you feeling.example: Sally: How are you feeling? Bill: Oh, better, thanks. Sally: That’s good

how are you getting on.definition: how are you managing?; how are you doing?
how are you getting on.example: Jane: Well, Mary, how are you getting on? Mary: Things couldn’t be better

how come.definition: how did that come about?; why?
how come.example: Sally: I have to go to the doctor. Mary: How come? Sally: I’m sick, silly

how could you do something.definition: how could you bring yourself to do a thing like that? (no answer is expected.)
how could you do something.example: Looking first at the broken lamp and then at the cat, Mary shouted, “How could you do that?”

how do you do.definition: a standard inquiry and response on greeting or meeting someone. (this expression never has rising question intonation, but the first instance of its use calls for a response. sometimes the response does, in fact, explain how one is.)
how do you do.example: Sally: Hello. How do you do. Bob: How do you do

how do you know.definition: how did you get that information? (a straightforward question. the stress in on know.)
how do you know.example: Bill: The train is about to pull into the station. Sue: How do you know? Bill: I hear it

how do you like school.definition: a phrase used to start a conversation with a school-age person
how do you like school.example: Bob: Well, Billy, how do you like school? Billy: I hate it. Bob: Too bad

how do you like that.definition: do you like that?; is that to your liking?
how do you like that.example: Tom: There’s a bigger one over there. How do you like that? Bill: It’s better, but not quite what I want

how do you like this weather.definition: something said when greeting someone. (a direct answer is expected.)
how do you like this weather.example: Henry: Hi, Bill. How do you like this weather? Bill: Lovely weather for ducks. Not too good for me, though

how does that grab you.definition: what do you think of that? (pronounced more like howzat grab ya?.)
how does that grab you.example: Looks good, okay? How does that grab you?

how dumb do you think i am.definition: your question is insulting. i am not stupid. (shows agitation. an answer is not expected or desired.)
how dumb do you think i am.example: Mary: Are you really going to sell your new car? Sally: Come on! How dumb do you think I am?

how goes it.definition: how are you?; how are things going?
how goes it.example: Nice to see you. How goes it?

how have you been.example: Bob: Hi, Fred! How have you been? Fred: Great! What about you? Bob: Fine

how is someone fixed for something.example: How are you fixed for ketchup? Do you have enough for the picnic?

how is someone getting along.definition: how is someone feeling or progressing?
how is someone getting along.example: How is your father getting along? Is he any better?

how is someone making out.definition: how is someone doing?; how is someone surviving or getting along?
how is someone making out.example: How are you making out since your retirement?

how many times do i have to tell you.definition: a phrase admonishing someone who has forgotten instructions
how many times do i have to tell you.example: Mother: How many times do I have to tell you? Do your homework! Bill: Mom! I hate school!

how\u2019s business.definition: a question asked in a conversation about the state of someone’s business or job
how\u2019s business.example: Tom: Hello, Sally. How’s business? Sally: Okay, I suppose

how\u2019s by you.example: Fred: Hey, man! How’s by you? John: Just fine, Fred

how\u2019s every little thing.definition: how are you?; how are things with you?
how\u2019s every little thing.example: Bill: Hello, Tom. Tom: Hi, Bill. How’s every little thing? Bill: Couldn’t be better

how\u2019s it with you.example: Tom: Hey, man. How’s with you? Bob: Great! And you? Tom: Okay

how\u2019s that again.definition: please say that again.; i did not hear it all
how\u2019s that again.example: Sue: Would you like some coffee? Mary: How’s that again? Sue: I said, would you like some coffee?

how\u2019s the wife.definition: a phrase used by a man when inquiring about a male friend’s wife
how\u2019s the wife.example: Tom: Hi, Fred, how are you? Fred: Good. And you? Tom: Great! How’s the wife? Fred: Okay, and yours? Tom: Couldn’t be better

how\u2019s the world been treating you.example: Hi, Jane. How’s the world treating you?

how\u2019s tricks.example: Bob: Fred! How’s tricks? Fred: How are you doing, Bob? Bob: Doing great!

how so.example: A: You have to bring all the lawn furniture in. B: How so?

how the mighty have fallen.definition: a jovial or mocking way of remarking that someone is doing something that he or she used to consider very demeaning
how the mighty have fallen.example: Jill: Ever since Fred’s wife left him, he has had to cook his own meals. Jane: Well! How the mighty have fallen!

how the other half lives.definition: how poorer people live; how richer people live
how the other half lives.example: Now that I am bankrupt I am beginning to understand how the other half lives

a howdy and a half.example: Tom: Is it far to the dime store? Jane: Just a howdy and a half

howl with something.definition: to yell or holler because of something, such as pain
howl with something.example: Roger howled with pain as the needle went into his arm

how\u2019re things going.example: Bob: Hi, Fred! How’re things going? Fred: Could be better. How’s by you?

how\u2019re things with you.example: Sally: How are you? Bill: Fine. How are things?

huddle around someone or something.definition: to gather or bunch around someone or something
huddle around someone or something.example: The girls huddled around Mary to hear what she had to say

huddle someone together.example: The scoutmaster huddled the boys together to give them a pep talk

huddle up together.example: The children huddled up together to keep warm

a hue and cry.definition: a loud public protest or opposition
a hue and cry.example: There was a hue and cry when the city government tried to build houses on the playing field

huff and puff.definition: to breathe very hard; to pant as one exerts effort
huff and puff.example: John came up the stairs huffing and puffing

hum with activity.definition: [for a place] to be busy with activity
hum with activity.example: The kitchen hummed with activity as usual

hunch over.example: The wounded man hunched over and staggered to the window

hunch something up.definition: to raise up or lift up some body part, usually the shoulders
hunch something up.example: He hunched his shoulders up in his effort to get warm

hunch up.definition: to squeeze or pull the parts of one’s body together
hunch up.example: He hunched up in a corner to keep warm

hung up on someone or something.definition: obsessed with someone or something; devoted to someone or something
hung up on someone or something.example: John is really hung up on Mary

hunger after something.definition: to crave for something, not necessarily food
hunger after something.example: I hunger after some old-fashioned gospel music

hunger for someone or something.definition: to desire someone or something; to yearn for someone or something
hunger for someone or something.example: I hunger for you. I want you madly

hunger is the best sauce.definition: everything tastes especially good when you are hungry, because you are so eager to eat it
hunger is the best sauce.example: After our twenty-mile hike, we stopped at a little roadside restaurant. It may have been that they made the most delicious food in the world there, or it may have been that hunger was the best sauce

hungry for something.definition: desiring something, often something other than food
hungry for something.example: The orphan was hungry for the warmth of a family

hunker down on something.definition: to squat down on one’s heels, a stool, a stone, etc
hunker down on something.example: Jeff hunkered down on the pavement and watched the world go by

hunker down to something.definition: to apply oneself to something, to get started working at something
hunker down to something.example: I hunkered down to my chores, hoping to get them done before noon

hunt after someone or something.definition: to seek or pursue someone or something
hunt after someone or something.example: I’m hunting after a tall man with straight black hair

hunt for someone or something.definition: to chase someone or something for sport
hunt for someone or something.example: The hunter hunted for grouse on the game preserve

hunt someone or something down.definition: to chase and catch someone or something
hunt someone or something down.example: I don’t know where Amy is, but I’ll hunt her down. I’ll find her

hunt someone or something out.definition: to find someone or something even if concealed
hunt someone or something out.example: We will hunt them all out and find every last one of those guys

hurl someone or something at someone or.definition: to throw someone or something at someone or something
hurl someone or something at someone or.example: The huge man actually hurled me at the tree

hurl someone or something down.definition: to throw or push someone or something downward to the ground
hurl someone or something down.example: Roger hurled the football down and it bounced away wildly

hurl someone or something into something.definition: to throw someone or something into something
hurl someone or something into something.example: She hurled the little boys into the storm cellar and went back to the house for the dog

hurl something around.definition: to throw something, such as words, around carelessly
hurl something around.example: Don’t just go hurling foul words around like they didn’t mean anything

hurl something away from someone or some.definition: to throw or push something away from someone or something
hurl something away from someone or some.example: She hurled the bricks away from the partially buried child

hurry back to someone or something.definition: to return to someone or something immediately or as fast as possible
hurry back to someone or something.example: Oh, please hurry back to me as soon as you can

hurry down to somewhere.example: We need you down here in the basement. Hurry down

hurry one on one\u2019s way.definition: to help someone to hasten on
hurry one on one\u2019s way.example: Mary hurried Joel on his way so he could catch his train

hurry someone or something along.definition: to make someone or something go faster
hurry someone or something along.example: Go hurry your mother along. We’re almost late

hurry someone or something into somethin.definition: to make someone or something go into something fast
hurry someone or something into somethin.example: She hurried the chickens into the coop and closed the door on them for the night

hurry someone or something up.definition: to make someone or something go or work faster
hurry someone or something up.example: Please hurry them all up. We are expecting to have dinner very soon

hurry up and wait.definition: to do some things in a series fast and then have to wait a long time to do the next things in the series. (originally military.)
hurry up and wait.example: That’s all we ever do. Rush to stand in line somewhere. We just hurry up and wait all day long

hurt someone\u2019s feelings.example: It hurts my feelings when you talk that way

hurtin\u2019 for something.example: I went to fetch a bottle of cough syrup. My sick child was hurtin’ for it

hurtle through something.definition: to travel through something at great speed or with great force, possibly causing breakage
hurtle through something.example: A brick hurtled through the window and fell on the f loor

a hush fell over someone or something.definition: a sudden silence enveloped something or a group
a hush fell over someone or something.example: As the conductor raised his arms, a hush fell over the audience

hush money.definition: money paid as a bribe to persuade someone to remain silent and not reveal certain information
hush money.example: Bob gave his younger sister hush money so that she wouldn’t tell Jane that he had gone to the movies with Sue

hush someone up.example: Please hush the children up. I have a telephone call

hush something up.definition: to keep something a secret; to try to stop a rumor from spreading
hush something up.example: We just couldn’t hush it up

hush up.definition: to be quiet; to get quiet; to stop talking
hush up.example: You talk too much. Hush up!

hush your mouth.example: I’ve heard enough of that talk. Hush your mouth!

hustle and bustle.example: I can’t stand the hustle and bustle of big cities

hustle up.example: Hustle up, you guys. We have to get moving

hygienically challenged.example: Bill always smells terrible. He must be hygienically challenged

hype someone or something up.definition: to promote, advertise, or boost someone or something, often excessively
hype someone or something up.example: No matter how much they hyped it up, it was still a very dull movie

hypothesize about something.definition: to speculate about something; to make guesses about something
hypothesize about something.example: Don’t waste time hypothesizing about what happened

hypothesize on something.definition: to conjecture on the origin or nature of something
hypothesize on something.example: We sat around hypothesizing on the origin of life

i am so sure.example: You are way rad! I am so sure!

i believe we\u2019ve met.definition: a phrase suggesting that one has already met a person to whom one is being introduced
i believe we\u2019ve met.example: John: Alice, have you met Fred? Alice: Oh, yes, I believe we’ve met. How are you, Fred? Fred: Hello, Alice. Good to see you again

i can accept that.definition: i accept your evaluation as valid
i can accept that.example: Bob: Now, you’ll probably like doing the other job much better. It doesn’t call for you to do the things you don’t do well. Tom: I can accept that

i can live with that.definition: that is something i can get used to.; that is all right as far as i’m concerned
i can live with that.example: Sue: I want to do this room in green. Bill: I can live with that

i can too.definition: you are wrong, i can.; don’t say i can’t, because i can! (the response to (you) cannot!)
i can too.example: Sue: I’m going to the party. Mother: You can’t. Sue: I can too. Mother: Cannot! Sue: Can too!

i can\u2019t accept that.definition: i do not believe what you said.; i reject what you said
i can\u2019t accept that.example: Sue: The mechanic says we need a whole new engine. John: What? I can’t accept that!

i can\u2019t argue with that.definition: i agree with what you said.; it sounds like a good idea
i can\u2019t argue with that.example: Tom: This sure is good cake. Bob: Can’t argue with that

i can\u2019t believe that.example: Tom: What a terrible earthquake! All the houses collapsed, one by one. Jane: I can’t believe that!

i can\u2019t get over something.definition: i am just so amazed! (the something can be a fact or a pronoun, such as that or it. also with just, as in the examples.)
i can\u2019t get over something.example: “I just can’t get over the way everybody pitched in and helped,” said Alice

i can\u2019t help it.definition: there is nothing i can do to help the situation.; that is the way it is.; there is nothing i can do. (often in answer to a criticism.)
i can\u2019t help it.example: Mary: Your hair is a mess. Sue: It’s windy. I can’t help it

i can\u2019t rightly say.definition: i do not know with any certainty
i can\u2019t rightly say.example: Fred: When do you think we’ll get there? Bill: Can’t rightly say

i can\u2019t say for sure.definition: i do not know with any certainty
i can\u2019t say for sure.example: Tom: When will the next train come through? Jane: I can’t say for sure

i can\u2019t thank you enough.example: Bill: Here’s the book I promised you. Sue: Oh, good. I can’t thank you enough

i changed my mind.definition: i have reversed my previous decision or statement
i changed my mind.example: Tom: I thought you were going to Atlanta today. Bill: I changed my mind. I’m leaving tomorrow

i could eat a horse.example: Where’s dinner? I could eat a horse!

i couldn\u2019t ask for more.definition: everything is fine, and there is no more that i could want
i couldn\u2019t ask for more.example: Bill: Are you happy? Sue: Oh, Bill. I couldn’t ask for more

i couldn\u2019t ask you to do that.definition: that is a very kind offer, but i would not ask you to do it. (this is not a refusal of the offer.)
i couldn\u2019t ask you to do that.example: Sally: Look, if you want, I’ll drive you to the airport. Mary: Oh, Sally. I couldn’t ask you to do that

i couldn\u2019t be better.example: John: How are you? Jane: Couldn’t be better

i couldn\u2019t care less.definition: it doesn’t matter to me. (the less bears the heaviest stress in both versions. despite the apparent contradiction, either reading of this—both the affirmative and negative—usually have the same meaning. the exception would be in a sentence where the could bears the heaviest stress: i could care less, [but i don’t.].)
i couldn\u2019t care less.example: Tom: The rain is coming! The carpet will get wet! Mary: I couldn’t care less

i couldn\u2019t help it.definition: there was no way i could prevent it.; i was unable to prevent something from happening.; i was unable to control myself
i couldn\u2019t help it.example: Sally: You let the paint dry with brush marks in it. Mary: I couldn’t help it. The telephone rang

i declare to goodness.example: I declare to goodness! You certainly have grown since I saw you

i do believe.definition: a way of affirming or reaffirming one’s opinion
i do believe.example: Jim’s in love with that gal, I do believe

i do declare.definition: i am surprised to hear that! (oldfashioned.)
i do declare.example: Mary: I’m the new president of my sorority! Grandmother: I declare! That’s very nice

i don\u2019t believe it.definition: an expression of amazement and disbelief
i don\u2019t believe it.example: Bob: Tom was just elected president of the trade association! Mary: I don’t believe it!

i don\u2019t believe i\u2019ve had the p.definition: an expression meaning i haven’t met you yet
i don\u2019t believe i\u2019ve had the p.example: Tom: I’m Tom Thomas. I don’t believe I’ve had the pleasure. Bill: Hello. I’m Bill Franklin. Tom: Nice to meet you, Bill. Bill: Likewise

i don\u2019t believe this.definition: what is happening right now is unbelievable!
i don\u2019t believe this.example: It’s snowing in July! I don’t believe this!

i don\u2019t care.example: Mary: Can I take these papers away? Tom: I don’t care. Do what you want

i don\u2019t care if i do.definition: thank you.; i will. don’t mind if i do.)
i don\u2019t care if i do.example: Tom: Have some more grits? Jane: Don’t care if I do

i don\u2019t mean maybe.definition: i am very serious about my demand or order
i don\u2019t mean maybe.example: Bob: Do I have to do this? Sue: Do it now, and I don’t mean maybe!

i don\u2019t mind if i do.example: Sally: Have some more coffee? Bob: Don’t mind if I do

i don\u2019t mind telling you something.definition: i want you to know something
i don\u2019t mind telling you something.example: Tom: You have a beautiful garden. Mary: Thank you. But I don’t mind telling you, it’s an awful lot of work

i don\u2019t rightly know.example: Tom: When will Joe be getting back? Charlie: I don’t rightly know

i don\u2019t want to sound like a busybo.definition: an expression used to introduce an opinion or suggestion
i don\u2019t want to sound like a busybo.example: Bob: I don’t want to sound like a busybody, but didn’t you intend to have your house painted? Bill: Well, I guess I did

i don\u2019t want to wear out my welcome.definition: a phrase said by a guest who doesn’t want to be a burden to the host or hostess or to visit too often
i don\u2019t want to wear out my welcome.example: Mary: Good night, Tom. You must come back again soon. Tom: Thank you. I’d love to. I don’t want to wear out my welcome, though

i doubt it.example: Tom: Think it will rain today? Sue: I doubt it

i doubt that.definition: i do not believe that something is so
i doubt that.example: Bob: I’ll be there exactly on time. Sue: I doubt that

i felt like a penny waiting for change.example: When I lost the race, I felt like a penny waiting for change

i hate to eat and run.definition: cliché an apology made by someone who must leave a social event soon after eating
i hate to eat and run.example: Bill: Well, I hate to eat and run, but it’s getting late. Sue: Oh, you don’t have to leave, do you? Bill: I think I really must

i have no problem with that.example: Bob: Is it okay if I sign us up to play mixed doubles? Sally: I have no problem with that

i have to go now.definition: an expression announcing the need to leave
i have to go now.example: Fred: Bye, have to go now. Mary: See you later. Take it easy

i have to run along.definition: an expression announcing the need to leave
i have to run along.example: Jane: It’s late. I have to run along. Tom: Okay, Jane. Bye. Take care

i have to wash a few things out.definition: i have to wash things by hand, such as socks and underwear
i have to wash a few things out.example: I have to wash a few things out before I go to bed

i haven\u2019t got all day.definition: please hurry.; i’m in a hurry
i haven\u2019t got all day.example: Rachel: Make it snappy! I haven’t got all day. Alice: Just take it easy. There’s no rush

i haven\u2019t seen you in a long time.definition: an expression of greeting, often said as part of a series
i haven\u2019t seen you in a long time.example: Mary: Hi, Fred! Haven’t seen you in a long time. Fred: Yeah. Long time no see

i haven\u2019t seen you in a month of su.definition: i haven’t seen you in a long time
i haven\u2019t seen you in a month of su.example: Tom: Hi, Bill. Haven’t seen you in a month of Sundays! Bill: Hi, Tom. Long time no see

i hope all goes well.example: Good luck on your operation tomorrow. I hope all goes well

i hope not.definition: a phrase expressing the desire and wish that something is not so
i hope not.example: John: It looks like it’s going to rain. Jane: Hope not

i hope so.definition: a phrase expressing the desire and wish that something is so
i hope so.example: Bill: Is this the right house? Bob: Hope so

i hope to see you again sometime.definition: an expression said when taking leave of a person one has just met
i hope to see you again sometime.example: Bill: Nice to meet you, Tom. Tom: Bye, Bill. Nice to meet you. Hope to see you again sometime

i promise you.definition: i am telling you the truth! (compare this with trust me!)
i promise you.example: John: Things will work out, I promise you! Jane: Okay, but when?

i read you loud and clear.definition: a response used by someone communicating by radio stating that the hearer understands the transmission clearly
i read you loud and clear.example: Controller: This is Aurora Center, do you read me? Pilot: Yes, I read you loud and clear

i really must go.definition: an expression announcing or repeating one’s intention to depart
i really must go.example: Bob: It’s getting late. I really must go. Jane: Good night, then. See you tomorrow

i rest my case.definition: i have completed the presentation of my argument. (said by a lawyer.)
i rest my case.example: Clearly the defendant is guilty. I rest my case. 2.  What you just heard sums up my point of view

i spoke out of turn.definition: i said the wrong thing.; i should not have said what i did. (an apology.)
i spoke out of turn.example: Bill: You said I was the one who did it. Mary: I’m sorry. I spoke out of turn. I was mistaken

i spoke too soon.definition: i am wrong.; i spoke before i knew the facts
i spoke too soon.example: Bill: I know I said I would, but I spoke too soon. Sue: I thought so

i swan.example: Well, I swan! I didn’t expect to see you here!

i was just wondering.definition: a comment made after hearing a response to a previous question. (see examples for typical patterns.)
i was just wondering.example: John: Do you always keep your film in the refrigerator? Mary: Yes, why? John: I was just wondering

i was up all night with a sick friend.definition: an unlikely, but popular excuse for not being where one was supposed to be the night before
i was up all night with a sick friend.example: Bill: Where in the world were you last night? Mary: Well, I was up all night with a sick friend

i wasn\u2019t brought up in the woods to.definition: i am not foolish or easily frightened
i wasn\u2019t brought up in the woods to.example: His threats don’t scare me. I wasn’t brought up in the woods to be scared by owls

i wish i\u2019d said that.definition: a comment of praise or admiration for someone’s clever remark
i wish i\u2019d said that.example: Mary: The weed of crime bears bitter fruit. Sue: I wish I’d said that. Mary: I wish I’d said it first

i wonder if.example: Henry: I wonder if I could have another piece of cake. Sue: Sure. Help yourself

i won\u2019t give up without a fight.definition: i will not give in easily. (compare this with don’t give up too eas(il)y.)
i won\u2019t give up without a fight.example: Sue: Stick by your principles, Fred. Fred: Don’t worry, I won’t give up without a fight

i would if i could but i can\u2019t.example: Jane: Can’t you fix this yourself ? John: I would if I could, but I can’t

i wouldn\u2019t if i were you.definition: a polite way to advise someone not to do something
i wouldn\u2019t if i were you.example: Mary: Do you think I should trade this car in on a new one? Sally: I wouldn’t if I were you

i wouldn\u2019t know.definition: there is no way that i would know the answer to that question
i wouldn\u2019t know.example: John: When will the f light from Miami get in? Jane: Sorry, I wouldn’t know

i wouldn\u2019t touch it with a tenfoot.definition: cliché i would not have anything to do with it under any circumstances. (said about something you think is untrustworthy, as in the first example, or in response to a remark that seems to invite a nasty reply, as in the second example. the british version is “i would not touch it with a bargepole.”)
i wouldn\u2019t touch it with a tenfoot.example: Jill: This advertisement says I can buy land in Florida for a small investment. Do you think I should? Jane: I wouldn’t touch it with a ten-foot pole

ice over.definition: [for water] to freeze and develop a covering of ice
ice over.example: I can’t wait for the river to ice over so we can do some ice fishing

ice something down.example: They are icing the champagne down now

ice something up.definition: to cause something to become icy
ice something up.example: I hope the cold doesn’t ice the roads up

the icing on the cake.example: Oh, wow! A tank full of gas in my new car. That’s icing on the cake!

i\u2019d bet money on it.example: Charlie: Do you think Joe’s planning to sell his house? Tom: I’d bet money on it

i\u2019d better get moving.definition: an expression announcing the need to depart
i\u2019d better get moving.example: Jane: It’s nearly dark. Better get moving. Mary: Okay. See you later

i\u2019d better get on my horse.definition: an expression indicating that it is time that one departed
i\u2019d better get on my horse.example: John: It’s getting late. Better get on my horse. Rachel: Have a safe trip. See you tomorrow

i\u2019d just as leave do something.example: Tom: Do you want to go to Joe’s party? Jane: We can if you want to, but I’d as leave not

i\u2019d just as soon as do something.definition: i would prefer to do something
i\u2019d just as soon as do something.example: Tom: Why don’t you give Joe a call? Jane: I’d as soon as you did it

i\u2019d like for you to meet someone.definition: an expression used to introduce someone to someone else. (the someone can be a person’s name, the name of a relationship, or the word someone.)
i\u2019d like for you to meet someone.example: Tom: Sue, I’d like you to meet my brother, Bill. Sue: Hi, Bill. How are you? Bill: Great! How are you?

i\u2019d like to speak to someone please.definition: the standard way of requesting to speak with a specific person on the telephone or in an office
i\u2019d like to speak to someone please.example: Sue (answering the phone): Hello? Bill: Hello, this is Bill Franklin. I’d like to speak to Mary Gray. Sue: I’ll see if she’s in

i\u2019d rather face a firing squad than.definition: i would prefer to stand and be executed by gunfire than to do something
i\u2019d rather face a firing squad than.example: I’d rather face a firing squad than go shopping the day after Christmas

identify oneself with someone or somethi.definition: to classify oneself with someone or something; to relate to someone or something; to see part of oneself represented in someone or something
identify oneself with someone or somethi.example: I identify myself with the others

identify someone as someone.definition: to determine that someone is a certain person
identify someone as someone.example: Can you identify Fred as the perpetrator?

identify someone or something by somethi.definition: to recognize someone or something because of something
identify someone or something by somethi.example: Can you identify your baggage by any special marks?

identify someone or something with someo.definition: to associate people and things, in any combination
identify someone or something with someo.example: I tend to identify Wally with big cars

idle about.example: Please don’t idle about. Get busy!

an idle brain is the devil\u2019s worksh.definition: people who have nothing worthwhile to think about will usually think of something bad to do
an idle brain is the devil\u2019s worksh.example: We need to figure out something constructive for Tom to do in the afternoons after school. An idle brain is the devil’s workshop

idle something away.definition: to waste one’s time in idleness; to waste a period of time, such as an afternoon, evening, one’s life
idle something away.example: She idled the afternoon away and then went to a party

idleness is the root of all evil.definition: if you have no useful work to do, you will think of harmful things to do in order to amuse yourself. (compare this with money is the root of all evil.)
idleness is the root of all evil.example: Child: Why do you make me do so many chores? Father: Idleness is the root of all evil

idolize someone or something as somethin.definition: to worship or adore someone or something as being something
idolize someone or something as somethin.example: We all idolized Jim as our hero

if a thing is worth doing it \u2019s wor.definition: if you decide to do something, do it as well as you possibly can
if a thing is worth doing it \u2019s wor.example: Jill: Do we have to wash the walls before we paint them? It seems like such a lot of extra work. Fred: Yes, we have to. The paint won’t stick properly otherwise. If a thing is worth doing, it’s worth doing well

if anything can go wrong it will.definition: every possible disaster will occur, whether you have prepared for it or not. (this saying is also referred to as “murphy’s law.”)
if anything can go wrong it will.example: Fred: Your car should be fine now, as long as the battery doesn’t die. Alan: Then we’d better put a new battery in. If anything can go wrong, it will; so let’s make sure it can’t go wrong

if at first you don\u2019t succeed try t.definition: you have to keep trying until you get what you want
if at first you don\u2019t succeed try t.example: Jill: I spent all morning trying to fix the computer, and it still won’t work. Jane: If at first you don’t succeed, try, try again

if god did not exist it would be necessa.definition: people need a deity to worship. (this is an english translation of a quote from voltaire. it is often parodied, using a person’s name instead of god and implying that the person is somehow necessary.)
if god did not exist it would be necessa.example: The atheist tried to convince Jerry that God does not exist, and that people should not waste their time worshiping Him. “But you can’t stop people from worshiping God,” Jerry replied. “If God did not exist, it would be necessary to invent Him.”

if i were you.definition: an expression introducing a piece of advice
if i were you.example: John: If I were you, I’d get rid of that old car. Alice: Gee, I was just getting to like it

if ifs and ands were pots and pans there.definition: wishing for things is useless. (often said in reply to someone who says something beginning with “if only. . . .”)
if ifs and ands were pots and pans there.example: Daughter: If only we didn’t have to move out of town, I’d be the happiest girl in the world. Grandmother: If ifs and ands were pots and pans, there’d be no work for tinkers’ hands

if it ain\u2019t chickens it\u2019s feat.definition: there are always problems.; that is life
if it ain\u2019t chickens it\u2019s feat.example: Now that I’m finally done with school, I’ve got to worry about getting a job. If it ain’t chickens, it’s feathers

if it was a snake it woulda bit you.definition: it was very close to you
if it was a snake it woulda bit you.example: Jane: Where’s the phone book? Tom: Right there! If it was a snake it woulda bit you

if i\u2019ve told you once i\u2019ve tol.definition: an expression that introduces a scolding, usually to a child
if i\u2019ve told you once i\u2019ve tol.example: Mother: If I’ve told you once, I’ve told you a thousand times, don’t leave your clothes in a pile on the f loor! Bill: Sorry

if looks could kill.definition: a catchphrase said when someone makes a frown at someone or when someone casts a dirty look
if looks could kill.example: Did you see the way she looked at me? If looks could kill

if my memory serves me correctly.definition: if i have remembered it correctly
if my memory serves me correctly.example: If my memory serves me correctly, you are the cousin of my closest friend

if not.definition: if that is not [the case]; if that is not so
if not.example: If not cleaned, the clock will stop running

if one knows what\u2019s good for one.definition: one had better do what is expected of one
if one knows what\u2019s good for one.example: You’d better be on time if you know what’s good for you

if one\u2019s a day.definition: a phrase attached to an expression of someone’s age
if one\u2019s a day.example: She’s fifty if she’s a day!

if so.definition: if that is [the case]; if that is so
if so.example: She might be late. If so, we will eat without her

if that don\u2019t beat a pig apecking.example: Tom: A Republican won the Senate seat! Jane: If that don’t beat a pig a-pecking!

if the mountain will not come to mahomet.definition: if things do not change the way you want them to, you must adjust to the way they are. (mohammed is often used instead of mahomet. also the mountain has come to mahomet, something or someone that you would not expect to travel has arrived. there are many variations of this proverb. see the examples.)
if the mountain will not come to mahomet.example: The president won’t see me so I will have to go to his office. If the mountain will not come to Mahomet, Mahomet must go to the mountain

if the shoe fits wear it.definition: an unflattering remark applies to you, so you should accept it. (slightly rude.)
if the shoe fits wear it.example: Fred: Hey, Jill, how’s your love life? Jill: I don’t like busybodies, Fred. Fred: Are you calling me a busybody? Jane: If the shoe fits, wear it

if the truth were known.definition: if people knew how something really was, instead of how it appears to be
if the truth were known.example: If the truth were known, people wouldn’t shop at that store. Its owners aren’t as honest as they seem

if the worst comes to the worst.definition: in the worst possible circumstances; if the worst possible thing should happen
if the worst comes to the worst.example: We should be able to catch the four-thirty train, but if the worst comes to the worst, we could get a taxi and still get into town on time

if there\u2019s anything you need don\u2.definition: a polite phrase offering help in finding something or by providing something. (often said by a host or by someone helping someone settle into something. see also if you don’t see what you want, please ask (for it).)
if there\u2019s anything you need don\u2.example: Mary: This looks very nice. I’ll be quite comfortable here. Jane: If there’s anything you need, don’t hesitate to ask

if two ride on a horse one must ride beh.definition: when two people do something together, one of them will be the leader and the other will have to be subordinate
if two ride on a horse one must ride beh.example: Jane: How come every time we get together, we always do what you want to do, and never do what I want to do? Ellen: Well, dear, if two ride on a horse, one must ride behind

if wishes were horses then beggars would.definition: people make a lot of wishes, but wishing is useless
if wishes were horses then beggars would.example: Jill: If I were Queen of the World, I would make sure that everyone had enough to eat. Jane: And if wishes were horses, then beggars would ride

if you can\u2019t be good be careful.definition: if you are going to do immoral things, make sure they are not dangerous.; if you are going to do something immoral, make sure to keep it secret. (sometimes used as a flippant way of saying good-bye.)
if you can\u2019t be good be careful.example: Be a good girl on your vacation trip. Or if you can’t be good, be careful

if you can\u2019t stand the heat get out.definition: if the pressures of some situation are too much for you, you should leave that situation. (somewhat insulting; implies that the person addressed cannot tolerate pressure.)
if you can\u2019t stand the heat get out.example: Alan: I didn’t think being a stockbroker could be so stressful. Fred: If you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen

if you don\u2019t like it you can lump i.definition: things cannot be changed to suit your preferences
if you don\u2019t like it you can lump i.example: We’re having fish for dinner tonight. And if you don’t like it, you can lump it

if you don\u2019t make mistakes you don\.definition: if you try to do something, you will likely make mistakes.; the only way to make no mistakes is to avoid trying to do anything. (can be used to console someone who has made a mistake.)
if you don\u2019t make mistakes you don\.example: Alan: I’m sorry there’s no dessert. I tried to make a cake, but I messed it up. Jane: That’s OK, dear; if you don’t make mistakes, you don’t make anything

if you don\u2019t mind.definition: an expression that rebukes someone for some minor social violation
if you don\u2019t mind.example: When Bill accidentally sat on Mary’s purse, which she had placed in the seat next to her, she said, somewhat angrily, “If you don’t mind!”

if you get my drift.definition: if you understand what i am saying or implying. (akin to get someone’s drift.)
if you get my drift.example: I’ve heard enough talk and seen enough inaction—if you get my drift

if you know what\u2019s good for you.definition: if you know what will be to your benefit; if you know what will keep you out of trouble
if you know what\u2019s good for you.example: Mary: I see that Jane has put a big dent in her car. Sue: You’ll keep quiet about that if you know what’s good for you

if you lie down with dogs you will get u.definition: if you associate with bad people, you will acquire their faults
if you lie down with dogs you will get u.example: Granddaughter: It’s not fair. I’m starting to get a bad reputation just because I’m friends with Suzy and she has a bad reputation. Grandmother: It’s only natural. People think that if you lie down with dogs, you will get up with f leas

if you must.definition: all right, if you have to
if you must.example: Sally: It’s late. I have to move along. Mary: If you must. Good-bye. See you tomorrow

if you play with fire you get burned.definition: if you do something dangerous, you will get hurt
if you play with fire you get burned.example: Joe said, “I have no sympathy for race-car drivers who get injured. They should know that if you play with fire, you get burned.”

if you run after two hares you will catc.definition: you cannot do two things successfully at the same time
if you run after two hares you will catc.example: Vanessa: If I want to pursue my acting career, I’ll have to take more days off to go to auditions. But I want to get ahead in the office, too. Jane: If you run after two hares, you will catch neither

if you want a thing done well do it your.definition: you cannot rely on other people to do things properly for you. (sometimes right is used instead of well.)
if you want a thing done well do it your.example: I asked my son to chop the vegetables for me, but he’s cut them into chunks too small to use. I should have known: if you want a thing done well, do it yourself

if you want peace you must prepare for w.definition: if a country is well armed, its opponents will be less likely to attack it
if you want peace you must prepare for w.example: Wilbur was always arguing with those of his friends who believed in disarmament. “Getting rid of our weapons won’t promote peace,” he would say. “If you want peace, you must prepare for war.”

if you would be well served serve yourse.definition: you should do things for yourself, since you cannot trust other people to do them exactly the way you want
if you would be well served serve yourse.example: I would never hire a maid, because a maid wouldn’t clean things the way I want them cleaned. Like they say: if you would be well served, serve yourself

if you\u2019ll pardon the expression.definition: excuse the expression i am about to say or just said
if you\u2019ll pardon the expression.example: This thing is—if you’ll pardon the expression—loused up

if you\u2019re born to be hanged then yo.definition: if you escape one disaster, it must be because you are destined for a different kind of disaster. (sometimes used to warn someone who has escaped drowning against gloating over good luck.)
if you\u2019re born to be hanged then yo.example: When their ship was trapped in a terrible storm, Ellen told her husband that she feared they would die. “Don’t worry,” he replied with a yawn, “if you’re born to be hanged, then you’ll never be drowned.”

if you\u2019ve a mind to do something.definition: if you really want to do something
if you\u2019ve a mind to do something.example: If you’ve a mind to run for class president, you’d best start making campaign posters

ignorance is bliss.definition: not knowing is better than knowing and worrying
ignorance is bliss.example: A: I never knew that the kid who mows our lawn has been in trouble with the police. B: Ignorance is bliss!

ignorance of the law is no excuse for br.definition: even if you do not know that something is against the law, you can still be punished for doing it. (an ancient legal principle.)
ignorance of the law is no excuse for br.example: Police officer: I’m giving you a speeding ticket. Motorist: But I didn’t know I was exceeding the speed limit! Police officer: Ignorance of the law is no excuse for breaking it

ill at ease.example: I feel ill at ease about the interview

i\u2019ll be a monkey\u2019s uncle.example: A: I just won $500,000 in the lottery! B: Well, I’ll be a monkey’s uncle!

i\u2019ll be right there.example: Bill: Tom! Come here. Tom: Be right there

i\u2019ll be right with you.definition: please be patient, i will attend to you soon. (often said by someone attending a sales counter or by an office receptionist.)
i\u2019ll be right with you.example: Mary: Oh, Miss? Clerk: I’ll be right with you

i\u2019ll be seeing you.definition: good-bye, i will see you sometime in the (near) future
i\u2019ll be seeing you.example: Bob: Bye. Be seeing you. Sally: Yeah. See you later

i\u2019ll bite.definition: okay, i will answer your question.; okay, i will listen to your joke or play your little guessing game
i\u2019ll bite.example: Bob: Guess what is in this box? Bill: I’ll bite. Bob: A new toaster!

i\u2019ll call back later.definition: a standard phrase indicating that a telephone caller will call again at a later time
i\u2019ll call back later.example: Sally: Is Bill there? Mary (speaking into the telephone): Sorry, he’s not here right now. Sally: I’ll call back later

i\u2019ll catch you later.definition: i will talk to you later
i\u2019ll catch you later.example: Mary: Got to f ly. See you around. Sally: Bye. Catch you later

i\u2019ll drink to that.definition: i agree with that! (originally used as a reply to a proposed toast.)
i\u2019ll drink to that.example: Great idea! I’ll drink to that

i\u2019ll eat my hat.definition: i will be very surprised. (used to express strong disbelief in something.)
i\u2019ll eat my hat.example: If Joe really joins the Army, I’ll eat my hat

i\u2019ll get right on it.definition: i will begin work on that immediately
i\u2019ll get right on it.example: Bob: Please do this report immediately. Fred: I’ll get right on it

i\u2019ll have to beg off.definition: a polite expression used to turn down an informal invitation
i\u2019ll have to beg off.example: Andrew: Thank you for inviting me, but I’ll have to beg off. I have a conf lict. Henry: I’m sorry to hear that. Maybe some other time

i\u2019ll have to let you go.definition: it is time to end this phone conversation
i\u2019ll have to let you go.example: Well, I’ll let you go. It’s getting late

i\u2019ll look you up when i\u2019m in t.definition: i will try to visit you or contact you the next time i am in town
i\u2019ll look you up when i\u2019m in t.example: Bill: I hope to see you again sometime. Mary: I’ll look you up when I’m in town

i\u2019ll put a stop to that.definition: i’ll see that the just-mentioned undesirable activity is stopped
i\u2019ll put a stop to that.example: Fred: There are two boys fighting in the hall. Bob: I’ll put a stop to that

i\u2019ll see you in a little while.definition: a phrase indicating that the speaker will see the person spoken to within a few hours at the most
i\u2019ll see you in a little while.example: John: I’ll see you in a little while. Jane: Okay. Bye till later

i\u2019ll see you next year.definition: a good-bye expression said toward the end of one year
i\u2019ll see you next year.example: Bob: Happy New Year! Sue: You, too! See you next year

i\u2019ll see you real soon.definition: good-bye. i will meet you again soon
i\u2019ll see you real soon.example: Bill: Bye, Sue. See you. Sue: See you real soon, Bill

i\u2019ll see you then.definition: i will see you at the time we’ve just agreed upon
i\u2019ll see you then.example: John: Can we meet at noon? Bill: Sure. See you then. Bye. John: Bye

i\u2019ll see you tomorrow.definition: i will see you when we meet again tomorrow. (typically said to someone whose daily schedule is the same as one’s own.)
i\u2019ll see you tomorrow.example: Bob: Bye, Jane. Jane: Good night, Bob. See you tomorrow

i\u2019ll talk to you soon.definition: i will talk to you on the telephone again soon
i\u2019ll talk to you soon.example: Sally: Bye now. Talk to you soon. John: Bye now

i\u2019ll thank you to keep your opinion.definition: i do not care about your opinion of this matter
i\u2019ll thank you to keep your opinion.example: Jane: This place is sort of drab. John: I’ll thank you to keep your opinions to yourself

i\u2019ll thank you to mind your own bus.definition: a version of mind your own business. (shows a little anger.)
i\u2019ll thank you to mind your own bus.example: Tom: How much did this cost? Jane: I’ll thank you to mind your own business

ill will.example: I hope you do not have any ill will toward me because of our argument

illdisposed to doing something.example: I am ill-disposed to doing hard labor

illgotten gains.definition: money or other possessions acquired in a dishonest or illegal fashion
illgotten gains.example: Bill cheated at cards and is now living on his ill-gotten gains

illuminate something with something.definition: to light up something with something
illuminate something with something.example: The lights illuminated the monument with a bright glow

illustrate something with something.definition: to provide pictorial examples for a book or other document
illustrate something with something.example: She illustrated her book with clever line drawings

i\u2019m busy.definition: do not bother me now.; i cannot attend to your needs now
i\u2019m busy.example: Bob: Can I talk to you? Bill: I’m busy. Bob: It’s important. Bill: Sorry, I’m busy!

i\u2019m cool.example: Bob: How you been? Fred: I’m cool, man. Yourself ? Bob: The same

i\u2019m damned if i do and damned if i.definition: there are problems if i do something and problems if i don’t do it
i\u2019m damned if i do and damned if i.example: I can’t win. I’m damned if I do and damned if I don’t

i\u2019m delighted to make your acquaint.definition: i am very glad to meet you
i\u2019m delighted to make your acquaint.example: Tom: My name is Tom. I work in the advertising department. Mary: I’m Mary. I work in accounting. Delighted to make your acquaintance. Tom: Yeah. Good to meet you

i\u2019m doing okay.example: Bob: How you doing? Bill: Doing okay. And you? Bob: Things could be worse

i\u2019m easy to please.definition: i accept that because i am not particular.; that’s okay with me
i\u2019m easy to please.example: Tom: Hey, man! Do you care if we get a sausage pizza rather than mushroom? Bob: Fine with me. I’m easy

i\u2019m feeling okay.definition: i am doing well.; i am feeling well
i\u2019m feeling okay.example: Alice: How are you feeling? Jane: I’m feeling okay

i\u2019m glad to hear it.definition: a phrase expressing pleasure at what the speaker has just said
i\u2019m glad to hear it.example: Sally: We have a new car, finally. Mary: I’m glad to hear it

i\u2019m having a wonderful time wish yo.definition: cliché a catchphrase that is thought to be written onto postcards by people who are away on vacation
i\u2019m having a wonderful time wish yo.example: John wrote on all his cards, “Having a wonderful time; wish you were here.” And he really meant it too

i\u2019m having quite a time.definition: i am having a very enjoyable time
i\u2019m having quite a time.example: John: Having fun? Jane: Oh, yes. I’m having quite a time

i\u2019m having the time of my life.definition: i am having the best time ever
i\u2019m having the time of my life.example: Bill: Are you having a good time, Mary? Mary: Don’t worry about me. I’m having the time of my life

i\u2019m just getting by.definition: an expression indicating that one is just surviving financially or otherwise
i\u2019m just getting by.example: Bob: How you doing, Tom? Tom: Just getting by, Bob

i\u2019m just minding my own business.definition: an answer to a greeting inquiry asking what one is doing. (this answer also can carry the implication “since i am minding my own business, why aren’t you minding your own business?”)
i\u2019m just minding my own business.example: Tom: Hey, man, what are you doing? Bill: Minding my own business. See you around

i\u2019m just plugging along.definition: i am doing satisfactorily.; i am just managing to function
i\u2019m just plugging along.example: Bill: How are things going? Bob: I’m just plugging along

i\u2019m just thinking out loud.definition: i’m saying things that might better remain as private thoughts. (a way of characterizing or introducing one’s opinions or thoughts. also past tense.)
i\u2019m just thinking out loud.example: Sue: What are you saying, anyway? Sounds like you’re scolding someone. Bob: Oh, sorry. I was just thinking out loud

i\u2019m like you.definition: an expression introducing a statement of a similarity that the speaker shares with the person spoken to
i\u2019m like you.example: Mary: And what do you think about this pair? Jane: I’m like you, I like the ones with lower heels

i\u2019m not finished with you.definition: i still have more to say to you
i\u2019m not finished with you.example: Bill started to turn away when he thought the scolding was finished. “I’m not finished with you,” bellowed his father

i\u2019m not kidding.definition: i am telling the truth.; i am not trying to fool you
i\u2019m not kidding.example: Mary: Those guys are all suspects in the robbery. Sue: No! They can’t be! Mary: I’m not kidding!

i\u2019m off.definition: an expression said by someone who is just leaving
i\u2019m off.example: Bob: Time to go. I’m off. Mary: Bye

i\u2019m pleased to meet you.definition: an expression said when introduced to someone. (very) glad to meet you.)
i\u2019m pleased to meet you.example: Tom: I’m Tom Thomas. Bill: Pleased to meet you. I’m Bill Franklin

i\u2019m really fed up with someone or s.definition: i have had enough of someone or something. something must be done
i\u2019m really fed up with someone or s.example: Tom: This place is really dull. John: Yeah. I’m fed up with it. I’m out of here!

i\u2019m sorry to hear that.definition: an expression of consolation or regret
i\u2019m sorry to hear that.example: John: My cat died last week. Jane: I’m sorry to hear that

i\u2019m sorry you asked that.definition: i regret that you asked about something i wanted to forget
i\u2019m sorry you asked that.example: Tom: What on earth is this hole in your suit jacket? Bill: I’m sorry you asked. I was feeding a squirrel and it bit through my pocket where the food was

i\u2019m speechless.definition: i am so surprised that i cannot think of anything to say
i\u2019m speechless.example: Mary: Fred and I eloped last week. Sally: I’m speechless

i\u2019m very glad to meet you.definition: a polite expression said to a person to whom one has just been introduced. pleased to meet you.)
i\u2019m very glad to meet you.example: Mary: I’d like you to meet my brother, Tom. Bill: I’m very glad to meet you, Tom

i\u2019m with you.definition: i agree with you.; i will join with you in doing what you suggest. (with a stress on both i and you.)
i\u2019m with you.example: Sally: I think this old bridge is sort of dangerous. Jane: I’m with you. Let’s go back another way

imagine someone or something as someone.definition: to think of someone or something as another person or another type of thing
imagine someone or something as someone.example: I really can’t imagine you as a sailor

imbue someone with something.definition: to indoctrinate someone with something; to build something into someone
imbue someone with something.example: I tried to imbue my children with a strong sense of justice

imitation is the sincerest form of flatt.definition: copying someone is flattering because it shows you want to be like that person
imitation is the sincerest form of flatt.example: Child: Susie’s doing everything I do. Make her stop. Mother: Don’t be cross with her. Imitation is the sincerest form of f lattery

immediate occupancy.definition: [of an apartment or house] ready to be moved into at this moment
immediate occupancy.example: This house is for immediate occupancy. You can move in today if you want

immerse someone or something in somethin.definition: to submerge someone or something beneath the surface of a liquid; to soak someone or something in a liquid
immerse someone or something in somethin.example: The preacher immersed the baptism candidate in the water

immigrate into some place from some plac.definition: to migrate into a place from some other place
immigrate into some place from some plac.example: Many of them immigrated into Minnesota from northern Europe

immunize someone against something.definition: to vaccinate someone against some disease; to do a medical procedure that causes a resistance or immunity to a disease to develop in a person
immunize someone against something.example: They wanted to immunize all the children against the measles
