impact upon someone or something.definition: [for something] to have an effect on someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
impact upon someone or something.example: This plant closing will impact upon the local economy for years to come

impale someone or something on something.definition: to put someone or something on a pointed object and press down
impale someone or something on something.example: The crowd had impaled an effigy of the dictator on a sharpened stick

impart something to someone or something.definition: to bestow a quality on someone or a group
impart something to someone or something.example: That hat imparts an aura of grandeur to her presence

impeach someone for something.definition: to charge someone with doing something illegal
impeach someone for something.example: You can’t impeach her for just disagreeing!

impinge upon someone or something.definition: to affect or interfere with someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
impinge upon someone or something.example: This will not impinge upon me at all

implant something into someone or someth.definition: to embed something into someone or something
implant something into someone or someth.example: The surgeon implanted a pacemaker into Fred

implicate someone in something.definition: to suggest that someone is involved in something
implicate someone in something.example: The mayor was implicated in the bribery scandal

import something from something into som.definition: to buy and transport something from a foreign place into a country
import something from something into som.example: We imported the carpets from the Orient into this country

impose something upon someone.definition: to force something on someone. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
impose something upon someone.example: Don’t try to impose your ideas upon me!

impose upon someone.definition: to be a bother to someone; to make a request of something to someone. (often refers to being an overnight guest or having a meal at someone’s house. upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
impose upon someone.example: I don’t mean to impose upon you, but could you put me up for the night?

impregnate something with something.definition: to saturate something with something; to penetrate something with some fluid
impregnate something with something.example: They impregnated the boards with a wood preservative

impress someone as something.definition: to be memorable to someone as a particular type of person
impress someone as something.example: She didn’t impress me as a particularly wise individual

impress someone by something.definition: to make someone notice one’s good qualities
impress someone by something.example: You impress me by your willingness to serve

impress someone with someone or somethin.definition: to awe someone with someone or something
impress someone with someone or somethin.example: Are you trying to impress me with your wisdom?

impress something into something.example: I impressed the key into the wax, making a perfect copy

impress something upon someone.definition: to make someone fully aware of something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
impress something upon someone.example: You must impress these facts upon everyone you meet

impress something upon something.definition: to press something into the surface of something, leaving a mark
impress something upon something.example: The ribbing of my socks impressed a pattern upon my calves

imprint something with something.definition: to print something with a message
imprint something with something.example: Amy imprinted each bookmark with her name

imprison someone in something.definition: to lock someone up in something
imprison someone in something.example: The authorities imprisoned him in a separate cell

improve upon something.definition: to make something better. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
improve upon something.example: Do you really think you can improve upon this song?

improvise on something.definition: [for a musician] to create a new piece of music on an existing musical theme
improvise on something.example: For an encore, the organist improvised on “Mary Had a Little Lamb.”

impute something to someone or something.definition: to ascribe something to someone or something; to attribute something to someone or something
impute something to someone or something.example: I didn’t mean to impute a bad intention to your company

in a bad mood.definition: sad; depressed; grouchy; with low spirits
in a bad mood.example: He’s in a bad mood. He may yell at you

in a big way.example: I’m really interested in her in a big way

in a blue funk.example: I’ve been in a blue funk all week

in a body.definition: as a group of people; as a group; in a group
in a body.example: The tour members always traveled in a body

in a cold sweat.example: He stood there in a cold sweat, waiting for something bad to happen

in a dead heat.definition: [finishing a race] at exactly the same time; tied
in a dead heat.example: The two horses finished the race in a dead heat

in a delicate condition.example: Are you sure you’re up for this hike? I know you’re in a delicate condition

in a dither.example: Mary is sort of in a dither lately

in a fix.example: I really got myself into a fix. I owe a lot of money on my taxes

in a flash.example: I’ll be there in a f lash

in a heartbeat.example: If I had the money, I would go back to college in a heartbeat

in a huff.definition: in an angry or offended manner
in a huff.example: He heard what we had to say, then left in a huff

in a jiffy.example: Just wait a minute. I’ll be there in a jiffy

in a lather.example: Now, calm down. Don’t be in a lather

in a little bit.definition: in a small amount of time
in a little bit.example: I will be there in a little bit. Please wait

in a mad rush.example: I ran around all day today in a mad rush, looking for a present for Bill

in a nutshell.definition: [of news or information] in a (figurative) capsule; in summary
in a nutshell.example: This cable channel provides the latest news in a nutshell

in a pinch.example: A piece of clothing can be used as a bandage in a pinch

in a pique.definition: having a feeling of resentment; feeling that one’s pride has been hurt
in a pique.example: In a real pique, Anne insulted all of her friends

in a pretty pickle.example: John has gotten himself into a pickle. He has two dates for the party

in a quandary.definition: uncertain about what to do; perplexed
in a quandary.example: Mary was in a quandary about what college to go to

in a rut.definition: in a type of boring habitual behavior. (as when the wheels of a buggy travel in the ruts worn into the ground by other buggies making it easiest to go exactly the way all the other buggies have gone before. *typically: be ~; get ~.)
in a rut.example: My life has gotten into a rut

in a sense.definition: in a way; in one way of looking at it
in a sense.example: In a sense, cars make life better

in a shambles.example: After the earthquake, the town lay in shambles

in a single file.definition: lined up, one behind the other; in a line, one person or one thing wide
in a single file.example: Have you ever seen ducks walking in single file?

in a snit.definition: in a fit of anger or irritation
in a snit.example: Don’t get in a snit. It was an accident

in a stage whisper.definition: in a loud whisper that everyone can hear
in a stage whisper.example: John said in a stage whisper, “This play is boring.”

in a stew about someone or something.definition: upset or bothered about someone or something
in a stew about someone or something.example: I’m in such a stew about my dog. She ran away last night

in a stupor.definition: in a dazed condition; in a condition in which one cannot concentrate or think
in a stupor.example: The drunk driver walked away from the car accident in a stupor

in a tight spot.definition: caught in a problem; in a jam
in a tight spot.example: Look, John, I’m in a tight spot. Can you lend me twenty dollars?

in a tizzy.definition: in an excited and confused condition
in a tizzy.example: John is in a tizzy because we’re an hour late

in a twit.example: She’s all in a twit because she lost her keys

in a twitter.example: Don’t get yourself in a twitter

in a vicious circle.definition: in a situation in which the solution of one problem leads to a second problem, and the solution of the second problem brings back the first problem, etc
in a vicious circle.example: Life is so strange. I seem to be in a vicious circle most of the time

in a world of one\u2019s own.example: John lives in a world of his own. He has very few friends

in abeyance.example: Until the judge determined that the evidence could be used in the trial, it was held in abeyance

in accord with someone or something abou.example: I am in complete accord with you about the policy changes

in accordance with something.definition: in agreement with something; in conformity with something
in accordance with something.example: In accordance with our discussion, I have prepared a contract

in addition to something.definition: additionally; further; moreover; as an additional thing or person
in addition to something.example: In addition, I would like for you to sweep the kitchen f loor

in advance.definition: [of something given, paid, or provided] before it is due
in advance.example: The bill isn’t due for a month, but I paid it in advance

in agreement with someone or something.definition: in conformity with someone or something; agreeing with someone or something

in all good conscience.definition: having good motives; displaying motives that will not result in a guilty conscience
in all good conscience.example: In all good conscience, I could not recommend that you buy this car

in all my born days.example: I’ve never seen such fireworks in all my born days

in all probability.example: He’ll be here on time in all probability

in an age of years.example: How have you been? I haven’t talked to you in an age of years

in an interesting condition.example: Young Mrs. Lutin is in an interesting condition

in an ivory tower.definition: in a place, such as a university, where one can be aloof from the realities of living
in an ivory tower.example: If you didn’t spend so much time in your ivory tower, you’d know what people really think!

in and of itself.example: The idea in and of itself is not bad, but the side issues introduce many difficulties

in any way shape or form.example: I refuse to tell a lie in any way, shape, or form!

in applepie order.definition: in very good order; very well organized
in applepie order.example: Please put everything in apple-pie order before you leave

in arrears.example: Jane’s student-loan payments are in arrears

in at one ear and out of the other.definition: heard but not remembered. (used to describe something that someone does not listen to.)
in at one ear and out of the other.example: Ellen: Did you tell Junior to be careful with the car when he drives it? Fred: Yes, but I think it went in one ear and out the other

in awe of someone or something.definition: fearful and respectful of someone or something
in awe of someone or something.example: Everyone in the country was in awe of the king and queen

in bad faith.definition: without sincerity; with bad or dishonest intent; with duplicity
in bad faith.example: It appears that you acted in bad faith and didn’t live up to the terms of our agreement

in bad sorts.example: Bill is in bad sorts today. He’s very grouchy

in bad with someone.example: I tried not to get in bad with Wally

in between.definition: located in the middle of two things, states, or possibilities
in between.example: The bath water is not hot or cold. It’s in between

in black and white.definition: [of an agreement, contract, or statement] official, in writing or printing
in black and white.example: I have it in black and white that I’m entitled to three weeks of vacation each year

in brief.example: The whole story, in brief, is that Bob failed algebra because he did not study

in broad daylight.definition: in the open light of day; clearly visible
in broad daylight.example: The crime was committed in broad daylight

in bulk.definition: in large quantities or amounts, rather than smaller, more convenient quantities or amounts
in bulk.example: Jane always bought office supplies in bulk to save money

in business.definition: operating; equipped or ready to operate
in business.example: We’re in business now, and things are running smoothly

in cahoots with someone.definition: in conspiracy with someone; in league with someone
in cahoots with someone.example: The mayor is in cahoots with the construction company that got the contract for the new building

in care of someone.definition: [to be delivered to someone] through someone or by way of someone. (indicates that mail is to be delivered to a person at some other person’s address.)
in care of someone.example: Bill Jones is living at his father’s house. Address the letter to Bill in care of Mr. John Jones

in case of something.definition: if a problem occurs; if something happens; in the event that something happens
in case of something.example: What do we do in case of fire?

in case something happens.definition: in the event that something takes place
in case something happens.example: She carries an umbrella in case it rains

in character.example: For Tom to shout that way wasn’t at all in character. He’s usually quite pleasant

in charge of someone or something.definition: in control of someone or something; having the responsibility for someone or something
in charge of someone or something.example: Who is in charge of this office?

in clover.definition: having good fortune; in a very good situation, especially financially
in clover.example: If I get this contract, I’ll be in clover for the rest of my life

in cold blood.definition: without feeling; with cruel intent. (frequently said of a crime, especially murder.)
in cold blood.example: The killer walked up and shot the woman in cold blood

in cold storage.definition: dead; in a state of death. (alludes to the actual storage of certain things, such as fur coats, in cold storerooms.)
in cold storage.example: Tom gets paid for putting his subjects in cold storage

in concert with someone.definition: in cooperation with someone; with the aid of someone
in concert with someone.example: Mrs. Smith planned the party in concert with her sister

in consequence of something.definition: as a result of something; because of something
in consequence of something.example: In consequence of the storm, there was no electricity

in consideration of something.definition: in return for something; as a result of something
in consideration of something.example: In consideration of your many years of service, we are pleased to present you with this gold watch

in contact with someone or something.definition: communicating with someone or a group; to share information with someone or a group
in contact with someone or something.example: I have been in contact with our supplier, who will deliver the part next week

in contempt of court.definition: showing disrespect for a judge or courtroom procedures
in contempt of court.example: The bailiff ejected the lawyer who was held in contempt

in control of someone or something.definition: in charge of someone or something
in control of someone or something.example: Who is in control of this place?

in debt.definition: having debts; having much debt; owing money

in deep.example: Mary and Sam are in deep

in deep water.definition: in a dangerous or vulnerable situation; in a serious situation, especially one that is too difficult or is beyond the level of one’s abilities; in trouble
in deep water.example: John is having trouble with back taxes. He’s in deep water

in defiance of someone or something.definition: against someone’s will or against instructions; in bold resistance to someone or someone’s orders
in defiance of someone or something.example: Jane spent the afternoon in the park in defiance of her mother’s instructions

in denial.definition: in a state of refusing to believe something that is true
in denial.example: Mary was in denial about her illness and refused treatment

in detail.definition: with lots of details; giving all the details. (often used with an adjective showing the level of detail, such as great, enormous, etc., as in the second example.)
in detail.example: I explained the policy to the customer in detail

in dire straits.definition: in a very serious, bad circumstance
in dire straits.example: We are nearly broke and need money for medicine. We are in dire straits

in disguise.definition: hidden behind a disguise; looking like something else
in disguise.example: Santa Claus was really the little child’s father in disguise

in drag.definition: wearing the clothing of the opposite sex. (usually refers to a man wearing women’s clothing.)
in drag.example: Two actors in drag did a skit about life on the farm

in dribs and drabs.definition: in small portions; bit by bit
in dribs and drabs.example: I’ll have to pay you what I owe you in dribs and drabs

in droves.example: The settlers arrived on the prairie in droves

in dutch with someone.example: I’m in Dutch with my parents for my low grades

in earnest.example: I’ve done all the research I need. I spent the day writing the paper in earnest

in effect.example: In effect, this new law will raise taxes for most people

in essence.example: I have lots of detailed advice for you, but in essence, I want you to do the best you can

in exchange for someone or something.definition: in return for someone or something
in exchange for someone or something.example: They gave us two of our prisoners in exchange for two of theirs

in existence.definition: now existing; currently and actually being
in existence.example: The tiger may not be in existence in a few decades

in fact.example: I’m over forty. In fact, I’m forty-six

in fashion.definition: in style; current and socially acceptable
in fashion.example: Is that kind of thing still in fashion?

in favor of someone.definition: to someone, as when writing a check
in favor of someone.example: Please make out a check for $300 in Tom’s favor

in favor of someone or something.definition: approving, supporting, or endorsing someone or something
in favor of someone or something.example: Are you in favor of lower taxes?

in fear and trembling.definition: cliché with anxiety or fear; with dread
in fear and trembling.example: In fear and trembling, I went into the room to take the test

in fine feather.definition: well dressed; of an excellent appearance. (alludes to a bird that has clean, bright, and flawless feathers.)
in fine feather.example: Well, you are certainly in fine feather today

in flight.example: A passenger became ill in f light and the pilot had to return to the airport

in focus.definition: [of an image] seen clearly and sharply
in focus.example: I have the slide in focus and can see the bacteria clearly. 2.  [for optics, such as lenses, or an optical device, such as a microscope] to be aligned to allow something to be seen clearly and sharply

in force.definition: [of a rule or law] currently valid or in effect
in force.example: Is this rule in force now?

in general.definition: referring to the entire class being discussed; speaking of the entire range of possibilities; in most situations or circumstances
in general.example: I like vegetables in general, but not beets

in glowing terms.definition: using words of praise; using complimentary expressions
in glowing terms.example: The college president described his accomplishments in glowing terms and awarded him with an honorary degree

in good faith.definition: with good and honest intent; with sincerity
in good faith.example: We are convinced you were acting in good faith, even though you made a serious error

in good hands.definition: in the safe, competent care of someone
in good hands.example: Don’t worry. Your children are in good hands. Sally is an experienced baby-sitter

in good repair.definition: operating well; well taken care of. (usually said of a thing rather than a person.)
in good repair.example: The house is in good repair and ought to attract a number of potential buyers

in good spirits.definition: happy and cheerful; positive and looking toward the future, despite unhappy circumstances
in good spirits.example: The patient is in good spirits and that will speed her recovery

in great demand.example: Liz is in great demand as a singer

in great haste.definition: very fast; in a big hurry
in great haste.example: John always did his homework in great haste

in hand.example: It’s in hand. I have it right here

in harm\u2019s way.definition: liable to be harmed; subject to potential causes of harm
in harm\u2019s way.example: Soldiers are expected to know what to do when they are in harm’s way

in harmony with someone or something.definition: in musical concord with someone or something
in harmony with someone or something.example: This part is in harmony with the tenor’s solo

in heat.definition: in a period of sexual excitement; in estrus. (estrus is the period of time in which females are most willing to breed. this expression is usually used for animals. it has been used for humans in a joking sense. *typically: be ~; get [into] ~; go [into] ~.)

in heaven.definition: in a state of absolute bliss or happiness
in heaven.example: Lisa was in heaven after winning the lottery

in high dudgeon.definition: feeling or exhibiting great resentment; taking great offense at something. (often with leave.)
in high dudgeon.example: After the rude remarks, the person who was insulted left in high dudgeon

in high hopes of something.example: I was in hopes of getting there early

in hock.example: After buying the luxury car, Bob was in hock for years

in hog heaven.definition: very happy; having a wonderful time
in hog heaven.example: Bill’s a fan of Clark Gable, so when the movie theater had a Clark Gable movie festival, Bill was in hog heaven

in honor of someone or something.definition: showing respect or admiration for someone or something
in honor of someone or something.example: Our club gave a party in honor of the club’s president

in horror.example: Mike stepped back from the rattlesnake in horror

in hot water with someone about someone.example: You are going to get into hot water with Rebecca about that

in ink.definition: written or signed with a pen that uses ink, not with a pencil
in ink.example: You should write your report in ink

in jeopardy.definition: to be at risk; to be at peril
in jeopardy.example: John puts himself in jeopardy every time he goes skydiving

in kind.definition: in goods rather than in money
in kind.example: The country doctor was usually paid in kind. He accepted two pigs as payment for an operation

in labor.definition: [of a woman] experiencing the pains and exertion of childbirth
in labor.example: Susan was in labor for nearly eight hours

in league with someone.definition: [of people] secretly cooperating, often to do something bad or illegal
in league with someone.example: The county sheriff is in league with criminals

in less than no time.example: I’ll be there in less than no time

in lieu of something.definition: in place of something; instead of something. (the word lieu occurs only in this phrase.)
in lieu of something.example: They gave me roast beef in lieu of ham

in limbo.definition: a region of the afterlife on the border of hell. (in some christian religions, there is a limbo set aside for souls that do not go to either heaven or hell. this sense is used only in this religious context. *typically: be ~; remain ~; stay ~.)
in limbo.example: The baby’s soul was in limbo because she had not been baptized. 2.  in a state of neglect; in a state of oblivion; in an indefinite state; on hold

in love with someone or something.definition: feeling love for someone or something; experiencing a strong affectionate emotion for someone or something
in love with someone or something.example: Mary was in love with her new car! It was perfect for her

in low cotton.example: She was in low cotton because her dress got torn

in luck.example: You want a red one? You’re in luck. There is one red one left

in marching order.definition: organized and equipped; ready to go. (originally military.)
in marching order.example: Is our luggage all packed and in marching order?

in memory of someone.definition: to continue the good memories of someone; for the honor of a deceased person
in memory of someone.example: Many streets were renamed in memory of John F. Kennedy

in midair.definition: in a point high in the air

in mint condition.example: This is a fine car. It runs well and is in mint condition

in my humble opinion.definition: cliché a phrase introducing the speaker’s opinion
in my humble opinion.example: “In my humble opinion,” began Fred, arrogantly, “I have achieved what no one else ever could.”

in name only.definition: nominally; not actual, only by terminology
in name only.example: The president is head of the country in name only. Congress makes the laws

in need of something.definition: [of someone or an animal] to require something
in need of something.example: We are in need of a new car

in neutral.definition: with the shift lever of a vehicle in the position where the motor is running but is not powering the wheels or other moving parts
in neutral.example: The car rolled down the hill because I’d left it in neutral and did not put on the brake

in no mood to do something.definition: not feeling like doing something; not wishing to do something
in no mood to do something.example: I’m in no mood to cook dinner tonight

in no time at all.definition: very quickly. (compare this with in less than no time.)
in no time at all.example: I’ll be there in no time

in no uncertain terms.definition: cliché in very specific and direct language
in no uncertain terms.example: I was so mad. I told her in no uncertain terms to leave and never come back

in on the act.definition: involved in something with someone else. (often refers to an unwelcome attempt to join someone’s performance. *typically: be ~; get ~; let someone ~.)
in on the act.example: Everybody wants to get in on the act

in on the ground floor.definition: involved at the very beginning of something. (alludes to riding in an elevator that will become increasingly crowded as it ascends. you will be able to get in most easily at the lowest level. *typically: be ~; get ~; let someone ~.)
in on the ground floor.example: If you are starting a new project, I want to get in on the ground floor

in one\u2019s birthday suit.definition: naked; nude. (in the “clothes” in which one was born. *typically: be ~; get [into] ~.)
in one\u2019s birthday suit.example: I’ve heard that John sleeps in his birthday suit

in one\u2019s cups.example: She doesn’t make much sense when she’s in her cups

in one\u2019s element.definition: in a natural or comfortable situation or environment
in one\u2019s element.example: Sally is in her element when she’s working with algebra or calculus

in one\u2019s glory.example: When I go to the beach on vacation, I’m in my glory

in one\u2019s mind\u2019s eye.definition: in one’s mind or imagination. (alludes to visualizing something in one’s mind.)
in one\u2019s mind\u2019s eye.example: In my mind’s eye, I can see trouble ahead

in one\u2019s opinion.definition: according to one’s belief or judgment
in one\u2019s opinion.example: In my opinion, that is a very ugly picture

in one\u2019s or its prime.definition: at one’s or its peak or best time
in one\u2019s or its prime.example: Our dog—which is in its prime—is very active

in one\u2019s own backyard.definition: very close to one, where one lives, or where one is
in one\u2019s own backyard.example: That kind of thing is quite rare. Imagine it happening right in your backyard

in one\u2019s own best interests.definition: to one’s advantage; as a benefit to oneself
in one\u2019s own best interests.example: It is not in your own interests to share your ideas with Jack. He will say that they are his

in one\u2019s own way.definition: as the best one can do; using a personal and individual strategy
in one\u2019s own way.example: I don’t know the answer to the problem, but perhaps I can help in my own way

in one\u2019s right mind.definition: sane; rational and sensible. (often in the negative.)
in one\u2019s right mind.example: That was a stupid thing to do. You’re not in your right mind

in one\u2019s salad days.definition: in one’s youth. (usually formal or literary. comparing the greenness of a salad with the greenness, or freshness and inexperience, of youth.)
in one\u2019s salad days.example: I recall the joys I experienced on school vacations in my salad days

in one\u2019s second childhood.definition: [of an adult] interested in things or people that normally interest children
in one\u2019s second childhood.example: My father bought himself a toy train, and my mother said he was in his second childhood

in one\u2019s spare time.definition: in one’s extra time; in the time not reserved for work or doing something else
in one\u2019s spare time.example: I write novels in my spare time

in one\u2019s sunday best.definition: in one’s best clothes; in the clothes one wears to church
in one\u2019s sunday best.example: All the children were dressed up in their Sunday best

in opposition to someone or something.definition: against someone or something; opposing someone or something
in opposition to someone or something.example: You’ll find that I’m firmly in opposition to any further expenditures

in orbit.example: The moon is in orbit around the earth

in order.example: Please get your desk in order

in order to do something.definition: for the purpose of doing something; as a means of doing something
in order to do something.example: I went to college in order to further my education

in other words.definition: a phrase introducing a restatement of what has just been said
in other words.example: Henry: Sure I want to do it, but how much do I get paid? Andrew: In other words, you’re just doing it for the money

in over one\u2019s head with someone or.definition: in water that is deeper than one is tall
in over one\u2019s head with someone or.example: Johnny! Don’t go out too far! You are in over your head. 2.  too deeply involved with someone or something, beyond what one can deal with

in park.definition: [of an automobile transmission] having the gears locked so the automobile cannot move
in park.example: The driver stopped the car and placed it in park

in part.definition: partly; to a lesser degree or extent
in part.example: I was not there, in part because of my disagreement about the purpose of the meeting. I also had a previous appointment

in particular.example: I’m not going anywhere in particular

in passing.definition: casually; said or mentioned as an aside
in passing.example: I just heard your name in passing. I didn’t hear more than that

in pencil.definition: written or signed with a pencil
in pencil.example: Why did you write your report in pencil?

in perpetuity.definition: for an indefinitely long period of time; eternally
in perpetuity.example: My trust fund generates income in perpetuity

in person.definition: [of someone] actually physically present in a place rather than appearing in a film, on a television or computer screen, on a telephone, or through a radio broadcast
in person.example: All the famous movie stars were there in person

in perspective.definition: within a reasonable view or appraisal
in perspective.example: Let’s try to keep everything in perspective

in place.definition: in (someone’s or something’s) proper place or location
in place.example: The maid came into the room and put everything into place

in place of someone or something.definition: instead of someone or something; as a substitute for someone or something
in place of someone or something.example: I changed my mind. I want a red one in place of the blue one

in play.definition: [of a ball, in a game] under the effect of the rules of the game
in play.example: The ball is in play again and the activity is furious

in point of fact.definition: just to point out a fact; in fact
in point of fact.example: In point of fact, I am not late. You are simply way too early

in practice.definition: in the actual doing of something; in reality
in practice.example: Our policy is to be very particular, but in practice we don’t care that much

in press.definition: [of a book or other document] in the process of being printed
in press.example: This book is in press. It won’t be available for at least two months

in print.definition: [of a book, magazine, newspaper, or other written material] to be available from the publisher
in print.example: Ten thousand copies of the first edition remain in print

in private.example: I’d like to speak to you in private

in progress.definition: under way; happening; developing or moving right now
in progress.example: Don’t enter the studio. There’s a show in progress

in proportion.definition: showing the correct size or proportion relative to something else
in proportion.example: That man’s large head is not in proportion to his small body

in public.definition: in a place or way so that other people can see or know about something
in public.example: It’s illegal to walk naked in public

in pursuit of something.example: Bill spends most of his time in pursuit of money

in rags.example: Oh, look at my clothing. I can’t go to the party in rags!

in rare form.definition: well prepared for a good performance; at one’s best
in rare form.example: The goalie is in rare form today; that’s his third great save already

in reality.example: Jane dreamed it was snowing, but in reality, it was very warm

in receipt of something.definition: in a state of having received something. (used in business correspondence.)
in receipt of something.example: We are in receipt of your letter of request

in recent memory.definition: the period of time in which things are still remembered and discussed
in recent memory.example: Never in recent memory has there been this much snow!

in reduced circumstances.example: After Frederick lost his position, we lived in reduced circumstances while waiting for my inheritance

in rehearsal.definition: a stage of development in the production of a play, opera, or concert, involving many rehearsals
in rehearsal.example: The play is in rehearsal now and will open next month

in relation to someone or something.definition: relating to someone or something; in connection with someone or something
in relation to someone or something.example: I mention this fact in relation to your proposed trip

in remission.definition: [of a serious disease] not worsening or progressing
in remission.example: While the disease was in remission, John got to leave the hospital

in return for someone or something.definition: by way of giving something back; as a way of paying someone back for something; as part of an exchange
in return for someone or something.example: I helped Tom yesterday, and he helped me in return for my efforts

in ruins.example: The enemy army left the cities they attacked in ruins

in season.definition: [of a game animal] subject to legal hunting
in season.example: You cannot shoot ducks. They are not in season. 2. [of a female animal] ready to breed; in estrus; in heat

in secret.example: They planned in secret to blow up the bridge

in session.definition: [of a court, congress, or other organization] operating or functioning
in session.example: Use of cameras is forbidden while the meeting is in session

in seventh heaven.example: Ann was really in seventh heaven when she got a car of her own

in short.example: At the end of the financial report, the board president said, “In short, we are okay.”

in short order.example: I can straighten out this mess in short order

in short supply.example: Fresh vegetables are in short supply in the winter

in sight.definition: within the range of vision; visible

in so many words.definition: exactly; explicitly; in plain, clear language
in so many words.example: I told her in so many words to leave me alone

in some neck of the woods.definition: in some vicinity or neighborhood; in some remote place. (the some is usually this, that, your, their, etc. can be used to refer to some specific section of a forest.)
in some neck of the woods.example: I think that the Smiths live in your neck of the woods

in someone\u2019s face.definition: sl. in a provocative attitude, as if ready to fight or argue
in someone\u2019s face.example: Ted’s a real pain. He likes to get in your face. He’ll argue about anything

in someone\u2019s favor.definition: to someone’s advantage or credit. (especially in sports scores, as in the examples.)
in someone\u2019s favor.example: The score was ten to twelve in our favor

in someone\u2019s good graces.definition: in good with someone; in someone’s favor
in someone\u2019s good graces.example: I’m not in her good graces so I shouldn’t be the one to ask her

in someone\u2019s hair.example: My bubble gum got in my hair and I had to cut it out. 2.  annoying someone

in someone\u2019s possession.definition: held by someone; owned by someone
in someone\u2019s possession.example: The book is now in my possession

in someone\u2019s prayers.definition: [of someone] remembered and called by name when someone prays
in someone\u2019s prayers.example: I am sorry to hear of your sickness. You will be in our prayers

in spades.definition: in the best or most extreme way possible; extravagantly
in spades.example: He f lunked the test in spades

in spite of someone or something.definition: without regard to someone or something; even though another course had been prescribed; ignoring a warning
in spite of someone or something.example: In spite of her orders to stay, I left

in step with someone.definition: [marching or dancing] in cadence with another person
in step with someone.example: Please keep in step with Jane

in step with someone or something.definition: as up-to-date as someone or something
in step with someone or something.example: Bob is not in step with the times

in stitches.example: Charlie had us in stitches with all his jokes

in stock.definition: to have merchandise available and ready for sale
in stock.example: Do you have extra-large sizes in stock?

in storage.definition: in a place where things are stored or kept
in storage.example: Mary placed her winter clothes in storage during the summer

in store for someone.example: None of us knows what lies in store for us tomorrow

in style.example: This old coat isn’t in style anymore

in surgery.definition: to be involved in surgery. (can refer to a doctor, nurse, or patients.)
in surgery.example: Dr. Smith is in surgery now

in tandem.definition: [of two or more things] in single file
in tandem.example: We marched to the door in tandem

in tatters.example: The poor man’s clothes hung in tatters

in terms of something.example: I don’t know what to do in terms of John’s problem

in the absence of someone or something.definition: while someone or something isn’t here; without someone or something
in the absence of someone or something.example: In the absence of the cook, I’ll prepare dinner

in the act of doing something.example: There he was, in the act of opening the door

in the affirmative.definition: in the form of an answer that means yes
in the affirmative.example: The soldier answered in the affirmative by nodding his head “yes.”

in the air.example: There is such a feeling of joy in the air

in the back.definition: in the back part of a building; in the back room of a building
in the back.example: I don’t have your size here, but perhaps I can find it in the back

in the back of someone\u2019s mind.definition: remembered by someone, but not very important; vaguely remembered by someone
in the back of someone\u2019s mind.example: You should put this problem in the back of your mind and concentrate on other things

in the bag.example: It’s in the bag—as good as done

in the balance.definition: in an undecided state; at risk
in the balance.example: He stood on the edge of the cliff, his life in the balance

in the ballpark.definition: within certain boundaries; [of an estimate] close to what is expected

interact with something.definition: to have a reciprocal action with something; to react with something. (often refers to the negative consequences of interaction.)

interest someone in someone or something.definition: to arouse the interest of someone in someone or something

interest someone in something.definition: to cause someone to wish to purchase something

interject someone into something.definition: to force someone into something, usually into someone else’s business

interject something into something.definition: to volunteer information or a comment into a conversation

interpose someone or something between p.definition: to put someone or something between people or things, in any combination

interpose something into something.definition: to introduce something into something; to put a question into a conversation

interpret something as something.definition: to assume that something means something

interpret something for someone.definition: to translate a foreign language for someone. (interpreting is done in real time.)

intersperse something among something.definition: to place something among things at random

intervene between someone and someone el.definition: to intercede between someone and someone else

intervene in something.example: I will have to intervene in this matter. It’s getting out of hand

intervene with someone or something.definition: to step into a matter concerning someone or something

interview someone for something.definition: [for an employer] to discuss employment in a particular job with a person seeking employment
interview someone for something.example: We will interview her for the manager’s job

intimate apparel.example: “You’ll find bras and body shapers in the intimate apparel,” said the salesclerk at the department store

intimate something to someone.definition: to suggest or imply something to someone

intimate with someone.definition: euph. having sexual intercourse with someone

intimidate someone into something.definition: to threaten or frighten someone into doing something
intimidate someone into something.example: Do you think you can intimidate me into working for you?

intimidate someone with something.definition: to threaten or frighten someone with something

into a jam.example: Mary cannot keep track of the many times Dave got himself into a jam

into being.example: The new law brought more problems into being

into someone\u2019s clutches.definition: in the control of someone who has power or authority over someone else
into someone\u2019s clutches.example: Snow White fell into the clutches of the evil witch

intoxicate someone with someone or somet.definition: to enthrall or entrance someone with someone or something

intoxicate someone with something.definition: to make someone drunk with alcohol
intoxicate someone with something.example: I think that the plaintiff set out to intoxicate the defendant with liquor and then fake a crime

intrigue someone with someone or somethi.definition: to fascinate someone with someone or something
intrigue someone with someone or somethi.example: Walter intrigued the baby with his keys and funny faces

intrigue with someone against someone.definition: to conspire with someone against someone

introduce someone into something.definition: to bring someone into something; to launch someone into something
introduce someone into something.example: Tony introduced Wally into his club

introduce someone to someone.definition: to make someone acquainted with someone else

introduce something into something.definition: to bring something into something or some place; to bring something into something as an innovation

intrude into something.definition: to get involved in something that is someone else’s business

inundate someone or something with somet.definition: to flood someone or something with fluid

inure someone or something to something.definition: to accustom someone to someone or something

inveigh against someone or something.definition: to attack someone or something verbally

inveigle someone into something.example: We tried to inveigle her into attending, but she caught on to us

invest someone with something.definition: to endow someone with something, such as power or privilege

invite someone out.definition: to ask someone out on a date

invite someone over for something.definition: to bid or request someone to come to one’s house for something, such as a meal, party, chat, cards, etc

invite someone to something.definition: to bid or request someone to come to an event
invite someone to something.example: Shall we invite Sally to the party?

invoke something upon someone or somethi.definition: to call something, such as judgment, power, wrath of god, etc., to deal with someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)

involve someone in something.definition: to draw someone into a matter or problem

involve someone with someone or somethin.definition: to cause someone to associate with someone or something

involved with someone.example: Sally is getting involved with Bill. They’ve been seeing a lot of each other

involved with something.definition: established in an association with something or some organization
involved with something.example: Bill got involved with a volunteer organization

iron something out.definition: to use a flatiron to make cloth flat or smooth
iron something out.example: I will iron the drapes out, so they will hang together

is anything going on.definition: is there anything exciting or interesting happening here?
is anything going on.example: Andrew: Hey, man! Anything going on? Henry: No. This place is dull as can be

is everything okay.definition: how are you?; how are things?
is everything okay.example: John: Hi, Mary. Is everything okay? Mary: Sure. What about you? John: I’m okay

is it cold enough for you.definition: a greeting inquiry made during very cold weather
is it cold enough for you.example: Bob: Hi, Bill! Is it cold enough for you? Bill: It’s unbelievable!

is it hot enough for you.definition: a greeting inquiry made during very hot weather
is it hot enough for you.example: Bob: Hi, Bill! Is it hot enough for you? Bill: Yup

is there any truth to something.definition: is something true?; is what i have heard true? (no truth to in the negative.)

is this seat taken.definition: an inquiry made by a person in a theater, auditorium, etc., asking someone already seated whether an adjacent seat is available or already taken

isolate someone or something from someon.definition: to keep people or things separated from one another, in any combination

issue a call for something.definition: to make a public invitation or request for something

issue forth from some place.definition: to go out or come out of a place

it ain\u2019t fittin\u2019.definition: it is not right; it is inappropriate
it ain\u2019t fittin\u2019.example: It ain’t fittin’ for the bridegroom to see his bride before the ceremony

it behooves one to do something.definition: cliché it is necessary for one to do something; it is incumbent (up)on someone to do something
it behooves one to do something.example: It behooves me to report the crime

it blows my mind.definition: sl. it really amazes and shocks me
it blows my mind.example: Bill: Did you hear about Tom’s winning the lottery? Sue: Yes, it blows my mind!

it cuts two ways.definition: there are two sides to the situation
it cuts two ways.example: You have to help, too. It cuts two ways

it don\u2019t bother me none.definition: it does not affect me one way or the other.; it doesn’t bother me any. (familiar and ungrammatical. sometimes used for effect.)

it figures.definition: it makes sense.; it confirms what one might have guessed.; i’m not surprised
it figures.example: Bob: Tom was the one who broke the window. Bill: It figures. He’s very careless

it has someone\u2019s name on it.definition: it belongs to someone.; it is meant for someone

it is a long lane that has no turning.definition: bad times cannot continue forever.; things will soon improve

it is a wise child that knows its own fa.definition: you can never have certain proof that a certain man is your father. (implies that the child in question might be illegitimate.)

it is better to be born lucky than rich.definition: if you are born rich, you may lose your money, but if you are born lucky, you will always get what you need or want just by chance

it is better to travel hopefully than to.definition: you should enjoy the process of doing something, rather than anticipate the result of doing it

it is better to wear out than to rust ou.definition: it is better to work until you die than to be idle just because you are old

it is easier to tear down than to build.definition: destroying things is easier than building them

it is never too late to mend.definition: it is never too late to apologize for something you have done or try to repair something you have done wrong

it never rains but it pours.definition: good (or bad) things do not just happen a few at a time, but in large numbers all at once

it only stands to reason.definition: it is only reasonable to hold a certain opinion

it really doesn\u2019t matter to me.example: Andrew: What shall I do? What shall I do? Alice: Do whatever you like. Jump off a bridge. Go live in the jungle. It really doesn’t matter to me

it\u2019s a dead cinch.definition: it’s a very easy task. (dead means absolutely.)

it\u2019s a deal.example: You want to sell me your stereo for $100? It’s a deal

it\u2019s ill waiting for dead men\u2019.definition: you should not be eager for someone to die so that you inherit something

it\u2019s no picnic.definition: there is nothing easy or pleasant about it

it \u2019s no trouble at all.definition: do not worry, this is not a problem

it \u2019s not half bad.definition: it’s not as bad as one might have thought

it\u2019s on me.definition: i will pay this bill. (usually a bill for a meal or drinks. compare this with this one’s on me.)
it\u2019s on me.example: As the waiter set down the glasses, Fred said, “It’s on me,” and grabbed the check

it\u2019s six of one half a dozen of ano.example: To get downtown, we can either take the highway or the side streets. It’s six of one, half a dozen of another, since both routes take the same amount of time

it \u2019s time for a change.definition: an expression announcing a decision to make a change

it\u2019s time we should be going.example: Mr. Franklin looked at his wife and said softly, “It’s time we should be going.”

it\u2019s written all over one\u2019s fa.definition: it is very evident and can easily be detected when looking at someone’s face

it\u2019s you.definition: it suits you perfectly.; it is just your style

it\u2019s your funeral.definition: if that is what you are going to do, you will have to endure the dire consequences

it strikes me that.example: Henry: It strikes me that you are losing a little weight. Mary: Oh, I’m so glad you noticed!

it takes money to make money.definition: in order to make money, you must first have some money to invest

let grass grow under one\u2019s feet.definition: to do nothing; to stand still
