let it all hang out.definition: to be yourself, assuming that you generally are not; to become totally relaxed and unpretentious
let it all hang out.example: Come on. Relax! Let it all hang out

let it be.definition: leave the situation alone as it is
let it be.example: Alice: I can’t get over the way he just left me there on the street and drove off. What an arrogant pig! Mary: Oh, Alice, let it be. You’ll figure out some way to get even

let it go.definition: forget it.; stop worrying about it
let it go.example: Don’t get so angry about it. Let it go

let loose of someone or something.definition: to loosen the grasp on someone or something

let on about someone or something to som.definition: to confirm or reveal something about someone or something
let on about someone or something to som.example: I won’t let on about Kate

let on something.example: She let on that she was a college graduate

let on to someone about someone or somet.definition: to reveal knowledge about someone or something to someone
let on to someone about someone or somet.example: Please don’t let on to anyone about what happened last night

let one\u2019s emotions show.definition: to be emotional, especially where it is not appropriate
let one\u2019s emotions show.example: I’m sorry for the outburst. I didn’t mean to let my emotions show

let one\u2019s guard down.definition: to stop guarding oneself against trouble; to relax one’s vigilance
let one\u2019s guard down.example: He never lets his guard down because he trusts no one

let one\u2019s hair down.definition: to undo one’s hair and let it fall freely
let one\u2019s hair down.example: When she took off her glasses and let her hair down, she was incredibly beautiful. 2.  to tell [someone] everything; to tell one’s innermost feelings and secrets

let oneself go.definition: to become less constrained; to get excited and have a good time
let oneself go.example: I love to dance and just let myself go

let oneself in for something.definition: to make oneself vulnerable to some difficulty
let oneself in for something.example: I don’t want to let myself in for a lot of extra work

let out.definition: [for an event that includes many people] to end. (the people are then permitted to come out.)
let out.example: What time does the movie let out? I have to meet someone in the lobby

let out some kind of sound.definition: [for a living creature] to make some kind of a noise or sound
let out some kind of sound.example: Be quiet. Don’t let out a sound!

let out with something.definition: to state or utter something loudly
let out with something.example: The man let out with a screaming accusation about the person whom he thought had wounded him

let\u2019s bump this place.definition: sl. let’s get out of this place!; let’s leave!
let\u2019s bump this place.example: Time to go. Let’s bump this place!

let\u2019s call it a day.definition: let us end what we are doing for the day
let\u2019s call it a day.example: Mary: Well, that’s the end of the reports. Nothing else to do. Sue: Let’s call it a day

let\u2019s get down to business.definition: a phrase marking a transition to a business discussion or serious talk
let\u2019s get down to business.example: John: Okay, enough small talk. Let’s get down to business. Mary: Good idea

let\u2019s get out of here.definition: let us leave (and go somewhere else)
let\u2019s get out of here.example: Alice: It’s really hot in this room. Let’s get out of here. John: I’m with you. Let’s go

let\u2019s get together sometime.definition: a vague invitation to meet again, usually said upon departing. (the sometime can be a particular time or the word sometime.)
let\u2019s get together sometime.example: Bill: Goodbye, Bob. Bob: See you, Bill. Let’s get together sometime

let\u2019s go somewhere where it\u2019s.definition: let us continue our conversation where there is less noise or where we will not be disturbed
let\u2019s go somewhere where it\u2019s.example: Tom: Hi, Mary. It’s sure crowded here. Mary: Yes, let’s go somewhere where it’s quiet

let\u2019s not go through all that again.definition: we are not going to discuss that matter again. (compare this with do we have to go through all that again?)
let\u2019s not go through all that again.example: Bill: Now, I still want to explain again about last night. Sally: Let’s not go through all that again!

let\u2019s rock and roll.definition: let’s get started!; let’s get moving!
let\u2019s rock and roll.example: A: Everybody ready? B: Yeah. A: Good. Let’s rock and roll!

let\u2019s say.definition: introduces an estimate or a speculation

let\u2019s shake on it.definition: let us mark this agreement by shaking hands on it
let\u2019s shake on it.example: Bob: Do you agree? Mary: I agree. Let’s shake on it. Bob: Okay

let\u2019s talk about it.definition: let us talk about the problem and try to settle things
let\u2019s talk about it.example: Tom: Bill! Bill! I’m sorry about our argument. Let’s talk. Bill: Get lost!

let sleeping dogs lie.definition: do not instigate trouble.; leave something alone if it might cause trouble
let sleeping dogs lie.example: Jill: Should I ask the boss if he’s upset at my coming in late in the mornings? Jane: If he hasn’t said anything about it, just let sleeping dogs lie

let someone down.definition: to disappoint someone; to fail someone
let someone down.example: I’m sorry I let you down. Something came up, and I couldn’t meet you

let someone get by with something.definition: to allow someone to do something wrong and not be punished or reprimanded. (an elaboration of get by (with something).)
let someone get by with something.example: She lets those kids get by with anything

let someone get off something.definition: to permit someone to disembark, dismount, or leave something
let someone get off something.example: Please move and let me get off the bus

let someone get on with something.definition: to permit someone to continue something
let someone get on with something.example: I will leave now and let you get on with your work

let someone get past.definition: to allow someone to pass; to get out of the way so someone can pass
let someone get past.example: Please let me get past. I’m in a hurry

let someone go.example: They let Jane go from her job

let someone have it with both barrels.definition: to strike someone or attack someone verbally. (with both barrels intensifies the phrase; it alludes to firing a double-barreled shotgun.)
let someone have it with both barrels.example: I really let Tom have it with both barrels. I told him he had better not do that again if he knows what’s good for him

let someone in for something.definition: to cause someone to be involved in something, usually something unpleasant
let someone in for something.example: Fred had no idea what his brother had let him in for when he agreed to take his place in the race

let someone know about something.definition: to tell someone something; to inform someone of something
let someone know about something.example: Please let me know about it soon

let someone or an animal get out of some.definition: to permit someone or an animal to exit or escape from something or some place
let someone or an animal get out of some.example: Please let the president get out of the car

let someone or something at someone or s.definition: to permit someone or something to attack or get at someone or something
let someone or something at someone or s.example: He did that? Just let me at him!

let someone or something down.definition: to fail someone or something; to disappoint someone or a group
let someone or something down.example: Please don’t let me down. I am depending on you

let someone or something through somethi.definition: to permit someone or something to move through an opening or through a congested area
let someone or something through somethi.example: The usher wouldn’t let me through the door

let someone slide by.definition: to permit someone to get past a barrier or a challenge too easily
let someone slide by.example: You let too many students slide by. You need to be more rigorous

let something off.definition: to release something; to give something off
let something off.example: The engine let some evil smelling smoke off

let something out.definition: to reveal something; to tell about a secret or a plan
let something out.example: It was supposed to be a secret. Who let it out?

let something out to someone.example: I let the back room out to a college boy

let something pass.definition: to let something go unnoticed or unchallenged
let something pass.example: Bob let Bill’s insult pass because he didn’t want to argue

let something ride.definition: to allow something to continue or remain as it is
let something ride.example: It isn’t the best plan, but we’ll let it ride

let something slip out.definition: to reveal a secret carelessly or by accident
let something slip out.example: I didn’t let it slip out on purpose. It was an accident

let the buyer beware.definition: clichéwhen you buy something, you must take precautions against being cheated, because you cannot trust merchants to be honest about what they sell
let the buyer beware.example: Let the buyer beware when shopping for a used car

let the cat out of the bag.definition: to reveal a secret or a surprise by accident
let the cat out of the bag.example: When Bill glanced at the door, he let the cat out of the bag. We knew then that he was expecting someone to arrive

let the chance slip by.definition: to lose the opportunity (to do something)
let the chance slip by.example: When I was younger, I wanted to become a doctor, but I let the chance slip by

let the chips fall where they may.definition: let something happen regardless of the consequences and no matter what happens
let the chips fall where they may.example: I’m going to tell Ellen the truth about her husband, let the chips fall where they may

let the cobbler stick to his last.definition: do not advise someone in matters outside your area of expertise
let the cobbler stick to his last.example: Whenever Ted, who is a lawyer, tried to give Bob suggestions about how to write his novel, Bob would say, “Let the cobbler stick to his last.”

let the dead bury the dead.definition: do not try to revive old grievances.; forget about past conflicts
let the dead bury the dead.example: The Nelson family and the Hopkins family had been feuding for decades, but when Andrew Nelson and Louise Hopkins declared that they wanted to get married, their families decided to let the dead bury the dead

let them eat cake.definition: a joking disclaimer of responsibility for some group of people. (supposed to have been said by marie antoinette when she heard that the common people had no bread.)
let them eat cake.example: Fred: The budget will allow each one of our managers to get a substantial holiday bonus. Jane: And what about the rest of the employees? Fred: Let them eat cake!

let up.example: I hope this rain lets up a little soon

let up on someone or something.definition: to reduce the pressure or demands on someone or something
let up on someone or something.example: You had better let up on Tom. He can’t handle any more work

level a charge against someone.definition: to place a charge against someone; to accuse someone of something
level a charge against someone.example: The neighbors leveled a disturbance of the peace charge against us

level off.definition: [for variation or fluctuation in the motion of something] to diminish; [for a rate] to stop increasing or decreasing
level off.example: The plane leveled off at 10,000 feet

level out.definition: [for something that was going up and down] to assume a more level course or path
level out.example: The road leveled out after a while and driving was easier

a level playing field.definition: a situation that is fair to all; a situation where everyone has the same opportunity. field.)
a level playing field.example: If we started off with a level playing field, everyone would have an equal chance

level something at someone or something.definition: to direct something at someone or something; to aim a remark at someone
level something at someone or something.example: The sheriff leveled his rif le at the f leeing bandit

level something down.definition: to make something level or smooth
level something down.example: The soil is very uneven in this part of the garden. Would you please level it down?

level something off.definition: to make something level or smooth
level something off.example: You are going to have to level the f loor off before you put the carpet down

level something out.definition: to cause something to assume a more level course or path
level something out.example: Level this path out before you open it to the public

level something to the ground.definition: to crush or demolish something down to the ground
level something to the ground.example: They were forced to level the building to the ground, because they could not afford to maintain it

level something up.definition: to move something into a level or plumb position
level something up.example: Use a piece of wood under the table’s leg to level it up

level the playing field.definition: to create a state where everyone has the same opportunity
level the playing field.example: Let’s level the playing field and give everyone a chance

level with someone about someone or some.definition: to be straightforward with someone about something; to be sincere or truthful about someone or something
level with someone about someone or some.example: The police encouraged the criminal to level with them about the crime

levy something upon someone or something.definition: to place a tax on someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
levy something upon someone or something.example: The Congress was very straight- forward. It levied room taxes upon rich people

a liar is not believed even when he tell.definition: if people think that you are a liar, they will not believe anything you say
a liar is not believed even when he tell.example: As it turned out, Fred was right when he warned his friends that the police were planning to raid their party; but they paid no attention to him, since they knew him to be a liar, and a liar is not believed even when he tells the truth

liberate someone or something from someo.definition: to free someone or something from someone or something; to set someone or something free from the control of someone or something
liberate someone or something from someo.example: The police hoped to liberate the child from his kidnappers

license to do something.definition: permission, right, or justification to do something
license to do something.example: You have no license to behave in that manner!

a lick and a promise.definition: a hasty bit of work; a quick once-over
a lick and a promise.example: I was pressed for time, so I just gave the housework a lick and a promise

lick at something.definition: to draw the tongue over something repeatedly
lick at something.example: Jimmy was just licking at the ice-cream cone, and soon it began to melt and drip off his elbow

a lick of work.definition: a bit of work. (used with a negative.)
a lick of work.example: I couldn’t get her to do a lick of work all day long!

lick one\u2019s chops.definition: to show one’s eagerness to do something, especially to eat something
lick one\u2019s chops.example: We could tell from the way the boys were licking their chops that they really wanted a turn at riding the motorcycle

lick one\u2019s lips.definition: to show eagerness or pleasure about a future event. (from the habit of people licking their lips when they are about to enjoy eating something.)
lick one\u2019s lips.example: The children licked their lips at the sight of the cake

lick one\u2019s wounds.definition: to recover from a defeat or a rebuke. (also literal for an animal.)
lick one\u2019s wounds.example: After the terrible meeting and all the criticism, I went back to my office to lick my wounds

lick someone or something into shape.definition: to press or force someone or something into good shape or condition
lick someone or something into shape.example: The drama coach will try to lick her into shape by performance time

lick something up.definition: to clean up all of some substance by licking with the tongue. (usually said of an animal.)
lick something up.example: Don’t worry about the spilled milk. The dog will lick it up

a licking.definition: a spanking; a beating in a fight
a licking.example: Billy, you had better get in here if you don’t want to get a licking

a lid on something.definition: a cover on something, such as a pot, pan, etc
a lid on something.example: Keep the lid on the pot until the stew is almost done

lie about.example: She just lay about through her entire vacation

lie about someone or something to someon.definition: to say something untrue about someone or something to someone
lie about someone or something to someon.example: I wouldn’t lie about my boss to anyone!

lie alongside of someone or an animal.definition: to lie next to someone or an animal. (of is usually retained before pronouns.)
lie alongside of someone or an animal.example: Jimmy came in to lie alongside of his father in bed

lie around some place.definition: to recline some place; to spend some time lazily in some place
lie around some place.example: I think I will just lie around the house all day

lie at anchor.definition: [for a ship] to wait or rest at anchor
lie at anchor.example: The ship lay at anchor throughout the day while a shore party searched for the runaway

lie at death\u2019s door.example: She lay at death’s door for over a month

lie back.definition: to relax; to lean back in a chair and relax
lie back.example: Just lie back and try to get comfortable

lie behind someone or something.definition: [for something] to be positioned to the rear of someone or something
lie behind someone or something.example: A wide expanse of water lay behind the sentry, and a narrow road- way lay in front

lie beyond someone or something.definition: to be located on the other side of someone or something
lie beyond someone or something.example: The stream lies beyond those men you see working in the field

lie doggo.definition: to remain unrecognized (for a long time)
lie doggo.example: This problem has lain doggo since 1967

lie down.example: Why don’t you lie down for a while?

lie down on something.example: Don’t lie down on that couch!

lie down under something.example: She was tired, so she lay down under a willow tree by the brook

lie fallow.definition: [for farmland] to exist unplanted for a period of time
lie fallow.example: The fields lay fallow under the burning sun. It had been too wet to plant last spring. 2.  [for a skill and talent] to remain unused and neglected

lie in.definition: [for a woman] to lie in bed awaiting the birth of her child
lie in.example: The child is due soon, and the mother is lying in at the present time

lie in ruins.definition: to exist in a state of ruin, such as a destroyed city, building, scheme, plan, etc
lie in ruins.example: The entire city lay in ruins

lie in something.definition: to recline in something, such as a bed, a puddle, etc
lie in something.example: I found my wallet lying in a puddle. My money was soaked!

lie in state.definition: [for a dead body] to be on display for public mourning
lie in state.example: The president will lie in state in the Capitol Rotunda

lie in wait for someone or something.definition: to stay still and hidden, waiting for someone or something
lie in wait for someone or something.example: Bob was lying in wait for Anne so he could scold her about something

lie like a rug.example: He says he didn’t take the money, but he’s lying like a rug

lie out in something.definition: to remain out (unenclosed or unprotected) in some area
lie out in something.example: Who left my screwdriver lying out in the rain?

lie through one\u2019s teeth.example: I knew she was lying through her teeth, but I didn’t want to say so just then

lie to someone about someone or somethin.definition: to tell an untruth about someone or something to someone
lie to someone about someone or somethin.example: You wouldn’t lie to me about Sarah, would you?

lie with someone.example: Come and lie with me and we will keep warm

lie within something.definition: to remain within a defined area or domain
lie within something.example: The boundaries of the village lie completely within the river valley

life begins at forty.definition: by the time you are forty years old, you have enough experience and skill to do what you want to do with your life. (often said as an encouragement to those reaching middle age.)
life begins at forty.example: Alan: Why are you so depressed? Jane: Tomorrow’s my fortieth birthday. Alan: Cheer up! Life begins at forty

life in the fast lane.definition: a very active or possible risky way to live
life in the fast lane.example: Life in the fast lane is too much for me

life is just a bowl of cherries.definition: everything is going well.; life is carefree. (often used ironically, as in the second example.)
life is just a bowl of cherries.example: The real estate salesman tried to convince us that life in the suburbs is just a bowl of cherries

life is short and time is swift.definition: you should enjoy life as much as possible, because it does not last very long
life is short and time is swift.example: Jill: Want to go to the movies with me? Jane: Oh, I don’t know; I should probably stay at work and finish a few things. Jill: Come on, Jane, life is short and time is swift

life is too short.definition: life is short and there is no point in wasting it on things like worry, hatred, vengeance, etc
life is too short.example: I am not going to spend any more time trying to get even with Wally. Life’s too short

life isn\u2019t all beer and skittles.definition: life is not pleasurable all the time; you cannot always be having fun. (skittles is a game like bowling.)
life isn\u2019t all beer and skittles.example: I don’t really mind going back to work when my vacation is over. Life isn’t all beer and skittles, and I enjoy my fun that much more because I have work to compare it to

the life of the party.definition: a person who is lively and helps make a party fun and exciting
the life of the party.example: Bill is always the life of the party. Be sure to invite him

life\u2019s been good to me.definition: i am grateful that i am doing well in life
life\u2019s been good to me.example: I can’t complain. Life’s been good to me

lift off.definition: [for a plane or rocket] to move upward, leaving the ground
lift off.example: The rocket lifted off exactly on time

lift someone or something down from some.definition: to move someone or something down (from something or some place) by lifting and carrying
lift someone or something down from some.example: Would you please lift Jimmy down from the top bunk?

lift someone or something up.example: I helped lift him up and put him on the stretcher

lift something from someone or something.definition: to raise something off someone or something
lift something from someone or something.example: Please lift this burden from me

lift up.example: Suddenly, the top of the box lifted up and a hand reached out

light out of some place for some place.definition: to leave a place in a great hurry for some place
light out of some place for some place.example: I lit out of there for home as fast as I could

a light purse makes a heavy heart.definition: if you do not have enough money, you will worry and be unhappy
a light purse makes a heavy heart.example: Nathan is a cheerful person by nature, but since he lost his job, worry has made him glum. A light purse makes a heavy heart

light someone or something up.definition: to shine lights on someone or something
light someone or something up.example: We lit Fred up with the headlights of the car

light something up.definition: to light a fire, a gas burner, etc
light something up.example: I lit the kindling up and soon the fire was going

light something with something.definition: to set something afire with something else
light something with something.example: Kelly lit the fire with her last match

light up.example: Suddenly, the sky lit up like day

light upon someone or something.definition: to land on someone or something; to settle on someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
light upon someone or something.example: Three butterf lies lit on the baby, causing her to shriek with delight

lighten something up.definition: to make something lighter or brighter
lighten something up.example: Some white paint will lighten this room up a lot

lighten up.example: We applied a new coat of white paint to the walls, and the room lightened up considerably

lighten up on someone or something.definition: to be less rough and demanding or rude with someone or something
lighten up on someone or something.example: Please lighten up on her. You are being very cruel

lightning never strikes the same place t.definition: the same highly unlikely thing never happens to the same person twice
lightning never strikes the same place t.example: Jill: I’m scared to drive ever since that truck hit my car. Alan: Don’t worry. Lightning never strikes the same place twice

like a bat out of hell.definition: very fast or sudden. (use caution with hell.)
like a bat out of hell.example: The cat took off like a bat out of hell

like a blind dog in a meat market.example: The drunk staggered out of the saloon like a blind dog in a meat market, stumbling all over the sidewalk

like a bump on a log.example: Don’t just sit there like a bump on a log; give me a hand!

like a can of corn.example: Whipping up dinner for twelve is like a can of corn, as far as Jane is concerned

like a fish out of water.definition: appearing to be completely out of place; in a very awkward manner
like a fish out of water.example: Bob stood there in his rented tuxedo, looking like a fish out of water

like a kid with a new toy.definition: very pleased; happily playing with something
like a kid with a new toy.example: Every time Bill gets a new gadget for his kitchen, he’s like a kid with a new toy

like a million dollars.definition: very good or well. (usually with verbs such as feel, look, run, etc.)
like a million dollars.example: This old buggy runs like a million dollars

like a threering circus.example: Our household is like a three-ring circus on Monday mornings

like a ton of bricks.definition: like a great weight or burden
like a ton of bricks.example: Suddenly, the truth hit me like a ton of bricks

like an open book.definition: [of someone or something] easy to understand
like an open book.example: Jane’s an open book. I always know what she is going to do next

like breeds like.definition: people tend to raise children who are like them; something tends to give rise to things that resemble it
like breeds like.example: Jill: I think Fred’s little boy is going to be just as disagreeable as Fred. Jane: That’s no surprise. Like breeds like

like death warmed over.example: Oh dear, I feel like death warmed over

like father like son.definition: fathers and sons resemble each other, and sons tend to do what their fathers did before them
like father like son.example: Jill: George’s father smoked all the time, and now George is smoking excessively, too. Jane: Like father, like son, eh?

like fighting snakes.definition: chaotic; challenging. (as if every time one snake is subdued, another one attacks.)
like fighting snakes.example: It’s like fighting snakes to get anything done at this time of year

like flies to manure.definition: eagerly gathering in large numbers. (has unpleasant connotations because of the reference to manure.)
like flies to manure.example: Look at all them folks going to the freak show like f lies to manure

like gangbusters.definition: with great excitement and speed. (from the phrase “come on like gangbusters,” a radio show that “came on” with lots of noise and excitement.)
like gangbusters.example: She works like gangbusters and gets the job done

like greased lightning.example: Once I get her tuned up, this old car will go like greased lightning

like hell and high lightning.example: The snowmobiles came zooming down the trail like hell and high lightning

like herding frogs.definition: chaotic; disorderly. (on the image of trying to direct frogs, which will jump any which way.)
like herding frogs.example: Trying to get those kids to march into the auditorium is like herding frogs

like it or lump it.definition: there is no other choice. take that or none
like it or lump it.example: John: I don’t like this room. It’s too small. Bill: Like it or lump it. That’s all we’ve got

like it\u2019s such a big deal.definition: it really isn’t all that important! (sarcastic.)
like it\u2019s such a big deal.example: So I dropped the glass. Like it’s such a big deal

like it was going out of style.example: I’m worried about Sally. She’s taking aspirin like it’s going out of style

like looking for a needle in a haystack.example: Trying to find a white glove in the snow is like looking for a needle in a haystack

like mother like daughter.definition: daughters resemble their mothers.; daughters tend to do what their mothers did before them
like mother like daughter.example: My mother loved sweets, and every time my father saw me with a cookie in my hand, he would sigh, “Like mother, like daughter.”

like nobody\u2019s business.example: She can sing like nobody’s business. What a set of pipes!

like nothing on earth.example: Joan arrived at the office looking like nothing on earth. She had fallen in the mud

like one of the family.definition: as if someone (or a pet) were a member of one’s family
like one of the family.example: We treat our dog like one of the family

like pigs to the slaughter.example: Look at all the people lining up to mail their tax forms on time, like pigs to the slaughter

like stealing acorns from a blind pig.example: Getting Mary to sign the house over to me was like stealing acorns from a blind pig

like stink.definition: rapidly. (as fast as a smell spreads. *typically: go ~; move ~; run ~; swim ~.)
like stink.example: Those kids moved through the whole test like stink. Real eagerbeavers

like the wind.definition: very fast; as fast and easy as the wind
like the wind.example: Emily’s sleek new bicycle can really go like the wind

like to hear oneself talk.definition: [for someone] to enjoy one’s own talking more than people enjoy listening to it
like to hear oneself talk.example: I guess I don’t really have anything to say. I just like to hear myself talk, I guess

like tryin\u2019 to scratch your ear wit.example: Getting those kids to settle down is like tryin’ to scratch your ear with your elbow

like two peas in a pod.definition: cliché very close or intimate. (compare this with as alike as (two) peas in a pod.)
like two peas in a pod.example: Yes, they’re close. Like two peas in a pod

like water off a duck\u2019s back.example: Insults rolled off John like water off a duck’s back

like you know.definition: a combining of the (essentially meaningless) expressions like and you know. (never used in formal writing.)
like you know.example: She is, well, like, you know, uncool

likely as not.definition: probably; with an even chance either way. (*also: as ~.)
likely as not.example: He will as likely as not arrive without warning

liken someone or something to someone or.definition: to compare someone or something to someone or something, concentrating on the similarities
liken someone or something to someone or.example: He is strange. I can only liken him to an eccentric millionaire

the likes of someone or something.definition: someone or something similar to that person or thing; the equal or equals of someone or something
the likes of someone or something.example: I never want to see the likes of you again!

likewise i\u2019m sure.definition: the same from my point of view. (a hackneyed phrase said in greeting someone. see examples.)
likewise i\u2019m sure.example: Alice: I’m delighted to make your acquaintance. Bob: Likewise, I’m sure

limber someone or something up.definition: to make someone or something more flexible or loose
limber someone or something up.example: Let me give you a massage; that will limber you up

limit someone to something.definition: to restrict someone to a certain amount or number of something

look the other way.example: To make sure it’s safe to cross the street, look the other way before you step off the curb. 2.  to ignore something on purpose

look to someone or something for somethi.definition: to expect someone or something to supply something

a looksee.definition: a look at someone or something; a peek

lope along.example: The dog loped along at a very even pace, answering to his master’s whistle

lord knows i\u2019ve tried.definition: i certainly have tried very hard

lord love a duck.example: Lord love a duck! How that rain is coming down!

a lot of giveandtake.example: It was a good meeting. There was a lot of give-andtake, and we all learned. 2.  a lot of negotiating and bargaining

no holds barred.example: I intend to argue it out with Mary, no holds barred

no joke.example: It’s no joke when you miss the last train

no kidding.definition: you are not kidding me, are you? (an expression of mild surprise.)
no kidding.example: Jane: I got elected vice president. Bill: No kidding! That’s great! 2.  Everyone already knows that! Did you just find that out? (Sarcastic.)

no laughing matter.example: Be serious. This is no laughing matter

no lie.definition: you are not lying, are you?
no lie.example: Bill: A plane just landed on the interstate highway outside of town! Tom: No lie? Come on! It didn’t really, did it? Bill: It did too! Tom: Let’s go see it!

no man can serve two masters.definition: you cannot work for two different people, organizations, or purposes in good faith, because you will end up favoring one over the other
no man can serve two masters.example: Al tried going to school and working, both full-time, but soon discovered that he could not serve two masters

no matter how you slice it.definition: no matter what your perspective is; no matter how you try to portray something
no matter how you slice it.example: No matter how you slice it, the results of the meeting present all sorts of problems for the office staff

no matter what happens.definition: in any event; without regard to what happens (in the future)
no matter what happens.example: We’ll be there on time, no matter what

no more than i have to.definition: an answer to the greeting question “what are you doing?”
no more than i have to.example: Bob: Hey, Fred. What you been doing? Fred: No more than I have to

no news is good news.definition: not hearing any news signifies that nothing is wrong
no news is good news.example: Fred: I wonder if Jill is doing all right in her new job. Jane: No news is good news

no no a thousand times no.example: Bob: Here, have some sweet potatoes. Bill: No, thanks. Bob: Oh, come on! Bill: No, no, a thousand times no!

no nonsense.definition: without any tricks, deceit, or wasting of time. (hyphenated before nominals.)
no nonsense.example: Let’s have no nonsense while we are rehearsing the presentation!

no offense meant.definition: i did not mean to offend [you]
no offense meant.example: Mary: Excuse that last remark. No offense meant. Susan: It’s okay. I was not offended

no offense taken.definition: i am not offended [by what you said]
no offense taken.example: Pete: Excuse that last remark. I did not want to offend you. Tom: It’s okay. No offense taken

no one is indispensable.definition: anyone may become unnecessary; anyone may lose his or her job
no one is indispensable.example: Fred: You can’t fire me. I’m absolutely necessary to this company. Nancy: No one is indispensable, Fred

no pain no gain.definition: if you want to improve, you must work so hard that it hurts. (associated with sports and physical exercise.)
no pain no gain.example: Player: I can’t do any more push-ups. My muscles hurt. Coach: No pain, no gain

no point in something.example: There is no point in locking the barn door now that the horse has been stolen

no questions asked.definition: no inquiries [to be] made to find out who did something
no questions asked.example: Fines at the library will be suspended, no questions asked, for all late books returned during the first week of July

no rest for the wicked.definition: it’s because you are wicked that you have to work hard. (usually jocular.)
no rest for the wicked.example: A: I can’t seem to ever get all my work done. B: No rest for the wicked

no sale.example: I wanted to go to Florida for the holidays, but my father said, “No sale.”

no salesman will call.definition: a phrase indicating that no salesman will visit or contact you if you make an inquiry about a product
no salesman will call.example: All inquiries are confidential and no salesman will call

no shortage of something.definition: lots of something; plenty of something
no shortage of something.example: Oh, don’t worry about that. I have no shortage of money!

no siree bob.definition: absolutely no! (not necessarily said to a male, and rarely to any bob.)
no siree bob.example: Bill: Do you want to sell this old rocking chair? Jane: No siree, Bob!

no soap.example: I can’t do it. No soap

no sooner said than done.definition: an expression indicating that something has been done quickly and obediently
no sooner said than done.example: Jill: Can I help you out? Jane: Yes! Put these files in alphabetical order. Jill: No sooner said than done

no spring chicken.definition: a person well past youth; an old person
no spring chicken.example: That actress is no spring chicken, but she does a pretty good job of playing a twenty-year-old girl

no thanks to you.definition: i cannot thank you for what happened, because you did not cause it.; i cannot thank you for your help, because you did not give it
no thanks to you.example: Bob: Well, despite our previous disagreement, he seemed to agree to all our demands. Alice: Yes, no thanks to you. I wish you’d learn to keep your big mouth shut!

no trespassing.definition: do not enter. (usually seen on a sign. not usually spoken.)
no trespassing.example: The sign on the tree said, “No Trespassing.” So we didn’t go in

no two ways about it.definition: no choice about it; no other interpretation of it. (note the form there’s rather than there are.)
no two ways about it.example: You have to go to the doctor whether you like it or not. There’s no two ways about it

no way.example: Me join the Army? No way!

no way jos\u00e9.definition: no! (an elaboration of no. josé is pronounced with an initial h.)
no way jos\u00e9.example: Bob: Can I borrow a hundred bucks? Bill: No way, José!

no wonder.example: No wonder the baby is crying. She’s wet

nobody\u2019s fool.definition: a sensible and wise person who is not easily deceived
nobody\u2019s fool.example: Mary is nobody’s fool. She watches out for people who might try to cheat her

the nod.definition: someone’s choice for a position or task
the nod.example: The manager is going to pick the new sales manager. I think Ann will get the nod

nod at someone.definition: to make a motion to someone with one’s head indicating a greeting, agreement, or something else
nod at someone.example: I nodded at Fred, but I really didn’t agree

a nod is as good as a wink to a blind ho.definition: you cannot get people to take a hint if they are determined not to
a nod is as good as a wink to a blind ho.example: Jill: I keep hinting to the boss that I deserve a raise, but he doesn’t seem to get the point. Jane: I’m not surprised. A nod’s as good as a wink to a blind horse

nod off.definition: to fall asleep, usually while sitting up
nod off.example: Jack nodded off during the minister’s sermon

nominate someone as something.definition: to suggest someone to be the candidate to serve as something
nominate someone as something.example: I would like to nominate Karen as our representative

nominate someone for something.definition: to suggest someone as a candidate for a particular office
nominate someone for something.example: I will nominate Carolyn for president

nominate someone to something.definition: to suggest someone to become a member of a group
nominate someone to something.example: I am the one who nominated her to the board

none but the brave deserve the fair.definition: only a courageous and gallant man deserves a beautiful woman.; only the best deserves the best
none but the brave deserve the fair.example: Stop making excuses and just call Gina. None but the brave deserve the fair

none of someone\u2019s beeswax.example: It’s none of your beeswax. I’m not telling

none of someone\u2019s business.definition: not of someone’s concern. (a gentle rebuke.)
none of someone\u2019s business.example: Q: When are you going to leave for home? A: None of your business

none of your lip.definition: shut up!; i don’t want to hear anything from you about anything!
none of your lip.example: A: You are being a real nuisance about the broken window. B: None of your lip! Just help me clean it up

none other than.example: The new building was opened by none other than the president

none the wiser.definition: not knowing any more in spite of events or exposure to facts
none the wiser.example: I was none the wiser about black holes after the lecture. It was a complete waste of time

none the worse for wear.definition: no worse because of use or effort
none the worse for wear.example: I lent my car to John. When I got it back, it was none the worse for wear

none too something.definition: not very something; not at all something
none too something.example: The towels in the bathroom were none too clean

noodle around.definition: to wander around; to fiddle around with something
noodle around.example: I couldn’t find the instructions so I spent the afternoon noodling around, trying to find out how it worked

noodle over something.example: Let’s noodle over this problem for a bit and discuss it at our next meeting

nose around something.definition: to pry into something; to snoop around something
nose around something.example: I caught her nosing around my desk

nose into something.definition: [for a boat or other vehicle] to move or be moved into something or some place carefully, nose first
nose into something.example: The captain nosed into the channel, and our journey had begun

nose out of something.definition: to move cautiously out of something or some place, nose first
nose out of something.example: She nosed out of the little room, hoping she hadn’t been observed

nose someone or a group out.definition: to defeat someone or something by a narrow margin. (alludes to a horse winning a race “by a nose.”)
nose someone or a group out.example: Karen nosed Bobby out in the election for class president by one vote

nosh on something.definition: to make a snack of something
nosh on something.example: After Thanksgiving, we noshed on turkey for three days

not a bit.definition: none at all; not at all
not a bit.example: Am I unhappy? Not a bit

not a chance.definition: there is no chance at all that something will happen. (a variation of (there is) no chance.)
not a chance.example: Sally: Do you think our team will win today? Mary: Not a chance!

not a kid anymore.example: You can’t keep partying all weekend, every weekend. You’re not a kid anymore

not a living soul.definition: nobody. (see some of the possible variations in the examples.)
not a living soul.example: I won’t tell anybody—not a living soul

not able to call one\u2019s time one\u20.definition: too busy; so busy as not to be in charge of one’s own schedule
not able to call one\u2019s time one\u20.example: It’s been so busy around here that I haven’t been able to call my time my own

not able to get something for love or mo.definition: not able to get something at any price; completely unable to get something
not able to get something for love or mo.example: Oranges were so scarce last winter that you couldn’t get them for love or money

not able to go on.definition: unable to continue (doing something— even living). (not able to is often expressed as can’t.)
not able to go on.example: I just can’t go on this way

not able to help something.definition: unable to prevent or control something. (not able to is often expressed as can’t.)
not able to help something.example: I’m sorry about being late. I wasn’t able to help it

not able to make anything out of someone.definition: unable to understand someone or something. (not able to is often expressed as can’t. the anything may refer to something specific, as in the first example.)
not able to make anything out of someone.example: I can’t make sense out of what you just said

not able to make head or tail of somethi.definition: not able to understand something at all
not able to make head or tail of somethi.example: I couldn’t make head or tail of the professor’s geology lecture this morning

not able to see the forest for the trees.definition: cliché allowing many details of a situation to obscure the situation as a whole. (not able to is often expressed as can’t.)
not able to see the forest for the trees.example: The solution is obvious. You missed it because you can’t see the forest for the trees

not able to wait.definition: to have to go to the bathroom urgently. (also more broadly literal.)

not again.definition: i cannot believe that it happened again!
not again.example: Mary: The sink is leaking again. Sally: Not again! Mary: Yes, again

not agree with someone.definition: [for food] to make someone ill; [for something that one has eaten] to give one stomach distress
not agree with someone.example: Fried foods don’t agree with Tom

not all there.definition: not mentally adequate; crazy or silly
not all there.example: Sometimes I think you’re not all there

not always.example: John: Do you come here every day? Jane: No, not always

not anymore.definition: the facts you mentioned are no longer true.; a previous situation no longer exists
not anymore.example: Mary: This cup of coffee you asked me to bring you looks cold. Do you still want it? Sally: Not anymore

not as young as one used to be.example: Aunt Lila isn’t as young as she used to be. She can’t take a lot of trips anymore

not bad at all.example: Bill: How do you like your new teacher? Jane: Not bad

not believe one\u2019s ears.definition: not believe the news that one has heard
not believe one\u2019s ears.example: I couldn’t believe my ears when Mary said I won the first prize

not believe one\u2019s eyes.definition: not to believe what one is seeing; to be shocked or dumbfounded at what one is seeing
not believe one\u2019s eyes.example: I walked into the room and I couldn’t believe my eyes. All the furniture had been stolen!

not born yesterday.definition: experienced; knowledgeable in the ways of the world
not born yesterday.example: I know what’s going on. I wasn’t born yesterday

not buy something.example: You may think so, but I don’t buy it

not by a long shot.definition: not by a great amount; not at all
not by a long shot.example: Did I win the race? Not by a long shot

not enough room to swing a cat.example: Their living room was very small. There wasn’t enough room to swing a cat

not for a moment.definition: not at all; not even for a short amount of time; never
not for a moment.example: I don’t want you to leave. Not for a moment!

not for all the tea in china.definition: not even if you rewarded me with all the tea in china; not for anything at all
not for all the tea in china.example: No I won’t do it—not for all the tea in China

not for hire.definition: [of a taxi] not available to take new passengers
not for hire.example: The taxi was going to pick someone up at a nearby hotel and was not for hire

not for my money.definition: not as far as i’m concerned. (has nothing to do with money or finance.)
not for my money.example: Sue: Do you think it’s a good idea to build all these office buildings in this part of the city? Mary: Not for my money. That’s a real gamble

not for publication.definition: not to be talked about openly; secret
not for publication.example: Please tell no one about this. It’s not for publication

not get one\u2019s hopes up.definition: [one] should not expect something to happen; [one] should not start hoping that something will happen
not get one\u2019s hopes up.example: The rain could stop so we can go to the beach, but you should not get your hopes up

not give a tinker\u2019s damn.definition: not to care at all. (a tinker’s damn or dam may be a worthless curse from a tinker or a small dam or barrier used to contain molten metal.)
not give a tinker\u2019s damn.example: I don’t give a tinker’s damn whether you go or not!

not give anyone the time of day.definition: to ignore someone (usually out of dislike)
not give anyone the time of day.example: Mary won’t speak to Sally. She won’t give her the time of day

not give it another thought.definition: not to worry about something anymore. (a polite way of accepting someone’s apology.)
not give it another thought.example: It’s okay. Please don’t give it another thought

not going to win any beauty contests.example: Fred isn’t going to win any beauty contests, but he’s smart and considerate and he does well at his job

not grow on trees.definition: not to be abundant; not to be expendable. (usually said about money.)
not grow on trees.example: I can’t afford that. Money doesn’t grow on trees, you know

not have a care in the world.definition: free and casual; unworried and carefree
not have a care in the world.example: I really feel good today—as if I didn’t have a care in the world

not have a leg to stand on.definition: [for an argument or a case] to have no support
not have a leg to stand on.example: You may think you’re in the right, but you don’t have a leg to stand on

not have a stitch of clothes on.example: He walked through the house and didn’t have a stitch of clothes on

not have all one\u2019s marbles.definition: not to have all one’s mental capacities
not have all one\u2019s marbles.example: John acts as if he doesn’t have all his marbles

not have the heart to do something.definition: to be too compassionate to do something
not have the heart to do something.example: I just don’t have the heart to tell him the bad news

not hold water.definition: [of a container] not able to contain water without leaking
not hold water.example: This old wading pool won’t hold water any longer. 2.  not able to be proved; not correct or true

not hold with something.definition: to disagree with something; to not tolerate something
not hold with something.example: I don’t hold with what you are saying

not hurt a flea.definition: not to harm anything or anyone, even a tiny insect. (also with other forms of negation.)
not hurt a flea.example: Ted would not even hurt a f lea. He could not have struck Bill

not in my book.definition: not according to my views. (compare this with not for my money.)
not in my book.example: John: Is Fred okay for the job, do you think? Mary: No, not in my book

not in the same league with someone or s.definition: not nearly as good as someone or something
not in the same league with someone or s.example: John isn’t in the same league with Bob at tennis

not just whistling dixie.definition: not talking nonsense. (alludes to a song titled “dixie.”)
not just whistling dixie.example: Man, you are right! You’re not just whistling Dixie

not know beans about someone or somethin.definition: to know nothing about someone or something
not know beans about someone or somethin.example: Bill doesn’t know beans about f lying an airplane

not know enough to come in out of the ra.example: Bob is so stupid he doesn’t know enough to come in out of the rain

not know from nothing.definition: to be stupid, innocent, and naive. (this nothing is not replaced with something. usually used with don’t, as in the examples.)
not know from nothing.example: Old John—he don’t know from nothing

not know one\u2019s own strength.definition: not to realize how destructive or harmful one’s strength can be
not know one\u2019s own strength.example: I didn’t mean to hurt you. I guess I don’t know my own strength

not know someone from adam.definition: not to know someone by sight at all
not know someone from adam.example: I wouldn’t recognize John if I saw him up close. I don’t know him from Adam

not know the first thing about someone o.definition: not to know anything about someone or something
not know the first thing about someone o.example: I don’t know the first thing about f lying an airplane

not know what to make of someone or some.definition: not to understand someone or something; not to be able to interpret something or the actions of someone
not know what to make of someone or some.example: We really don’t know what to make of his request

not know which end is up.definition: not to be alert and knowledgeable
not know which end is up.example: Don’t try to hustle me, sister. You think I don’t know which end is up?

not let the grass grow under one\u2019s.definition: not to stay in one place for a long time; to be always on the move
not let the grass grow under one\u2019s.example: He is always doing something. He never lets the grass grow under his feet

not likely.definition: that is probably not so; that probably will not happen
not likely.example: Mary: Is it possible that you’ll be able to fix this watch? Sue: Not likely, but we can always try

not long for this world.example: Our dog is nearly twelve years old and not long for this world

not made of money.definition: [of a person] not having a lot of money; not having an unlimited supply of money
not made of money.example: I can’t afford a car like that. I’m not made of money you know

not move a muscle.example: Be quiet. Sit there and don’t move a muscle

not one iota.example: I won’t give you any at all! Not one iota!

not one\u2019s cup of tea.definition: not one’s choice or preference. (used to describe an activity you do not enjoy. can sound somewhat affected.)
not one\u2019s cup of tea.example: You three visit the museum without me. Looking at fussy old paintings is not my cup of tea

not one\u2019s place.definition: not one’s role to do something
not one\u2019s place.example: It was not my place to criticize my boss

not put it past someone.definition: to think that someone would not dare to do something
not put it past someone.example: He might run away from school. I wouldn’t put it past him

not right now thanks.definition: no for the present. (it is hoped that one will be asked again later. usually used for a [temporary] refusal of a serving of food or drink. there is an implication that more will be wanted later.)
not right now thanks.example: Waiter: Do you want some more coffee? Mary: Not right now, thanks

not set foot somewhere.example: I wouldn’t set foot in John’s room. I’m very angry at him

not shed a tear.definition: not to show any emotion even when something is very sad
not shed a tear.example: At his uncle’s funeral, he didn’t shed a tear. They never got along

not show one\u2019s face.definition: not to appear somewhere; not to go to some place
not show one\u2019s face.example: After what she said, she had better not show her face around here again

not sleep a wink.example: I couldn’t sleep a wink last night

not so hot.example: The service here is not so hot. This restaurant is highly overrated

not take no for an answer.definition: not to accept someone’s refusal. (a polite way of being insistent.)
not take no for an answer.example: Now, you must drop over and see us tomorrow. We won’t take no for an answer

not tell a living soul.definition: not to reveal something to anyone
not tell a living soul.example: You secret is safe with me. I won’t tell a living soul

not to put too fine a point on it.definition: a phrase introducing a fine or important point, apologetically
not to put too fine a point on it.example: Rachel: Not to put too fine a point on it, Mary, but you’re still acting a little rude to Tom. Mary: I’m sorry, but that’s the way I feel

not to touch a drop.definition: not to drink any of something, usually alcohol
not to touch a drop.example: He pledged not to touch a drop all weekend, but he broke his pledge on Friday night

not to worry.example: Bill: The rain is going to soak all our clothes. Tom: Not to worry, I put them all in plastic bags

not too much.definition: a response to greeting inquiries into what one has been doing
not too much.example: John: What have you been doing? Mary: Not much

not too shabby.definition: nice; well done. (with emphasis on shabby.)
not too shabby.example: Is that your car? Not too shabby!

not touch someone or something with a te.definition: cliché not to have anything to do with someone or something. (always negative.)
not touch someone or something with a te.example: No, I won’t hire Fred. I wouldn’t touch him with a ten-foot pole

not trouble one\u2019s pretty little hea.definition: not to worry about something. (considered demeaning by many.)
not trouble one\u2019s pretty little hea.example: Don’t you trouble your little head about that. I’ll take care of it

not with it.definition: not able to think clearly; not able to understand things
not with it.example: Lisa’s mother is not really with it anymore. She’s going senile

not worth a damn.example: This pen is not worth a damn

not worth mentioning.definition: not important enough to require a comment
not worth mentioning.example: There are others, but they are not worth mentioning

not worth one\u2019s while.definition: not worth bothering with; not worth spending time on
not worth one\u2019s while.example: It’s not worth my while to discuss it with you

not worth the trouble.definition: not important enough to require a comment or any effort
not worth the trouble.example: Don’t bother with it. It isn’t worth the trouble

a notch below someone or something.definition: a little lower in quality than someone or something
a notch below someone or something.example: I believe that this wine is a notch below the one we had with the fish

notch something up.definition: to count up something; to add up or score something
notch something up.example: We notched yet another victory up in our efforts to regain the trophy

note something down.definition: to write down a note about something

noted for something.definition: famed for something; memorable for something
noted for something.example: We were all noted for our polite manners

nothing comes of nothing.definition: if you contribute nothing, you will get nothing
nothing comes of nothing.example: Jill: Why are you so depressed today? Jane: No reason. Jill: There has to be a reason. Nothing comes of nothing

nothing doing.definition: i will not permit it!; i will not participate in it!
nothing doing.example: John: Can I put this box in your suitcase? Bill: Nothing doing! It’s too heavy now

nothing down.example: You can have this car for nothing down and $140 a month

nothing for me thanks.definition: i do not want any of what was offered. (typically to decline a serving of food or drink.)
nothing for me thanks.example: Waiter: Would you care for dessert? Bob: Nothing for me, thanks

nothing is certain but death and taxes.definition: everything in life is unpredictable, except that you can be sure you will die and you will have to pay taxes. (you can also refer to death and taxes as the only certain things in life.)
nothing is certain but death and taxes.example: Son: I can’t believe how much tax money is being withheld from my paycheck! Father: Welcome to adult life, where nothing is certain but death and taxes

nothing is certain but the unforeseen.definition: you cannot foresee what will happen
nothing is certain but the unforeseen.example: Jill: Now that we’ve got a new boss, this is certain to be a nicer place to work. Jane: Nothing is certain but the unforeseen

nothing is given so freely as advice.definition: people will give you advice more willingly than they give you anything else
nothing is given so freely as advice.example: Although no one in my family was willing to give me a loan, they all had suggestions about how I could get the money from elsewhere. Nothing is given so freely as advice

nothing much.definition: not much; hardly anything; nothing of importance. (often a reply to a greeting asking what one has been doing.)
nothing much.example: John: Hey, man! How’s by you? Bob: Hiya! Nothing much

nothing of the kind.example: I didn’t tear your jacket—nothing of the kind!

nothing short of something.definition: more or less the same as something bad; as bad as something
nothing short of something.example: His behavior was nothing short of criminal

nothing so bad but it might have been wo.definition: although bad things do happen, they are not as bad as other things you can imagine that might have happened
nothing so bad but it might have been wo.example: Joan: This is like a nightmare! My house burned down—I lost everything! Nancy: At least you and your family are safe. Nothing so bad but might have been worse

nothing succeeds like success.definition: if you have succeeded in the past, you will continue to be successful in the future
nothing succeeds like success.example: After Alan’s brilliant courtroom victory, everyone wanted to be his client. Nothing succeeds like success

nothing to boast about.example: In high school, my grades were acceptable, but they were nothing to boast about

nothing to choose from.definition: no choice; no choice in the selection; not enough of something to make a choice
nothing to choose from.example: I went to the store looking for new shoes, but there was nothing to choose from

nothing to it.example: Look, anybody can do it! Nothing to it!

nothing to speak of.example: John: What’s happening around here? Bill: Nothing to speak of

nothing to write home about.definition: mediocre; not as good as you expected
nothing to write home about.example: I went to that new restaurant last night. It’s nothing to write home about

nothing upstairs.example: Tom is sort of stupid. You know—nothing upstairs

nothing ventured nothing gained.definition: if you do not take risks, you will never accomplish anything
nothing ventured nothing gained.example: Bill: Should I ask my boss for a promotion? Jane: Nothing ventured, nothing gained

notify someone about someone or somethin.definition: to inform someone about someone or something
notify someone about someone or somethin.example: Please notify the insurance company about the accident

notify someone of something.example: Can you notify my parents of my arrival at the airport?

now and then.example: I like to go to a movie now and then

now hear this.definition: pay attention to what is going to be said! (in the manner of an announcement over a public address system, especially in the military.)
now hear this.example: Now hear this! You have to turn off the television and go to bed!

now now.definition: a calming and consoling phrase that introduces good advice
now now.example: “Now, now, don’t cry,” said the mother to the tiny baby

now or never.definition: at this time and no other
now or never.example: This is your only chance, John. It’s now or never

now then.definition: a sentence opener indicating that a new topic is being opened or that the speaker is getting down to business. (expressions such as this often use intonation to convey the connotation of the sentence that is to follow. the brief intonation pattern accompanying the expression may indicate sarcasm, disagreement, caution, consolation, sternness, etc.)
now then.example: “Now then, where’s the pain?” asked the doctor

now where was i.definition: i was interrupted, so please help me remember what i was talking about. (the emphasis is on was.)
now where was i.example: Now, where was I! I think I lost my place

now you\u2019re cooking with gas.definition: now you are doing what you should be doing!
now you\u2019re cooking with gas.example: As Bob came to the end of the piece, the piano teacher said, “Now you’re cooking with gas!”

now you\u2019re talking.definition: now you are saying the right things
now you\u2019re talking.example: Tom: I won’t put up with her behavior any longer. I’ll tell her exactly what I think of it. Bill: Now you’re talking!

nowhere near.example: We have nowhere near enough wood for the winter

nowin situation.definition: a situation where there is no correct or satisfactory solution
nowin situation.example: The general was too weak to fight and too proud to surrender. It was a no-win situation

nudge someone or something aside.definition: to push or bump someone or something out of the way
nudge someone or something aside.example: We nudged the old man aside and went on ahead

null and void.definition: cliché without legal force; having no legal effect
null and void.example: The court declared the law to be null and void

number in something.definition: to total up to a certain figure
number in something.example: The birds numbered in the thousands

a number of things or people.definition: some things or people, in an indefinite amount
a number of things or people.example: I subscribe to a number of different magazines

number off by something.definition: to say a number in a specified sequence when it is one’s turn

number someone or something among someth.definition: to include someone or something in a group of something
number someone or something among someth.example: I number her among my best friends

number someone with something.definition: to include someone in a list of people
number someone with something.example: I number Clara Wilson with the all-time greats

nurse a grudge against someone.definition: to keep resenting and disliking someone over a period of time. (usually implies that it has been an unreasonably long time.)

nurse someone back to health.definition: to care for a sick person until good health returns
nurse someone back to health.example: Sally was glad to help nurse her mother back to health

nurse someone or an animal along.definition: to aid or encourage the well-being or return to health of someone or an animal
nurse someone or an animal along.example: She nursed the old man along for a few years until he died

nurse someone through something.definition: to care for a sick person during the worst part of a sickness or recovery
nurse someone through something.example: There was no one there to nurse him through the worst part of his illness

nurse something along.definition: to manage something with care and thrift
nurse something along.example: The board of directors agreed to nurse the firm along for a while and then sell it

a nut case.definition: a crazy person; an irrational person
a nut case.example: Bob is acting stranger and stranger. He is turning into a real nut case

nut up.example: I knew I would nut up if I didn’t quit that job

nuts and bolts.definition: the mundane workings of something; the basics of something
nuts and bolts.example: I want you to learn how to write well. You have to know the nuts and bolts of writing

nuts to you.example: Well, nuts to you! You are just plain rude!

object to someone or something.definition: to disapprove of someone or something
object to someone or something.example: I object to him as your choice

obligate someone to someone or something.definition: to force someone to do something for someone or something
obligate someone to someone or something.example: This contract obligates you to the company for five years!

oblige someone by something.definition: to accommodate someone by doing something
oblige someone by something.example: Please oblige me by closing the window

oblige someone to do something.definition: to require someone to do something
oblige someone to do something.example: You are obliged to arrive on time and enter by the side door

oblige someone with something.example: He obliged her with a willing attitude

obliterate someone or something from som.definition: to destroy or wipe out someone or something from something
obliterate someone or something from som.example: Karen obliterated the writing from the wall

obsessed with someone or something.example: Kathy was obsessed with the kitten

obtain something for someone or somethin.definition: to get or receive something for someone or something

occupy oneself by something.definition: to keep busy by doing something
occupy oneself by something.example: Don’t worry. I can occupy myself by knitting or sewing

occupy someone with something.definition: to keep someone busy with something
occupy someone with something.example: Can you occupy the child with this toy?

occur to someone.definition: [for an idea or thought] to come into someone’s mind

odd man out.definition: an unusual or atypical person or thing

the odd something.definition: an extra or spare something; a chance something

odds and ends.example: There were lots of odds and ends in the attic, but nothing of real value

the odds are against one.definition: [for fate] to be against one generally

the oddson favorite.definition: the most popular choice of a wager

odor of sanctity.definition: an atmosphere of excessive holiness or piety

of age.definition: old enough to marry, buy alcohol, or to sign legal agreements
of age.example: Now that Mary is of age, she can buy her own car

of all things.definition: can you imagine?; imagine that! (usually said about something very strange.)
of all things.example: She wore jeans to the dance. Of all things!

of benefit to someone.definition: serving someone well; to the good of someone

of course.example: Sally: Are you ready to go? Bob: Of course. Sally: Then let’s go

of interest to someone.example: These archived files are no longer of any interest

of late.example: Have you seen Sally of late?

of mature years.example: My employer is a man of mature years

of service to someone.example: Good morning, madam. May I be of service to you?

of the first water.example: This is a very fine pearl—a pearl of the first water

of the persuasion that.definition: holding a belief that something is true or is in existence

of two minds about someone or something.definition: holding conflicting opinions about someone or something; being undecided about someone or something

off and running.definition: [of horses, dogs, or people] having started racing

off base.definition: [of a runner in baseball] not having a foot touching the base
off base.example: The runner was off base but the first baseman didn’t tag him out. 2.  unrealistic; inexact; wrong. *Typically: be ~; get ~.)

off campus.definition: not located or present on the grounds of a college or university
off campus.example: Tom has an apartment off campus

off center.definition: not exactly in the center or middle

off course.definition: not going in the right direction

off duty.definition: not working at one’s job. (the opposite of on duty.)

off on a sidetrack.definition: on a digression; discussing a topic that is not the main topic. (alludes to a train waiting on a siding. *typically: be ~; get ~; get someone ~.)
off on a sidetrack.example: Anne got off on a sidetrack and never returned to her topic

off on someone or something.definition: in a rage about someone or something; on a tirade about someone or something
off on someone or something.example: Are you off on Sally again? Why can’t you leave her alone?

off one\u2019s game.definition: not able to play a sport as well as normal

off season.definition: not in the busy time of the year

off someone or something goes.definition: someone or something is leaving. (said on the departure of someone or something.)

off the air.definition: not broadcasting (a radio or television program)
off the air.example: The radio audience won’t hear what you say when you’re off the air

off the hook.definition: freed from an obligation. (alludes to a fish freeing itself from a fishhook. *typically: be ~; get ~; get someone ~; let someone ~.)

off the record.definition: unofficial; informal. (of comments to the press that one does not want reported.)

off the shelf.definition: ready made for purchase; not custommade. (hyphenated when prenominal.)

off the subject.definition: not concerned with the subject being discussed

off the track.example: I’m afraid you’re off the track, John. Try again

off the wagon.definition: drinking liquor after a period of abstinence

off to a running start.definition: with a good, fast beginning, possibly a head start

off to one side.definition: beside something; (moved) slightly away from something

off to the races.definition: an expression characterizing the activity or excitement that is just beginning; [we are] leaving for something interesting or exciting

off to the side with someone.definition: moving aside with someone to discuss something

off topic.definition: not on the topic of discussion; far from the general subject of a discussion; not part of the purpose of a particular communication channel, such as an internet newsgroup

off with you.definition: go away!; get going! (formal or pompous.)
off with you.example: Off with you! We’ve had enough of your banter!

offend against someone or something.definition: to anger or affront someone or something
offend against someone or something.example: We do not wish to offend against anyone

offend someone with something.definition: to anger or affront someone with something
offend someone with something.example: Don’t offend us with your bad jokes

an offer one cannot refuse.example: He made me an offer I could not refuse, so I sold him my car

offer something for something.definition: to suggest a certain amount of money as a purchase price for something
offer something for something.example: I’ll offer you ten bucks for that watch

offer something to someone as something.definition: to propose giving something to someone as a gift, peace offering, payment, etc
offer something to someone as something.example: They offered us a bunch of f lowers as a peace offering

offer something up to someone or somethi.definition: to give something to someone or something as a mark of devotion, thanks, etc

offkey.definition: [of music or singing] off pitch; out of tune

offline.definition: not connected to a computer, by direct connection or via the telephone system, etc. (compare this with online.)

offthecuff.example: Her remarks were off-the-cuff, but very sensible

offthewall.example: Why are you so offthe- wall today?

ogle at someone or something.definition: to stare at someone or something, usually with amorous or erotic relish
ogle at someone or something.example: Don’t just stand there and ogle at me!

oh boy.definition: wow! (usually oh, boy! an exclamation. it has nothing to do with boys.)
oh boy.example: Bill: Oh, boy! An old-fashioned circus!

oh sure someone or something will.definition: a sarcastic expression claiming that someone or something will do something or that something will happen
oh sure someone or something will.example: Andy: Don’t worry. I’ll do it. Rachel: Oh, sure you will. That’s what you always say

oh ye of little faith.definition: you who trust no one. (jocular; the word ye is an old form of you used in the bible.)
oh ye of little faith.example: You thought I wouldn’t show up on time? Oh, ye of little faith

oh yeah.definition: is that what you think? (rude and hostile.)
oh yeah.example: Tom: You’re getting to be sort of a pest. Bill: Oh, yeah? Tom: Yeah

oink out.example: I oink out every time we have chocolate cake

old as methuselah.definition: very old. (of a person; refers to a biblical figure held to have lived to be 969. *also: as ~.)
old as methuselah.example: Old Professor Stone is as old as Methusehah but still gets around with a cane

old as the hills.example: That’s not a new joke; it’s as old as the hills!

old battleaxe.example: She is such an old battle-axe. I’ll bet she’s hell to live with

old college try.example: Will made the old college try, but that wasn’t enough to get the job done

old habits die hard.definition: people find it difficult to change their accustomed behavior
old habits die hard.example: Joan retired last year, but she still gets up as early as she used to when she had to go to work. Old habits die hard

an old hand at doing something.definition: someone who is experienced at doing something
an old hand at doing something.example: The maid was an old hand at polishing silver

old hat.example: That’s a silly idea. It’s old hat

the old heaveho.definition: the act of throwing someone out; the act of firing someone. (from nautical use, where sailors used heave-ho to coordinate hard physical labor. one sailor called “heave-ho,” and all the sailors would pull at the same time on the ho. *typically: get ~; give someone ~.)

the old onetwo.definition: a series of two punches delivered quickly, one after another
the old onetwo.example: Tom gave Bill the old one-two, and the argument was ended right there

an old poacher makes the best gamekeeper.definition: the best person to guard something is someone who knows all about how to steal it, so he or she can anticipate what thieves might do
an old poacher makes the best gamekeeper.example: We should hire the computer hacker to design computer security systems. An old poacher makes the best gamekeeper

an old warhorse.definition: a performance piece that is performed often
an old warhorse.example: The symphony orchestra played a few old warhorses and then some ghastly contemporary stuff that will never again see the light of day

an old wives\u2019 tale.example: You really don’t believe that stuff about starving a cold do you? It’s just an old wives’ tale

omit someone or something from something.definition: to leave someone or something out of something
omit someone or something from something.example: You omitted Carol from the list

on a diet.definition: trying to lose weight by eating less food or specific foods
on a diet.example: I didn’t eat any cake because I’m on a diet

on a firstname basis with someone.definition: knowing someone very well; good friends with someone
on a firstname basis with someone.example: I’m on a first-name basis with John

on a fool\u2019s errand.definition: involved in a useless journey or task
on a fool\u2019s errand.example: Bill went for an interview, but he was on a fool’s errand. The job had already been filled

on a pedestal.definition: elevated to a position of honor or reverence. (alludes to honoring someone on display on a pedestal like a statue. *typically: place someone ~; put someone ~.)
on a pedestal.example: He puts his wife on a pedestal. She can do no wrong in his opinion

on a power trip.definition: exercising power and authority, especially unduly

on a roll.definition: in the midst of a series of successes
on a roll.example: Don’t stop me now. I’m on a roll

on a shoestring.definition: with a very small amount of money
on a shoestring.example: We lived on a shoestring for years before I got a goodpaying job

on a silver platter.definition: using a presentation [of something] that is appropriate for a very formal setting

on a string.definition: under control, as one would control a marionette

on a tight leash.definition: [of an animal] on a leash, held tightly and close to its owner
