on a wing and a prayer.definition: to arrive or fly in with one’s plane in very bad condition. (sometimes used fig. of other vehicles. *typically: come (in) ~; arrive ~.)

on account.definition: [money paid or owed] on a debt
on account.example: I paid twelve dollars on account last month. Wasn’t that enough?

on active duty.definition: in battle or ready to go into battle. (military.)

on all fours.example: I dropped a contact lens and spent an hour on all fours looking for it

on any account.definition: for any purpose; for any reason; no matter what

on approval.definition: for examination, with the privilege of return

on bended knee.definition: kneeling, as in supplication. (the verb form is obsolescent and occurs now only in this phrase.)

on broadway.definition: located in the broadway theater district in new york city; performed in the broadway theater district. (regarded as having the best of american stage productions.)

on campus.definition: located or being on the grounds of a college or university

on consignment.definition: [of goods] having been placed in a store for sale, with payments made for the goods by the operator of the store only if they are sold

on course.definition: going in the right direction or on the right route

on credit.definition: using credit; buying something using credit

on dead center.definition: at the exact center of something

on deck.definition: on the deck of a boat or a ship

on duty.definition: at work; currently doing one’s work. (the opposite of off duty.)

on easy street.definition: in a state of financial independence and comfort

on edge.example: Can you stand a dime on edge?

on fire.example: Help! My car is on fire!

on foot.example: My car won’t work so I have to travel on foot

on good terms with someone.definition: friendly with someone; able to interact well and be friends with someone

on hold.example: The building project is on hold while we try to find money to complete it

on horseback.definition: on the back of a horse

on ice.definition: stored or preserved on ice or under refrigeration

on its feet.definition: organized and functioning; started up and functioning

on location.definition: [of a movie] being filmed in a place distant from the studio

on medication.definition: taking medicine for a current medical problem

on occasion.example: I like to go to the movies on occasion

on one\u2019s best behavior.example: When we went out, the children were on their best behavior

on one\u2019s deathbed.definition: while one is in bed and dying

on one\u2019s feet.example: Get on your feet. They are playing the national anthem

on one\u2019s guard against someone or s.example: Try to stay on guard against pickpockets

on one\u2019s high horse.definition: in a haughty manner or mood
on one\u2019s high horse.example: Larry is on his high horse again, bossing people around

on one\u2019s honor.example: On my honor, I’ll be there on time

on one\u2019s mind.definition: occupying one’s thoughts; currently being thought about
on one\u2019s mind.example: You’ve been on my mind all day

on one\u2019s own.example: Our baby can now walk on his own

on one\u2019s own hook.example: I don’t need any help. I can do it on my own hook

on one\u2019s own time.definition: not while one is at work

on one\u2019s person.example: Always carry identification on your person

on one\u2019s toes.example: You have to be on your toes if you want to be in this business

on one\u2019s way to some place.definition: leaving one place for another; en route to a place

on order.example: Your car is on order. It’ll be here in a few weeks

on par with someone or something.example: Your effort is simply not on par with what’s expected from you

on pins and needles.example: I’ve been on pins and needles all day, waiting for you to call with the news

on probation.definition: serving a period of probation, typically after conviction for a crime

on purpose.definition: intentionally; in a way that is meant or intended; not an accident

on sale.definition: available for sale at a reduced price. (always implies lower than usual sale price.)

on schedule.definition: at the expected or desired time

on someone\u2019s account.example: Don’t do it on my account

on someone\u2019s head.definition: [for something negative] belonging only to one person or group
on someone\u2019s head.example: All the blame fell on their heads

on someone\u2019s heels.definition: following someone very closely; following very closely at someone’s heels

on someone\u2019s or something\u2019s la.definition: for someone or something to be almost worn out or finished

on someone\u2019s sayso.definition: on someone’s authority; with someone’s permission

on someone\u2019s tail.example: There is a huge truck on my tail. What should I do?

on someone\u2019s watch.definition: while someone is on duty; while someone is supposed to be in charge of a situation

on speaking terms with someone.definition: on friendly terms with someone. (often with the negative.)

on spec.definition: using money risked in the hope of profit; on speculation

on standby.definition: waiting for one’s turn, especially describing the status of travelers who wait at a soon-to-depart train, plane, or bus, hoping that a seat will become available

on tap.definition: having to do with beer served from a barrel or keg

on the air.example: The radio station came back on the air shortly after the storm

on the alert for someone or something.definition: watchful and attentive for someone or something
on the alert for someone or something.example: Be on the alert for pickpockets

on the back burner.definition: [of something] on hold or suspended temporarily. (alludes to putting a pot that needs less active attention on a back burner of a stove, leaving space for pots that need to be stirred. compare this with on the front burner. *typically: be ~; put something ~.)

on the ball.example: This guy is really on the ball

on the bandwagon.definition: on the popular side (of an issue); taking a popular position
on the bandwagon.example: You really should get on the bandwagon. Everyone else is

on the beam.definition: exactly right; thinking along the correct lines

on the bench.definition: [of a judge] directing a session of court

on the bias.definition: on a diagonal line; on a diagonal pathway or direction

on the bird.example: There is a whole lot of good stuff on the bird, but you need a receiving dish to get it

on the block.definition: on a city or suburban block

on the borderline.definition: in an uncertain position between two statuses; undecided

on the bright side.definition: [ignoring the bad for a moment] considering the positive aspects of a situation

on the brink of doing something.definition: on the verge of doing something; almost to the point of doing something
on the brink of doing something.example: I was on the brink of selling my car to make ends meet when the tax refund came in the mail

on the button.definition: exactly right; in exactly the right place; at exactly the right time

on the cusp of something.definition: at the point in time that marks the beginning of something

on the cutting edge.definition: [for someone] to be trendy and very up-to-date; [for something] to be of the latest design. (akin to on the bleeding edge.)

on the defensive.definition: weary and ready to defend oneself

on the dot.definition: at exactly the right time.  ~; get somewhere ~; see someone ~; show up ~.)

on the edge.definition: very anxious and about to become distraught; on the verge of becoming irrational

on the edge of one\u2019s seat.definition: [of a member of an audience] closely following the action and excitement of a performance

on the eve of something.definition: just before something, possibly the evening before something
on the eve of something.example: John decided to leave school on the eve of his graduation

on the face of it.definition: superficially; from the way it looks
on the face of it.example: This looks like a serious problem on the face of it. It probably is minor, however

on the fast track.definition: following an expedited procedure; being acted upon sooner or more quickly than is typical
on the fast track.example: Let’s put this project on the fast track and maybe we’ll see results sooner

on the fence about something.example: Ann is on the fence about going to Mexico

on the fly.definition: [done] while something or someone is operating or moving
on the fly.example: I’ll try to capture the data on the f ly

on the fringe.definition: at the outer boundary or edge of something
on the fringe.example: He doesn’t live in the city, just on the fringe. 2.  at the extremes of something, typically political thought

on the front burner.definition: receiving particular attention or consideration. (compare this with on the back burner. *typically: be ~; put something ~.)
on the front burner.example: So, what’s on the front burner for us this week?

on the go.example: I’m usually on the go all day long

on the heels of something.example: There was a rainstorm on the heels of the windstorm

on the horizon.definition: appearing at the boundary between the earth and the sky
on the horizon.example: There is a storm on the horizon. 2.  soon to happen

on the horns of a dilemma.definition: having to decide between two things, people, etc
on the horns of a dilemma.example: Mary found herself on the horns of a dilemma. She didn’t know which to choose

on the hour.definition: at each hour on the hour mark
on the hour.example: I have to take this medicine every hour on the hour

on the house.definition: [of something] given away free by a merchant
on the house.example: “Here,” said the waiter, “have a cup of coffee on the house.”

on the job.definition: working; doing what one is expected to do
on the job.example: I’m always on the job when I should be

on the lam.example: Richard has been on the lam for a week now

on the level.example: Come on now, on the level, tell me the truth

on the lookout for someone or something.example: Be on the lookout for signs of a storm

on the loose.example: Look out! There is a bear on the loose from the zoo

on the make.example: There is a company that is on the make

on the mark.definition: right on the measurement point; showing just the right anount
on the mark.example: It’s exactly one quart, right on the mark

on the market.example: We put our house on the market last year and it still hasn’t sold

on the mend.example: I cared for my father while he was on the mend

on the move.example: Are the cattle on the move now, or are they still grazing? 2. progressing; advancing

on the off chance.definition: because of a slight possibility that something may happen or might be the case; just in case
on the off chance.example: I went to the theater on the off chance that there were tickets for the show left

on the one hand.definition: from one point of view; as one side (of an issue)
on the one hand.example: On one hand, I really ought to support my team. On the other hand, I don’t have the time to attend all the games

on the other hand.definition: a phrase introducing an alternate view
on the other hand.example: John: I’m ready to go; on the other hand, I’m perfectly comfortable here. Sally: I’ll let you know when I’m ready, then

on the outs with someone.definition: in a mild dispute with someone; sharing ill will with someone
on the outs with someone.example: Tom and Bill are on the outs again

on the pill.example: Is it true that Mary is on the pill?

on the prowl.definition: looking for someone for sexual purposes. (alludes to a prowling cat.)
on the prowl.example: Tom looks like he is on the prowl again tonight

on the qt.example: The company president was making payments to his wife on the QT

on the rag.example: Kim’s on the rag and in a bad mood

on the right track.definition: following the right track or trail; riding on the correct track, as with a train
on the right track.example: The train was on the right track when it left the station. I can’t imagine how it got lost. 2.  following the right set of assumptions

on the rise.example: The number of auto thefts in Cook County is on the rise again

on the road.definition: traveling from place to place, not necessarily on the highways; working away from one’s home or office
on the road.example: I was on the road with the circus for six months

on the road to recovery.example: It’s been two weeks since her surgery, and she is on the road to recovery

on the rocks.definition: [of a ship] broken and marooned on rocks in the sea
on the rocks.example: The ship crashed and was on the rocks until the next high tide. 2.  [of an alcoholic drink] served with ice cubes

on the run.definition: while one is moving from place to place
on the run.example: I will try to pick up some aspirin today on the run

on the safe side.example: Let’s be on the safe side and call first

on the same wavelength.example: We’re not on the same wavelength. Let’s try again

on the sauce.example: Poor old Ron is on the sauce again

on the scene.definition: available or present where something is happening or where something has happened
on the scene.example: The ambulance was on the scene almost immediately

on the shelf.definition: not active socially; left to oneself in social matters. (alludes to being left or stored on a shelf.)
on the shelf.example: I’ve been on the shelf long enough. I’m going to make some friends

on the side.definition: extra, such as with a job or an additional order of food
on the side.example: I would like an order of eggs with toast on the side, please

on the skids.example: My newly started business is on the skids

on the sly.example: She was stealing little bits of money on the sly

on the spot.definition: at exactly the right place; at exactly the right time
on the spot.example: It’s noon, and I’m glad you’re all here on the spot. Now we can begin

on the spur of the moment.example: We decided to go on the spur of the moment

on the stick.example: Get on the stick and get this job done!

on the street.example: Sue put it on the street, and now everyone knows

on the strength of something.definition: because of the support of something, such as a promise or evidence; due to something
on the strength of something.example: On the strength of your comment, I decided to give John another chance

on the table.definition: subject to discussion by the group; submitted as a point of discussion
on the table.example: The chairman said we could not discuss salaries since the topic was no longer on the table

on the take.example: I heard that the mayor is on the take

on the throne.example: King Samuel was on the throne for two decades. 2.  Sl. seated on the toilet

on the tip of one\u2019s tongue.definition: [of a thought or idea] about to be said or almost remembered
on the tip of one\u2019s tongue.example: I have his name right on the tip of my tongue. I’ll think of it in a second

on the upandup.example: Is this deal on the up-and-up? What’s the catch?

on the wagon.example: No, I don’t care for a cocktail. I’m on the wagon

on the wane.example: Her inf luence in on the wane, but she is still the boss

on the warpath.example: The boss is on the warpath again. Watch out!

on the watch for someone or something.definition: alert and watching for someone or something
on the watch for someone or something.example: Please stay on the watch for trouble

on the whole.example: On the whole, this was a very good day

on the wing.definition: while flying; while in flight. (usually refers to birds, fowl, etc., not people or planes.)
on the wing.example: There is nothing as pretty as a bird on the wing

on the witness stand.definition: [of a witness] giving testimony in court, seated in place in view of the court
on the witness stand.example: I was on the witness stand, answering questions, when the judge declared a recess

on the wrong track.definition: [of a train] following the wrong set of tracks
on the wrong track.example: We had to back up, because somehow we got on the wrong track. 2.  going the wrong way; following the wrong set of assumptions

on thin ice.definition: on ice that is too thin to support one
on thin ice.example: Billy is on thin ice and is in great danger. 2.  in a risky situation

on tiptoe.definition: standing or walking on the front part of the feet (the balls of the feet) with no weight put on the heels. (this is done to gain height or to walk quietly.)
on tiptoe.example: I had to stand on tiptoe in order to see over the fence

on top of something.definition: up-to-date on something; knowing about the current state of something
on top of something.example: Ask Mary. She’s on top of this issue

on top of the world.example: Wow, I feel on top of the world

on track.example: Try to keep these procedures on track this time

on trial.definition: [of someone] in a legal case before a judge
on trial.example: The criminal was on trial for over three months

on vacation.definition: away, taking time off work; on holiday
on vacation.example: Where are you going on vacation this year?

on view.example: The painting will be on view at the museum

on with someone.definition: [of a date or appointment] agreed to and confirmed with someone
on with someone.example: Is the Friday date still on with you?

once and for all.example: Sue: I’m going to get this place organized once and for all! Alice: That’ll be the day!

once bitten twice shy.definition: when something or someone has hurt you once, you tend to avoid that thing or person
once bitten twice shy.example: Jill: Let’s go ride the roller coaster. Jane: No, thanks. I got really sick on one of those once—once bitten, twice shy

once in a blue moon.example: Jill: Does your husband ever bring you f lowers? Ellen: Once in a blue moon

once upon a time.definition: cliché once in the past. (a formula used to begin a fairy tale.)
once upon a time.example: Once upon a time, there were three bears

the onceover.example: Every time John walks by I get the once-over. Does he like me?

onceoverlightly.definition: a quick and careless treatment. (a noun. said of an act of cleaning, studying, examination, or appraisal.)
onceoverlightly.example: Bill gave his geometry the once-overlightly and then quit studying

one and all.example: “Good morning to one and all,” said Jane as she walked through the outer office

the one and only.definition: the famous and talented (person). (used in theatrical introductions. see also my one and only. )
the one and only.example: And now—the one and only—Jane Smith!

one and the same.definition: cliché the very same person or thing
one and the same.example: John Jones and J. Jones are one and the same

one brick shy of a load.example: Joyce has done some stupid things. Sometimes I think she is one brick shy of a load

one cannot be in two places at once.definition: you cannot be in more than one place or do more than one thing at the same time
one cannot be in two places at once.example: Child: Mom! Mom! Come help me wash my hair! Mother: Just a minute! I’m putting clean sheets on your bed right now, and I can’t be in two places at once

one cannot love and be wise.definition: people often fall in love with someone with whom they are not compatible or behave foolishly when they are in love
one cannot love and be wise.example: My son and his girlfriend have decided to get married in the spring. I don’t think that’s wise, since they won’t have enough money saved by then to set up house. But then, one cannot love and be wise

one eye on someone or something.definition: [get/have] a small amount of attention devoted to someone or something
one eye on someone or something.example: I have to have one eye on you at all times or you will get into trouble

one for the record books.definition: a record-breaking or very remarkable act
one for the record books.example: What a dive! That’s one for the record books

one for the road.definition: a drink; a drink before a journey or before leaving a bar
one for the road.example: Let’s have one for the road

one good turn deserves another.definition: if someone does you a favor, you should do a favor for that person in return
one good turn deserves another.example: Jill: Thanks for the ride. Jane: It’s the least I can do after you helped me wash the car last week. One good turn deserves another

one hand for oneself and one for the shi.definition: when you are on a ship, always use one hand to steady yourself, and one to work; likewise, always put some effort into safeguarding yourself as well as into working
one hand for oneself and one for the shi.example: The old sailor chastised us for forgetting to hold onto something during the rough weather. “One hand for yourself and one for the ship,” he bellowed

one has to draw the line somewhere.definition: it is necessary to set limits and enforce them
one has to draw the line somewhere.example: Ellen: This is the fifth night this week that my son has stayed out too late. Jane: Why not punish him, then? You have to draw the line somewhere

one law for the rich and another for the.definition: rich people are sometimes able to escape without punishment when they commit crimes, while poor people are usually punished
one law for the rich and another for the.example: It doesn’t seem fair—rich people can avoid paying their taxes and not get in trouble, but poor people are always punished if they don’t pay. We shouldn’t have one law for the rich and another for the poor

one little bit.example: Jean could not be persuaded to change her mind one little bit

one man\u2019s loss is another man\u2019.definition: when one person loses something, another person gets it. (you can substitute appropriate names or pronouns for the phrases one man’s and another man’s, as in the second example.)
one man\u2019s loss is another man\u2019.example: Mike found a five-dollar bill on the sidewalk. “One man’s loss is another man’s gain,” he thought to himself, as he took the money

one man\u2019s meat is another man\u2019.definition: something that one person likes may be distasteful to someone else
one man\u2019s meat is another man\u2019.example: Fred: What do you mean you don’t like French fries? They’re the best food in the world! Alan: One man’s meat is another man’s poison

one man\u2019s trash is another man\u201.definition: something that one person considers worthless may be considered valuable by someone else
one man\u2019s trash is another man\u201.example: Q: Why would anyone want to hang a picture like that on the wall? A: One man’s trash is another man’s treasure

one moment please.definition: please wait briefly. (a polite way of acknowledging that you noticed someone’s request.)
one moment please.example: John: Can you help me? Clerk: One moment, please. I will be with you shortly

one of these days.definition: someday; in some situation like this one
one of these days.example: One of these days, someone is going to steal your purse if you don’t take better care of it

one of these days is none of these days.definition: if you say you will do something “one of these days,” you probably do not seriously intend to do it, and therefore it will not get done
one of these days is none of these days.example: Alan: When are you going to fix the garage door? Jane: One of these days. Alan: One of these days is none of these days

one\u2019s bark is worse than one\u2019s.definition: someone makes a lot of harsh-sounding threats but never carries them out
one\u2019s bark is worse than one\u2019s.example: Don’t get upset at anything my father says. His bark is worse than his bite

one\u2019s bearings.definition: the knowledge of where one is; the knowledge of how one is oriented to one’s immediate environment
one\u2019s bearings.example: After he fell, it took Ted a few minutes to get his bearings

one\u2019s best bib and tucker.example: I always put on my best bib and tucker on Sundays

one\u2019s best shot.example: That was his best shot, but it wasn’t good enough

one\u2019s better half.definition: one’s spouse. (usually refers to a wife.)
one\u2019s better half.example: I think we’d like to come for dinner, but I’ll have to ask my better half

one\u2019s butter and egg money.definition: money that a farm woman earns. (farm women would often sell butter and eggs for extra money that would be stashed away for an emergency.)
one\u2019s butter and egg money.example: Jane was saving her butter and egg money for a new TV

one\u2019s claws are showing.definition: one is acting catty; one is saying spiteful and cruel things
one\u2019s claws are showing.example: Gloria: Did you see what she was wearing? I wouldn’t be caught dead in it! Sally: Gloria, my dear, your claws are showing

one\u2019s days are numbered.definition: one is facing death or dismissal
one\u2019s days are numbered.example: If I don’t get this contract, my days are numbered at this company

one\u2019s deepest sympathy.example: I am so sorry about the death of your father. You have my deepest sympathy

one\u2019s ears are red.definition: [for someone’s ears] to be red from embarrassment
one\u2019s ears are red.example: I’m so embarrassed. Wow, are my ears red!

one\u2019s ears are ringing.definition: [for someone’s ears] to have a ringing sound because of an illness or other condition; very loud music, or some other very loud sound
one\u2019s ears are ringing.example: After the explosion, my ears were ringing for hours

one\u2019s eyes are bigger than one\u201.definition: one has taken more food than one can eat
one\u2019s eyes are bigger than one\u201.example: I can’t eat all this. I’m afraid that my eyes were bigger than my stomach

one\u2019s fair share.definition: the amount of something that one is due relative to what other people are receiving
one\u2019s fair share.example: Let him take more. He didn’t get his fair share

one\u2019s fill of someone or something.definition: [get/have] as much of someone or something as one needs or can tolerate
one\u2019s fill of someone or something.example: You’ll soon get your fill of Tom. He can be quite a pest

one\u2019s for the asking.definition: [can become] one’s property if one asks for it
one\u2019s for the asking.example: I have a cherry pie here. A slice is yours for the asking if you want it

one\u2019s frame of mind.example: My frame of mind is sort of low at the moment. I’ve had a very bad day

one\u2019s future looks bright.example: Tom’s future looks bright and he will do well if he keeps working hard

one\u2019s goose is cooked.definition: one is finished; one has been found out and is in trouble
one\u2019s goose is cooked.example: It’s over. His goose is cooked!

one\u2019s heart goes out to someone.definition: one feels great sympathy for someone
one\u2019s heart goes out to someone.example: My heart goes out to the grieving family

one\u2019s heart is dead set against som.example: Jane’s heart is set against going to that restaurant ever again

one\u2019s heart is in one\u2019s mouth.definition: one feels strongly emotional (about someone or something)
one\u2019s heart is in one\u2019s mouth.example: “Gosh, Mary,” said John, “My heart is in my mouth whenever I see you.”

one\u2019s heart is in the right place.definition: one has good intentions, even if the results are bad
one\u2019s heart is in the right place.example: She gave it a good try. Her heart was in the right place

one\u2019s heart is set on something.example: Jane’s heart is set on going to London

one\u2019s heart stands still.definition: one’s heart (figuratively) stops beating because of strong emotions
one\u2019s heart stands still.example: When I first saw you, my heart stood still

one\u2019s home away from home.definition: a place, other than one’s home, where one can feel at home
one\u2019s home away from home.example: Please make our house your home away from home when you are in town

one\u2019s last resting place.example: Daddy has gone to his last resting place

one\u2019s luck runs out.example: My luck ran out, so I had to come home

one\u2019s mind went blank.definition: someone’s mind has experienced total forgetfulness
one\u2019s mind went blank.example: He knew all his lines in rehearsal, but his mind went blank when he went before an audience

one\u2019s money\u2019s worth.definition: everything that one has paid for; the best quality for the money paid
one\u2019s money\u2019s worth.example: Weigh that package of meat before you buy it. Be sure you’re getting your money’s worth

one\u2019s name is mud.definition: one is in trouble or humiliated
one\u2019s name is mud.example: If I can’t get this contract signed, my name will be mud

one\u2019s next of kin.definition: one’s closest living relative or relatives
one\u2019s next of kin.example: The police notified the dead man’s next of kin

one\u2019s nextdoor neighbor.definition: the person living in the house or apartment closest to one’s own
one\u2019s nextdoor neighbor.example: My next-door neighbor came over to borrow a shovel

one\u2019s nose is in the air.definition: one is acting conceited or aloof
one\u2019s nose is in the air.example: Mary’s nose is always in the air since she got into that exclusive boarding school

one\u2019s number is up.definition: one’s time to die—or to suffer some other unpleasantness—has come
one\u2019s number is up.example: John is worried. He thinks his number is up

one\u2019s old stamping ground.definition: the place where one was raised or where one has spent a lot of time. (there are variants with stomping and grounds.)
one\u2019s old stamping ground.example: Ann should know about that place. It’s near her old stamping ground

one\u2019s own worst enemy.definition: consistently causing oneself to fail; more harmful to oneself than other people are
one\u2019s own worst enemy.example: Ellen: My boss is my enemy. She never says anything good about me. Jane: Ellen, you’re your own worst enemy. If you did your job responsibly, your boss would be nicer

one\u2019s sea legs.definition: one’s ability to tolerate the movement of a ship at sea
one\u2019s sea legs.example: Jean was a little awkward on the cruise at first, but in a few days she got her sea legs and was fine

one\u2019s second wind.definition: one’s stabilized breathing after exerting oneself for a short time
one\u2019s second wind.example: John was having a hard time running until he got his second wind

one\u2019s sunset years.example: Many people in their sunset years love to travel

one\u2019s walking papers.definition: a notice that one is fired from one’s job
one\u2019s walking papers.example: Well, I’m through. I got my walking papers today

one\u2019s way of life.definition: one’s lifestyle; one’s pattern of living
one\u2019s way of life.example: That kind of thing just doesn’t fit into my way of life

one\u2019s word is one\u2019s bond.definition: one’s statement of agreement is as sound as a posting of a performance bond
one\u2019s word is one\u2019s bond.example: Of course, you can trust anything I agree to verbally. My word is my bond. There’s no need to get it in writing

one\u2019s work is cut out for one.definition: one’s task is prepared for one; one has a lot of work to do
one\u2019s work is cut out for one.example: This is a big job. My work is cut out for me

one sandwich short of a picnic.example: Poor Bob just isn’t too bright. He’s one sandwich short of a picnic

the one that got away.definition: the big fish that got away, especially as the subject of a fisherman’s story
the one that got away.example: The one that got away is always bigger than the one that got caught

one thing leads to another.definition: one event sets things up for another event, and so on. (as an explanation of how little things lead to big problems.)
one thing leads to another.example: I kept spending more and more money until I was broke. You know how one thing leads to another

one thing or person after another.definition: a series of things or people that seems without limit
one thing or person after another.example: It’s just one problem after another

one to a customer.definition: each person can have or receive only one. (as in sales restrictions where each customer is permitted to buy only one.)
one to a customer.example: “Only one to a customer!” said the chef as he handed out the hamburgers

one too many.definition: euph. one drink of liquor too many, implying drunkenness
one too many.example: I think I’ve had one too many. It’s time to stop drinking

one up on someone.definition: ahead of someone; having an advantage over someone
one up on someone.example: Tom is one up on Sally because he got a job and she didn’t

one way or another.example: Tom: Can we fix this radio, or do I have to buy a new one? Mary: Don’t fret! We’ll get it repaired one way or another

onehorse town.definition: a very small town; a small and backward town
onehorse town.example: I refuse to spend a whole week in that onehorse town!

oneman show.definition: a performance put on by one person
oneman show.example: It was a one-man show, but it was very entertaining

onenight stand.definition: a performance lasting only one night
onenight stand.example: The band did a series of one-night stands down the East Coast

onetrack mind.definition: a mind that thinks entirely or almost entirely about one subject
onetrack mind.example: Adolescent boys often have one-track minds. All they’re interested in is the opposite sex

online.definition: connected to a computer or network
online.example: As soon as I get online, I can check the balance of your account

only have eyes for someone.definition: [to be] loyal to only one person, in the context of romance
only have eyes for someone.example: Oh, Jane! I only have eyes for you!

only time will tell.definition: you will only know the outcome after time has passed
only time will tell.example: Jill: Do you think Bill and Nancy will have a happy marriage? John: Only time will tell

the only way to go.definition: the best way to do something; the best choice to make
the only way to go.example: Get a four-wheel drive car. It’s the only way to go

onto a good thing.definition: having found something useful, promising, or profitable
onto a good thing.example: This is a great scheme. I know I’m onto a good thing

ooze with something.definition: to flow or seep with something; to be covered with some oozing substance

open a conversation.example: I tried to open a conversation with him, but he had nothing to say

open confession is good for the soul.definition: if you have done something wrong, you will feel better if you confess that you did it
open confession is good for the soul.example: You ought to tell Dad that you broke his radio. Open confession is good for the soul

open fire on someone.definition: to start (doing something, such as asking questions or criticizing). (based on open fire on someone or something.)
open fire on someone.example: The reporters opened fire on the mayor

open fire on someone or something.definition: to begin shooting at someone or something
open fire on someone or something.example: The troops opened fire on the enemy

open for business.definition: [of a shop, store, restaurant, etc.] operating and ready to do business
open for business.example: The store is now open for business and invites you to come in

open into something.example: The passageway opened into a dining room

an open mind.definition: a mind or attitude that is open to new ideas and opinions
an open mind.example: Please try to be nice and keep an open mind. It’s all not as bad as you think

open one\u2019s heart to someone or some.definition: to tell all of one’s private thoughts to someone
open one\u2019s heart to someone or some.example: I didn’t mean to open my heart to you

open oneself to criticism.definition: to do something that makes one vulnerable to criticism
open oneself to criticism.example: By saying something so stupid in public, you really opened yourself to criticism

open out onto something.definition: [for a building’s doors] to exit toward something
open out onto something.example: The French doors opened out onto the terrace

open pandora\u2019s box.definition: to uncover a lot of unsuspected problems
open pandora\u2019s box.example: When I asked Jane about her problems, I didn’t know I had opened Pandora’s box

open season on some creature.definition: a time of unrestricted hunting of a particular game animal
open season on some creature.example: It’s always open season on rabbits around here

open season on someone.definition: a period of time when everyone is criticizing someone. (based on open season (on some creature).)
open season on someone.example: It seems as if it’s always open season on politicians

an open secret.definition: something that is supposed to be known only by a few people but is known in fact to a great many people
an open secret.example: Their engagement is an open secret. Only their friends are supposed to know, but in fact, the whole town knows

open someone\u2019s eyes to someone or s.definition: to cause someone, including oneself, to become aware of someone or something
open someone\u2019s eyes to someone or s.example: We finally opened our eyes to what was going on around us

open someone up.definition: to perform a surgical operation requiring a major incision on someone
open someone up.example: The doctor had to open George up to find out what was wrong

open something out.definition: to unfold or expand something; to open and spread something out
open something out.example: When she opened the fan out, she saw it was made of plastic

open something up.definition: to unwrap something; to open something
open something up.example: Yes, I want to open my presents up

open something up to someone.definition: to make something available to someone; to permit someone to join something or participate in something
open something up to someone.example: We intend to open the club up to everyone

open the door to someone.definition: to permit someone to enter a room, building, etc
open the door to someone.example: The butler opened the door to the guests and they all entered

open the door to something.example: The armistice opened the door to peace talks

open to criticism.example: Anything the president does is open to criticism

open to question.definition: [an action or opinion] inviting question, examination, or refutation
open to question.example: Everything he told you is open to question and you should look into it

open to something.definition: agreeable to hear or learn about new ideas and suggestions
open to something.example: The store owner was open to suggestions from her employees

open up.definition: open your door; open your mouth. (usually open up!)

open up on someone something or an anima.definition: to fire a gun or other weapon at someone, something, or an animal
open up on someone something or an anima.example: The sergeant told the soldiers to open up on the enemy position

open up one\u2019s kimono.definition: sl. to reveal what one is planning. (from the computer industry, referring especially to the involvement of the japanese in this field.)
open up one\u2019s kimono.example: Sam isn’t one to open his kimono much when it comes to new products

open up to something.definition: to become more accepting of someone or something
open up to something.example: Finally, he opened up to the suggestion that he should leave

open with someone or something.definition: to begin a season, session, series, or performance with someone or something
open with someone or something.example: The conference will open with a series of invited speakers

an openandshut case.definition: a simple and straightforward situation without complications. (often said of criminal cases where the evidence is convincing.)
an openandshut case.example: The murder trial was an open-and-shut case. The defendant was caught with the murder weapon

opening gambit.definition: an opening movement, tactic, or statement which is made to secure a position that is to one’s advantage
opening gambit.example: The rebel army’s opening gambit was to bomb the city’s business district

operate against someone or something.definition: to work against someone or something; to have a negative effect on someone or something
operate against someone or something.example: All of this operates against our idea of fixing the garage up as a family room

operate from something.definition: to work out of something or some place
operate from something.example: I’m in business for myself. I operate from my home

operate on someone.definition: to perform a surgical operation on someone
operate on someone.example: They decided not to operate on her

operate on something.definition: to work on something; to work with the insides of something. (as a surgeon might operate.)
operate on something.example: He tried to operate on his watch and ruined it

opportunity knocks but once.definition: you will only have one chance to do something important or profitable. (you can say opportunity knocks to signal that someone’s chance to do something important is here right now.)
opportunity knocks but once.example: When Nancy got a scholarship offer from a college far away, her parents encouraged her to go, even though they didn’t like the thought of her moving so far from home. “Opportunity knocks but once,” they said, “and this may be your only chance to get a good education.”

opportunity makes a thief.definition: anyone would steal, given a chance to do so without being punished
opportunity makes a thief.example: Mr. Cooper thought of himself as a moral man. But opportunity makes a thief, and with the safe unguarded he had the opportunity to steal thousands of dollars undetected

opposed to something.example: I am strongly opposed to your suggestion

the opposite sex.definition: the other sex; (from the point of view of a female) males; (from the point of view of a male) females. (also with member of, as in the example.)
the opposite sex.example: Ann is crazy about the opposite sex

opt for something.example: I opted for the orange one

opt in favor of someone or something.definition: to choose a particular person; to choose a particular thing
opt in favor of someone or something.example: Do you think she will opt in favor of this one or that?

opt out of something.definition: to choose not to be in something
opt out of something.example: If you do that, I’m going to have to opt out of the club

or else.definition: or suffer the consequences. (an inspecific threat of bad consequences.)
or else.example: Do what I tell you, or else

or what.definition: a way of adding emphasis to a yes-or-no question the speaker has asked. (in effect, if it wasn’t what i said, what is it?)
or what.example: Bob: Now, is this a fine day or what? John: Looks okay to me

or words to that effect.definition: or similar words meaning the same thing
or words to that effect.example: John: It says right here in the contract, “You are expected to attend without fail,” or words to that effect. Mary: That means I have to be there, huh? John: You got it!

orbit around someone or something.definition: to circle around something in an orbit
orbit around someone or something.example: The f lies orbited around Fred and his ice-cream cone

ordain someone as something.definition: to establish someone as a priest or minister
ordain someone as something.example: In a lovely ceremony, they ordained David as a priest

the order of the day.definition: something necessary or usual at a certain time
the order of the day.example: Warm clothes are the order of the day when camping in the winter

order someone into something.definition: to command someone to get into something
order someone into something.example: The officer ordered Ann into the wagon

order someone off the field.definition: [for a game official] to command a player to leave the playing area
order someone off the field.example: The referee will order you off the field

order something from someone or somethin.definition: to agree to purchase something from someone or a group
order something from someone or somethin.example: We ordered some plants from the mail-order company

order something in.definition: to have something, usually food, brought into one’s house or place of business
order something in.example: Do you want to order pizza in?

orient someone to something.definition: to help someone locate a compass direction or other similar location
orient someone to something.example: Try to orient Karen to the light so I can photograph her

originate from something.definition: to come from something or some place
originate from something.example: Did you originate from around here?

originate in something.definition: to have had a beginning in something or some place
originate in something.example: The river originates in the Andes Mountains

originate with someone or something.definition: to have been started by someone, something, or during a time period or event
originate with someone or something.example: Did this policy originate with you?

ornament something with something.example: The driver ornamented his truck with lots of chrome

oscillate between someone or something a.definition: to swing between (choosing) someone and someone else; to swing between (choosing) something and something else
oscillate between someone or something a.example: Fred oscillated between going to college and getting a job

the other place.example: If you’re good, you’ll go to heaven, and if you’re bad, you’ll go to the other place

other times other manners.definition: different generations or eras have different customs
other times other manners.example: Amy thought her grandchildren addressed their friends in startlingly rude terms. “But then,” she ref lected, “other times, other manners.”

the other way around.example: No, it won’t fit that way. Try it the other way round

an ounce of common sense is worth a poun.definition: common sense will help you solve problems more than theory will
an ounce of common sense is worth a poun.example: The psychologist had many elaborate theories about how to raise her child, but often forgot that an ounce of common sense is worth a pound of theory

an ounce of discretion is worth a pound.definition: knowing when to refrain from making jokes is better than being able to make jokes all the time
an ounce of discretion is worth a pound.example: Mabel makes fun of everybody, regardless of whether or not she hurts their feelings. Someone should tell her that an ounce of discretion is worth a pound of wit

an ounce of prevention is worth a pound.definition: if you put in a little effort to prevent a problem, you will not have to put in a lot of effort to solve the problem
an ounce of prevention is worth a pound.example: Brush your teeth every day; that way you won’t have to go to the dentist to have cavities filled. An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure

oust someone from something.definition: to force someone to leave something or some place; to throw someone out of something or some place
oust someone from something.example: They ousted the boys from the bar

out and about.example: Beth has been ill, but now she’s out and about

out at some place.example: Tom’s out at the farm and there’s no phone there, so you can’t talk to him

out for blood.definition: aggressively seeking to harm or get revenge; angry and looking for the cause of one’s distress
out for blood.example: The opposite team is out for blood, but we have a good defense

out from something.example: I would like to be farther out from the city

out front.definition: in the front of one’s house

out in force.example: What a night! The mosquitoes are out in force

out in left field.example: Sally is a lot of fun, but she’s sort of out in left field

out in the cold.example: Open the door! Let me in! Don’t keep me out in the cold!

out in the open.definition: visible in an open space; exposed in an open area
out in the open.example: The trucks are out in the open where we can see them

out of action.definition: not operating temporarily; not functioning normally
out of action.example: The pitcher was out of action for a month because of an injury

out of all proportion.definition: of exaggerated importance; of an unrealistic importance or size compared to something else
out of all proportion.example: This problem has grown out of all proportion

out of character.example: Ann’s remark was quite out of character

out of circulation.definition: no longer available for use or lending. (usually said of library materials, certain kinds of currency, etc.)
out of circulation.example: I’m sorry, but the book you want is temporarily out of circulation

out of commission.definition: [for a ship] to be not currently in use or under command
out of commission.example: This vessel will remain out of commission for another month

out of consideration for someone or some.definition: with consideration for someone or something; with kind regard for someone or something
out of consideration for someone or some.example: Out of consideration for your past efforts, I will do what you ask

out of context.definition: [of an utterance or the report of an action] removed from the surrounding context of the event, thereby misrepresenting the intent of the utterance or report
out of context.example: You took her remarks out of context! You’re the dishonest person, not her!

out of courtesy to someone.definition: in order to be polite to someone; out of consideration for someone
out of courtesy to someone.example: We invited Mary’s brother out of courtesy to her

out of debt.example: I’ve taken a second job so I can get myself out of debt

out of earshot.definition: too far from the source of a sound to hear the sound
out of earshot.example: I was out of earshot and could not hear the conversation

out of favor with someone.definition: no longer desirable or preferred by someone
out of favor with someone.example: I can’t ask John to help. I’m out of favor with him

out of focus.example: What I saw through the binoculars was sort of out of focus

out of gas.definition: without gasoline (in a car, truck, etc.)
out of gas.example: We can’t go any farther. We’re out of gas

out of harm\u2019s way.definition: not liable to be harmed; away from any causes of harm
out of harm\u2019s way.example: We should try to get all the civilians out of harm’s way

out of hock.definition: [of something] bought back from a pawn shop
out of hock.example: When I get my watch out of hock, I will always be on time. 2.  out of debt; having one’s debts paid

out of it.example: Bill is really out of it. Why can’t he pay attention?

out of keeping with something.definition: [of something said or some behavior] failing to fit in with something
out of keeping with something.example: This kind of thing is completely out of keeping with our standards of behavior

out of left field.definition: suddenly; from an unexpected source or direction
out of left field.example: Most of your ideas are out of left field

out of line with something.definition: not properly lined up in a line of things
out of line with something.example: I told you not to get out of line. Now, get back in line

out of luck.definition: without good luck; having bad fortune
out of luck.example: If you wanted some ice cream, you’re out of luck

out of necessity.definition: because of necessity; due to need
out of necessity.example: I bought this hat out of necessity. I needed one, and this was all there was

out of nowhere.example: A huge bear appeared out of nowhere and roared and threatened us

out of one\u2019s depth.definition: involved in something that is beyond one’s capabilities
out of one\u2019s depth.example: You know, you are really out of your depth in this project

out of one\u2019s element.definition: not in a natural or comfortable situation
out of one\u2019s element.example: When it comes to computers, I’m out of my element

out of one\u2019s skull.example: Oh, man, I drank till I was out of my skull

out of order.definition: [of something or things] out of the proper sequence
out of order.example: She noticed that the books on the shelf were out of order

out of patience.definition: annoyed and impatient after being patient for a while
out of patience.example: I finally ran out of patience and lost my temper

out of place.example: The book I wanted was out of place, and I almost did not find it

out of practice.definition: performing poorly due to a lack of practice
out of practice.example: I used to be able to play the piano extremely well, but now I’m out of practice

out of print.definition: [for a book] to be no longer available from the publisher
out of print.example: The book you want just went out of print, but perhaps I can find a used copy for you

out of reach.definition: not near enough to be reached or touched
out of reach.example: Place the cookies out of reach, or the children will eat them all

out of season.example: Sorry, oysters are out of season. We don’t have any

out of service.example: Both elevators had been put out of service, so I had to use the stairs

out of sight.definition: not visible; too far away to be seen
out of sight.example: The cat kept out of sight until the mouse came out

out of sight out of mind.definition: if you do not see someone or something frequently, you will forget about it. (sometimes used to imply that you will forget about people who have moved away.)
out of sight out of mind.example: Ever since I moved, none of my old friends have gotten in touch with me. It’s out of sight, out of mind with them, evidently

out of someone\u2019s hands.example: The police officer took the gun out of Fred’s hands

out of sorts.definition: not feeling well; grumpy and irritable
out of sorts.example: I’ve been out of sorts for a day or two. I think I’m coming down with something

out of spite.definition: with the desire to harm someone or something
out of spite.example: Jane told some evil gossip about Bill out of spite

out of stock.definition: not immediately available in a store; [for goods] to be temporarily unavailable
out of stock.example: Those items are out of stock, but a new supply will be delivered on Thursday

out of sync.definition: uncoordinated; unsynchronized. (an abbreviation for synchronization. *typically: be ~; get ~.)
out of sync.example: Our efforts are out of sync

out of the ballpark.definition: beyond the amount of money suggested or available
out of the ballpark.example: Your estimate is completely out of the ballpark. Just forget it

out of the closet.example: Tom Brown came out of the closet and admitted that he likes to knit

out of the corner of one\u2019s eye.definition: [seeing something] at a glance; glimpsing something, as with peripheral vision
out of the corner of one\u2019s eye.example: I saw someone do it out of the corner of my eye. It might have been Jane who did it

out of the frying pan and into the fire.definition: from a bad situation to a worse situation
out of the frying pan and into the fire.example: When I tried to argue about my fine for a traffic violation, the judge charged me with contempt of court. I really went out of the frying pan into the fire

out of the goodness of one\u2019s heart.example: What are you going to pay me? You don’t expect me to do this out of the goodness of my heart, do you?

out of the hole.example: I get paid next week, and then I can get out of the hole

out of the mouths of babes oft times com.definition: children occasionally say remarkable or insightful things
out of the mouths of babes oft times com.example: Mr. and Mrs. Doyle were quietly bickering in the kitchen when their seven-year-old daughter came in and said, “You guys should get counseling.” After a surprised pause, Mrs. Doyle remarked, “Out of the mouths of babes.”

out of the ordinary.example: It was a good meal, but not out of the ordinary

out of the picture.definition: no longer relevant to a situation; departed; dead
out of the picture.example: Now that Tom is out of the picture, we needn’t concern ourselves about his objections

out of the question.example: I’m sorry, but your taking my car is out of the question

out of the red.example: This year our company is likely to get out of the red before fall

out of the running.definition: no longer being considered; eliminated from a contest
out of the running.example: After the first part of the diving meet, three members of our team were out of the running

out of the swim of things.definition: not in the middle of activity; not involved in things. (the opposite of in the swim of things.)
out of the swim of things.example: While I had my cold, I got out of the swim of things

out of the window.example: All that work gone out the window because my computer crashed

out of the woods.definition: past a critical phase; out of the unknown
out of the woods.example: When the patient got out of the woods, everyone relaxed

out of the woodwork.definition: out into the open from other places or a place of concealment
out of the woodwork.example: When the cake appeared, all the office people suddenly came out of the woodwork

out of thin air.definition: out of nowhere; out of nothing
out of thin air.example: Suddenly—out of thin air—the messenger appeared

out of this world.example: This pie is out of this world

out of touch with someone or something.definition: knowing no news of someone or something; not keeping informed of the developments relating to someone or something
out of touch with someone or something.example: I’ve been out of touch with my brother for many years

out of town.definition: temporarily not in one’s own town
out of town.example: I’ll go out of town next week. I’m going to be at a conference

out of tune with someone or something.definition: not in musical harmony with someone or something
out of tune with someone or something.example: The oboe is out of tune with the f lute

out of turn.definition: not at the proper time; not in the proper or expected order
out of turn.example: We were permitted to be served out of turn because we had to leave early

out of whack.example: Why do you always act as if you’re out of whack?

out of work.example: Todd was out of work for almost a year

out on a limb.definition: out on a limb of a tree where it is dangerous
out on a limb.example: It’s okay to climb the tree, but don’t go out on a limb and fall off. 2.  in a dangerous position to do something; at risk

out on bail.definition: out of jail after a court appearance and pending trial because bail bond money has been paid. (the money will be forfeited if the person who is out on bail does not appear for trial at the proper time.)
out on bail.example: Bob got out on bail waiting for his trial

out on parole.definition: out of prison, conditionally, before one’s total sentence is served
out on parole.example: Bob was caught using drugs while out on parole and was sent back to prison

out on patrol.definition: away from a central location, watching over a distant or assigned area. (said especially of police and soldiers.)
out on patrol.example: Officer Smith is out on patrol and cannot see you now

out on the town.definition: celebrating at one or more places in a town
out on the town.example: I’m really tired. I was out on the town until dawn

out please.definition: please let me get out. (said by someone trying to get out of an elevator. compare this with coming through(, please).)
out please.example: The elevator stopped again, and someone at the back said, “Out, please.”

out to get someone.definition: intending to harm someone in particular
out to get someone.example: I know they are out to get me! They hate me!

out to win.example: Bobby is out to win at all costs! He can’t face losing

out west.definition: in the western part of the united states
out west.example: We lived out West for nearly ten years

outofpocket expenses.definition: the actual amount of money spent. (alludes to the money one person pays while doing something on someone else’s behalf. one is usually paid back this money.)
outofpocket expenses.example: My out-of-pocket expenses for the party were nearly $175

outside of something.example: Outside of the cost of my laundry, I have practically no expenses

over a barrel.definition: out of one’s control; in a dilemma
over a barrel.example: He got me over a barrel, and I had to do what he said

over and above something.definition: more than something; in addition to something
over and above something.example: I’ll need another twenty dollars over and above the amount you have already given me

over and done with.example: I’m glad that’s over and done with

over and out.definition: i am finished talking. (from two-way radio communications.)
over and out.example: That’s all. Good day. Over and out

over and over again.example: She stamped her foot over and over again

over easy.example: I want mine cooked over easy

over my dead body.definition: a defiant phrase indicating the strength of one’s opposition to something. (a joking response is “that can be arranged.”)
over my dead body.example: Sally: Alice says she’ll join the circus no matter what anybody says. Father: Over my dead body! Sally: Now, now. You know how she is

over the counter.definition: [of medication bought or sold] without a prescription. (hyphenated when prenominal. see also under the counter.)
over the counter.example: This is a good product. You can buy it over the counter

over the edge.example: His performance was over the edge. Too long, too dirty, and too loud!

over the hill.definition: escaped from prison or the military
over the hill.example: Two privates went over the hill last night

over the hump.definition: over the hard part; past the midpoint
over the hump.example: Things should be easy from now on. We finally got over the hump

over the top.definition: having gained more than one’s goal
over the top.example: Our fund-raising campaign went over the top by $3,000

over the wall.example: Max tried to go over the wall, but they caught him

overflow into something.example: The river overf lowed into the surrounding farmland

overflow with someone or something.definition: to have so much or so many people or things that they spill over
overflow with someone or something.example: The kitchen overf lowed with the guests

owe someone a debt of gratitude.definition: a large amount of thanks owed to someone who deserves gratitude. (actually payment of the debt is owed.)
owe someone a debt of gratitude.example: We owe you a debt of gratitude for all you have done for us

owe something to someone for something.definition: to be under obligation to pay or repay someone for something
owe something to someone for something.example: I owe forty dollars to Ann for the dinner

owing to.definition: because of something; due to the fact of something
owing to.example: Owing to the lateness of the evening, I must go home

own up to someone.definition: to confess or admit something to someone
own up to someone.example: Finally, he owned up to his mother about breaking the vase

own up to something.definition: to admit something; to confess to something
own up to something.example: I know you broke the window. Come on and own up to it

pace something off.definition: to mark off a distance by counting the number of even strides taken while walking
pace something off.example: The farmer paced a few yards off and pounded a stake into the soil

pace something out.definition: to measure a distance by counting the number of even strides taken while walking
pace something out.example: He paced the distance out and wrote it down

pack down.definition: [for something] to settle down in a container
pack down.example: The cereal has packed down in the box so that it seems that the box is only half full

pack it in.definition: to quit trying to do something; to give up trying something and quit
pack it in.example: I was so distressed that I almost packed it in

a pack of lies.example: The thief told a pack of lies to cover up the crime

pack someone off to someone or something.definition: to send someone away to someone or some place
pack someone off to someone or something.example: Laura just packed all the kids off to summer camp

pack someone or something in like sardin.definition: to squeeze in as many people or things as possible. (from the way that many sardines are packed into a can.)
pack someone or something in like sardin.example: They packed us in like sardines. There was no room to breathe

pack someone or something together.definition: to press or squeeze people or things together
pack someone or something together.example: The ushers packed the people together as much as they dared

pack something away.definition: to pack something up and put it away
pack something away.example: Pack this mirror away where it will be safe

pack something down.definition: to make something more compact; to press something in a container down so it takes less space
pack something down.example: The traffic packed down the snow

pack something in something.definition: to surround or enclose something in something
pack something in something.example: They packed his wounded hand in ice, then took him to the hospital

pack something off to someone or somethi.definition: to send something to someone or something
pack something off to someone or somethi.example: I will pack the books off to you immediately

pack something up in something.definition: to prepare something to be transported by placing it into a container
pack something up in something.example: Gerry will pack the dishes up in a strong box, using lots of crumpled paper

pack them in.definition: to draw a lot of people
pack them in.example: It was a good night at the theater. The play really packed them in

pack up.definition: to prepare one’s belongings to be transported by placing them into a container; to gather one’s things together for one’s departure
pack up.example: If we are going to leave in the morning, we should pack up now

a package deal.definition: a collection or group of related goods or services sold as a unit
a package deal.example: I got all these tools in a package deal for only $39.95

packed in like sardines.example: It was terribly crowded there. We were packed in like sardines

pad down some place.definition: sl. to make one’s bed somewhere, usually a casual or temporary bed
pad down some place.example: Do you mind if I pad down at your place for the night?

pad out.definition: sl. to go to bed or to sleep
pad out.example: Man, if I don’t pad out by midnight, I’m a zombie

pad something out.definition: to make something appear to be larger or longer by adding unnecessary material
pad something out.example: If we pad the costume out here, it will make the person who wears it look much plumper

pad the bill.definition: to put unnecessary or additional items on a bill to make the total cost higher
pad the bill.example: The plumber had padded the bill with things we didn’t need

paddle one\u2019s own canoe.definition: to do something by oneself; to be alone
paddle one\u2019s own canoe.example: I’ve been left to paddle my own canoe too many times

a pain in the neck.example: This assignment is a pain in the neck

paint on something.definition: to apply paint to the surface of something
paint on something.example: He painted on the fence a while and then went inside to rest

paint over something.definition: to cover something up with a layer of paint
paint over something.example: Sam painted over the rusty part of the fence

paint something in.definition: to paint something extra onto a painted area
paint something in.example: I know that there is supposed to be a big white spot here. We will have to paint it in

paint something out.definition: to cover something up or obliterate something by applying a layer of paint
paint something out.example: The worker painted the graffiti out

paint the town red.definition: sl. to go out and celebrate; to go on a drinking bout; to get drunk
paint the town red.example: I feel like celebrating my promotion. Let’s go out and paint the town

pair off.definition: [for two people or other creatures] to form a couple or pair
pair off.example: All of them paired off and worked as teams to solve the puzzle

pair up with someone.definition: to join with someone to make a pair
pair up with someone.example: Sally decided to pair up with Jason for the dance contest

pal around with someone.definition: to associate with someone as a good friend
pal around with someone.example: I like to pal around with my friends on the weekends

pal up with someone.definition: to join with someone as a friend
pal up with someone.example: I palled up with Henry and we had a fine time together

pale at something.definition: to become weak, frightened, or pale from fear of something or the thought of something
pale at something.example: Bob paled at the thought of having to drive all the way back to get the forgotten suitcase

pale beside someone or something.definition: to appear to be weak or unimportant when compared to someone or something
pale beside someone or something.example: He is competent, but he pales beside Fran

pally with someone.definition: friendly or overly friendly with someone, as a pal would be
pally with someone.example: I don’t know why Sue acts so pally. I hardly know her

pan across to someone or something.definition: to turn or rotate a film or television camera so that the picture follows movement or moves to and settles on someone or something
pan across to someone or something.example: The camera panned across to Mary, who was sitting, looking out the window

pan for something.definition: to search for a precious metal, usually gold, by using a pan to locate the bits of metal in sand and gravel in a stream bed
pan for something.example: When I was in Alaska, I panned for gold in a little stream set aside for tourists

pan over someone or something.definition: to turn or rotate a film or television camera so that the picture moves across a view of someone or something
pan over someone or something.example: The camera panned over the skyline, picking up interesting cloud formations

pander to someone or something.definition: to cater toward undesirable tastes or people with undesirable tastes
pander to someone or something.example: All your writing seems to pander to persons with poor taste

panic at something.definition: to lose control in a frightening or shocking situation
panic at something.example: Try not to panic at what you see. It will be a shock

panic someone by something.definition: to make someone lose control by doing something
panic someone by something.example: She panicked Denise by describing the event too vividly

pant for air.definition: to breathe fast and hard in need of air
pant for air.example: The dog was panting for air

pant for someone or something.definition: to desire or long for someone or something
pant for someone or something.example: My heart is panting for you!

pant something out.definition: to tell something while panting for breath
pant something out.example: Laura had been running but she was able to pant the name of the injured person out

paper over something.definition: to put a layer of wallpaper on a wall
paper over something.example: We papered over the wall, giving the room a bright, new look

paper over the cracks in something.definition: to try to hide faults or difficulties, often in a hasty or not very successful way. (based on paper over something w.)
paper over the cracks in something.example: The politician tried to paper over the cracks in his party’s economic policy

a paper trail.definition: a series of records that is possible to examine to find out the sequence of things that happen
a paper trail.example: The legal department requires all these forms so that there is a paper trail of all activity

par for the course.definition: typical; about what one could expect. (this refers to golf courses, not school courses.)
par for the course.example: So he went off and left you? Well that’s about par for the course. He’s no friend

parade by someone.definition: ) to march past someone in a parade or as if in a parade
parade by someone.example: The soldiers paraded by the commander in chief

parade someone or an animal out.definition: to bring or march someone or an animal out in public
parade someone or an animal out.example: He parades his children out every Sunday as they go to church

parade someone or something in front of.definition: to exhibit someone or something in front of someone or something, as if in a parade
parade someone or something in front of.example: One by one, the teacher paraded the honor students in front of the parents

a paradise on earth.definition: a place on earth that is as lovely as paradise

search something for someone or somethin.definition: to examine something, looking for someone or something
search something for someone or somethin.example: Everyone searched the house for little Wally, but he was not to be found

search through something.definition: to examine all the things found in something
search through something.example: I searched through my books for the answer

season something with something.definition: to make something more flavorful with specific spices and herbs
season something with something.example: I always season my stews with lots of freshly ground black pepper

secede from something.example: Which was the first state to secede from the Union?

secondguess someone.definition: to try to predict what some person will do before it is known to anyone, including the person
secondguess someone.example: There is no point in trying to second-guess Bob. He is completely unpredictable

second hand.definition: from another person or source, not directly from personal experience or observation
second hand.example: I wasn’t present at the meeting. I heard about it at second hand

second nature to someone.example: Swimming is second nature to Jane

second thoughts about someone or somethi.definition: new doubts about someone or something

second to none.example: This is an excellent car—second to none

secure something against someone somethi.definition: to fasten something against the entry of someone, an animal, or something

security against something.definition: something that keeps something safe; something that protects; a protection

seduce someone from something.definition: to lure someone away from something
seduce someone from something.example: The crooked agent seduced Jerry from his usual honest behavior

see a man about a dog.definition: to leave for some unmentioned purpose. (often refers to going to the rest room.)

see about someone or something.definition: to investigate someone or something; to check on something that someone has said
see about someone or something.example: I don’t know who is going on the trip. You ask Jill, and I’ll see about Jerry

see after someone or something.example: Would you please see after Walter? He looks a little pale

see around something.definition: to see what is on the other side of or partially concealed by something

see if i care.definition: i do not care if you do it!
see if i care.example: Mary: That does it! I’m going home to Mother! John: See if I care!

see no evil hear no evil speak no evil.definition: ignore any evil that you come in contact with; be virtuous even though there is evil around you. (often represented by three monkeys, one of which is covering his eyes, one his ears, and one his mouth.)
see no evil hear no evil speak no evil.example: Jill: Do you have any idea why Fred is staying in the office so late every night? Jane: Not me. Like the three little monkeys, I see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil

see one\u2019s way clear to do something.definition: to find it possible to do something
see one\u2019s way clear to do something.example: I’d be happy if you could see your way clear to attend our meeting

see over something.definition: to be able to have a view over something such as a wall, fence, etc
see over something.example: I couldn’t see over the fence, but I could hear what was going on

see red.example: Whenever I think of the needless destruction of trees, I see red

see someone about someone or something.definition: to confer with someone about someone or something
see someone about someone or something.example: Jill has to see the boss about one of her office staff members

see someone across something.definition: to accompany someone across a dangerous area

see someone as someone or something.definition: to visualize someone as some other person or type of person

see someone as something.definition: to consider someone or something; to deem someone or something as something
see someone as something.example: The manager saw the skilled employee as a godsend

see someone back to something.definition: to accompany someone back to something or some place
see someone back to something.example: I saw her back to her apartment

see someone down to something.definition: to accompany or escort someone to a lower level

see someone to some place.example: I saw Mary to her apartment, and then got back in my car and left

see something against something.definition: to view something against something else

see to someone or something.definition: to take care of someone or something
see to someone or something.example: Tom will see to the horses. Come to the house and freshen up

see which way the wind is blowing.definition: to determine what is the most expedient thing to do under the conditions at hand

see ya byebye.example: Bill: I have to be off. Bob: See ya, bye-bye

see you around.definition: i will see you again somewhere

seek after someone or something.definition: to keep looking for someone or something

seek someone or something out.definition: to search for and find someone or something

seize onto someone or something.definition: to grab onto someone or something

seize someone or something with somethin.definition: to grab someone or something with something
seize someone or something with somethin.example: The robot seized Roger with its mechanical claws

the sport of kings.example: The sport of kings has sure impoverished a lot of commoners

that\u2019s too bad.definition: it is unfortunate.; i’m sorry to hear that
