that\u2019s what i say.definition: i agree with what was just said
that\u2019s what i say.example: Tom: We’ve got to get in there and stand up for our rights! Mary: That’s what I say

that\u2019s why.definition: a tag on the end of a statement that is an answer to a question beginning with why. (shows a little impatience.)
that\u2019s why.example: Sue: Why do you always put your right shoe on first? Bob: Because, when I get ready to put on my shoes, I always pick up the right one first, that’s why!

that takes care of that.example: That takes care of that, and I’m glad it’s over

that takes the cake.definition: that is good, and it wins the prize! (assuming that the prize is a cake.)
that takes the cake.example: “What a performance!” cheered John. “That takes the cake!”

that there.example: Gimme that there can of nails

that very thing.example: Why, I was just looking for that very thing!

that will do.definition: that is enough.; do no more
that will do.example: That’ll do, Billy. Stop your crying

that\u2019ll be the day.definition: it will be an unusually amazing day when that happens!
that\u2019ll be the day.example: Bill: I think I’ll fix that lamp now. Andy: When you finally get around to fixing that lamp, that’ll be the day!

that\u2019ll teach someone.definition: what happened to someone is a suitable punishment! (the someone is usually a pronoun.)
that\u2019ll teach someone.example: Bill: Tom, who has cheated on his taxes for years, finally got caught. Sue: That’ll teach him

thaw out.definition: to warm up from being frozen
thaw out.example: How long will it take for the chicken to thaw out?

thaw someone or something out.definition: to raise the temperature of someone or something above freezing; to warm someone up
thaw someone or something out.example: We need to get inside so I can thaw my brother out. His toes are almost frozen

the american dream.definition: the idealistic notion that americans are preoccupied with obtaining certain materialistic goals
the american dream.example: The American dream of home ownership, a car in the garage, and a chicken in every pot started in the early thirties

the beall and the endall.definition: cliché something that is the very best or most important; something so good that it will end the search for something better
the beall and the endall.example: Finishing the building of his boat became the be-all and end-all of Roger’s existence

the best of luck to someone.definition: i wish good luck to someone
the best of luck to someone.example: Alice: Good-bye, Bill. Bill: Goodbye, Alice. Best of luck. Alice: Thanks. Bye

the butler did it.definition: the butler performed the crime. (a catchphrase.)
the butler did it.example: I know who killed Lord Drax. The butler did it! I saw him! 2.  It happened just the way it always happens

the heavens opened.example: The heavens opened, and we had to run for cover

the hell you say.example: A: I won the lottery! B: The hell you say!

the lord only knows.example: The Lord only knows if John’s marriage will be a happy one

the luck of the irish.definition: luck associated with the irish people. (also said as a catch phrase for any kind of luck.)
the luck of the irish.example: Bill: How did you manage to do it, Jeff. Jeff: It’s the luck of the Irish, I guess

the proof of the pudding is in the eatin.definition: you don’t know the quality of something until you have tried it or experienced it
the proof of the pudding is in the eatin.example: Theory says that this material will produce a superior widget, but the proof of the pudding is in the eating

the race card.definition: cliché the issue of race magnified and injected into a situation which might otherwise be nonracial
the race card.example: At the last minute, the opposition candidate played the race card and lost the election for himself

the very idea.definition: i do not approve!; that is outrageous!

the wages of sin is death.definition: doing bad things can get you in a lot of trouble
the wages of sin is death.example: Serves him right. I always said, “The wages of sin is death.”

the wolf is at the door.definition: the threat of poverty is upon us
the wolf is at the door.example: I lost my job, my savings are gone, and now the wolf is at the door

them as has gits.definition: rich people can always get more
them as has gits.example: The millionaire keeps making more and more money, because he has lots of money to invest. Them as has, gits

them\u2019s fighting words.definition: what you just said will lead to a fight. (said as a threat.)
them\u2019s fighting words.example: I heard what you said about my brother, and them’s fighting words

then and there.definition: cliché right at that time and place
then and there.example: I asked him right then and there exactly what he meant

theorize about someone or something.definition: to hypothesize about someone or something; to conjecture about someone or something
theorize about someone or something.example: Let’s not waste time theorizing about Ted. He won’t change

theorize on something.definition: to make a theory about something
theorize on something.example: There is no point in theorizing on something when you have all the empirical evidence you need to draw a conclusion

there ain\u2019t nothin\u2019 to it.example: Mary: How do you keep your car so shiny? Tom: There ain’t nothin’ to it. I just wax it once a week

there are plenty of other fish in the se.definition: there are other choices. (used to refer to persons.)
there are plenty of other fish in the se.example: When John broke up with Ann, I told her not to worry. There are plenty of other fish in the sea

there are tricks in every trade.definition: in every occupation, there are established ways of doing things
there are tricks in every trade.example: John thought that he wouldn’t have to learn much in order to wait tables. But there are tricks in every trade, and the experienced waiters were able to teach him a lot

there aren\u2019t enough hours in the da.definition: there are too many things to do and not enough time
there aren\u2019t enough hours in the da.example: I am behind in all my work. There aren’t enough hours in the day!

there but for the grace of god go i.definition: i would likely have experienced or done the same bad thing if god had not been watching over me. (you can say this to refer to someone who has had bad luck; implies that the person is no less virtuous than you are but is now miserable purely because of bad luck, which might happen to you as well.)
there but for the grace of god go i.example: Jill: Ever since Julia’s house burned down, she’s been drinking heavily; she’ll probably lose her job because of it. Jane: There but for the grace of God

there is a fine line between something a.definition: there is little difference between something and something else
there is a fine line between something a.example: There is a fine line between a frown and a grimace

there is a remedy for everything except.definition: everything but death can be cured.; as long as you are alive, your problems can somehow be solved
there is a remedy for everything except.example: Bill: I’ll never recover from losing Nancy. Fred: Nonsense. There is a remedy for everything except death

there is a tide in the affairs of men.definition: if you have a favorable opportunity to do something, do it, or you will lose your chance. (from shakespeare’s play, julius caesar.)
there is a tide in the affairs of men.example: I think that this is the best possible time to start our own business. We shouldn’t hesitate. There is a tide in the affairs of men

there is a time and a place for everythi.definition: different things are appropriate on different occasions
there is a time and a place for everythi.example: There is a time and a place for everything, but this formal dinner is not the time or the place to eat with your fingers

there is honor among thieves.definition: criminals do not commit crimes against each other
there is honor among thieves.example: The gangster was loyal to his associates and did not tell their names to the police, demonstrating that there is honor among thieves

there is no accounting for tastes.definition: you cannot blame different people because they like different things, even if you do not understand why they like what they like
there is no accounting for tastes.example: Jill: I can’t believe so many people are going to see that idiotic movie. Jane: There’s no accounting for tastes

there is no chance.definition: there is no chance that something will happen. (no chance is informal.)
there is no chance.example: Tom: Do you think that some little country like that will actually attack England? John: There’s no chance

there is no doubt about it.definition: it cannot be doubted.; it is obvious
there is no doubt about it.example: Jane: It’s really cold today. Fred: No doubt about it!

there is no love lost between someone an.definition: there is no friendship wasted between someone and someone else (because they are enemies)
there is no love lost between someone an.example: Ever since their big argument, there has been no love lost between Tom and Bill

there is no need to.definition: you do not have to.; it is not necessary
there is no need to.example: Mary: Shall I try to save all this wrapping paper? Sue: No need. It’s all torn

there is no pleasure without pain.definition: for every pleasure you enjoy, you must suffer some pain
there is no pleasure without pain.example: We had a fabulous vacation, but it’s going to take us years to pay for it. Oh, well, there’s no pleasure without pain

there is no rest for the weary.definition: even people who are worn-out must continue to work. (describes a situation in which a tired person has to do more work.)
there is no rest for the weary.example: By the time I finished doing the laundry, it was so late I had to begin cooking supper for the family. There is no rest for the weary

there is no royal road to learning.example: Sue: I don’t see why we have to do homework every night. Why can’t we just listen to the lectures? Nancy: There is no royal road to learning

there is nothing new under the sun.definition: everything that is happening now has happened before
there is nothing new under the sun.example: Jill: The newspaper today is shocking. Three prominent politicians have been convicted of fraud. Jane: That’s not shocking. It only proves that there’s nothing new under the sun

there is safety in numbers.definition: a group of people is less likely to be attacked than a single person
there is safety in numbers.example: Gail never went out after dark without at least three friends, since she knew that there is safety in numbers

there\u2019s many a good tune played on.definition: old people can be very capable
there\u2019s many a good tune played on.example: Just because Nigel is old doesn’t mean he’s useless. There’s many a good tune played on an old fiddle

there\u2019s many a slip \u2019twixt the.definition: many things may happen to prevent you from carrying out what you intend to do
there\u2019s many a slip \u2019twixt the.example: Bob: Now that I have a contract with a publisher, nothing in the world can stop me from writing this book. Alan: Don’t be so sure. There’s many a slip ’twixt the cup and the lip

there\u2019s more than one way to skin a.definition: you can always find more than one way to do something
there\u2019s more than one way to skin a.example: Jill: How will we fix the sink without a wrench? Jane: There’s more than one way to skin a cat

there\u2019s no accounting for taste.definition: cliché there is no explanation for people’s preferences
there\u2019s no accounting for taste.example: Look at that purple and orange car! There’s no accounting for taste

there\u2019s no flies on someone.definition: someone is full of energy and drive
there\u2019s no flies on someone.example: There’s no f lies on Jane. She’s up at five every morning, training for the big race

there\u2019s no fool like an old fool.definition: cliché old people are supposed to be wise, so if an old person behaves foolishly, it is worse than a young person behaving foolishly
there\u2019s no fool like an old fool.example: As old Mrs. Fleischman watched her husband try to dance the way their grandchildren danced, she muttered, “There’s no fool like an old fool.”

there\u2019s no place like home.definition: cliché home is the most satisfying place to be
there\u2019s no place like home.example: After his long trip, Bob came into his house, sat down in his favorite chair, and happily sighed, “There’s no place like home.”

there\u2019s no rose without a thorn.definition: to enjoy any beautiful or pleasant thing, you must endure something difficult or painful
there\u2019s no rose without a thorn.example: Mike: My bride is lovely and gracious, but I’m discovering that she has a terrible temper. Bill: There’s no rose without a thorn

there\u2019s no time like the present.definition: cliché do what you are supposed to do now. (you can use this to suggest that something be done right away.)
there\u2019s no time like the present.example: Jill: When should we start cleaning up the house? Jane: No time like the present

there\u2019s no way to tell.definition: no one can find out the answer
there\u2019s no way to tell.example: Tom: How long are we likely to have to wait before the plane takes off ? Clerk: Sorry, sir. There’s no way to tell

there\u2019s nobody home.definition: there are no brains in someone’s head
there\u2019s nobody home.example: There’s lots of goodwill in that head, but there’s nobody home

there\u2019s none so blind as those who.definition: you cannot make someone pay attention to something that he or she does not want to notice. (used often to upbraid someone for being unwilling to notice what you are trying call attention to.)
there\u2019s none so blind as those who.example: Mother: This is the fifth time our daughter has been arrested for shoplifting. Don’t you think we ought to seek some kind of help for her? Father: Our girl would never shoplift. I’m sure all those arrests were just some kind of mistake. Mother: There’s none so blind as those who will not see

there\u2019s none so deaf as those who w.definition: if you tell someone something that he or she does not want to know, he or she will not pay attention to you
there\u2019s none so deaf as those who w.example: I tried repeatedly to tell my supervisor about the low morale in our department, but there’s none so deaf as those who will not hear

there\u2019s nothing to it.example: John: Is it hard to learn to f ly a small plane? Sue: There’s nothing to it!

there you are.definition: that’s the way things are.; this is the way things have worked out. (a fatalistic dismissal.)
there you are.example: “There’s nothing more that can be done. We’ve done what we could. So there you are,” said Fred, dejected

there you go.definition: hooray! you did it right! (usually there you go!)
there you go.example: There you go! That’s the way!

thereby hangs a tale.definition: there is an interesting story connected with this matter
thereby hangs a tale.example: Yes, she comes in late most mornings, and thereby hangs a tale. She has a drinking problem

they also serve who only stand and wait.definition: sometimes you must be patient and do nothing, even though you would like to be actively helping. (from john milton’s poem, “on his blindness.”)
they also serve who only stand and wait.example: Jill: Can I help? Jane: No, we’ve got enough people helping. Jill: But I want to help. Jane: They also serve who only stand and wait

they don\u2019t make them like they used.definition: cliché goods are not as well made now as they were in the past. (often used as a catchphrase. them is often ’em.)
they don\u2019t make them like they used.example: Look at this flimsy door! They don’t make ’em like they used to

they must have seen you coming.definition: you were really cheated. they saw you coming and decided they could cheat you easily
they must have seen you coming.example: Andy: It cost two hundred dollars. Rachel: You paid two hundred dollars for that thing? Boy, they must have seen you coming

they went that a\u2019way.definition: cliché the villains went in that direction. (from western movies.)
they went that a\u2019way.example: Those guys aren’t here. They went that a’way

thick and fast.definition: in large numbers or amounts and at a rapid rate
thick and fast.example: The enemy soldiers came thick and fast

thick as pea soup.example: This fog is as thick as pea soup. You can’t see ten feet in front of you

thick as thieves.definition: cliché very close-knit; friendly; allied. (thick = close and loyal. *also: as ~.)
thick as thieves.example: Mary, Tom, and Sally are as thick as thieves. They go everywhere together

thicken something up.definition: to make something, such as a fluid, thicker
thicken something up.example: I have to thicken this gravy up before we can serve dinner

thickskinned.definition: not easily upset or hurt; insensitive. (the opposite of thin-skinned. *typically: be ~; become ~; grow ~.)
thickskinned.example: Tom won’t worry about your insults. He’s completely thick-skinned

thin down.example: He stopped eating desserts and fatty foods so he could thin down

thin on top.example: James is wearing a hat because he’s getting thin on top

thin out.definition: to spread out; to become less dense
thin out.example: The trees began to thin out as we got higher up the mountain

thin someone down.definition: to make someone thinner or slimmer
thin someone down.example: What you need to thin you down is less, not more

thin something down.example: You should thin this down with a little water

thin something out.definition: to make something less dense; to scatter something
thin something out.example: You will have to thin the young plants out, because there is not room for all of them

a thing of beauty is a joy forever.definition: beautiful things give pleasure that lasts even longer than the beautiful things themselves. (this is a line from john keats’s poem “endymion.” also a thing of beauty and a joy forever, used to describe something beautiful in lofty terms, often ironically.)
a thing of beauty is a joy forever.example: Jill: I don’t understand why someone would pay millions of dollars to have some old painting. Jane: Because a thing of beauty is a joy forever

a thing or two about someone or somethin.definition: bits of information or criticism about someone or something; a few facts about someone or something
a thing or two about someone or somethin.example: I told Bob a thing or two about cars

a thing you don\u2019t want is dear at a.definition: you should not buy something just because it is cheap
a thing you don\u2019t want is dear at a.example: Jill: There’s a sale on black-and-white film; we should get some. Jane: We never use black-and-white film. Jill: But it’s so cheap. Jane: A thing you don’t want is dear at any price

things are looking up.example: Since I got a salary increase, things are looking up

things are seldom what they seem.definition: things often appear different from what they really are
things are seldom what they seem.example: Emily seems to be a fine young lady, but be careful. Things are seldom what they seem

think about someone or something.example: Whenever I think about him, I get goose bumps

think ahead to something.definition: to have thoughts about something that is to happen in the future
think ahead to something.example: I began to think ahead to next year when the same thing might happen

think back on someone or something.definition: to remember and think about someone or something
think back on someone or something.example: When I think back on Sally and the good times we had together, I get very sad

think back to something.definition: to remember back to something in the past
think back to something.example: Now, try and think back to the night of January 16

think before doing something.definition: to consider the consequences before doing something
think before doing something.example: You really ought to think before you take on a job like that

think better of someone or something.definition: to raise one’s opinion of someone or something
think better of someone or something.example: I think better of him since I saw how well he does in the sales meetings

think better of something.definition: to reconsider doing something and end up not doing it
think better of something.example: I hope that you will think better of what you are doing and how many people you are hurting

think for oneself.definition: to do one’s own thinking; to think independently
think for oneself.example: I think for myself. I don’t need anyone to tell me what to do, do I?

think inside the box.definition: to think in traditional fashion, bound by old, nonfunctional, or limiting structures, rules, or practices. (as if thinking or creativity were confined or limited by a figurative box. compare this with think outside the box.)
think inside the box.example: You won’t come up with good ideas if you think only inside the box

think nothing of doing something.definition: to give no thought or hesitation to doing something
think nothing of doing something.example: She thinks nothing of helping other people at any time of day or night

think on one\u2019s feet.definition: to be able to speak and reason well while (standing and talking) in front of an audience, especially extemporaneously
think on one\u2019s feet.example: She really thinks on her feet well

think out loud.example: Excuse me. I didn’t really mean to say that. I was just thinking out loud

think outside the box.definition: to think freely, not bound by old, nonfunctional, or limiting structures, rules, or practices. (as if thinking or creativity were confined in or limited by a figurative box. compare this with think inside the box.)
think outside the box.example: You won’t come up with good ideas until you think outside the box

think someone fit for something.definition: to judge someone to be in condition or healthy enough for something
think someone fit for something.example: Do you think me fit for the race?

think someone or something fit for someo.definition: to judge someone or something to be suitable for someone or something
think someone or something fit for someo.example: I do not think this book fit for young readers

think something out.definition: to think through something; to prepare a plan or scheme
think something out.example: This is an interesting problem. I’ll have to take some time and think it out

think something over.definition: to think about something and whether one will choose to do it
think something over.example: I need a few minutes to think it over

think something through.definition: to run over and try to settle something in one’s mind
think something through.example: Let me think this through and call you in the morning

think something up.example: Don’t worry. I’ll find a way to do it. I can think something up in time to get it done

think straight.example: I’m so tired I can’t think straight

think the sun rises and sets on someone.definition: to think someone is the most important person in the world
think the sun rises and sets on someone.example: Her daddy just thinks the sun rises and sets on her

think the world of someone or something.definition: to be very fond of someone or something
think the world of someone or something.example: Mary thinks the world of her little sister

think to do something.example: Sorry. I didn’t think to call you in time

think twice about someone or something.definition: to give careful consideration to someone or something
think twice about someone or something.example: Ed may be a good choice, but I suggest that you think twice about him

think twice before doing something.definition: to consider carefully whether one should do something; to be cautious about doing something
think twice before doing something.example: You should think twice before quitting your job

think upon someone or something.definition: to contemplate someone or something; to muse or reflect on someone or something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
think upon someone or something.example: I thought upon Abraham Lincoln and how much we all owe him

thinskinned.definition: easily upset or hurt; sensitive. (the opposite of thick-skinned. *typically: be ~; become ~; grow ~.)
thinskinned.example: You’ll have to handle Mary’s mother carefully. She’s very thin-skinned

the third degree.definition: a long and detailed period of questioning
the third degree.example: Why is it I get the third degree from you every time I come home late?

the third time\u2019s the charm.definition: the third time you try to do something, it will work
the third time\u2019s the charm.example: Jill: I’ve called Miriam twice, but she doesn’t answer her phone. Jane: Try again. The third time’s the charm

thirst for something.definition: to desire something to drink. (somewhat formal.)
thirst for something.example: “I thirst for something cooling and refreshing.” said the preacher

thirsty for something.example: I’m thirsty for a glass of cold water. 2.  craving or desiring something

this away and that away.definition: first one way and then the other
this away and that away.example: She was craning her neck this a-way and that a-way, looking for him

this here.example: Just let me fix this here chair leg

this is it.definition: this is the time, place, or thing that we have been looking or waiting for
this is it.example: This is it. This is the chance you’ve been waiting for!

this is my floor.definition: a phrase said by someone at the back of an elevator suggesting that people make way for that person to exit at a particular floor
this is my floor.example: Mary said, “This is my f loor,” and everyone made room for her to get out of the elevator

this is where i came in.definition: i have heard all this before. (said when a situation begins to seem repetitive, as when a film one has seen part of before reaches familiar scenes.)
this is where i came in.example: John sat through a few minutes of the argument, and when Tom and Alice kept saying the same thing over and over John said, “This is where I came in,” and left the room

this one is on someone.definition: the cost of this drink or meal will be paid by the person named or designated
this one is on someone.example: A: Should we ask for separate checks or what? B: No, no, this one’s on the boss!

this vale of tears.definition: the earth; mortal life on earth. (a vale is a literary word for valley.)
this vale of tears.example: When it comes time for me to leave this vale of tears, I hope I can leave some worthwhile memories behind

thither and yon.example: I sent my résumé thither and yon, but no one responded

those were the days.definition: cliché the days we have been referring to were the greatest of times
those were the days.example: Ah, yes. The eighties. Those were the days!

those who can do those who can\u2019t te.definition: people who are able to do something well can do that thing for a living, while people who are not able to do anything that well make a living by teaching. (used to disparage teachers. from george bernard shaw’s man and superman.)
those who can do those who can\u2019t te.example: Bob: I’m so discouraged. My writing teacher told me my novel is hopeless. Jane: Don’t listen to her, Bob. Remember: those who can, do; those who can’t, teach

thrash around.definition: to move about restlessly or violently
thrash around.example: Settle down and stop thrashing around

thrash something out.definition: to discuss something thoroughly and solve any problems
thrash something out.example: The committee took hours to thrash the whole matter out

thrash something out of someone.definition: to beat something out of someone
thrash something out of someone.example: The sheriff really wanted to thrash the truth out of Tex, but that is illegal

thread one\u2019s way through something.definition: to make a path for oneself through a crowded area; to make one’s way carefully through a crowded area
thread one\u2019s way through something.example: The spy threaded his way through the crowd

thread through something.definition: to travel through a crowded area; to move carefully through an area where there are many obstacles
thread through something.example: The spy threaded through the crowd at the palace

threaten someone with someone or somethi.definition: to warn someone that there will be punishment in the form of someone or something if conditions are not met
threaten someone with someone or somethi.example: No, no! Your Uncle Herman is not coming here! Please don’t threaten me with Uncle Herman!

three bricks shy of a load.example: I would never say she was dense. Just three bricks shy of a load

three squares a day.definition: three nourishing meals a day. (with breakfast, lunch, and dinner considered the usual three meals.)
three squares a day.example: I was glad to get back home to three squares

three strikes and you are out.definition: three chances and you are finished. (from baseball.)
three strikes and you are out.example: One more arrest for speeding and you lose your license. You know, three strikes and you’re out

thrill at someone or something.definition: to become excited by someone or something
thrill at someone or something.example: The opera was mystically intoxicating, and the audience thrilled at the tenor lead

thrill someone with something.definition: to create or use something to cause someone much joy
thrill someone with something.example: The famous singer thrilled us with a lovely song

thrill to something.definition: to become excited by something; to experience great joy while experiencing something
thrill to something.example: I always thrill to the sound of a marching band

thrive upon something.definition: to grow vigorously because of something. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
thrive upon something.example: These plants thrive upon wet soil

throng around someone or something.definition: to crowd around someone or something
throng around someone or something.example: The children thronged around the lady with the bags of candy

throng into something.definition: [for a crowd] to swarm into some place
throng into something.example: The eager crowd thronged into the department store to partake in the advertised sale

throng out of something.definition: [for a crowd] to swarm out of something or some place
throng out of something.example: The people thronged out of the concert hall at the end of the program

throttle something down.definition: to reduce the speed of an engine by adjusting the throttle
throttle something down.example: She throttled her engine down and came to a stop

through and through.example: I’ve studied this report through and through trying to find the facts you’ve mentioned

through hell and high water.definition: through all sorts of severe difficulties. (use hell with caution.)
through hell and high water.example: I came through hell and high water to get to this meeting on time. Why don’t you start on time?

through the cracks.definition: [moving] past the elements that are intended to catch or detect such things
through the cracks.example: I am afraid that some of these issues will slip through the cracks unless we make a note about each one

through the mill.definition: badly treated; abused and exhausted. ( on a grain mill. *typically: be ~; go ~; put someone ~; send someone ~.)
through the mill.example: This has been a rough day. I’ve really been through the mill

through thick and thin.definition: cliché through good times and bad times
through thick and thin.example: We’ve been together through thick and thin, and we won’t desert each other now

through with someone or something.example: I’m all through with course requirements. Now I can learn something I really enjoy

throw a fight.definition: to lose a boxing match on purpose. (boxing. other words can replace a.)
throw a fight.example: I just know that Wilbur didn’t throw that fight

throw a game.definition: to lose a game on purpose
throw a game.example: I know Wilbur. He could never throw a game

throw a glance at someone or something.definition: to take a quick peek at someone or something
throw a glance at someone or something.example: Liz threw a glance at her brother to see what he was going to do

throw a monkey wrench in the works.definition: to cause problems for someone’s plans

two jumps ahead of someone.definition: a good way ahead of someone

two of a kind.definition: people or things of the same type or that are similar in character, attitude, etc

two shakes of a lamb\u2019s tail.example: I’ll be there in two shakes of a lamb’s tail

two strikes against one.definition: two strikes on a baseball batter, three being the number that will put the batter “out.” (such a player is in a vulnerable position. *typically: get ~; have ~.)

two whoops and a holler.example: Lexington? That’s just two whoops and a holler from here

two wrongs do not make a right.definition: someone else may do something bad and not be punished, but that does not mean you are allowed to do bad things

twofisted.example: Perry is a real, two-fisted cowboy, always ready for a fight or a drunken brawl

a twotime loser.example: Poor Richard is a two-time loser

twotime someone.definition: sl. to cheat on or betray one’s spouse or lover by dating or seeing someone else

a twoway street.example: This is a twoway street, you know. You will have to help me someday in return

type over something.definition: to type one letter over another

ugly as a toad.definition: [of a living creature] very ugly. (*also: as ~.)

ugly as sin.example: Why would anyone want to buy that dress? It’s as ugly as sin!

unaccustomed to someone or something.definition: not used to someone or something

unbosom oneself to someone.definition: to reveal one’s inner thoughts and secrets to someone

under construction.example: We cannot travel on this road because it’s under construction

under one\u2019s breath.definition: [spoken] so softly that almost no one can hear it

under the influence of alcohol.definition: euph. drunk; nearly drunk; affected by alcohol

under the sun.example: This is the largest cattle ranch under the sun

under the table.example: Jed was under the table by midnight

under the weather.example: I feel sort of under the weather today

under the wire.definition: just barely in time or on time

unfold into something.definition: [for something folded up] to unfold into something

unify someone or something into somethin.definition: to combine people or things into a united whole

union is strength.definition: if people join together, they are more powerful than if they work by themselves

unite against someone or something.definition: to join against someone or something

until all hours.example: Mary is out until all hours, night after night

up against something.example: The car is up against the back of the garage! Back out a little! 2.  in conflict with something; facing something as a barrier. ( on Q. *Typically: be ~; go ~.)

up in arms.example: The entire population is up in arms

very good.example: John: How do you like your lobster? Alice: Mmm. Very good

weary someone with something.example: He wearied her with his constant requests

weasel out of something.definition: to squeeze one’s way out of something
weasel out of something.example: Somehow, the child managed to weasel out of the hole she was stuck in

weather permitting.example: Weather permitting, we will be there on time

weather the storm.definition: to experience and survive a storm
weather the storm.example: We decided to stay in the building and weather the storm there with the other visitors. 2.  to experience something and survive it. ( on Q.)

weave around.definition: to move about, changing directions at random
weave around.example: The drunken driver wove around all over the road

weave in and out of something.definition: to move, drive, or walk in and out of something, such as traffic, a line, etc
weave in and out of something.example: The car was weaving in and out of traffic dangerously

weave something from something.definition: to make a fabric from some type of fiber
weave something from something.example: They weave this cloth from a fine plant fiber

weave something into something.definition: to form fibers into a fabric
weave something into something.example: They could weave the threads into simple cloth with a primitive loom

weave through something.definition: to move through something by turning and dodging
weave through something.example: The car wove through traffic, almost hitting a number of other cars

wed someone to someone.definition: to marry someone to someone else
wed someone to someone.example: Her parents wedded her to a young prince when she was only twelve

wed someone to something.definition: to join someone firmly to a concept. ( on wed someone to someone.)
wed someone to something.example: Don’t try to wed me to your way of doing things. I have my own way

wedded to someone.example: The couple will have been wed to each other for fifty years next June

wedded to something.definition: mentally attached to something; firmly committed to something. ( on wed(ded) to someone.)
wedded to something.example: The manager was wedded to the idea of getting new computers

wedge someone or something in between pe.definition: to work someone or something into a tiny space between people or things
wedge someone or something in between pe.example: The usher wedged us in between two enormously fat people, and we were all very uncomfortable

weed someone or something out.definition: to remove someone or something unwanted or undesirable from a group or collection. ( on removing weeds from the soil.)
weed someone or something out.example: We had to weed the less productive workers out one by one

week in week out.example: We have the same old food, week in, week out

weep about someone or something.definition: to cry about someone or something; to mourn someone or something
weep about someone or something.example: She was weeping about her grandfather, who had passed away in the night

weep for joy.example: She was so happy, she wept for joy

weep for someone or an animal.definition: to cry out of sorrow for someone or an animal
weep for someone or an animal.example: She wept for her puppy when it was terribly sick

weep over someone or something.definition: to cry about someone or something
weep over someone or something.example: No need to weep over me. I’ll do all right

weigh against someone or something.definition: to count against someone or something; [for some fact] to work against someone or something
weigh against someone or something.example: I hope my many absences do not weigh against me on the final grade

weigh in at something.definition: to present oneself at a certain weight. (usually said of boxers.)
weigh in at something.example: The fighter weighed in at over two hundred pounds

weigh on someone\u2019s mind.definition: [for something] to be in a person’s thoughts; [for something] to be bothering someone’s thinking
weigh on someone\u2019s mind.example: This problem has been weighing on my mind for many days now

weigh someone down.definition: [for a thought] to worry or depress someone
weigh someone down.example: All these problems really weigh me down

weigh someone or something down.example: The heavy burden weighed the poor donkey down

weigh someone\u2019s words.definition: to consider carefully what someone says
weigh someone\u2019s words.example: I listened to what he said, and I weighed his words very carefully

weigh something against something.definition: to ponder something by balancing it against something
weigh something against something.example: I weighed going to town against staying here and sleeping and I decided to stay here

weigh something out.definition: to weigh something as it is distributed
weigh something out.example: The merchant weighed the cuts of meat out for each of the waiting women

weigh something up.definition: to find out the weight of something
weigh something up.example: I can’t tell you how much this will cost until I weigh it up

weigh upon someone.definition: to burden or worry someone. (upon is formal and less commonly used than on.)
weigh upon someone.example: The problems at the office were beginning to weigh upon Mr. Franklin

weight someone or something down with so.definition: to place a heavy weight in or on someone or something; to press down or hold down someone or something with a heavy weight
weight someone or something down with so.example: The inquisitors weighted the accused down with stones, but he still refused to say what they wanted

weight something against someone or some.definition: to bias something against someone or something
weight something against someone or some.example: The prosecutor tried to weight the evidence against the defendant

weird out.definition: sl. to become emotionally disturbed or unnerved; to flip out
weird out.example: The day was just gross. I thought I would weird out at noon

weirded out.definition: sl. disturbed or unnerved by drugs or events
weirded out.example: I was totally weirded out and couldn’t control myself

welcome aboard.definition: welcome to employment at our company
welcome aboard.example: Glad to meet you. Welcome aboard

welcome someone or something back.definition: to greet the return of someone or something
welcome someone or something back.example: We are delighted to welcome you back to our house

welcome someone to something.definition: to greet someone who has come into something or some place
welcome someone to something.example: I am very pleased to welcome you to Adamsville!

welcome someone with something.definition: to present something to someone as a sign of greeting
welcome someone with something.example: The natives welcomed us with garlands of f lowers

welcome to do something.definition: free to do something; allowed to do something
welcome to do something.example: The audience is welcome to ask questions at the end of the speech

welcome to our house.definition: an expression said by a host or hostess when greeting guests and bringing them into the house
welcome to our house.example: Andy: Hello, Sally. Welcome to our house. Come on in. Sally: Thanks. It’s good to be here

weld someone and someone else together.definition: to bind people together. ( on weld something and something else together.)
weld someone and someone else together.example: Their experiences in the war welded Tom and Sam together for life

weld something and something else togeth.definition: to attach things to one another by welding
weld something and something else togeth.example: The worker welded the ends of the rods together

well begun is half done.definition: beginning a project well makes it easier to do the rest.; once you have begun a project well, you do not need to put in much more effort to finish it
well begun is half done.example: Jill: I’m afraid I’ll never be able to finish writing this report. Jane: You’ve already written a good introduction. Well begun is half done

well bust my buttons.example: Well, bust my buttons! It’s good to see you!

well disposed toward someone or somethin.definition: friendly with someone or something; having a positive or favorable attitude toward someone or something
well disposed toward someone or somethin.example: I am not well disposed toward Walter

well done.example: Sally: Well done, Tom. Excellent speech. Tom: Thanks

well in hand.example: Is that matter well in hand?

well into something.definition: far into something or far along in something
well into something.example: It was well into the morning before she awoke

well out of something.example: I opened the door and the water welled out

well outside of something.example: We were well out of the city when the air-raid sirens went off

well over.definition: [for a liquid] to fill up and spill over
well over.example: The laundry tub finally welled over as it became too full

well said.definition: you said that very well, and i agree
well said.example: As Sally sat down, Mary complimented her, “Well said, Sally. You made your point very well.”

well shut my mouth.example: Well, shut my mouth! I didn’t know you were in town!

well up in years.example: Jane’s husband is well up in years. He is nearly seventy-five

well up inside someone.definition: [for a feeling] to seem to swell and move inside one’s body
well up inside someone.example: A feeling of revulsion began to well up inside Fred

well up with something.definition: to fill up or gush with something, such as water
well up with something.example: Her eyes welled up with tears

well what do you know.definition: a way of expressing surprise at finding something that is unexpected; an expression of mild surprise at something someone has said. (no answer is expected or desired.)
well what do you know.example: Andy: Well, what do you know! Here’s a brand new shirt in this old trunk. Bob: I wonder how it got there

welltodo.definition: wealthy and of good social position. (often with quite, as in the examples.)
welltodo.example: The Jones family is quite well-to-do

welsh on someone.definition: to renege on a bet or an agreement made with someone. (also spelled welch.)
welsh on someone.example: You had better not welsh on me if you know what is good for you

welsh on something with someone.definition: to renege on a bet or agreement made with someone. (also spelled welch.)
welsh on something with someone.example: Max welshed on his bet with Lefty. That was not a wise thing to do

welter in something.definition: to roll about or wallow in something; to be immersed in or surrounded by something
welter in something.example: Most breeds of pigs will welter happily in mud

were you born in a barn.definition: an expression chiding someone who has left a door open or who is ill-mannered or messy
were you born in a barn.example: Andy: Close the door! Were you born in a barn? Bob: Sorry

a wet blanket.definition: a dull or depressing person who spoils other people’s enjoyment
a wet blanket.example: Jack’s fun at parties, but his brother’s a wet blanket

wet one\u2019s whistle.example: He stopped at the bar to wet his whistle

wet someone or something down.definition: to put water onto someone or something
wet someone or something down.example: Mother wet the children down with a hose while she was washing the car

whack someone or something up.definition: sl. to damage someone or something
whack someone or something up.example: Bob got mad at Greg and whacked him up

whack something off.definition: sl. to complete something easily or quickly
whack something off.example: If you want a pair of these, I can whack them off for you in a few minutes

whack something up.example: In about an hour, he had whacked the tree up into small logs

whale into someone or an animal.definition: to attack or punish someone or an animal
whale into someone or an animal.example: Jimmy’s dad really whaled into him

whale the tar out of someone.example: My father threatened to whale the tar out of me

wham bam thank you ma\u2019am.example: We hit a wham bam thank you ma’am and lost one of our hubcaps

what about doing something.definition: would you like to do something?
what about doing something.example: What about going on a picnic?

what about having something.definition: would you like to have something?

what about it.definition: so what?; do you want to argue about it? (contentious.)
what about it.example: Bill: I heard you were the one accused of breaking the window. Tom: Yeah? So, what about it?

what about you.definition: what is your choice? (compare this with how about you?)
what about you.example: Tom: I’m having the pot roast and a cup of coffee. What about you? Mary: I want something fattening and unhealthy

what are you drinking.definition: a phrase inquiring what someone is already drinking so that the person who asks the question can offer another drink of the same thing
what are you drinking.example: Bill: Hi, Tom. Nice to see you. Can I get you something to drink? Tom: Sure. What are you drinking? Bill: Scotch and water

what are you driving at.definition: what are you implying?; what do you mean?
what are you driving at.example: What are you driving at? What are you trying to say?

what are you having.definition: what food or drink are you planning to order? (either part of a conversation or a request from food service personnel. in a restaurant, sometimes the host or hostess will signal to a guest to order first by saying this. sometimes a guest will ask this of a host or hostess to determine the price range that is appropriate.)
what are you having.example: Waiter: Would you care to order now? Tom: What are you having? Mary: You order. I haven’t made up my mind

what brings you here.definition: what is your reason for being here? (a polite request for this information. more polite than “why are you here?”)
what brings you here.example: Tom: Hello, Mary. What brings you here? Mary: I was invited, just like you

what can i say.definition: i have no explanation or excuse. what do you expect me to say?
what can i say.example: Bill: Why on earth did you lose that big order? Sally: What can I say? I’m sorry!

what can i tell you.definition: what kind of information do you want?
what can i tell you.example: Bill: I have a question. Bob: What can I tell you? Bill: When do we arrive at Chicago?

what can\u2019t be cured must be endured.definition: if you cannot do anything about a problem, you will have to live with it
what can\u2019t be cured must be endured.example: Alan: No matter what I do, I can’t make the dog stop barking in the middle of the night. Jane: What can’t be cured must be endured, then, I guess

what difference does it make.definition: does it really matter?; does it cause any trouble?
what difference does it make.example: What if I choose to leave home? What difference does it make?

what do you know.definition: a typical inquiry on greeting someone. (a specific answer is not expected. often pronounced “wha-da-ya know?”)
what do you know.example: Bob: Hey, Tom! What do you know? Tom: Look who’s here! Hi, Bob!

what do you know about that.example: Tom: I heard that Jim and Mary are getting married. Jane: Well! What do you know about that?

what do you know for sure.definition: how are you?; what do you know? (familiar. an elaboration of what do you know? does not require a direct answer.)
what do you know for sure.example: Tom: Hey, man! What do you know for sure? Bill: Howdy, Tom. What’s new?

what do you say.example: Bob: What do you say, Tom? Tom: Hey, man. How are you doing?

what do you think.example: Mary: This is our new company stationery. What do you think? Bill: Stunning. Simply stunning

what do you think of this weather.definition: a phrase used to open a conversation with someone, often someone one has just met
what do you think of this weather.example: Sue: Glad to meet you, Mary. Mary: What do you think about this weather? Sue: I’ve seen better

what do you think you are doing here.definition: why are you in this place? (stern and threatening.)
what do you think you are doing here.example: John: Mary! Mary: John! John: What do you think you’re doing here?

what do you want me to say.definition: you caught me and i’m sorry, and i don’t know what more to say
what do you want me to say.example: What do you want me to say? I apologized. There is nothing more I can do

what does that prove.definition: so what?; that does not mean anything. (a defensive expression. the heaviest stress is on that. often with so, as in the examples.)
what does that prove.example: Tom: It seems that you were in the apartment the same night that it was robbed. Bob: So, what does that prove? Tom: Nothing, really. It’s just something we need to keep in mind

what else can i do for you.definition: in what other way can i serve you? (said by shopkeepers, clerks, and service personnel.)
what else can i do for you.example: Bill: What else can I do for you? Bob: Please check the oil

what for.example: Billy’s mother gave him what for because he didn’t get home on time

what gives.definition: what happened?; what went wrong?; what’s the problem?
what gives.example: Bill: Hi, you guys. What gives? Bob: Nothing, just a little misunderstanding. Tom’s a little angry

what goes up must come down.definition: anything that has risen or been raised up must eventually fall down
what goes up must come down.example: When it came time to move out of our second-f loor apartment, we looked at our large, heavy sofa with dismay, not sure how we would get it down the stairs. “What goes up must come down,” my husband said, “Somehow.”

what happened.example: Bob (approaching a crowd): What happened? Tom (with Bob): What’s wrong? Bystander: Just a little mix-up. A car wanted to drive on the sidewalk, that’s all

what have you been up to.definition: i haven’t seen you for a long time, so tell me what you have been doing?
what have you been up to.example: Hi, Tom. Where have you been? What have you been up to?

what if.definition: what would be the result if something were true?
what if.example: What if you had all the money you want?

what if i do.definition: does it matter to you if i do it?; what difference does it make if i do it?
what if i do.example: Tom: Are you really going to sell your leather coat? Bob: What if I do?

what if i don\u2019t.definition: does it matter to you if i do not do it?; what difference does it make if i do not do it?
what if i don\u2019t.example: Bob: You’re certainly going to tidy up a bit before going out, aren’t you? Tom: What if I don’t?

what in the hell.example: What in the hell? Who did this?

what in the sam hill.definition: what has happened?; what? (an elaboration of what. sam hill is a euphemism for hell. often with the force of an exclamation. see examples for variations.)
what in the sam hill.example: What in Sam Hill is going on around here?

what is it.definition: what do you want from me?; why do you want to get my attention?
what is it.example: Tom: John, can I talk to you for a minute? John: What is it?

what makes someone tick.definition: something that motivates someone; something that makes someone behave in a certain way. ( on what makes something tick.)
what makes someone tick.example: William is sort of strange. I don’t know what makes him tick

what makes something tick.definition: the sense or mechanism that makes something run or function. (with reference to the ticking of a clock representing the functioning of the clock.)
what makes something tick.example: I don’t know what makes it tick

what makes you think so.definition: why do you think that?; what is your evidence for that conclusion?
what makes you think so.example: Tom: This bread may be a little old. Alice: What makes you think so? Tom: The green spots on the edges

what number are you calling.definition: an expression used when one suspects that a telephone caller may have gotten the wrong number
what number are you calling.example: Bob (on the telephone): Hello? Mary: Hello, is Sally there? Bob: Uh, what number are you calling? Mary: I guess I have the wrong number. Sorry. Bob: No problem. Good-bye

what of it.definition: what does it matter?; why treat it as if it were important?; why do you think that this is any of your business? (a bit contentious.)
what of it.example: John: I hear you’ve been having a little trouble at the office. Bob: What of it?

what one doesn\u2019t know won\u2019t hu.definition: cliché unknown facts cannot worry or upset a person
what one doesn\u2019t know won\u2019t hu.example: Don’t tell me that I have made a mistake. What I don’t know won’t hurt me

what price something.definition: what is the value of something?; what good is something? (said when the value of the thing referred to is being diminished or ignored.)
what price something.example: Jane’s best friend told us all about Jane’s personal problems. What price friendship?

what\u2019s coming to one.example: If you cheat, you’ll get in trouble. You’ll get what’s coming to you

what\u2019s cooking.definition: what is happening?; how are you?
what\u2019s cooking.example: Bob: Hi, Fred! What’s cooking? Fred: How are you doing, Bob?

what\u2019s done cannot be undone.definition: you cannot change what has already happened
what\u2019s done cannot be undone.example: Jill: I wish I hadn’t insulted Maria. Jane: What’s done cannot be undone

what\u2019s done is done.definition: it is final and in the past
what\u2019s done is done.example: It’s too late to change it now. What’s done is done

what\u2019s eating someone.example: Tom: Go away! Bob: Gee, Tom, what’s eating you?

what\u2019s going on around here.definition: what is happening in this place?; what is the explanation for the strange things that are happening here?
what\u2019s going on around here.example: Bill: There was an accident in the factory this morning. Bob: That’s the second one this week. What’s going on around here?

what\u2019s gotten into someone.definition: what is bothering someone?; what caused someone to act that way? (past or perfect only. the has is contracted except for emphasis.)
what\u2019s gotten into someone.example: I just don’t know what’s gotten into her

what\u2019s in a name.definition: the name of a thing does not matter as much as the quality of the thing. (from shakespeare’s play, romeo and juliet.)
what\u2019s in a name.example: Sue: I want to buy this pair of jeans. Mother: This other pair is much cheaper. Sue: But it doesn’t have the designer brand name. Mother: What’s in a name?

what\u2019s in it for me.definition: what is the benefit for me in this scheme?
what\u2019s in it for me.example: Bob: Now that plan is just what is needed. Bill: What’s in it for me? What do I get out of it?

what\u2019s it to you.definition: why does it matter to you?; it’s none of your business. (a bit contentious.)
what\u2019s it to you.example: Tom: Where are you going? Jane: What’s it to you?

what\u2019s keeping someone.definition: what is delaying someone? (the someone is replaced by a person’s name or a pronoun.)
what\u2019s keeping someone.example: Bob: Wasn’t Mary supposed to be here? Bill: I thought so. Bob: Well, what’s keeping her? Bill: How should I know?

what\u2019s new.definition: what things have happened since we last met?
what\u2019s new.example: Mary: Greetings, Jane. What’s new? Jane: Nothing much

what\u2019s new with you.definition: a typical greeting, often a response to what’s new?
what\u2019s new with you.example: Mary: What’s new with you? Sally: Oh, nothing. What’s new with you? Mary: The same

what\u2019s on tap for today.definition: what is on the schedule for today?; what is going to happen today? (as a beer that is on tap and ready to be served.)
what\u2019s on tap for today.example: Tom: Good morning, Fred. Fred: Morning. What’s on tap for today? Tom: Trouble in the morning and difficulty in the afternoon. Fred: So nothing’s new

what\u2019s sauce for the goose is sauce.definition: what is good for one person is good for another.; what is good for the man in a couple is good for the woman
what\u2019s sauce for the goose is sauce.example: Jane: You’re overweight; you should get more exercise. Alan: But I don’t really have time to exercise. Jane: When I was overweight, you told me to exercise; what’s sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander

what\u2019s shakin\u2019 bacon.definition: sl.how are you?; what is new?
what\u2019s shakin\u2019 bacon.example: What’s shakin’ bacon? What’s going down?

what\u2019s that.example: Tom: We’re leaving tomorrow. Jane: What’s that?

what\u2019s the big idea.definition: why did you do that? (usually said in anger.)
what\u2019s the big idea.example: Please don’t do that! What’s the idea?

what\u2019s the catch.definition: sl. what is the drawback?; it sounds good, but are there any hidden problems?
what\u2019s the catch.example: Sounds too good to be true. What’s the catch?

what\u2019s the damage.definition: sl. what are the charges?; how much is the bill?
what\u2019s the damage.example: Bill: That was delicious. Waiter, what’s the damage? Waiter: I’ll get the check, sir

what\u2019s the drill.example: Bill: I just came in. What’s the drill? Tom: We have to carry all this stuff out to the truck

what\u2019s the good of something.definition: what is the point of something?; why bother with something?
what\u2019s the good of something.example: What’s the good of my going at all if I’ll be late?

what\u2019s the good word.example: Hi, Jim! What’s the good word?

what\u2019s the matter with you.definition: is there something wrong with you?; are you ill?
what\u2019s the matter with you.example: Bill: What’s the matter with you? Fred: I have this funny feeling in my chest. Bill: Sounds serious

what\u2019s the problem.definition: what problem are you presenting to me?
what\u2019s the problem.example: Bill (coming in): I need to talk to you about something. Tom: What’s the problem, Bill?

what\u2019s the scoop.definition: what is the news?; what’s new with you?
what\u2019s the scoop.example: Bob: Did you hear about Tom? Mary: No, what’s the scoop?

what\u2019s there to know.definition: this doesn’t require any special knowledge, so what are you talking about?
what\u2019s there to know.example: Bill: Do you know how to wind a watch? Bob: Wind a watch? What’s there to know?

what\u2019s up doc.definition: cliché what’s happening around here?; what are you doing?
what\u2019s up doc.example: Your bike’s spread out all over the garage. What’s up, Doc?

what\u2019s with someone or something.definition: why is someone or something in that condition?; what’s going on with someone or something?
what\u2019s with someone or something.example: Mary: What’s with Tom? He looks depressed. Bill: He broke up with Sally

what\u2019s wrong.definition: there is something wrong here. what has happened?
what\u2019s wrong.example: Mary: Oh, good grief! Bill: What’s wrong? Mary: I forgot to feed the cat

what\u2019s your age.example: Tim: What’s your age? Joe: Hey, Tim, what’s going on with you?

what\u2019s yours is mine and what\u2019.definition: a humorous way of saying, “everything belongs to me.”; (a jocular variant of “what’s yours is mine, and what’s mine is yours,” an expression of generosity.)
what\u2019s yours is mine and what\u2019.example: I know you won’t mind lending me your radio. After all, what’s yours is mine, and what’s mine is mine

what someone or something is cracked up.definition: what someone or something is supposed to be
what someone or something is cracked up.example: This pizza isn’t what it’s cracked up to be

what the deuce.definition: sl. what has happened?; what? (deuce is an old word for devil.)
what the deuce.example: What the deuce! Who are you?

what the eye doesn\u2019t see the heart.definition: you cannot be upset by something you do not know about
what the eye doesn\u2019t see the heart.example: When Robbie cracked his mother’s favorite vase, he simply turned the cracked side toward the wall. “What the eye doesn’t see, the heart doesn’t grieve over,” he thought

what the heck.definition: it doesn’t matter! (often with the force of an exclamation.)
what the heck.example: Oh, what the heck! Come on in. It doesn’t matter

what was the name again.definition: please tell me your name again. (more typical of a clerk than of someone just introduced.)
what was the name again.example: Clerk: What was the name again? Bill: Bill

what with something.example: What with the children being at home and my parents coming to stay, I have too much to do

what would you like to drink.definition: an offer to prepare or serve a drink
what would you like to drink.example: Bill: Come in and sit down. What would you like to drink? Andy: Nothing, thanks. I just need to relax a moment

what would you say if.definition: an expression introducing a request for an opinion or a judgment
what would you say if.example: Bill: What would you say if I ate the last piece of cake? Bob: Go ahead. I don’t care

what you see is what you get.definition: the product you are looking at is exactly what you get if you buy it
what you see is what you get.example: It comes just like this. What you see is what you get

whatever goes around comes around.definition: the results of things that one has done will someday have an effect on the person who started the events
whatever goes around comes around.example: So he finally gets to see the results of his activities. What goes around, comes around

whatever turns you on.definition: whatever pleases or excites you is okay
whatever turns you on.example: Mary: Do you mind if I buy some of these f lowers? Bill: Whatever turns you on

wheedle someone into something.definition: to get someone to agree to do something by begging or flattery
wheedle someone into something.example: She is always trying to wheedle us into coming for a visit

wheel and deal.definition: to take part in clever (but sometimes dishonest or immoral) business deals
wheel and deal.example: John loves to wheel and deal in the money markets

wheel around.definition: to turn around quickly; to change direction quickly
wheel around.example: She wheeled around quickly to face him

wheel someone or something around.definition: to push or steer around someone or something on wheels
wheel someone or something around.example: I had to wheel my great-uncle around all day when we visited the zoo

wheel someone or something away.definition: to push away someone or something on wheels
wheel someone or something away.example: The nurse wheeled the old man away, into the shelter of the porch

wheel someone or something off.definition: to push or steer someone or something on wheels some distance away
wheel someone or something off.example: The nurse wheeled the old man off

wheeze something out.definition: to say something, while wheezing; to say something, using a wheeze for a voice. (as if one is out of breath.)
wheeze something out.example: He was out of breath from running and was only able to wheeze a few words out

when all is said and done.definition: cliché when everything is finished and settled; when everything is considered
when all is said and done.example: When all is said and done, this isn’t such a bad part of the country to live in after all

when do we eat.definition: what time is the next meal served? (indicates that the speaker is hungry, but considered impolite.)
when do we eat.example: Bill: This is a lovely view, and your apartment is great. When do we eat? Mary: We’ve already eaten. Weren’t you just leaving? Bill: I guess I was

when in rome do as the romans do.definition: behave however the people around you behave. adapt yourself to the customs of the places you visit
when in rome do as the romans do.example: Jill: Everyone in my new office dresses so casually. Should I dress that way, too? Jane: By all means. When in Rome, do as the Romans do

when it comes right down to it.definition: cliché all things considered; when one really thinks about something
when it comes right down to it.example: When it comes right down to it, I’d like to find a new job

when it comes to something.definition: as for something; speaking about something
when it comes to something.example: When it comes to fishing, John is an expert

when least expected.definition: when one does not expect something
when least expected.example: An old car is likely to give you trouble when least expected

when one door shuts another opens.definition: when you lose one opportunity, you often find a different one
when one door shuts another opens.example: Jane: I just found out I’m failing two classes. I’ll never get into college with grades like this. Jill: Well, maybe you’ll find something better than college. When one door shuts, another opens

when one is good and ready.example: I’ll be there when I’m good and ready

when one\u2019s ship comes in.definition: when one becomes rich and successful
when one\u2019s ship comes in.example: When my ship comes in, we’ll live in one of these huge mansions on the hill, my lass

when the cat\u2019s away the mice will p.definition: when no one in authority is present, the subordinates can do as they please
when the cat\u2019s away the mice will p.example: When the teacher left for a few minutes, the children nearly wrecked the classroom. When the cat’s away, the mice will play

when the chips are down.definition: at the final, critical moment; when things really get difficult
when the chips are down.example: When the chips are down, I know that I can depend on Jean to help out

when the dust settles.definition: when the dust falls out of the air
when the dust settles.example: When the dust settles, we will have to begin sweeping it up. 2.  when things have calmed down

when the going gets tough the tough get.definition: when things are difficult, strong people take action and do not despair. (can be used to encourage someone to take action.)
when the going gets tough the tough get.example: The football team was losing the game, so at halftime the coach reminded them that when the going gets tough, the tough get going

when the shit hits the fan.definition: sl. when all the expected trouble materializes
when the shit hits the fan.example: When the shit hits the fan, you had better be prepared to support those of us who are involved in this mess

when the time is ripe.example: I’ll tell her the good news when the time is ripe

where do you think you get off.definition: what do you think you are doing?; who do you think you are? (a sharp reply to something offensive or impolite.)
where do you think you get off.example: How rude! Where do you think you get off ?

where have you been all my life.definition: an expression of admiration usually said to a lover
where have you been all my life.example: Mary: I feel very happy when I’m with you. John: Oh, Mary, where have you been all my life?

where ignorance is bliss \u2019tis folly.definition: if knowing something makes you unhappy, it would be better not to know it. (also the cliché: ignorance is bliss.)
where ignorance is bliss \u2019tis folly.example: Ellen: The doctor didn’t tell Dad that Mom probably won’t recover from her illness. Do you think we should tell him? Bill: No. It would only make him unhappy and ruin their last months together. Where ignorance is bliss, ’tis folly to be wise

where in the world.definition: where? (an intensive form of where. see examples for variations.)
where in the world.example: Where in the world have you been?

where is the restroom.definition: the appropriate way of asking for the toilet in a public place
where is the restroom.example: Bob: ’Scuse me. Waiter: Yes, sir. Bob: Where is the restroom? Waiter: To your left, sir

where it\u2019s at.definition: sl. what one is aiming for; what is needed. (this does not refer to a place.)
where it\u2019s at.example: Keep on trying. That’s where it’s at!

where on god\u2019s green earth.definition: (exactly) where? (an intensive form of where. see examples for variations.)
where on god\u2019s green earth.example: Where on God’s green earth did you get that ridiculous hat?

where one is coming from.example: I think I know what you mean. I know where you’re coming from

where\u2019s the beef.definition: where is the substance?; where is the important content?
where\u2019s the beef.example: That’s really clever and appealing, but where’s the beef ?

where\u2019s the fire.definition: where are you going in such a hurry? (typically said by a police officer after stopping a speeding driver.)

where someone is at.definition: sl. what mental condition someone is in
where someone is at.example: I know where you’re at. I know what you are talking about

where someone lives.definition: at one’s core; in one’s personal situation
where someone lives.example: That really hits you where you live, doesn’t it?

where someone\u2019s head is at.definition: the state of one’s mental well-being
where someone\u2019s head is at.example: As soon as I figure where my head is at, I’ll be okay

where the action is.example: I want to be where the action is

where the rubber meets the road.definition: at the point in a process where there are challenges, issues, or problems

where the sun don\u2019t shine.definition: sl. in a dark place, namely the anus

where there\u2019s a will there\u2019s a.definition: cliché if you truly want to do something, you will find a way to do it, in spite of obstacles

where will i find you.definition: please give me directions for finding you. (said when people are arranging a meeting somewhere.)

the wherewithal to do something.definition: the means to do something, especially energy or money

whet someone\u2019s appetite.definition: to cause someone to be interested in something and to be eager to have, know, learn, etc., more about it

whether or not.definition: either if something is the case or if something is not the case; one way or the other
whether or not.example: I’ll drive to New York tomorrow whether or not it rains

which brings me to the main point.definition: a transitional phrase that introduces the main point of a discussion
which brings me to the main point.example: Bill: Keeping safe at times like this is very important—which brings me to the main point. Does your house have an adequate burglar alarm? Sally: I knew you were trying to sell me something! Out!

a whiff of something.definition: the smell or odor of something
a whiff of something.example: Did you get a whiff of the turkey roasting? Yummy

while a period of time away doing someth.definition: to spend or waste time doing something

whine about someone or something.definition: to whimper or complain about someone or something

whine something out.definition: to say something in a whine; to say something, using a whine for a voice

whip around.definition: to reverse suddenly. (as with the tip of a whip.)

whip back on someone.definition: [for something] to snap back and strike someone

whip someone or something around.definition: to cause someone or something to reverse direction quickly

whiz past someone or something.definition: to move or travel past someone or something at a high speed

who cares.definition: does anyone really care?; it is of no consequence
who cares.example: John: I have some advice for you. It will make things easier for you. Bob: Who cares? John: You might

who is this.definition: who is making this telephone call?; who is on the other end of this telephone line?

who knows.example: Tom: When will this train get in? Rachel: Who knows?

the whole shebang.example: Mary’s all set to give a fancy dinner party. She’s got a fine tablecloth, good crystal, and silverware, the whole shebang

the whole wide world.example: It’s the best in the whole wide world

why don\u2019t you.definition: a question tag that is put onto the end of a command

why keep a dog and bark yourself.definition: you should not do something you have hired someone else to do

wide of the mark.example: Tom’s shot was wide of the mark

wide open.definition: as fast as possible; at full throttle

a wide place in the road.example: The town is little more than a wide place in the road

wig out.example: One more drink and Wally will wig out
