wreathe itself around someone or someth.definition: [for something] to form itself into a wreath or circle around someone or something
wreathe itself around someone or someth.example: The smoke wreathed around the smokers’ heads, almost obliterating sight of them

wreathe someone or something in somethin.definition: to enclose someone or something in a wreath or a wreath-shaped area
wreathe someone or something in somethin.example: The trees wreathed them in a lovely frame. It made a beautiful photograph

wreathe something around someone or some.definition: to form something into a wreath around someone or something
wreathe something around someone or some.example: The smoke wreathed a ring around the old man holding a pipe

wrench something from someone.definition: to grab or twist something out of someone’s grasp
wrench something from someone.example: The policeman wrenched the gun from Lefty’s hand and called for his partner

wrench something out of something.definition: to yank or twist something out of something
wrench something out of something.example: The policeman wrenched the gun out of Lefty’s hand and told Lefty to put his hands up

wrest someone or something away from som.definition: to struggle to get someone or something from the grip of someone or something
wrest someone or something away from som.example: The kidnappers wrested the baby from his mother and ran away with him

wrestle something from someone.definition: to get something away from someone after a physical struggle
wrestle something from someone.example: Wally wrestled the gun away from Max and threw it out the window

wrestle something into something.definition: to struggle with something large to get it into something or some place
wrestle something into something.example: She wrestled the packages into the backseat of the car

wrestle with someone.definition: to contend with someone in a physical wrestling match
wrestle with someone.example: You are too big to wrestle with him!

wrestle with something.definition: to struggle with something large to move it about
wrestle with something.example: He wrestled with the piano and finally got it to move

wriggle into something.definition: to wiggle and squeeze into something or some place
wriggle into something.example: You will never be able to wriggle into that swimming suit

wriggle out of something.definition: to wiggle and squeeze out of something or some place
wriggle out of something.example: She wriggled out of her tight skirt and changed into something more comfortable

wring something out.definition: to squeeze or twist something dry of liquid
wring something out.example: He wrung the rag out and wiped up more of the spilled milk

wring something out of someone.definition: to pressure someone into telling something
wring something out of someone.example: The police will wring the truth out of her

wrinkle something up.definition: to make something get wrinkles and creases
wrinkle something up.example: I love the way you wrinkle your nose up

wrinkle up.definition: [for something] to draw up in wrinkles; [for something] to become wrinkled
wrinkle up.example: His nose wrinkled up as he smelled the burning pie

write about someone or something.definition: to write a narrative or description of someone or something
write about someone or something.example: I wanted to write about wild canaries, but there is not much to say

write against someone or something.definition: to oppose someone or something in writing
write against someone or something.example: John writes against the current administration too harshly

write away.definition: to write a lot; to continue writing
write away.example: There he was, writing away, not paying attention to anything else

write away for something.definition: to send for something in writing, from a distant place
write away for something.example: I wrote away for a book on the rivers of the world

write back to someone.definition: to write a letter to someone in return for a letter received from someone
write back to someone.example: I wrote back to her at once, but I have heard no more from her

write down to someone.example: You should never write down to your audience if you want to be convincing

write for something.example: I wrote for clarification but received none

write into something for something.definition: to send a written request to something for something in particular
write into something for something.example: Please write in for a detailed recipe of all the dishes on today’s program

write of someone or something.definition: to write about the general topic of someone or something
write of someone or something.example: He wrote of the beauty of nature and the way we are destroying it

write off to someone for something.definition: to send a written request for something away to someone
write off to someone for something.example: I wrote off to my parents for some money, but I think they are ignoring me

write on and on.definition: to write too much; to write endlessly
write on and on.example: You tend to write on and on. Try to focus on one point and leave it at that

write someone down as something.definition: to list someone’s name, noting something
write someone down as something.example: I’ll write you down as a contributor

write someone for something.definition: to send a written request to someone for something
write someone for something.example: Henry wrote Harry for a firm quote, but Harry never responded

write someone in on something.definition: to write the name of someone in a special place on a ballot, indicating a vote for the person. (done when the person’s name is not already printed on the ballot.)
write someone in on something.example: Please write my name in on the ballot

write someone or something about somethi.definition: to send an inquiry or statement to someone in writing about someone or something
write someone or something about somethi.example: I will write her about what you just told me

write someone or something off.definition: to drop someone or something from consideration
write someone or something off.example: The manager wrote Tom off for a promotion

write someone or something off as a some.definition: to give up on turning someone or something into something
write someone or something off as a some.example: I had to write Jill off as a future executive

write someone or something up.definition: to write an article about someone or something
write someone or something up.example: A reporter wrote me up for the Sunday paper

write something against someone or somet.definition: to write something in opposition to someone or something
write something against someone or somet.example: I wrote an article against her proposal, but they refused to print it

write something back to someone.definition: to write a letter answering someone
write something back to someone.example: I wrote an answer back to her the same day that I received the letter

write something down.definition: to make a note of something; to record something in writing

write something off.definition: to absorb a debt or a loss in accounting
write something off.example: The bill couldn’t be collected, so we had to write it off

write something off on one\u2019s taxes.definition: to deduct something from one’s income taxes
write something off on one\u2019s taxes.example: Can I write this off on my income taxes?

write something out.definition: to spell or write a number or an abbreviation
write something out.example: Don’t just write “7,” write it out

write something to someone.definition: to send specific information to someone in writing
write something to someone.example: I wrote the facts to John, and he thanked me for the information

write something to something.definition: to write something that is supplementary to something else
write something to something.example: Molly wrote an epilogue to her story covering the time up till now

write something up.definition: to prepare a bill, order, or statement
write something up.example: Please write the order up and send me a copy

write to someone.definition: to compose a letter or e-mail and send it to someone
write to someone.example: I will write to her again, but I don’t expect to hear anything

write upon someone or something.definition: to write about someone or something. (upon is very formal here and much less commonly used than on.)
write upon someone or something.example: I had to write an essay, so I wrote on my uncle

writer\u2019s block.definition: the temporary inability for a writer to think of what to write
writer\u2019s block.example: I have writer’s block at the moment and can’t seem to get a sensible sentence on paper

writhe under something.definition: to squirm with pain from being beaten with something
writhe under something.example: The sailor writhed under the sting of the lash

the wrong number.example: He got the wrong number and hung up

wrote the book on something.definition: to be very authoritative about something; to know enough about something to write the definitive book on it. (always in past tense.)
wrote the book on something.example: Ted wrote the book on unemployment. He’s been looking for work in three states for two years

wrought up.definition: disturbed or excited. (wrought is an old past tense and past participle meaning “worker.” *typically: be ~; get ~.)
wrought up.example: She is so wrought up, she can’t think

x marks the spot.definition: this is the exact spot. (sometimes the speaker will draw an x in the spot while saying this.)
x marks the spot.example: This is where the rock struck my car—X marks the spot

x someone or something out.definition: to mark out something printed or in writing, with xs
x someone or something out.example: Sally X’d the incorrect information out

x\u2019d out.example: But the Babbits are X’d out

yack one\u2019s head off.example: Jane yacked her head off and ended up with a sore throat

yack something up.definition: to talk a great deal [about someone or something]. (the something is often it.)
yack something up.example: She yacked the concert up endlessly

yammer away about someone or something.definition: to talk endlessly about someone or something

yank at someone or something.definition: to pull or tug at someone or something
yank at someone or something.example: Please don’t yank at the drapery cord

yank on something.definition: to pull or tug on something

yank someone around.definition: sl. to harass someone; to give someone a hard time
yank someone around.example: Listen, I don’t mean to yank you around all the time, but we have to have the drawings by Monday

yank someone or something apart.definition: to pull, tear, or rip someone or something to pieces
yank someone or something apart.example: Please don’t yank the book apart!

yank someone or something around.definition: to pull or jerk someone or something around
yank someone or something around.example: Don’t yank Billy around so. You’ll hurt him!

yank someone or something away from some.definition: to jerk someone or something away from someone or something
yank someone or something away from some.example: He yanked his hand away from the fire

yank someone\u2019s chain.definition: sl. to harass someone; to give someone a hard time. (as if one were a dog wearing a choker collar, on a leash.)

yank something off.definition: to pull or jerk off something, such as a piece of clothing

yank something up.definition: to pull or jerk something up

yap about someone or something.definition: to talk casually about someone or something; to gossip or complain about someone or something

yap at someone.definition: [for a small dog] to bark at someone or something
yap at someone.example: The dog yapped at the cat in great frustration

ye gods and little fishes.example: Ye gods and little fishes! Someone covered my car with broken eggs!

year after year.definition: for many years, one after another
year after year.example: We go to the same place for our vacation year after year

year in year out.example: I seem to have hay fever year in, year out. I never get over it

yearn for someone or something.definition: to long for someone or something; to desire someone or something strongly
yearn for someone or something.example: Sam sat alone in his room, yearning for Mary

yell at someone or something.definition: to shout at someone or something, usually in anger

yell out.definition: to cry out; to shout loudly
yell out.example: The pain caused the child to yell out

yell something at someone or something.definition: to shout something at someone or something, usually in anger
yell something at someone or something.example: Please don’t yell those things at me

yell something out at someone or somethi.definition: to shout something loudly at someone or something
yell something out at someone or somethi.example: The dictator yelled curses out at the troops

a yellow streak down someone\u2019s back.example: Tim’s got a yellow streak down his back a mile wide

yen for someone or something.definition: to long for someone or something
yen for someone or something.example: I yen for a great big bowl of highly fattening ice cream

yes indeedy do.example: Tom: Will you marry me? Jane: Yes indeedy do, I will!

yes siree bob.definition: absolutely!; without a doubt! (not necessarily said to a male and not necessarily to bob.)
yes siree bob.example: Mary: Do you want some more cake? Tom: Yes siree, Bob!

yesterday wouldn\u2019t be too soon.definition: immediately.; right away. (an answer to the question “when do you want this?”)
yesterday wouldn\u2019t be too soon.example: Mary: Mr. Franklin, when do you want this? Fred: Well, yesterday wouldn’t be too soon

yield someone or something over to someo.definition: to give up someone or something to someone or something. (the over is typically used where the phrase is synonymous with hand over.)
yield someone or something over to someo.example: You must yield Tom over to his mother

yield someone or something up to someone.definition: to give someone or something up to someone
yield someone or something up to someone.example: He had to yield his daughter up to Claire

yield something to someone.definition: to give the right-of-way to someone
yield something to someone.example: You must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians

yield to someone.definition: to let someone go ahead; to give someone the right-of-way
yield to someone.example: Please yield to the next speaker

a yoke around someone\u2019s neck.definition: something that oppresses people; a burden
a yoke around someone\u2019s neck.example: John’s greedy children are a yoke around his neck

yoke people or things together.definition: to connect two people together with a yoke; to connect two animals together with a yoke
yoke people or things together.example: Todd yoked the oxen together for the parade

you ain\u2019t just whistlin\u2019 dixie.example: Tom: Sure is hot today. Bill: Yeah, you ain’t just whistlin’ Dixie. It’s a scorcher

you ain\u2019t seen nothing yet.definition: the best, most exciting, or cleverest part is yet to come! (the use of ain’t is a fixed part of this idiomatic expression.)
you ain\u2019t seen nothing yet.example: Alice: Well, the first act was simply divine. Sue: Stick around. You ain’t seen nothing yet!

you always give up too easily.definition: you don’t stand up for your rights.; you give up without a fight
you always give up too easily.example: Bill: Well, I guess she was right. Bob: No, she was wrong. You always give up too easily

you are more than welcome.definition: you are very welcome to be here
you are more than welcome.example: Please make yourself at home. You are more than welcome. 2. Your thanks are very gratefully accepted

you are something else again.example: After Sally finished telling her joke, everyone laughed and someone said, “Oh, Sally, you are something else!”

you asked for it.definition: you are getting what you requested
you asked for it.example: The waiter set a huge bowl of ice cream, strawberries, and whipped cream in front of Mary, saying apologetically, “You asked for it!”

you betcha.definition: yes!; you can be sure of it! (literally, you bet, you.)
you betcha.example: Will I be there? You betcha

you called.definition: a phrase used when returning a telephone call, meaning “what did you want to talk about when you called before?”
you called.example: Bill (answering the phone): Hello? Bob: This is Bob. You called?

you can bet the farm on someone or somet.definition: you can be certain of someone or something
you can bet the farm on someone or somet.example: This is a good investment. You can bet the farm on it

you can catch more flies with honey than.definition: it is easier to get what you want by flattering people and being polite to them than by making demands
you can catch more flies with honey than.example: Jill: This meal is terrible. Let’s get the restaurant manager over here and make a scene unless he gives us our money back. Jane: We might have more luck if we ask politely. You can catch more f lies with honey than with vinegar

you can lead a horse to water but you ca.definition: you can present someone with an opportunity, but you cannot force him or her to take advantage of it
you can lead a horse to water but you ca.example: Jill: I told Katy about all the jobs that are available at our company, but she hasn’t applied for any of them. Jane: You can lead a horse to water, but you can’t make it drink

you cannot get a quart into a pint pot.definition: you cannot fit too much of something into a space that is too small
you cannot get a quart into a pint pot.example: That dog is simply too big to get into this kennel. You can’t get a quart into a pint pot

you cannot have your cake and eat it too.definition: you cannot enjoy two desirable things at the same time
you cannot have your cake and eat it too.example: Jill: There’s an apartment across the street from me, much bigger and prettier than mine, and it even costs less. I’d really like to rent it—but I don’t want to go to the trouble of moving. Jane: You can’t have your cake and eat it too

you cannot lose what you never had.definition: you should have not lost something if you only wished that you had it to begin with
you cannot lose what you never had.example: Bill: I’ve lost Mary. She’s gotten engaged to Tom. Fred: But, Bill, Mary was never your girlfriend. You can’t lose what you never had

you cannot make a silk purse out of a so.definition: you cannot make someone more refined than he or she is by nature
you cannot make a silk purse out of a so.example: I’ve given up trying to get my cousin to appreciate classical music. You can’t make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear

you cannot make an omelet without breaki.definition: in order to get something good or useful, you must give up something else

you cannot make bricks without straw.definition: you have to have all the necessary materials in order to make something
you cannot make bricks without straw.example: Ellen: I really wanted to give Fred a birthday party, but none of the people I invited were able to come. Jane: Don’t blame yourself. You can’t make bricks without straw

you cannot please everyone.definition: cliché no matter what you do, there will always be some people who do not like it
you cannot please everyone.example: Nancy: My mother wants me to have a big wedding in the church, but my fiancé’s mother insists that we should have an informal ceremony. What am I going to do? Jane: Well, you can’t please everyone. Just do what you and your fiancé want to do

you cannot put new wine in old bottles.definition: you should not try to combine the new with the old
you cannot put new wine in old bottles.example: I think it is a mistake for the managers of that traditional art gallery to exhibit modern paintings. You can’t put new wine in old bottles

you cannot serve god and mammon.definition: you cannot both be a good person and dedicate yourself to making money. (biblical. mammonmeans riches.)

you cannot teach an old dog new tricks.definition: someone who is used to doing things a certain way cannot change. (usually not polite to say about the person you are talking to; you can say it about yourself or about a third person.)

you can\u2019t fight city hall.definition: there is no way to win in a battle against a bureaucracy
you can\u2019t fight city hall.example: Bill: I guess I’ll go ahead and pay the tax bill. Bob: Might as well. You can’t fight city hall

you can\u2019t get there from here.definition: a catchphrase said jokingly when someone asks directions to get to a place that can be reached only by a circuitous route
you can\u2019t get there from here.example: Bill: How far is it to Adamsville? Tom: Adamsville? Oh, that’s too bad. You can’t get there from here

you can\u2019t mean that.definition: surely you do not mean what you said!
you can\u2019t mean that.example: Bill: I hate you! Mary: You can’t mean that

you can\u2019t take it with you.definition: cliché since you cannot take your wealth with you when you die, you ought to enjoy it while you’re alive
you can\u2019t take it with you.example: Go ahead, splurge a little while you’ve got it. You can’t take it with you

you could have fooled me.definition: i would have thought otherwise.; i would have thought the opposite

you could have knocked me over with a fe.definition: i was extremely surprised.; i was so surprised that it was as if i was disoriented and could have been knocked over easily
you could have knocked me over with a fe.example: When she told me she was going to get married, you could have knocked me over with a feather

you don\u2019t get something for nothing.definition: everything costs something, and anything that appears to be free must be deceptive
you don\u2019t get something for nothing.example: Jill: This newspaper ad says we can get a trip to Hawaii for free. Jane: There must be a catch to it somewhere. You don’t get something for nothing

you don\u2019t know the half of it.definition: you really don’t know how bad it is.; you might think that what you have heard is bad, but you do not know the whole story
you don\u2019t know the half of it.example: Mary: They say you’ve been having a bad time at home. Sally: You don’t know the half of it

you don\u2019t know where it\u2019s been.definition: do not touch something or put it in your mouth, because you do not know where it has been and what kind of dirt it has picked up. (most often said to children.)
you don\u2019t know where it\u2019s been.example: Mother: Don’t put that money in your mouth. You don’t know where it’s been. Bill: Okay

you don\u2019t say.definition: a general response to something that someone has said. (expresses a little polite surprise or interest, but not disbelief.)
you don\u2019t say.example: Bill: I’m starting work on a new job next Monday. Bob: You don’t say

you first.definition: an invitation for someone to precede the speaker. (see the examples.)
you first.example: Bill: Let’s try some of this goose liver stuff. Jane: You first

you get what you pay for.definition: cliché if you do not pay much money for something, it is probably of poor quality.; if you pay well for something, it is more likely to be of good quality
you get what you pay for.example: Alan: I was so pleased to find shoes for such a low price, but look, they’re falling apart already. Jane: You get what you pay for

you got it.definition: i agree to what you asked!; you will get what you want!
you got it.example: You want a green one? You got it!

you got me there.definition: i do not know the answer to your question. (also with subjects other than second person.)
you got me there.example: You got me there. I don’t know

you have to eat a peck of dirt before yo.definition: no one can escape eating a certain amount of dirt on his or her food.; everyone must endure a number of unpleasant things in his or her lifetime. (often said to console someone who has eaten some dirt or had to endure something unpleasant.)
you have to eat a peck of dirt before yo.example: Ellen: Oh, no! I forgot to wash this apple before I took a bite out of it. Fred: You have to eat a peck of dirt before you die

you heard someone.definition: don’t argue. you heard your instructions from someone. (the someone can be a person’s name, a title, or a pronoun.)
you heard someone.example: Andy: You heard the man. Get moving. Henry: Don’t rush me!

you just don\u2019t get it.definition: you really don’t see what people are trying to tell you! (also with subjects other than second person.)
you just don\u2019t get it.example: You just don’t get it! People avoid you because you offend them

you make a better door than you do a win.definition: i cannot see through you, so move aside
you make a better door than you do a win.example: Joe was just standing in front of the TV. “Hey,” I said, “You make a better door than you do a window.”

you make me laugh.definition: what you said is totally ridiculous.; you are totally ridiculous. (compare this with don’t make me laugh!)
you make me laugh.example: Bill: I have this plan to make electricity from garbage. Sally: What a dumb idea! You make me laugh!

you must lose a fly to catch a trout.definition: you have to sacrifice something in order to get what you want. (implies that what you sacrifice is minor compared to what you will get.)
you must lose a fly to catch a trout.example: Amy was willing to live cheaply for several years in order to save enough money to buy her own house. She knew that you must lose a f ly to catch a trout

you never know what you can do till you.definition: even if you think you are not able to do something, you should try to do it

you never miss the water till the well r.definition: people are not grateful for what they have until they lose it
you never miss the water till the well r.example: Jill: I never realized what a good friend Jeanie was until she moved away. Jane: You never miss the water till the well runs dry

you pays your money and you takes your c.definition: you must resign yourself to taking risks.; everything costs something, but paying for something does not guarantee that you will get it. (the grammatical errors are intentional.)
you pays your money and you takes your c.example: Customer: Can you guarantee that this washing machine won’t break? Salesman: No guarantees. You pays your money and you takes your chances

you really said a mouthful.definition: you said exactly what needed to be said.; what you said was very meaningful and had great impact
you really said a mouthful.example: Bill: Did you hear what I said to her? Jane: Yes. You said a mouthful. Was she mad?

you scratch my back and i\u2019ll scratc.definition: you do a favor for me and i’ll do a favor for you.; if you do something for me that i cannot do for myself, i will do something for you that you cannot do for yourself
you scratch my back and i\u2019ll scratc.example: I’ll grab the box on the top shelf if you will creep under the table and pick up my pen. You scratch my back, and I’ll scratch yours

you think you\u2019re so smart.definition: you act as if you know far more than you do. (also with subjects other than second person.)
you think you\u2019re so smart.example: You think you’re so smart! You don’t know anything!

you took the words right out of my mouth.definition: you said exactly what i meant to say before i had a chance to say it, and, therefore, i agree with you very much
you took the words right out of my mouth.example: Bill: I think she’s old enough to know better. Tom: You took the words right out of my mouth

you want a piece of me.definition: sl. do you want to fight with me?
you want a piece of me.example: Come on, Wussy. You want a piece of me?

you wouldn\u2019t dare to do something.definition: an exclamation that shows disbelief about something that the speaker has stated an intention of doing

you\u2018d better believe it.definition: a way of emphasizing a previous statement
you\u2018d better believe it.example: Bill: Man, you’re the best goalie this team has ever had! Tom: You better believe it!

you\u2019d better get moving.definition: an expression encouraging someone to leave
you\u2019d better get moving.example: Jane: It’s nearly dark. Better get moving. Mary: Okay. I’m leaving right now

you\u2019ll be sorry you asked.definition: the answer to the question you just asked is so bad that you will be sorry you asked it. (compare this with (are you) sorry you asked?)
you\u2019ll be sorry you asked.example: Father: What are your grades going to be like this semester? Sally: You’ll be sorry you asked

you\u2019ll get the hang of it.definition: don’t worry. you will learn soon how it is done
you\u2019ll get the hang of it.example: Mary: It’s harder than I thought to glue these things together. Tom: You’ll get the hang of it

you\u2019ll never get away with it.definition: you will never succeed with that illegal or outrageous plan
you\u2019ll never get away with it.example: Bill: I have a plan to cheat on the exam. Mary: You’ll never get away with it

young at heart.definition: having a youthful spirit no matter what one’s age
young at heart.example: I am over 70 but I still feel young at heart

young men may die but old men must die.definition: young people may be killed by accidents or disease, but old people cannot avoid dying for very long, simply because they are old
young men may die but old men must die.example: When Grandfather was so sick, he told us, “Don’t feel too bad if I pass on; it’s my time. Young men may die, old men must die.”

your guess is as good as mine.example: Jane: Are there any good movies playing tonight? Alan: Your guess is as good as mine

your place or mine.definition: an expression asking someone about whose dwelling should be the site of a rendezvous. (often associated with a sudden or spontaneous sexual encounter.)
your place or mine.example: Bill: So, do you want to go somewhere? Mary: Your place or mine?

your secret is safe with me.definition: i will not tell your secret to anyone
your secret is safe with me.example: Don’t worry. I won’t tell. Your secret’s safe with me

you\u2019re dern tootin\u2019.definition: you are absolutely right! (never the full form tooting.)
you\u2019re dern tootin\u2019.example: Tom: Are you really going to take up boxing? Bob: You’re dern tootin’!

you\u2019re excused.definition: you may leave the room, the table, etc. (said in response to may i be excused?)
you\u2019re excused.example: Mother: Are you finished, Tom? Tom: Yes, ma’am. Mother: You’re excused

you\u2019re just wasting my time.definition: what you have to say is of no interest to me
you\u2019re just wasting my time.example: Rachel: I’ve heard enough. You’re just wasting my time. Good-bye. Mary: If that’s the way you feel about it, good-bye

you\u2019re telling me.definition: i know all too well the truth of what you are saying

outofbounds.example: The ball went out-of-bounds just at the end of the game

offlimits.example: This area is off-limits. You can’t go in there

over someone\u2019s head.definition: [of the intellectual content of something] too difficult for someone to understand
over someone\u2019s head.example: All that talk about computers went over my head

pan out.definition: to move back to a wider angle picture using a zoom lens

pick holes in something.definition: to criticize something severely; to point out the flaws or fallacies in an argument
pick holes in something.example: The lawyer picked holes in the witness’s story

pick something to pieces.definition: to criticize something severely; to point out the flaws or fallacies in an argument
pick something to pieces.example: The lawyer picked holes in the witness’s story

plain as the nose on one\u2019s face.example: The lecture was as plain as day. No one had to ask questions

play around with someone or something.definition: to play and frolic with someone or something
play around with someone or something.example: Kelly likes to play around with the other kids

play about with someone or something.definition: to play and frolic with someone or something
play about with someone or something.example: Kelly likes to play around with the other kids

play something by ear.definition: to be able to play a piece of music after just listening to it a few times, without looking at the notes

play by ear.definition: to play a musical instrument well, without formal training
play by ear.example: John can play the piano by ear

poke around.example: I’ve been poking around in the library looking for some statistics

poke about.example: I’ve been poking around in the library looking for some statistics

pour cold water on something.definition: to douse something with cold water
pour cold water on something.example: Pour cold water on the vegetables to freshen them

puff away at something.definition: to blow at or into something in puffs
puff away at something.example: She puffed away at the beach ball, blowing it up as fast as she could

puff away on something.definition: to smoke something, such as a cigar, cigarette, or pipe
puff away on something.example: Scott was puffing away at his pipe

pull something off.definition: to manage to make something happen
pull something off.example: Yes, I can pull it off

push ahead with something.definition: to go on ahead, pushing with something
push ahead with something.example: The worker pushed ahead with the plow, moving the snow to the side of the road

push ahead on something.definition: to continue to progress with something
push ahead on something.example: Let’s push ahead with this project immediately

put someone away.example: The gangster threatened to put me away if I told the police

send someone away.definition: euph. to sentence someone to prison for a length of time. (underworld.)
send someone away.example: They put Richard away for fifteen years

reach for the sky.example: Reach for the sky! Go for it!

aim for the sky shoot for the sky.example: Reach for the sky! Go for it!

remain on.definition: to continue to stay in one place. (the on is an adverb, not a preposition.)
remain on.example: Everyone else left, but I decided to remain on there

remain on something.definition: to continue to be on something; to continue to serve on a body
remain on something.example: Will you remain on the board of directors for another year?

run in circles.definition: to run in a circular path
run in circles.example: The horses ran in circles around the corral for their daily exercise

run the gauntlet.definition: to race, as a punishment, between parallel lines of men who thrash one as one runs
run the gauntlet.example: The knight was forced to doff his clothes and run the gauntlet. 2.  to endure a series of problems, threats, or criticism

run the gauntlet of something.definition: to endure a series of problems, threats, or criticism
run the gauntlet of something.example: After the play, the director found himself running the gauntlet of questions and doubts about his ability

the runt of the litter.definition: the smallest animal born in a litter; the animal in a litter least likely to survive
the runt of the litter.example: No one wanted to buy the runt of the litter, so we kept it. 2. the runt of the family  the smallest child in the family

the runt of the family.definition: the smallest child in the family
the runt of the family.example: I was the runt of the litter and the butt of all the jokes

sewed up.definition: [the sewing of a gap in cloth] completed
sewed up.example: Have you got that tear sewed up yet? 2.  settled or finished

wrapped up.example: I’ll take the contract to the mayor tomorrow morning. I’ll get the whole deal sewed up by noon

shake something out.definition: to clean something of dirt or crumbs by shaking

shake something down.definition: to test something to find out how it works or what the problems are
shake something down.example: I need to spend some time driving my new car to shake it out

sharp as a razor.example: The penknife is sharp as a razor

sharp as a tack.example: The old man’s senile, but his wife is as sharp as a razor

slip away.definition: to go away or escape quietly or in secret; to slip out
slip away.example: I slipped away when no one was looking

slip off.definition: to go away or escape quietly or in secret; to slip out
slip off.example: I slipped away when no one was looking

slip by.definition: to move by someone or something quickly or unnoticed; to move through a tight area or past someone or something in a tight area
slip by.example: The hall was narrow, and I could hardly have slipped by. 2. [for time] to pass quickly or unnoticed

slip by someone or something.definition: to move by someone or something quickly or unnoticed; to move through a tight area or past someone or something in a tight area
slip by someone or something.example: The hall was narrow, and I could hardly have slipped by

slow on the draw.definition: slow in drawing a gun. (cowboy and gangster talk.)

slow on the uptake.definition: slow to figure something out; slow-thinking
slow on the uptake.example: Sally didn’t get the joke because she’s sort of slow on the draw

smooth something out.definition: to flatten or even something by smoothing or pressing

smooth something over.definition: to reduce the intensity of an argument or a misunderstanding; to try to make people feel better about something disagreeable that has happened. ( on q.)
smooth something over.example: Mary and John had a terrible argument, and they are both trying to smooth it over

a jumpstart.definition: battery power to help start someone’s car, etc
a jumpstart.example: My car is stalled. I need to get a start

step into something.definition: to step into something wet, messy, or dirty

step in something.definition: to step into something wet, messy, or dirty

take a punch at someone.definition: to hit at someone; to poke someone
take a punch at someone.example: Max took a jab at Lefty and missed

that does it.definition: that completes it!; it is now done just right!
that does it.example: When Jane got the last piece put into the puzzle, she said, “That does it!”

that tears it.definition: that’s the last straw!; enough is enough!
that tears it.example: Bill: We’re still not totally pleased with your work. Bob: That does it! I quit!

throw someone off the track.definition: to cause someone to lose the trail (when following someone or something. see also put someone off the track)
throw someone off the track.example: The raccoon threw us off the track by running through the creek

throw someone off the trail.definition: to cause someone to lose the trail (when following someone or something. see also put someone off the track)
throw someone off the trail.example: The raccoon threw us off the track by running through the creek

tickle someone to death.definition: to tickle someone a great deal
tickle someone to death.example: Bobby nearly tickled Tim to death. Tim was left breathless

tickle someone to pieces.definition: to please someone a great deal
tickle someone to pieces.example: What you told her just tickled her to death!

tight as a drum.example: Julia stretched the upholstery fabric over the seat of the chair until it was as tight as a drum

tight as midas\u2019s fist.example: He won’t contribute a cent. He’s as tight as a drum

tune in to something.definition: to pay attention to someone or something
tune in to something.example: I just can’t tune in on these professors

turn over.definition: to rotate so that the side that was on the bottom is now on top
turn over.example: The turtle turned over and crawled away

kick over.definition: [for an engine] to start or to rotate
kick over.example: My car engine was so cold that it wouldn’t even turn over

under pressure.definition: facing or enduring something such as pressure or a deadline
under pressure.example: I have to get back to work. I am under a deadline

under a deadline under the gun about som.definition: facing or enduring something such as pressure or a deadline
under a deadline under the gun about som.example: I have to get back to work. I am under a deadline

up to speed.definition: moving, operating, or funtioning a normal or desired rate
up to speed.example: Terri did everything she could to bring her workers up to speed, but couldn’t

up to speed on someone or something.definition: fully apprised about someone or something; up-to-date on the state of someone or something
up to speed on someone or something.example: Please bring me up to speed on this matter

wait up for someone or something.definition: to stay up late waiting for someone to arrive or something to happen
wait up for someone or something.example: I’ll be home late. Don’t wait up for me

warm up.definition: [for the weather or a person] to become warmer or hotter
warm up.example: I think it is going to warm up next week. 2.  [for someone] to become more friendly. (A warm person is a friendly person.)

warm up for something.definition: to prepare for some kind of performance or competition
warm up for something.example: The team had to warm up before the game

look out watch out.definition: to try to avoid a confrontation with someone or something
look out watch out.example: Watch out! That car nearly hit you!

work up a sweat.definition: to work very hard and sweat very much. (in the way that a horse works up a lather.)
work up a sweat.example: Don’t work yourself up into a lather. We don’t need to finish this today

work oneself up to something.definition: to prepare oneself with sufficient energy or courage to do something

work one\u2019s way up to something.definition: to progress in one’s work to a particular rank or status

writhe with something.definition: [for someone or an animal] to squirm because of something, such as pain
writhe with something.example: Carl writhed with pain and began to cry

writhe in something.definition: [for someone or an animal] to squirm because of something, such as pain
writhe in something.example: Carl writhed with pain and began to cry

zoom in on someone or something.definition: to move in to a close-up picture of someone or something, using a zoom lens or a similar lens
zoom in on someone or something.example: The camera zoomed in on the love scene

pan in on someone or something.definition: to move in to a close-up picture of someone or something, using a zoom lens or a similar lens
